passage_content: באה' אל משה בא אל פרעה וגו' כבר דקדקו באומרו בא ולא אמר לך אל פרעה, גם אומרו כי אני הכבדתי את לבו קשה להבין מה נתינת טעם הוא זה, גם תיבת אני מיותר דהי' סגי לומר כי הכבדתי, ובמדרש הובא בישועות יעקב בא אל פרעה בשליחותי וצ"ב מה בעי בזה.
translation: In "Hashem" said to Moshe, "Come to Pharaoh," etc. It has already been scrutinized why it says "come" and not "go" to Pharaoh. Also, the statement "for I have hardened his heart" is difficult to understand what kind of reasoning this is, and the word "I" is superfluous, as it would suffice to say "for I have hardened." And in the Midrash it is brought in "Yeshuot Yaakov" that "come to Pharaoh" is in My mission, and it is questioned what is needed in this.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the divine command to Moses to approach Pharaoh, noting the significance of the phrasing "come to Pharaoh" rather than "go to Pharaoh." The mention of God hardening Pharaoh's heart raises questions about divine intervention and free will, suggesting a deeper theological inquiry into the nature of God's sovereignty and human agency. The reference to the Midrash highlights the idea that Moses is acting as a messenger of God, emphasizing the importance of divine purpose in the unfolding of events. Overall, the text invites contemplation on the interplay between divine will and human response in the context of redemption.

passage_content: ואפשרלומר דהנה לכאורה קשה הלא אין הקב"ה מייחד שמו על הרעה, וענין הכבדת הלב הי' עונש לפרעה על שחטא ברצונו תחלה כמבואר ברמב"ם ז"ל (פ"י מה' תשובה עיי"ש), וא"כ האיך הי' הקב"ה מייחד שמו ע"ז באומרו "אני" הכבדתי את לבו ומאתו ית' לא תצא הרעות, אמנם כבר נודע מ"ש הקדושת לוי בכללות הנסים דלכן הי' מכות בכורות ע"י הקב"ה בכבודו ובעצמו אף דמאתו לא תצא הרעות, מ"מ כאן הי' טובה גדולה גם למצרים. שע"י מכה זו נתקדש ש"ש על ידם, ואין לך טובה גדולה מזו, שע"ז נברא העולם לקדש ש"ש ברבים יעיי"ש שהאריך בדברות קדשו מלהבות אש, אמנם בליקוטי תורה מהאר"י ז"ל כתב בפ' לכה ואשלחך אל פרעה דכיון שהולך לשני דברים לעשות טובה לישראל ורעה למצרים, ועל הרעה אין הקב"ה מייחד שמו, ע"כ אמר לכה נגד בחי' הרעה כלומר שילך מעצמו, ונגד הטובה לישראל אמר ואשלחך שיהי' בתורת שליחות מאתו ית'.
translation: And it is possible to say that, behold, at first glance it is difficult, for the Holy One, blessed be He, does not designate His name for evil, and the matter of hardening the heart was a punishment for Pharaoh for having sinned of his own will, as explained by the Rambam, may his memory be blessed (in the laws of repentance, chapter 9, see there). And if so, how could the Holy One, blessed be He, designate His name for this by saying, "I have hardened his heart," and from Him, evil will not come forth? However, it is already known what the Kedushas Levi says regarding the generality of the miracles, that is why the plague of the firstborn was done by the Holy One, blessed be He, in His glory and essence, even though from Him evil will not come forth. Nevertheless, here there was also great goodness for Egypt, for through this plague, the Name of Heaven was sanctified by them, and there is no greater goodness than this, for this is why the world was created—to sanctify the Name of Heaven in public, as he elaborated in his holy words from the flames of fire. However, in Likkutei Torah from the Ari, may his memory be blessed, it is written in the section "Go and I will send you to Pharaoh" that since he is going for two purposes—to do good for Israel and evil for Egypt—and for the evil, the Holy One, blessed be He, does not designate His name, therefore it says "Go" against the aspect of evil, meaning that he should go of his own accord, and against the goodness for Israel, it says "I will send you," that it should be in the manner of a mission from Him, blessed be He.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of God's actions during the plagues in Egypt, particularly the hardening of Pharaoh's heart. It emphasizes that while God does not associate His name with evil, the plagues served a dual purpose: to bring about the redemption of the Israelites and to sanctify God's name through the suffering of the Egyptians. The text highlights that the ultimate goal of creation is to glorify God's name, and even in acts perceived as negative, there can be a greater good and divine intention at play.

passage_content: ובקדושתלוי הנ"ל כתב לחלק שמכות הקודמין לא היו גורמים קידוש השם כ"כ, ע"כ הי' עדיין רעה למצרים, להכי היו ע"י שליח כי מאתו ית' לא תצא הרעה, משא"כ במכת בכורות שגרמה קדושת שמו הגדול, הי' טובה גמורה גם להם והי' באפשרי שיהי' ע"י הקב"ה בכבודו ובעצמו יעיי"ש, ובאמת גם במכות הכנים כבר הודו החרטומים ואמרו אצבע אלקים הוא, ובוודאי מה שהודו כל חרטומי מצרים בכח אלקי נצמח קידוש השם גדול, א"כ גם מכה זו הי' להם לטובה גדולה, וע"כ נראה כי מה שאמר הקב"ה לכה ואשלחך שלא רצה שהמכות למצרים יהי' בדרך שליחות, זה הי' רק במכות הראשונים שהיו המצריים מחזיקים אותם למעשה כשפים כמו שאמרו תבן אתם מכניסים לעפרים, ולא נתקדש ש"ש עי"ז כלל, ואדרבה כי נתחזקו למכשפים, וא"כ הי' לפי שעה באמת רעה גדולה להם, ולא הי' באפשרי שיהי' בדרך שליחות מאתו ית', משא"כ אח"כ שהודו אצבע אלקים הוא, ומה שלא עשה הקב"ה בכבודו ובעצמו כ"א מכת בכורות, ולא המכות הקודמין אף שהיו ג"כ טובה כנז"ל אין זה קושיא, דמכות בכורות הי' עיקר הפירסום הגדול בקדושת שמו ית' עד סוף כל הדורות והוא טובה לאין שיעור וערך למעלה מהשגת כל הנבראים, אולי עבור זה לא הי' מהראוי שיהי' נעשה ע"י שליח כ"א ע"י הקב"ה בכבודו ובעצמו. אבל מכות הראשונות אף שהיו באמת ג"כ טובה להם, מ"מ הלא מצינו כמה טובות באים לעולם ע"י שליח ממנו ית', וכן גאולתן של ישראל במצרים הי' ע"י שליח, יען שלא הי' עדיין גאולה נצחית ואך הגאולה העתידה במהרה יהי' ע"י הקב"ה בעצמו יען שהוא גאולה נצחית כנודע וכן במכות מצרים אף שהיו טובה גדולה להם. אבל תכלית טובתן בשלימות הי' רק במכות בכורות שנתפרסם שמו ית' עי"ז עד סוף כל הדורות.
translation: In the holiness of Levi mentioned above, it is written that the plagues that preceded did not cause a sanctification of the Name to such an extent; therefore, there was still evil for the Egyptians. That is why they were through a messenger, for from Him, may He be blessed, evil does not come forth. In contrast, with the plague of the firstborn, which caused the sanctification of His great Name, there was complete goodness even for them, and it was possible that it would be through the Holy One, blessed be He, in His glory and essence, as you can see there. And indeed, even with the earlier plagues, the magicians admitted and said, "It is the finger of God," and certainly, what all the magicians of Egypt acknowledged as the power of God resulted in a great sanctification of the Name. Therefore, it seems that what the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "Come, and I will send you," was that He did not want the plagues upon Egypt to be through a messenger; this was only for the first plagues, which the Egyptians held as acts of sorcery, as they said, "You are bringing straw to the bricks," and thus the sanctification of the Name was not achieved at all through that. On the contrary, they were strengthened in their sorcery, and thus, for the time being, it was indeed a great evil for them, and it was not possible for it to be through a messenger from Him, may He be blessed. In contrast, afterwards, when they acknowledged, "It is the finger of God," and what the Holy One, blessed be He, did in His glory and essence was only the plague of the firstborn, and not the earlier plagues, even though they were also good as mentioned above, this is not a question. The plague of the firstborn was the main proclamation of the greatness of His Name, may He be blessed, until the end of all generations, and it is a goodness without measure and value beyond the comprehension of all created beings. Perhaps for this reason, it was not fitting for it to be done through a messenger, but rather through the Holy One, blessed be He, in His glory and essence. However, the earlier plagues, even though they were indeed also good for them, we find that many goods come into the world through a messenger from Him, may He be blessed, and so too the redemption of Israel in Egypt was through a messenger, since there was not yet an eternal redemption, and only the future redemption will be quickly through the Holy One, blessed be He, since it is an eternal redemption, as is known. And so it is with the plagues of Egypt, even though they were a great goodness for them. But the ultimate goodness for them in completeness was only in the plague of the firstborn, through which His Name, may He be blessed, was proclaimed until the end of all generations.
summary: The passage discusses the nature of the plagues in Egypt, emphasizing that the earlier plagues did not sanctify God's name as significantly as the final plague, the death of the firstborn. It argues that while the earlier plagues were beneficial, they were executed through intermediaries, reflecting a lesser degree of divine presence. In contrast, the death of the firstborn was a direct act of God, resulting in a profound sanctification of His name that would resonate throughout generations. Ultimately, the text highlights that true and complete goodness for the Egyptians came only through the revelation of God's greatness in the final plague.

passage_content: והנהגם בענין הכבדת לבו של פרעה, דלולא זאת לא הי' באפשרי שיבואו עליו כל המופתיםהאלה עד מכת בכורות, כמבואר בקרא כ"פ דלכן הכביד את לבו למען רבות המופתים, ש"מ דלא סגי בלא"ה שלא הי' מקום לעשות גמר כל המופתים לולא הכבדת הלב, א"כ גם ענין זה הי' טובה גדולה לאין שיעור וערך, שהי' הכנה לגמר כל המופתים ותכלית טובתן בעולם, וע"כ מובן שפיר למה גם זה נעשה ע"י הקב"ה בעצמו, ואמר "ואני" אקשה את לב פרעה, וגם כאן כתיב "אני'' הכבדתי, דאף שזה עונש, הי' באפשרי שיהי' נעשה ע"י הקב"ה בעצמו, ומזה ראי' לדברינו דגם כל המכות שבאו מעת שהכביד הקב"ה את לבו בע"כ, נחשבים ג"כ לטובה ולא רעה ח"ו, כי יען שהכל הי' אך ע"י הכבדת הלב מהקב"ה, ואילו הי' נחשב לרעה לא הי' באפשרי שיגרום זה הקב"ה ע"י פעולתו בעצמו ית', וע"כ אך במכות הראשונות הי' קפידא שאמר ית"ש לכה מעצמך ולא בדרך שליחות כמבואר לעיל.
translation: And regarding the matter of hardening Pharaoh's heart, for without this it would not have been possible for all these miracles to come upon him until the plague of the firstborn, as it is explained in the verse repeatedly that therefore He hardened his heart in order to multiply the miracles. This teaches us that it was not sufficient on its own, that there would not have been a place to complete all the miracles without the hardening of the heart. Therefore, this matter was an immense and incomparable good, as it was a preparation for the completion of all the miracles and the ultimate goodness of them in the world. Thus, it is understood well why this was also done by the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself, and He said, "And I will harden Pharaoh's heart," and here it is also written, "I have hardened," for even though this is a punishment, it was possible for it to be done by the Holy One, Blessed be He, Himself. And from this, there is proof to our words that all the plagues that came from the time that the Holy One, Blessed be He, hardened his heart against his will, are also considered good and not evil, Heaven forbid, because since everything was only through the hardening of the heart by the Holy One, Blessed be He, if it were considered evil, it would not have been possible for the Holy One, Blessed be He, to cause this through His own action. Therefore, only in the first plagues was there a concern that He said, "Go by yourself and not through a messenger," as explained above.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of God hardening Pharaoh's heart, emphasizing that this action was necessary for the fulfillment of the plagues and ultimately served a greater good. It highlights that the hardening of Pharaoh's heart, although perceived as a punishment, was orchestrated by God to enable the completion of the miracles, thus demonstrating God's direct involvement in the process. The text suggests that even seemingly negative events can be understood as part of a divine plan for ultimate goodness, reinforcing the idea that all actions of God, even those that appear punitive, are ultimately for the benefit of the world.

passage_content: והנהנודע מ"ש זקיני הגה"ק זלה"ה בישמח משה עה"פ וזרח השמש ובא השמש ואל מקומו שואף זורח הוא שם, דהטעם שנקרא שקיעת השמש בלשון ביאה, עפי"מ שאמרו חכז"ל (סנהדרין דף צ"א ע"ב) למה חמה יוצאת במזרח ושוקעת במערב כדי לתת שלו' לקונה, וההתרחקות מבורא ית"ש נקרא בלשון יציאה, והתקרבות אליו נקרא בלשון ביאה, וע"כ נקרא בלשון ביאת השמש יען שמתקרבת אז אליו ית"ש, וז"ש וזרח השמש ובא השמש שנקרא בלשון ביאה יען] ואל מקומו שואף זורח הוא שם עכ"ד.
translation: And behold, it is known what my venerable grandfather, the holy one, may his memory be blessed, said in "Yismach Moshe" on the verse "The sun rises and the sun sets, and hastens to its place where it shines." The reason that the setting of the sun is referred to in the language of "coming" is according to what our sages, of blessed memory, said (Sanhedrin 91b) that the sun rises in the east and sets in the west in order to give peace to its Creator. The distance from the Blessed Creator is referred to in the language of "going out," while the closeness to Him is referred to in the language of "coming." Therefore, it is called the "coming of the sun" because it is drawing closer to Him, blessed be He. And thus it is written, "The sun rises and the sun sets," which is called in the language of "coming," because it is hastening to its place where it shines. Thus is the matter concluded.
summary: The passage discusses the Hasidic interpretation of the sun's rising and setting, emphasizing that the term "setting" is referred to as "coming" because it symbolizes a return to the Creator. This reflects the idea that the sun's journey from east to west represents a process of distancing from God (departure) and then a return (coming) as it sets. The text highlights the theological concept that every movement of the sun signifies a spiritual dynamic of closeness and distance to the Divine, illustrating the cyclical nature of creation and the relationship between the physical and spiritual realms.

passage_content: והנהמרע"ה אשר תמיד הי' דבוק בקדושתו ית"ש והוצרך לילך למצרים ארץ מלאה גילולים. אשר אפי' תפלה קלה לא הי' באפשרי להתפלל שם, כנאמר כצאתי את העיר אפרוש כפי, ולא הי' שם מקום להשראת שכינתו ית', הנה בוודאי הי' הדבר נקרא אצלו ליציאה שהוצרך לצאת ממקום דביקותו בהשי"ת למקום יבש מלחלוחית קדושה, וע"כ אמר לו הקב"ה שמעת הכביד את לב פרעה למען עשות בו כל המופתים הגדולים לפרסם קדושת שמו ית', מאז נעשה כלי לקדושת השם שזה תכלית כל הנבראים והי' לו קצת עלי' וממילא יש גם שם מציאת השי"ת, וע"כ ביאתו אליו באפשרי לקרותו גם בלשון ביאה לכח אלוקי שהי' אז בתוכו להכביד את לבו.
translation: And behold, Moshe Rabbeinu, who was always attached to His holiness, blessed be He, needed to go to Egypt, a land full of idols. Even a light prayer was not possible to pray there, as it is said, "When I leave the city, I will spread out my hands," and there was no place for the resting of His Divine Presence. Certainly, this was considered by him as a departure from a place of attachment to the Holy One, Blessed be He, to a dry place devoid of the moisture of holiness. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "I have hardened Pharaoh's heart in order to perform all the great signs to proclaim the sanctity of His name." From then on, he became a vessel for the sanctity of the name, which is the purpose of all creations, and he had some elevation, and consequently, there was also a finding of the Holy One, Blessed be He, there. Therefore, his coming to him could also be called by the term "coming" to the Divine power that was then within him to harden his heart.
summary: המעשה של משה רבנו, שיצא ממצרים מקום של גילולים, מדגיש את הקושי להתפלל שם ואת חוסר השראת השכינה. הקב"ה הכביד את לב פרעה כדי להראות את קדושת שמו דרך המופתים הגדולים, ובכך הפך את פרעה לכלי לקדושת השם. זה מצביע על כך שגם במקומות של יובש רוחני ניתן למצוא את השי"ת, והביאה של משה למקום זה נושאת עמה את הכוח האלוקי שיכול לשנות את המצב.

passage_content: ובזהאפשר לתרץ מה שנתחבטו המפורשים בדברי רש"י ז"ל שפי' דבעמדו לפני פרעה נאמרה לו נבואה זו, דהאיך אפשר לומר במקום שלא הי' יכול להתפלל אפי' תפלה קלה, ואיך נאמרה לו פרשה שלימה שם, ועפ"י הנ"לאפשר לומר דמעת שנמצא אצלו הקב"ה עכ"פ לענין הכבדת לבו, מעט מן האור דוחה הרבה מן החושך, והי' באפשרי גם למרע"ה לקבל שם נבואה מאתו ית'.
translation: And with this, it is possible to explain what the commentators struggled with in the words of Rashi, of blessed memory, who interpreted that this prophecy was given to him while standing before Pharaoh. How can it be said in a place where he could not even pray a simple prayer, and how was a complete section said to him there? According to the above, it is possible to say that from the moment the Holy One, blessed be He, was found with him, at least concerning the hardening of his heart, a little bit of light pushes away a lot of darkness, and it was also possible for Moshe Rabbeinu to receive a prophecy from Him there.
summary: The passage discusses the theological tension regarding Moses receiving prophecy while standing before Pharaoh, where he was unable to pray even a simple prayer. It suggests that despite the challenging spiritual environment, God's presence was still accessible to Moses, allowing for the possibility of receiving divine revelation. The idea that "a little light dispels much darkness" is emphasized, indicating that even a small amount of divine illumination can enable one to connect with God, regardless of the surrounding circumstances.

passage_content: וז"שבא אל פרעה, שכעת נקרא ביאתך אל פרעה בלשון ביאה, כי אני הכבדתי את לבו למען שיתי אותותי וגו', וכיון שאני נמצא שם לצורך הטובה הגדולה של האותות והמופתים, שפיר דמי למיקרי הליכתך לשם בלשון ביאה, וזה אפשר לומר גם בכוונת דברי המדרש בא אל פרעה בשליחותי, שא"צ לזה לשון הליכה שיהי' ע"י עצמך כמו שאמר בתחלה לכה שלא רצה שיהי' בדרך שליחות יען שהי' רעה, אבל כאן ע"כ שהוא טובה והראי' ממה שאני הכבדתי את לבו כנז"ל, וע"כ אפשר שיהי' בשליחותי והבן. (ע"כ מכתי"ק).
translation: And this is what is meant by "Come to Pharaoh," that now your coming to Pharaoh is referred to in the language of coming, for I have hardened his heart in order to show My signs, etc. And since I am present there for the great good of the signs and wonders, it is fitting to refer to your going there in the language of coming. This can also be said regarding the intention of the words of the Midrash "Come to Pharaoh in My mission," that there is no need for the language of going to be by yourself, as was said at first "Go, for he did not want it to be in the way of a mission because it was bad." But here, since it is for good, and the proof is that I have hardened his heart as mentioned above, therefore it is possible that it will be in My mission, and understand. (Thus I have written).
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine intervention in the context of Moses' mission to Pharaoh, emphasizing that God hardened Pharaoh's heart to facilitate the performance of miracles and signs. This act is framed as a "coming" to Pharaoh rather than merely a "going," indicating a purposeful divine presence aimed at achieving a greater good. The text suggests that when the mission is for a positive outcome, it can be understood as being carried out in God's name, contrasting with earlier reluctance to act as a messenger due to negative implications. Ultimately, it highlights the transformative power of divine intention in the unfolding of events.

passage_content: ובזהאפ"ל למען שתי אותותי אלה בקרבו, רומז על אותיות התורה שפרשה שלימה בתורה עוד נגע אחד אביא על פרעה וגו' נאמרה בתוך פלטין שלו, ומסתמא הי' זה לצורך התקון להוציא בלעם מפיהם, ועמקו מחשבותיו ית', והנה זכה לזה בסיבת הכבדת הלב כנ"ל, וז"א כי אני הכבדתי את לבו למען שתי אותותי אלה היינו אותיות התורה בקרבו דייקא.
translation: And in this, it is for the sake of these two signs within him, alluding to the letters of the Torah, that a complete section in the Torah states, "One more plague I will bring upon Pharaoh," which was said within his palace. And it is certain that this was for the purpose of rectification to remove Balaam from their mouths, and His thoughts are deep. And behold, he merited this due to the hardening of the heart, as mentioned above. And it is said, "For I have hardened his heart for the sake of these two signs," meaning the letters of the Torah specifically within him.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of the letters of the Torah as divine signs within the heart, particularly in the context of Pharaoh's hardened heart. It suggests that this hardening serves a higher purpose, allowing for the revelation of God's deeper intentions and the eventual redemption from the influence of Balaam. The text highlights the interplay between divine will and human agency, illustrating how God's actions are intricately tied to the unfolding of His plan through the Torah. Ultimately, it reflects on the profound wisdom and depth of God's thoughts in guiding events for the sake of spiritual rectification.

passage_content: (מכתי"ק)ה' אל משה בא אל פרעה וגו' למען שיתי אותותי אלה בקרבו, צ"ב הלשון שאמר במכה זו מכת הארבה למען שיתי אותותי אלה ולא אמר כן בשאר המכות, גם צריך להבין הלא אמרו חז"ל כל מקום שנאמר אלה פוסל אתהראשונים, וא"כ צ"ב מה שאמר אותותי "אלה" דמה פוסל בזה.
translation: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh," etc., "so that I may set these signs of Mine in his midst." It is puzzling why in this plague, the plague of locusts, it says "so that I may set these signs of Mine," and it does not say so regarding the other plagues. Additionally, we need to understand that our Sages have said, "Wherever it says 'these,' it disqualifies the first ones." Therefore, it is puzzling why it says "My signs 'these'" and what disqualifies in this context.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on God's command to Moses regarding the plague of locusts, emphasizing the unique phrasing "למען שיתי אותותי אלה" (to set these signs) which distinguishes this plague from others. The inquiry arises as to why this specific language is used, especially since the term "אלה" typically indicates a disqualification of previous signs. This highlights a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine signs and their purpose in demonstrating God's sovereignty and power, suggesting that the locust plague serves a distinct role in the unfolding narrative of redemption and divine revelation.

passage_content: ב)ז"ל שיתי שימי שאשית אני, וצ"ב הכוונה, דבוודאי לשון שיתי סובב על הקב"ה, ולמה הוצרך להאריך ולפרט שאשית אני.
translation: In the words of the tzaddik, "I have set," and the question arises regarding the intention, for certainly the term "I have set" refers to the Holy One, blessed be He, and why it was necessary to elaborate and specify "that I have set."
summary: The passage discusses the phrase "שיתי שימי שאשית אני," emphasizing that "שיתי" refers to God. It questions the necessity of elaborating on "שאשית אני," suggesting a deeper understanding of God's role in creation and existence. This reflects a Hasidic perspective on the intimate relationship between the Divine and the individual, highlighting the importance of recognizing God's active presence in the world. Ultimately, it invites contemplation on the nature of divine providence and the personal connection each individual has with God.

passage_content: ג)נתקשו שלא הזכיר הקב"ה התראה זו של מכת הארבה ומנא ידע משרע"ה, ומסיק דהבין משה המכה מדאמר לו הקב"ה ולמען תספר, ודרך הוא לספר על מכת הארבה, שהרי גם במכת הארבה דיואל כתיב עלי' לבניכם ספרו, והרמב"ן הביא כן ממדרש שמות רבה, ולמען תספר באזני בנך הודיעו הקב"ה למשה מה מכה יביא עליהם, וכתב אותה ברמז ולמען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך זו מכת הארבה כמה דתימר ביואל עלי' לבניכם ספרו ובניכם לבניכם וגו', וכתב הכלי יקר גם שאר מפורשים דעדיין אין זה מספיק והוא גופה קשיא למה נאמר במכה זו שיספרה לבניו יותר מבכל המכות.
translation: 3) They were perplexed as to why the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not mention this warning of the plague of locusts, and how did Moshe know about it. He concludes that Moshe understood the plague from what the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, "And so that you may tell," and it is customary to recount the plague of locusts, for it is written in the plague of locusts in Joel, "Tell your children about it." The Ramban brought this from the Midrash Shemot Rabbah, and "And so that you may tell in the ears of your son" indicates that the Holy One, Blessed be He, informed Moshe what plague He would bring upon them, and He wrote it in a hint. "And so that you may tell in the ears of your son and your grandson" refers to the plague of locusts, as it is stated in Joel, "Tell your children about it and your children to their children," etc. The Kli Yakar and other commentators also wrote that this is still not sufficient, and it is itself a question why it is said regarding this plague that it should be told to one's children more than regarding all the other plagues.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the plague of locusts in the context of divine communication and the importance of storytelling in Jewish tradition. It highlights that God instructed Moses to convey the details of this specific plague to future generations, emphasizing the need to remember and recount the events of the Exodus. The reference to the verse in Joel reinforces the idea that the plague serves as a pivotal lesson for children, suggesting a deeper theological insight into the continuity of faith and the transmission of history. The text raises questions about why this particular plague warrants special emphasis in the narrative of the plagues.

passage_content: ו)עה"כ בא אל פרעה ר"י פתח ואמר אשרי העם יודעי תרועה ה' באור פניך יהלכון ע"כ, ואינו מובן קישור פסוק זה לכאן ובהגהות מהרח"ו ז"ל כתב לפרש וז"ל סמיכות פ' זה כאן יראה שהוא דרך דרש: כי משה צפה שהשטן הי' מקטרג על יציאת ישראל ממצרים וזה הי' בר"ה, ומסיבת זה לא הי' משה רוצה ליכנס לפרעה, ואמר השם אל משה בא אל פרעה ואל תפחד מקטרוג השטן כי כפרך נתתי בר"ה ואיהו איוב כנז"ל, ולכן אמר אשרי העם יודעי תרועה בר"ה עכ"ד, והנה באמת שבזוה"ק במאמר שלאחריו כתב ר"א פתח ויהי היום ויבאו בני האלהים להתייצב על ה' ויבוא גם השטן בתוכם, והאריך שם שבר"ה מתכנשין כלהו רברבן ממנן לקטרג על ישראל, ויבוא גם השטן בתוכם, ולכן מסר בידו את איוב, עכת"ד הזוה"ק, אמנם עדיין אינו מובן למה הביא כ"ז במכת הארבה, והי' לו להביא זה בקראי דיציאת מצרים או בקי"ס, או במכות הראשונות שהיו סמוך לר"ה, משא"כ מכת הארבה הי' בניסן כמבואר ברמב"ן, ולמה דייקא במכת הארבה נתעורר פחדו של משה והסמיכו לזה הקרא דאשרי העם יודעי תרועה שהוא בר"ה, גם בעטרת צבי ז"ל כתב שלא נודע פי' דבר זה איך יתקשר פסוק זה לכאן.
translation:
And the verse states, "Happy is the people that know the sound of the shofar; they shall walk, O Lord, in the light of Your countenance." This connection of this verse here is not understood, and in the glosses of the Mahari"v, he wrote to explain, saying that the proximity of this section here indicates it is a way of interpretation: for Moses foresaw that the Satan would accuse regarding the departure of Israel from Egypt, and this was on Rosh Hashanah. Because of this, Moses did not want to go to Pharaoh, and the Lord said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh and do not be afraid of the Satan's accusation, for I have given you a denial on Rosh Hashanah, and he is Job, as mentioned." Therefore, he said, "Happy is the people that know the sound of the shofar on Rosh Hashanah." Thus far is the explanation. 

And indeed, in the Zohar, in the subsequent discourse, Rabbi Elazar opened and said, "And it was on that day that the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and the Satan also came among them," and he elaborated there that on Rosh Hashanah all the great ones gather to accuse Israel, and the Satan also comes among them. Therefore, he handed Job over to him, as stated in the Zohar. However, it is still not understood why all this was brought in the plague of locusts, and it would have been appropriate to bring this in the verses of the Exodus from Egypt or in the crossing of the sea, or in the first plagues that were close to Rosh Hashanah, whereas the plague of locusts occurred in Nisan, as explained by the Ramban. Why specifically in the plague of locusts was Moses's fear aroused, and this verse of "Happy is the people that know the sound of the shofar," which is on Rosh Hashanah, was connected to it? Also, in the Atarat Tzvi, it was written that the meaning of this matter is not known, how this verse is connected here.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the verse "אשרי העם יודעי תרועה" and Moses' fear of the Satan's accusations against the Israelites during their impending exodus from Egypt. It highlights the significance of Rosh Hashanah as a time when the Satan gathers to challenge Israel, and how this fear influenced Moses' reluctance to confront Pharaoh. The text emphasizes the idea that despite the accusations, the people who know the sound of the shofar (the "teruah") are blessed, suggesting a deep connection between spiritual awareness and divine protection during critical moments. The mention of Job serves to illustrate the trials faced by the righteous amidst such heavenly deliberations.

passage_content: והנלפענ"דבביאור כל הנ"ל, דהנה רש"י ז"ל כתב על אומרו לפניו לא הי' כן ארבה כמוהו ואחריו לא יהי' כן. ואותו שהי' בימי יואל שנא' כמוהו לא נהי' מן העולם למדנו שהי' כבד משל משה ע"י מינין הרבה שהיו וכו', אבל של משה לא הי' אלא מין א' וכמוהו לא הי' ולא יהי', והקשו בעה"ת והרמב"ן ז"ל שהרי מפורש בתהלים ויתן לחסיל יבולם ויגיעם לארבה, וכתוב א' אמר ויבא ארבה וילק ואין מספר. אלמא שגם בימי משה היו מינים הרבה, ובבע"ת נדחקו לתרץ והרמב"ן פליג בזה על רש"י וסיים אבל בכל גבול מצרים נמשך לפניו לא הי' כן ארבה כמוהו ואחריו לא יהי' כן שם יעיי"ש שהאריך בזה, ונראה כוונתו דמה שאמה"כ ואחריו לא יהי' כן נמשך על גבול מצרים שנזכר בקרא לעיל מיני' שלא יהי' אחריו כן שם, וא"כ אין קושיא משל יואל שהי' בא"י לא במצרים.
translation: And according to my humble opinion regarding the explanation of all the above, behold, Rashi, of blessed memory, wrote on the verse "before Him there was never such a locust, and after Him there will never be such," that the one that was in the days of Joel, which is said to be like it, will not be from the world. We learned that it was heavier than that of Moses due to many species that were, etc., but that of Moses was only one species, and like it there was not, nor will there be. And the commentators and Ramban, of blessed memory, questioned this, for it is explicitly stated in Psalms, "He gave to the locusts their food and to the grasshoppers their portion," and it is written in another verse, "He said, and the locust came, and there was no number." Thus, it is evident that even in the days of Moses there were many species. And the commentators were pressed to explain, and Ramban disagrees with Rashi and concluded that "but in all the borders of Egypt, before Him there was never such a locust, and after Him there will never be such," as it is explained there that he elaborated on this. It seems his intention is that what the verse states "and after Him there will never be such" refers to the borders of Egypt mentioned in the verse above, that there will not be such after him there. Therefore, there is no question from Joel, who was in the Land of Israel, not in Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the uniqueness of the locust plague during the time of Joel compared to that of Moses, emphasizing that while Moses faced only one type of locust, Joel encountered many. This distinction highlights the severity and unprecedented nature of Joel's experience, suggesting a deeper theological significance in the divine judgment specific to the land of Israel. The text also addresses the apparent contradiction in the biblical accounts regarding the presence of multiple locust types, ultimately affirming that the extraordinary nature of Joel's plague serves a unique purpose in the context of Israel's spiritual journey.

passage_content: ולפענ"דאפשר ליישב עוד דהנה הי' זמן כל מכה ומכה חודש א' בלבד, ופליגי חכז"ל (במד"ר פר' ט' סי' י"ב) דלחד מ"ד הי' המכה משמשת ז' ימים וכ"ד ימים הי' מתרה בהם, ולחד מ"ד הי' המכה משמשת כ"ד ימים וז' ימים הי' מתרה בהם, אבל עכ"פ לא הי' המכה משמשת יותר מכ"ד ימים לכל הדיעות, אמנם בימי יואל אף שלא הי' קשה כ"כ כמו בימי משה, מ"מ אריכת הזמן שסבלו ישראל מן הארבה ד' שנים רצופים, זה גרם כבידות יותר אשר כמוהולא נהייתה, וי"ל עוד עפ"י דרכו של הרמב"ן ז"ל דמאמר לפניו לא הי' כן וגו' נמשך על גבול מצרים, ועפי"ד הגמ' סוטה(דף כ' ע"ב) ר' ישמעאל אומר יש זכות תולה י"ב חודש אע"פ שאין ראי' לדבר זכר לדבר דכתיב (דניאל ד') וחטיך בצדקה פרוק ועויתך במיחן ענין וגו' שנדחה גזירת העונש לנבוכדנצר י"ב חודש בשביל שפרנס והספיק מזונות לעניי ישראל ומסקנת הגמ' דאין ראי' גמורה משם דלמא שאני עכו"ם דלא מפקיד דינא עלייהו, ועיין פירש"י שם, ומצינו כ"פ בש"ס שאין להביא ראי' מעכו"ם לישראל ומישראל לעכו"ם, וא"כ י"ל דממה שאה"כ בגבול מצרים ואחריו לא יהי' כן, כיון דשם מיירי בעכו"ם אין ראי' משם לישראל, ואותו שהי' בימי יואל זה הי' עונש לישראל על חטאם לעוררם על התשובה, ואח"כ שילם להם הקב"ה כל הצער והנזק שסבלו בכל השנים שהי' הארבה כמבואר בקרא (יואל ב' כ"ה) ושלמתי לכם את השנים אשר אכל הארבה וגו': וא"כ זה ענין אחר ואין בזה סתירה מקרא הנאמר לגבי עכו"ם.
translation: And in my humble opinion, it is possible to reconcile further, for behold, each plague lasted only one month, and the sages disagree (in Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Tazria, Section 12) that according to one opinion, the plague lasted for seven days and for twenty-four days it warned them, while according to another opinion, the plague lasted for twenty-four days and for seven days it warned them. However, in any case, the plague did not last more than twenty-four days according to all opinions. Nevertheless, in the days of Joel, even though it was not as severe as in the days of Moses, the prolonged time that Israel suffered from the locusts for four consecutive years caused a greater heaviness that had not occurred before. It can also be explained according to the way of the Ramban, that the statement "before him it was not so" refers to the border of Egypt, and according to the Gemara in Sotah (20b), Rabbi Ishmael says that there is a merit that can extend for twelve months, even though there is no proof for this, as it is written (Daniel 4) "and your sins with righteousness redeem," which indicates that the decree of punishment against Nebuchadnezzar was postponed for twelve months because he provided and supplied food for the poor of Israel. And the conclusion of the Gemara is that there is no definitive proof from there, perhaps it is different for a gentile who does not have the law imposed upon him, and see Rashi's explanation there. We find many times in the Talmud that one cannot bring proof from a gentile to Israel or from Israel to a gentile. Therefore, it can be said that since it is mentioned in the border of Egypt and afterwards it will not be so, since there it deals with a gentile, there is no proof from there to Israel. And that which occurred in the days of Joel was a punishment for Israel for their sin to awaken them to repentance, and afterwards, the Holy One, blessed be He, compensated them for all the pain and damage they suffered during all the years that the locusts were present, as it is explained in the verse (Joel 2:25) "And I will restore to you the years that the locust has eaten." Therefore, this is a different matter and there is no contradiction to the verse mentioned regarding gentiles.
summary: The passage discusses the duration and severity of the plagues faced by the Israelites, particularly the locust plague during the time of Joel, which lasted four years and was a divine punishment for their sins, intended to prompt repentance. It contrasts this with the shorter durations of plagues in earlier times, suggesting that the prolonged suffering was a unique consequence of their actions. The text also references the idea that God compensates for the suffering endured, as indicated in the verse from Joel, where He promises to restore what was lost due to the locusts. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of divine justice and mercy, emphasizing that suffering can lead to spiritual awakening and eventual restoration.

passage_content: והנהבקרא דיואל כתיב ושלמתי לכם את השנים אשר אכל הארבה הילק והחסיל והגזם חילי הגדול אשר שלחתי בכם, ולפי פשוטו פירשו המפורשים שנשלם להם אח"כ ברכה מרובה ושובע גדול, שהי' משלים כל מה שנחסרו בשנים הקודמים ע"י הארבה, אמנם בתרגום יונתן פי' הכתוב הנ"ל, ואשלם לכון שניא טבתא חלף שניא דבזו יתכון פלחי כוכביא אומיא ולישניא ושלטוניא ומלכותא פורענות חילי רבא דשלחית בכון, וכתב הרד"ק נראה כי דעתו הי' שהוא נבואה עתידה לימות המשיח עכ"ל, ובוודאי שלפי פשוטו של מקרא דברו הכתובים מהארבה שהי' אז בימי יואל, אבל דברי הת"י צ"ל שהוא כעין דרשא, שמידי דברו מהארבה שהי' אז, רמז הנבואה גם על ימות המשיח שהקב"ה ישלם כל מה שסבלו ישראל מהאומות המצירים להם בכל משך זמן גלותם, וקרא הכתוב כל אותן האומות בשמות של ד' מיני הארבה, והפשט והדרש שבדברי חכז"ל שניהם אמיתים, ואלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים: כנודע שדרך הכתובים בכל מלה להורות על כמה ענינים, וממה שירמוז הכתוב על אותן האומות שישראל סובלין מהם בימי הגלות בשמות של ד' מיני הארבה, נראה ששורש אחד להם, כי לא בחנם קראם הכ' בשמות הללו, וכבר כתבו במה שאדה"ר קרא שמות לכל הנבראים כמבואר בקרא, שזהו מגודל חכמתו שהבין שרשו ויסודו של כל נברא, אשר לפי שורשו וענינו יקרא בשם זה, וכתב הרמב"ן בפ' בראשית עה"כ וכל אשר יקרא לו האדם נפש חי' הוא שמו, שהקב"ה הביא כל חית השדה וכל עוף השמים לפני אדם, והוא הכיר טבעם וקרא להם שמות כלומר השם הראוי להם כפי טבעיהם, ובשמות נתבאר הראוי להיות עזר לחבירו כלומר הראוים להוליד זה מזה יעיי"ש שהאריך. ובספרי חכמי האמת ביארו בזה. יותר, ועכ"פ זה וודאי שהשמות הנזכרים בתורה ובנביאים המה מכוונים כפי שורשם ומהותם של בעלי השמות.
translation: And behold, in the book of Joel it is written, "And I will repay you the years that the locust has eaten, the grasshopper, the caterpillar, and the great army which I sent among you." According to its simple meaning, the interpreters explain that He will repay them afterwards with abundant blessing and great plenty, which will make up for all that they were lacking in the previous years due to the locusts. However, in the translation of Jonathan, the above verse is interpreted, "And I will repay you for the years of the good that have passed, for the years in which the nations have oppressed you and your sovereignty and dominion and the great punishment that I sent upon you." The Radak wrote that it seems his opinion was that it is a prophecy for the future days of the Messiah. Indeed, according to the simple meaning of the scripture, the verses speak of the locusts that were then in the days of Joel, but the words of the Targum should be understood as a kind of drash, that from the mention of the locusts that were then, it hints at the prophecy also regarding the days of the Messiah, when the Holy One, blessed be He, will repay all that Israel has suffered from the nations that oppress them throughout their entire period of exile. The scripture calls all those nations by the names of the four types of locusts, and both the simple meaning and the drash in the words of our sages are true, and both these and those are the words of the living God. As is known, it is the way of the scriptures to indicate several matters in every word, and from what the scripture hints at regarding those nations from which Israel suffers during the exile by the names of the four types of locusts, it seems they have one root, for it is not in vain that the Holy One called them by these names. It has already been written that when Adam HaRishon named all the creations, as is explained in the scripture, this was due to his great wisdom, as he understood the root and essence of every creation, which according to its root and nature would be called by this name. The Ramban wrote in the portion of Genesis regarding the verse, "And whatever the man called every living creature, that was its name," that the Holy One brought all the beasts of the field and all the birds of the heavens before Adam, and he recognized their nature and called them names, meaning the name appropriate to them according to their natures. And in the names, it was clarified what is fitting to be a help to one another, meaning those that are suitable to give birth to one another, as is explained there at length. And in the books of the sages of truth, this is further elucidated. And nevertheless, it is certain that the names mentioned in the Torah and the Prophets are directed according to their root and essence of the bearers of the names.
summary: The passage discusses the biblical promise of restoration for Israel after suffering from the locust plague, interpreting it as a foreshadowing of future redemption during the Messianic era. It highlights the connection between the four types of locusts and the nations that oppress Israel, suggesting a shared root of suffering. The text emphasizes the significance of names in the Torah, indicating that they reflect the essence and nature of their subjects, thus revealing deeper spiritual truths. Ultimately, both the simple and deeper interpretations of the scripture are seen as valid and divinely inspired.

passage_content: וכמו"כלענינינו במכת הארבה רמז הכתוב על גלות האומות עד ביאת המשיח, ובפרט בפסוקי יואל לפי דעת התרגום שהוא נביאה עתידה על ימות המשיח וירמוז על האומות בשמות של מיני הארבה מפני ששורש א' להם, וא"כ אין קושיא מה שנאמר שם ביואל עלי' לבניכם ספרו ובניהם לבניהם ובניהם לדור אחר, דכיון שנרמז שם ענין הגליות עד ביאת המשיח, גם נרמז בו דברי התחזקות שאחר ביאת המשיח ישלם הקב"ה לישראל כל מה שסבלו מהאומות, ע"כ צריכין לידע זה בכל דור ודור. כמבואר בזוה"ק שלולא הנחמות שרואים בתוה"ק מה שיהי' אחר ביאת המשיח, לא הי' אפשרות לסבול עול הצרות ועול הגלויות. גם תלוי בתשובה ומע"ט שבדור שזה גורם להקל מצב הגליות ולקרב את הגאולה, וצריך שימת לב בכל דור ודור לעניני הגליות ולעורר רחמי שמים, ומעתה אפשר להבין גם במכת הארבה שבמצרים, דכיון ששורשם של מיני הארבה הוא שורש א' עם האומות המצירין לישראל בגלותם עד ביאת המשיח, והמשכילים יבינו שורשם ומקורם ורואים בזה עניני הגלות, לכן אמר הכתוב ולמען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך, כמו שהוא בפסוקי יואל, ושפיר כתבו רז"ל דבמאמר ולמען תספר שם רמז על מכת הארבה שכן הוא ביואל, והן המה האומות המצירין לישראל וצריכין לרחמי שמים בכל דרא ודרא להנצל מהם.
translation: And just as "in our matter regarding the plague of locusts, the scripture hints at the exile of the nations until the coming of the Messiah, particularly in the verses of Joel according to the understanding of the translation, which is a prophecy about the days of the Messiah, and it hints at the nations by the names of the types of locusts because they share a common root. Therefore, there is no difficulty with what is stated there in Joel about telling your children and your children's children and their children to another generation, for since the matter of the exiles until the coming of the Messiah is hinted at there, it also hints at words of encouragement that after the coming of the Messiah, the Holy One, blessed be He, will repay Israel for all that they have suffered from the nations. Thus, we need to know this in every generation. As is explained in the Zohar, were it not for the consolations that we see in the Torah regarding what will be after the coming of the Messiah, it would not be possible to bear the yoke of troubles and the burden of exiles. It also depends on the repentance and good deeds of the generation, which causes the alleviation of the state of the exiles and brings closer the redemption. Attention must be paid in every generation to the matters of the exiles and to awaken the mercy of Heaven. From now on, it is also possible to understand the plague of locusts in Egypt, for since the root of the types of locusts shares a common root with the nations that oppress Israel in their exile until the coming of the Messiah, the wise will understand their root and source and see in this matters of exile. Therefore, the scripture says, 'and in order that you tell in the ears of your son and your son's son,' just as it is in the verses of Joel. And it is well written by our sages that in the statement 'and in order that you tell' there is a hint to the plague of locusts, as it is in Joel, and they are the nations that oppress Israel and need the mercy of Heaven in every generation to be saved from them."
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the plague of locusts and the exile of the nations until the coming of the Messiah, as interpreted through the lens of the prophet Joel. It emphasizes that the suffering endured by Israel at the hands of the nations is ultimately linked to their redemption, with the promise of divine recompense after the Messiah's arrival. The text highlights the importance of recognizing these themes in every generation, as well as the role of repentance and good deeds in alleviating the hardships of exile and hastening redemption. It underscores the necessity of invoking divine mercy in response to the ongoing challenges faced by the Jewish people throughout history.

passage_content: ובאמתבעודם במצרים הבני עלי' שבישראל השיגו גלויות העתידים עד ימות המשיח, וע"ד שפירשתי(בפ' שמות) שאמר משה להקב"ה הנה אנכי בא אל בני ישראל ואמרו לי מה שמו מה אומר אלהם ויאמר אלקים אל משה אקי' אשר אקי' ויאמר כה תאמר לבני ישראל אקי' שלחני אליכם, ואמרו חכז"ל בגמ' ברכות (דף ט' ע"ב) ובמד"ר והובא שם ברש"י ז"ל דבתחלה אמר הקב"ה אהי' עמם בצרה זאת אשר אהי' עמם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות, אמר לפניו רבש"ע מה אני מזכיר להם צרה אחרת די' לצרה בשעתה, אמר לו יפה אמרת כה תאמר וגו' והוא פלא לכאורה שמרע"ה הקשה קושי' לאלוקינו ית"ש, וכתב שם בהגה ברש"י ז"ל לא שהשכיל חלילה משה ביותר, אלא שלא הבין דברי הקב"ה כי לא מחשבתו מחשבת השי"ת, שמאז כך היתה דעתו באומרו ית' אקי' אשר אקי' למשה לבדו הגיד ולא שיגיד לישראל, וזהו יפה אמרת שגם דעתי מתחלה כך היתה שלא תגיד לבני ישראל כדברים האלה, אלא כה תאמר לבני ישראל אהי' פעם אחת עכ"ל וכן הוא במהרש"א ברכות (ד' ט'). אבל קשה לי טובא שהרי מבואר בקרא ששאל משה הנה אנכי בא אל בני ישראל ואמרו לי מה שמו מה אומר להם. א"כ לא שאל כלל בשביל עצמו לידע השם, אלא כל שאלתו הי' מה יאמר לישראל, ואם נימא דהתשובה שהשיב לו הקב"ה אקי' אשר אקי' לא הי' אלא להודיע למשה לבדו ולא להגיד לישראל, א"כ לא הי' התשובה מעין השאלה כלל.
translation: And indeed, while they were still in Egypt, the sons of Eli in Israel attained knowledge of the future exiles until the days of the Messiah, and as I explained (in Parashat Shemot), when Moses said to the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Here I am, I come to the children of Israel, and they will say to me, 'What is His name? What shall I say to them?'" And God said to Moses, "I will be that I will be." And He said, "Thus shall you say to the children of Israel, 'I will be has sent me to you.'" And our sages, of blessed memory, said in the Gemara Berakhot (page 9b) and in the Midrash, as brought there in Rashi, of blessed memory, that initially the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "I will be with them in this trouble as I will be with them in the servitude of other kingdoms." Moses said before Him, "Master of the Universe, why should I mention to them another trouble? It is enough for them to suffer in their time." He said to him, "You have spoken well; thus shall you say..." And it is seemingly a wonder that Moses posed a difficulty to our God, may He be blessed. And it is written there in the gloss of Rashi, of blessed memory, that it was not that Moses understood more, God forbid, but that he did not comprehend the words of the Holy One, Blessed be He, for His thoughts are not like our thoughts. For since then, this was His intention in saying to Moses alone, "I will be that I will be," and not that it should be told to Israel. And this is what He meant when He said, "You have spoken well," that my intention from the beginning was that it should not be told to the children of Israel in such terms, but "Thus shall you say to the children of Israel, 'I will be' once." Thus far the text, and so it is in Maharsha, Berakhot (page 9). But it is very difficult for me, for it is clear from the verse that Moses asked, "Here I am, I come to the children of Israel, and they will say to me, 'What is His name? What shall I say to them?'" Therefore, he did not ask at all for himself to know the name, but his entire question was what he should say to Israel. And if we say that the answer that the Holy One, Blessed be He, gave him, "I will be that I will be," was only to inform Moses alone and not to tell Israel, then the answer was not at all in the nature of the question.
summary: In the passage, the author discusses the profound dialogue between Moses and God regarding the revelation of God's name to the Israelites during their time in Egypt. It highlights the tension between divine intention and human understanding, emphasizing that God's response "I will be" was meant for Moses alone, not for the people. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the hiddenness of divine wisdom, suggesting that human perception is limited and that God's plans often transcend our understanding. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of faith in the face of divine mystery and the unique relationship between God and His chosen leaders.

passage_content: ואפשרלומר עפ"י המבואר במד"ר (פ' נשא פ' י"ג סי' י"ג) והי' מסורת ביד שבט יהודא חכמיהם וגדוליהם מן יעקב אבינו, כל מה שעתיד ליארע לכל שבט עד ימות המשיח. וכן הי' ביד כל שבט ושבט מסורת כל מה שיארע לו עדימות המשיח מן יעקב אביהם עכ"ל, וא"כ שהי' בכל שבט ושבט חכמים גדולים שידעו בקבלה מיעקב אבינו ע"ה כל מה שיארע להם עד ימות המשיח, ע"כ שהשיגו גלויות העתידים, כי רוב המאורעות שבאותן הזמנים עד ימות המשיח המה מאורעות של גלויות, אלא שרוב ההמון לא ידעו מכ"ז אלא יחידי סגולה החכמים הגדולים, וכמו שהוא בלשון המדרש שהי' המסורה ביד חכמיהם וגדוליהם.
translation: And it is possible to say according to what is explained in the Midrash (Parashat Naso, Chapter 13, Section 13) that there was a tradition in the hand of the tribe of Judah, their sages and great ones from our forefather Jacob, regarding everything that would happen to each tribe until the days of the Messiah. Likewise, each tribe had a tradition of everything that would happen to it until the days of the Messiah from their father Jacob. Therefore, in every tribe there were great sages who knew through tradition from our forefather Jacob, peace be upon him, everything that would happen to them until the days of the Messiah. Thus, they attained knowledge of the exiles to come, for most of the events that will occur during those times until the days of the Messiah are events of exile. However, the majority of the masses did not know of this, only select individuals, the great sages, as it is stated in the language of the Midrash that it was a tradition in the hands of their sages and great ones.
summary: The passage discusses the tradition held by the tribe of Judah, as well as other tribes, regarding the knowledge passed down from Jacob about future events until the Messianic era. It emphasizes that each tribe had wise individuals who understood the prophetic revelations concerning their destinies, particularly the exiles they would face. While the majority of the people remained unaware of these insights, the select few, the great sages, were privy to this profound knowledge, highlighting the importance of wisdom and tradition in understanding the unfolding of history and divine plans.

passage_content: ולפי"זאותן גדולי הדור שידעו עתידות הגלות לא הי' קשה קושית מרע"ה די' לצרה בשעתה, כי הם ידעו בלא"ה מכל הצרות והמאורעות שיהיו עד ימות המשיח, וא"כ אדרבא מהראוי הי' להגיד להם נחמה זו שהקב"ה יהי' עמהם בשיעבוד שאר המלכיות, אלא שהבין מרע"ה שהקב"ה אומר לו להגיד תשובה זו לכל ישראל ונכלל בזה גם רוב ההמון שאינם יודעים כלל מגלויות העתידים, וע"ז בוודאי יפה אמר מרע"ה די' לצרה בשעתה, אמנם באמת עיקר שליחותו של מרע"ה הי' לגדולי הדור, כמו שאה"כ לך ואספת את זקני ישראל ופירש"י מיוחדים לישיבה לא זקנים סתם, ועל ידם בא הידיעה אח"כ לכל ישראל, גם השואלין ודורשין על שמותיו של הקב"ה היו המיוחדים שבדור היודעין ומבינים בידיעת השמות, כי לההמון אין להם ידיעה והבנה בזה. בפרט במצרים קודם מ"ת, ועכ"פ מובן הענין כי הקב"ה אמר לו מתחילה מה שיגיד לגדולי החכמים היודעין בלא"ה מהגלות, ע"כ הצורך להגיד לפניהם שהקב"ה יהי' עמהם גם בשעבוד שאר מלכיות, אבל בשביל ההמון שאינם יודעין מהצרות נאמרה מימרא שני' כה תאמר וגו' אקי' פ"א ולא יותר וזה ששאל משה די' לצרה בשעתה, זה הי' טרם שמע מימרא שני', אבל באמת שני המימרות האלו הם תשובה על שאלתו מה אומר לישראל, אלא שלא נאמרו לו אלו המימרות להגיד כן לכל ישראל בנוסח א', אלא הקב"ה הודיע כ"ז למשה שיבין להשיב לכל שואל כפי בחינתו וידיעתו בענין הגלות ובזה מיושב הענין, ועכ"פ הי' אז חכמים גדולים בכל שבט שהי' להם הכל בקבלה מיע"א ע"ה והבינו גם שורשם של מיני הארבה שהן המה האומות המצירים לישראל עד סוף כל הדורות, וע"ז נאמר ולמען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך וכמ"ש בנבואת יואל.
translation: According to this, those great ones of the generation who knew the future of the exile did not find it difficult to answer Moses' question about why it is said that "it is difficult in its time," for they knew in any case about all the troubles and events that would occur until the days of the Messiah. Therefore, on the contrary, it would have been appropriate to tell them this comfort that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would be with them during the subjugation of the other kingdoms. However, Moses understood that the Holy One, Blessed be He, was telling him to convey this response to all of Israel, which also includes the majority of the masses who do not know at all about the future exiles. For this reason, Moses indeed said that "it is difficult in its time." However, in truth, the main mission of Moses was for the great ones of the generation, as it is written, "Go and gather the elders of Israel," and Rashi explains that this refers to those who are special for the assembly, not just any elders. Through them, the knowledge later came to all of Israel. Also, those who inquired and sought the names of the Holy One, Blessed be He, were the special ones of the generation who knew and understood the knowledge of the names, for the masses do not have knowledge and understanding in this. Especially in Egypt before the giving of the Torah, and in any case, the matter is understood because the Holy One, Blessed be He, initially told him what to say to the great wise men who already knew about the exile. Therefore, there was a need to tell them that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would be with them also during the subjugation of the other kingdoms. But for the masses who do not know about the troubles, a second saying was stated: "So shall you say," etc., as it is written in the first chapter and no more. And this that Moses asked, "Why is it difficult in its time?" was before he heard the second saying. But in truth, these two sayings are a response to his question of what to say to Israel, except that these sayings were not told to him to convey them to all of Israel in one formulation, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, informed Moses of all this so that he would understand to respond to each inquirer according to their understanding and knowledge regarding the exile. And in this, the matter is settled. In any case, there were great sages in every tribe who had everything received from their ancestors, peace be upon them, and they also understood the root of the types of locusts, which are the nations that oppress Israel until the end of all generations. And for this, it is said, "And in order that you tell in the ears of your son and your son's son," as it is stated in the prophecy of Joel.
summary: The passage discusses the role of Moses in conveying God's message of comfort to the Jewish people during their suffering, emphasizing that he was instructed to address both the wise leaders and the general populace. It highlights the understanding that the great leaders of the generation were already aware of the future exiles and tribulations, thus necessitating a message of divine presence during their hardships. The text underscores the importance of tailored communication, where Moses was to respond to each group's level of understanding regarding the impending exiles, ensuring that the essence of God's promise was accessible to all. Ultimately, it reflects the Hasidic belief in the interconnectedness of knowledge, leadership, and divine reassurance throughout the generations.

passage_content: ובזהאפשר לפרש ג"כ מה שאמר למען שיתי אותותי "אלה" בקרבו, (עיין קושיא א') דהנה ק"ז בישמח משה כתב דיותר נראה לפרש מה שאמר אותותי אלה בקרבו דקאי על ישראל, מלפרשו על מצרים יעיי"ש טעמו ונימוקו, ועפי"ד אפשר לומר עפימ"ד בגמ' (ברכות י"ב ע"ב) דלדעת בן זומאאין מזכירין כלל יציאת מצרים לימות המשיח, ולדעת חכמים לא תעקר יציאת מצרים ממקומה אלא שתהא שעבוד מלכיות עיקר ויציאת מצרים טפל לו, ועכ"פ לכל הדיעות הגאולה משעבוד מלכיות תעשה יציאת מצרים לטפל, ולכן במכת הארבה שנרמז שם נבואה על ימות המשיח, והשיגו המבינים שבישראל שהצלתם ממכת הארבה ירמוז על הצלה משעבוד מלכיות המרומזים בשמות מיני הארבה, ולכן אמר בזה אותותי אלה פוסל את הראשונים, כי הצלתם בשעבוד מלכיות פוסל כל מה שקדם לפני', ואף יציאת מצרים יהי' טפל, וע"כ פירש"י ז"ל שיתי שימי שאשית אני, כי אמרו חכז"ל במדרש (ילקוט זכרי' רמז תקע"ז) עה"כ ישראל נושע בה' תשועת עולמים, לשעבר הייתם נושעים ע"י בשר ודם לכן לא הי' תשועת עולמים, אבל לעתיד כתיב ופדויי ה' ישובון ולא כתיב ופדויי משה ואהרן או פדויי משיח ואלי' אלא ופדויי ה' ואז תהי' תשועת עולמים והנה גם גאולת מצרים הי' ע"י שלוחים משה ואהרן אבל גאולה העתידה משעבוד מלכיות לא יהי' אלא ע"י הקב"ה בכבודו ובעצמו הוא ולא אחר, עיין מ"ש הרמב"ן עה"פ וה' הולך לפניהם יומם, וכן הוא בזוה"ק ובמדרשי חכז"ל בכ"מ, ולכן בפ' הארבה שמרמז על הגאולה משעבוד מלכיות הוצרך לפרש שיתי שימי שאשית אני, כי שיתי לבד אפשר לפרשו גם ע"י שליח כמו ביציאת מצרים שאה"כ כי ה' הוציא את ישראל ממצרים אף שהי' ע"י שליח, אבל הגאולה משעבוד מלכיות יהי' דוקא באופן שאשית אני ולא ע"י שליח.
translation: And with this, it is also possible to explain what was said, "in order that I may set My signs 'these' within him" (see question 1). Behold, in the verse "And Moses rejoiced" it is written that it seems more appropriate to explain what is said, "My signs these within him," as referring to Israel, rather than to explain it as referring to Egypt. See there for the reason and explanation. According to this, it is possible to say according to the opinion of the Gemara (Berakhot 12b) that according to the view of Ben Zoma, the Exodus from Egypt is not mentioned at all in the days of the Messiah, while according to the Sages, the Exodus from Egypt will not be uprooted from its place, but rather the subjugation of the kingdoms will be primary and the Exodus from Egypt will be secondary to it. And in any case, according to all opinions, the redemption from the subjugation of kingdoms will make the Exodus from Egypt secondary. Therefore, in the plague of locusts, which hints at the prophecy regarding the days of the Messiah, those who understand among Israel realized that their salvation from the plague of locusts hints at salvation from the subjugation of kingdoms, which is hinted at in the names of the various types of locusts. Therefore, it was said, "My signs these" disqualifies the earlier ones, because their salvation from the subjugation of kingdoms disqualifies everything that preceded it, and even the Exodus from Egypt will be secondary. And thus Rashi, of blessed memory, explained "I will set the days that I will set," because our Sages, of blessed memory, said in the Midrash (Yalkut Zechariah, hint 897) regarding the verse, "Israel will be saved by the Lord with an eternal salvation," that in the past you were saved by flesh and blood, therefore there was no eternal salvation. But in the future it is written, "And the redeemed of the Lord will return," and it is not written, "And the redeemed of Moses and Aaron" or "the redeemed of the Messiah and Elijah," but "the redeemed of the Lord," and then there will be eternal salvation. And behold, even the redemption from Egypt was through agents, Moses and Aaron, but the future redemption from the subjugation of kingdoms will be only through the Holy One, blessed be He, in His glory and essence, and not through another. See what the Ramban wrote on the verse, "And the Lord went before them by day," and so it is in the Zohar and in the Midrashim of our Sages everywhere. Therefore, in the chapter of locusts, which hints at the redemption from the subjugation of kingdoms, it was necessary to explain "I will set the days that I will set," because "I will set" alone could also be interpreted as through an agent, as in the Exodus from Egypt, as it is written, "For the Lord brought Israel out of Egypt," even though it was through an agent. But the redemption from the subjugation of kingdoms will be specifically in a manner that "I will set" and not through an agent.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the redemption from Egypt and the future redemption from the dominion of nations, emphasizing that while the former was facilitated by human agents like Moses and Aaron, the latter will be a direct intervention by God Himself. It highlights that the future redemption will render the previous redemptions secondary, as it will be a complete and ultimate salvation. The text also references the idea that true salvation will come from God alone, as indicated in the prophetic visions of the future, contrasting it with past salvations that involved intermediaries. This underscores a key Hasidic concept of divine immediacy in the ultimate redemption.

passage_content: ובזהאפשר לפרש המסורה וינח הארבה וינח ביום השביעי, כי במכת הארבה נרמז הגלות של כל המלכיות כמבואר ביואל, והעצה להנצל משיעבוד מלכיות הוא ע"י שמירת השבת, ואמרז"ל בגמ' שבת (קי"ח ע"ב) אלמלי משמרין ישראל שתי שבתות מיד נגאלין, ובזוה"ק ובמדרש מבואר דע"י שמירת שבת א' מיד נגאלין, ואפשר להשוות המימרות עפ"י המבואר בזוהר הק' דשבת דלילה ושבת דיממא הם שתי בחינות, וא"כ אפשר דגם מה שאמרו בגמ' שתי שבתות הכוונה על שבת א' בשלימות יום ולילה ישבותו, וזה נקרא שתי שבתות דלילה ודיממא, ועכ"פ השבת הוא ההצלה משיעבוד מלכיות, ולכן א"ש קישור המסורה וינח הארבה שם רמז על המלכיות הנקראים כן, ויתקשר אליו וינח ביום השביעי כי הוא העצה היעוצה להנצל מהמלכיות.
translation: And with this, it is possible to interpret the Masorah "And the locust settled, and it settled on the seventh day," for in the plague of locusts is hinted the exile of all the kingdoms, as explained in Joel. The advice to be saved from the subjugation of kingdoms is through the observance of Shabbat. And our Sages of blessed memory said in the Gemara Shabbat (118b) that if Israel would observe two Shabbatot, they would be redeemed immediately. And in the Zohar and in the Midrash, it is explained that by observing one Shabbat, they would be redeemed immediately. It is possible to compare the sayings according to what is explained in the holy Zohar that the Shabbat of night and the Shabbat of day are two aspects. Therefore, it is possible that what they said in the Gemara about two Shabbatot refers to one Shabbat in its completeness, where they rest both day and night. This is called two Shabbatot of night and day. Nevertheless, Shabbat is the salvation from the subjugation of kingdoms. Therefore, it is clear that the connection of the Masorah "And the locust settled" hints at the kingdoms that are called so, and it is connected to "And it settled on the seventh day," for it is the advised counsel to be saved from the kingdoms.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the plague of locusts and the exile of the Jewish people, emphasizing that the key to escaping the subjugation of kingdoms lies in the observance of the Sabbath. It cites teachings from the Talmud and Zohar, suggesting that by keeping the Sabbath fully, both day and night, one can achieve redemption. The text highlights the significance of the Sabbath as a means of salvation from oppression, linking it to the broader theme of divine protection and liberation.

passage_content: ובזהאפשר לפרש המסורה ולמען תספר ולמען יאריכון ימיך, דלפי דברי המד"ר והרמב"ן ובעה"ת במה שאמר ולמען תספר באזני בנך שם רמז על נבואת יואל דכתיב בי' ספרו לבניכם, וכבר כתבתי הטעם בזה בשביל שבאותה נבואה נאמר ושלמתי לכם השנים, ופי' התרגום שהוא נבואה על ימות המשיח שישלם הקב"ה שניא טבתא חלף שניא וגו', והנה בזה כבר נתקשו הקדמונים דבאמת כן משמע גם מהכ' שמחנו כימות עניתנו, שיתארכו ימי השמחה כמו ימי העינוי, אבל לפי חשבון שאמרו בגמ' שית אלפי שנין הוי עלמא, כבר לא נשארו בחשבון השנים של עמידת העולם כחשבון השנים שעברו בגלות, בפרט אחר שכבר עברו שנים הרבה מאלף השישי, וניחא להו שאחר הגאולה יתארכו הימים, ויהי' יום א' ארוך כ"כ עד שיושלם החשבון של הרבה שנים, ובזה פי' המגלה עמוקות ויהי מקץ שנתיים ימים, דר"ל שבזמן הקץ יהי' חשבון שנתיים אף בימים, כי יתארכו הימים כ"כ, וזה נרמז בהמסורה שאמר ולמען תספר באזני בנך וגו' שאמרו הרמז בזה לנבואת יואל דכתיב בי' ספרו לבניכם, ולפי האמורהטעם הוא בשביל דשם כתוב ושלמתי לכם את השנים וגו' שהוא נבואה עתידה על ימות המשיח ויקשה לכאורה האיך אפשר לפרש כפי' התרגום דקאי על ימות המשיח, הלא אחר ביאת המשיח איך אפשר לשלם השנים המרובין שעברו בימי הגלות לפי חשבון השנים שנשארו לעמידת העולם, והאיך אמר ושלמתי לכם השנים וגו' וע"כ הסמיכו לזה הכ' ולמען יאריכון ימיך, שזה תי' מספיק שהקב"ה ישלים הזמן ע"י אריכת הימים.
translation: And with this, it is possible to interpret the Masorah, "and in order that you may tell and that your days may be prolonged," for according to the words of the Midrash and the Ramban, and in the Torah where it says, "and in order that you may tell in the ears of your son," there is a hint to the prophecy of Joel, as it is written, "Tell it to your children." And I have already written the reason for this, for in that prophecy it is said, "And I will restore to you the years," and the translation explains that it is a prophecy concerning the days of the Messiah, that the Holy One, blessed be He, will restore the years that were lost, etc. And behold, in this, the ancients were already troubled, for it indeed seems to imply from the verse, "You have made us rejoice as in the days of our affliction," that the days of joy will be prolonged like the days of affliction. But according to the calculation stated in the Gemara, that the world will last for six thousand years, there are no longer years left in the calculation of the existence of the world as there are years that have passed in exile, especially after many years have already passed since the sixth millennium. And it is pleasing to them that after the redemption, the days will be prolonged, and there will be one day so long that it will complete the calculation of many years. And with this, the Megaleh Amukos explains, "And it came to pass at the end of two years," meaning that at the time of the end, there will be a calculation of two years even in days, for the days will be prolonged so much. And this is hinted at in the Masorah, which says, "and in order that you may tell in the ears of your son," etc., which they said hints at the prophecy of Joel, as it is written, "Tell it to your children." And according to the aforementioned reason, it is because there it is written, "And I will restore to you the years," etc., which is a future prophecy concerning the days of the Messiah. And it seems difficult at first glance how it is possible to interpret according to the translation that refers to the days of the Messiah, for after the coming of the Messiah, how can it be possible to restore the many years that have passed during the days of exile according to the calculation of the years that remain for the existence of the world? And how can it say, "And I will restore to you the years," etc.? Therefore, they connected this to the verse, "and in order that your days may be prolonged," which is a sufficient answer that the Holy One, blessed be He, will complete the time through the prolongation of the days.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of the verse "ולמען תספר ולמען יאריכון ימיך" in relation to the prophecy of Joel, which speaks of God restoring the years lost during exile. It emphasizes the belief that in the Messianic era, time will be extended, allowing for the fulfillment of the years that were diminished during suffering. The text suggests that God's promise to "restore the years" implies a miraculous extension of time, ensuring that the joy of redemption will surpass the pain of past hardships. This theological insight reflects a deep faith in divine intervention and the transformative power of the Messianic age.

passage_content: ובזהאפשר לפרש גם דברי הזוה"ק שהביא בתחלת פ' בא) הכתוב אשרי העם יודעי תרועה ה' באור פניך יהלכון, דלפי האמור במכת הארבה ובפסוק ולמען תספר וגו' רמז על כל המלכיות המצערין לישראל, והביא שם בזוה"ק שבר"ה מתכנשיןכל שרי האומות והשטן בתוכם לקטרג על ישראל, ובר"ה הוא עיקר הדין על הגאולה משיעבוד מלכיות, כמו שהוא רוב התפלות בר"ה על זה, וכח התק"ש הוא המזכה את ישראל כנגד האומות כמבואר זה בכ"מ בדברי חכז"ל, ומובן מה שהסמיכו בזוה"ק לכאן הפסוק אשרי העם יודעי תרועה וגו', שאך בכח תק"ש ניצולין מהם, באור פניך יהלכון להצילנו ממים הזדונים ויגאלנו בקרב גאולת עולם ויתגלה כבוד מלכותו עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן. (ע"כ מכתי"ק)
translation: And with this, it is possible to explain also the words of the Zohar that he brought at the beginning of Parshat Bo: "Blessed is the people that knows the sound of the shofar; they shall walk, O Lord, in the light of Your countenance." According to what is stated regarding the plague of locusts and in the verse "and in order that you tell," it hints at all the kingdoms that oppress Israel. And there it is brought in the Zohar that on Rosh Hashanah all the princes of the nations and Satan among them gather to accuse Israel. And on Rosh Hashanah is the main judgment regarding the redemption from the servitude of the kingdoms, as most of the prayers on Rosh Hashanah are for this. And the power of the shofar is what merits Israel against the nations, as this is explained everywhere in the words of our Sages, of blessed memory. And it is understood why the Zohar connects here the verse "Blessed is the people that knows the sound of the shofar," etc., for it is only through the power of the shofar that they are saved from them. "In the light of Your countenance they shall walk" to save us from the wicked waters and redeem us in the time of the ultimate redemption, and may His royal glory be revealed upon us speedily in our days, Amen. (Thus is written in my holy handwriting)
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the verse "Ashrei Ha'am Yodei Teruah" in relation to the Jewish people's reliance on divine protection during times of judgment, particularly on Rosh Hashanah. It highlights the gathering of nations and the adversary, Satan, who seek to accuse Israel, emphasizing that the power of the shofar (teruah) serves as a merit for the Jewish people against these forces. The text connects the shofar's power to the hope for redemption from oppression and the ultimate revelation of God's sovereignty in the world. The passage concludes with a prayer for swift redemption and the manifestation of divine glory.

passage_content: באופןאחר יתבארו דקדוקים הנ"ל בהעיר עוד על מ"ש בזוה"ק (דף ל"ד ע"א) בא אל פרעה לך אל פרעה מבעי' לי' מאי בא, אלא דעייל לי' קוב"ה אדרין בתר אדרין, (פי' חדרים לפנים מחדרים) וכו' דחמא קוב"ה דדחיל משה וכו' וצ"ב מ"ט נתגדל יראתו של משרע"ה במכת הארבה יותר מבאחרינא, עוד איתא בזוה"ק (ר"פ בא) בא אל פרעה וגו' ר"י פתח ואמר אשרי העם יודעי תרועה ד' באור פניך יהלכון. והאריך בזוה"ק לבאר דכד לא אשתכחו עובדין דישראל כדקא יאות, מתכנשין הרבה מקטריגין לעילא לקטרגא עליהון, והבוי"ת מצילם מקטרוגם, ועד"ז פי' בהגהות מהרח"ו ז"ל לבאר סמיכות הפסוק אשרי העם יודעי תרועה לפ' הארבה, כי משה צפה שהשטן מקטרג על יציאת ישראל ממצרים, וזה הי' בר"ה, ומסיבת זה לא הי' משה רוצה ליכנס לפרעה, ואמר השם אל משה בא אל פרעה ואל תפחד מקטרוג השטן וכו', וכל זה צ"ב מדוע נתיירא משרע"ה מן הקטרוג במכת הארבה דייקא, ומדוע נתעוררו המקטריגים במכה זו יותר מבאחריני.
translation: In another manner, the aforementioned nuances will be clarified by noting what is stated in the Zohar (page 34a): "Come to Pharaoh, go to Pharaoh" – it is necessary to ask what "come" means, rather, it is that the Holy One, blessed be He, brings him in chambers after chambers (meaning rooms within rooms), etc., for the Holy One, blessed be He, is afraid of Moses, etc. And it is to be questioned why the fear of Moses was heightened during the plague of locusts more than in other plagues. Furthermore, it is stated in the Zohar (Parashat Bo) "Come to Pharaoh," etc. Rabbi Yitzchak opened and said, "Blessed is the people that know the sound of the shofar; they walk, O Lord, in the light of Your countenance." The Zohar elaborates that when the deeds of Israel are not found as they should be, many accusers gather above to accuse them, and the Blessed One saves them from their accusations. Similarly, it is explained in the glosses of the Mahari"ch, may his memory be blessed, to clarify the connection of the verse "Blessed is the people that know the sound of the shofar" to the section of the locusts, for Moses foresaw that the Satan would accuse regarding the departure of Israel from Egypt, and this was on Rosh Hashanah. Because of this, Moses did not want to enter to Pharaoh, and the Lord said to Moses, "Come to Pharaoh and do not be afraid of the accusations of the Satan," etc. All this raises the question of why Moses was specifically afraid of the accusations during the plague of locusts, and why the accusers were aroused during this plague more than in others.
summary: The passage discusses the deeper meanings behind the biblical narrative of Moses confronting Pharaoh, particularly in relation to the Zohar's insights on divine judgment and the role of fear in spiritual leadership. It highlights that during the plague of locusts, Moses was particularly apprehensive due to the intensified accusations from the heavenly accusers against the Israelites. The text emphasizes the connection between the people's spiritual state and the challenges they face, illustrating that when the Israelites fail to uphold their spiritual duties, they become targets for heavenly criticism. Ultimately, it reflects on the necessity of divine protection and the importance of faith in overcoming spiritual adversities.

passage_content: ואפ"לעפי"ד התרגום יוב"ע (שהבאנו לעיל) עה"פ (יואל ב' כ"ה) ושלמתי לכם את השנים אשר אכל הארבה הילק והחסיל והגזם חילי הגדול אשר שלחתי בכם, פי' ביוב"ע ואשלם לכון שניא טבתא חלף שניא דבזו יתכון פלחי כוכביא אומיא ולישניא ושלטוניא ומלכותא פורענית חילי רבא דשלחית בכון עכ"ל, הרי שמפרש ארבה ילק חסיל והגזם שבקרא על אומה"ע שהצירו לישראל בימי גלותם, והרד"ק כתב ויונתן תרגם הפסוק הזה דרך משל, נראה כי דעתו שהוא נבואה עתידה לימות המשיח שתרגם ואשלם לכון שניא טבתא וכו' עכ"ל, אמנם צ"ב שמוציא הכתוב מפשוטו לגמרי, ופשטות הכתוב מיירי שבאו על ישראל ארבה ילק חסיל וגזם בימי יואל, וכללא אית לן דאין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו לעולם, וכבר ביארנו בזה בדרוש הקדום, וכעת נבארהו בתוס' נופך ובאופן אחר, בהקדם מ"ש השלה"ק (ח"א דף י"ט בשער בית אחרון) וז"ל כל מה שיש בגשמיות הוא התפשטות והשתלשלות השפע מלמעלה, וע"כ נקרא לשוננו לשון הקודש, כי כל השמות והתיבות הם למעלה בשרשם במקום קדוש עליון, ואח"כ כשיורד ומשתלשל בעוה"ז נקרא בשמו העליון על דרך השאלה וכל מה שאנו קורין דבר בשמו, אין זה שמו העצם אלא מושאל, ועצם השם הוא למעלה בקדושה עיי"ש שהאריך בביאור הענין (הו"ד לעיל פ' ויגש עמוד תט"ז).
translation: And according to the translation of the Yov"ah (which we brought above) on the verse (Joel 2:25) "And I will restore to you the years that the locust has eaten, the cankerworm, and the caterpillar, and the palmerworm, my great army which I sent among you," the explanation in Yov"ah is "And I will repay you for the years that the idol-worshippers have taken from you, the years of your servitude to the nations and their dominion and the oppressive rule of the great army that I sent upon you." Thus, it is explained that the locust, cankerworm, caterpillar, and palmerworm in the verse refer to the nations that oppressed Israel during their exile. The Radak wrote, and Yonatan translated this verse as a metaphor, indicating that he believes it is a prophecy for the future days of the Messiah, as he translated "And I will repay you for the years of servitude," etc. However, it is questionable that he completely removes the verse from its simple meaning, as the simple meaning of the verse refers to the locust, cankerworm, caterpillar, and palmerworm that came upon Israel in the days of Joel. And there is a general principle that a verse never departs from its simple meaning. We have already explained this in the earlier discourse, and now we will clarify it with an additional nuance and in a different manner, by first mentioning what the Shelah HaKadosh (Part 1, page 19 in the Gate of the Last House) wrote: "All that exists in the physical realm is an expansion and unfolding of the flow from above. Therefore, our language is called the Holy Tongue, for all names and terms are above in their root in a holy, exalted place, and afterwards, when it descends and unfolds in this world, it is called by its higher name in a borrowed manner. And everything we call a thing by its name is not its essence but borrowed; the essence of the name is above in holiness." Thus he elaborated on the matter (as cited above in Parashat Vayigash, page 416).
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of the biblical verse from Joel regarding the locusts as a metaphor for nations that oppressed Israel during their exile. It emphasizes that the physical manifestations in the world are reflections of spiritual realities, with names and terms in Hebrew representing higher, sacred concepts. The text highlights the idea that all material experiences are a result of divine influence descending from a higher spiritual source, reinforcing the connection between the physical and the spiritual realms in Hasidic thought.
