passage_content: ומעתהנחזור לענינינו לפרש משאה"כ למען שתי אותותי אלה וגו' עפימ"ש ק"ז זלה"ה בישמח משה (פ' תשא) לפרש הפסוק כי אות היא ביני וביניכם וגו' עפי"ד השלה"ק כי ס"ר נשמות לישראל וס"ר שבתות, שי"ן אלפים בשית אלפי שני, וש' אלפים ביום שכולו שבת דהוא אלף השביעי, וכל נשמה נחצבה משבת אחד וכו', והיינו כי אות היא, דידוע דס"ר אותיות לתורה וכל נשמה יש לה אות אחת, ויובן מזה שכל שבת נחצב ג"כ מאות אחת, וא"כ כל שבת ושבת הוא ממש איזה אות בתורה, כל שבת אות אחר וזה שאמר כי אות היא עכ"ל, ולהלן בפסוק אות הוא לעולם האריך עוד יותר להסביר הדברים, דמיום שנברא העולם כל שבת ושבת מתייחס לאות אחר מהתוה"ק ולנשמה אחרת המתייחסת לאותו השבת ולאותו האות מהתוה"ק יעיי"ש, וכתב באוהחה"ק (פ' בראשית) עה"כ כי בו שבת וגו' שמיום ברא אלקים אדם על הארץ לא חסר מעולם דבר המעמיד צדיק יסוד עולם שהוא שומר שבת, ולולא זאת לא הי' אפשרות לעולם לעמוד ואפי' במצרים היו שומרי שבתות יעיי"ש.
translation: And now let us return to our matter to explain the verse "for the sake of these two signs" etc., according to what is stated in Tehillim 90:15, as it is written "Moses rejoiced" (Parashat Tisa) to explain the verse "for it is a sign between Me and you" etc., according to the explanation of the Shelah HaKadosh that there are 600,000 souls for Israel and 600,000 Shabbatot, which is 30,000 in six thousand years, and 60,000 on the day that is entirely Shabbat, which is the seventh millennium, and each soul is hewn from one Shabbat, etc. This means that it is a sign, for it is known that there are 600,000 letters in the Torah and each soul has one letter, and it can be understood from this that each Shabbat is also hewn from one letter, and thus each Shabbat is indeed a specific letter in the Torah, each Shabbat a different letter, and this is what is meant by "for it is a sign." Furthermore, in the verse "it is a sign forever," he elaborates even more to explain the matters, that from the day the world was created, each Shabbat is related to a different letter from the Holy Torah and to another soul that is connected to that Shabbat and to that letter from the Holy Torah, see there. And he wrote in the Ohev Yisrael (Parashat Bereishit) on the verse "for in it He rested" etc., that from the day God created man on the earth, there has never been lacking in the world something that upholds the righteous, the foundation of the world, which is the one who observes Shabbat, and were it not for this, it would not be possible for the world to stand, and even in Egypt there were those who observed the Shabbat, see there.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the Jewish soul and the Sabbath, emphasizing that each soul is linked to a specific letter of the Torah, with each Sabbath representing a unique letter as well. It highlights the idea that since the creation of the world, every Sabbath corresponds to a different aspect of the Torah and a distinct soul, reinforcing the significance of observing the Sabbath as essential for the world's existence. The text also notes that the observance of the Sabbath is crucial for maintaining the spiritual foundation of the world, even in challenging circumstances like those faced in Egypt.

passage_content: וכברהבאתי שהארבה נח ושבת בשבת שלא הי' כן בשאר המכות, וא"כ ממכת הארבה נקבע להם יותר כח שמירת שבת, וכל שבת ושבת נקרא אות והוא מקושר עם אות אחת בתורה, ולכן אמר במכת הארבה למען שתי אותותי אלה, ר"ל כח השבתות הנקראים אותות וגם המה מקושרים כאו"א עם אות בתוה"ק, ואלה האותות של השבתות עם אותיות התוה"ק יהי' שימה בפיהם ובלבבם ע"י מכת הארבה שיראו כח קדושת שבת, ועפימ"ש ק"ז בישמח משה (ר"פ זו באופן ז' בסופו) בפסוק למען שתי אותותי אלה בקרבו, דיותר מתיישב הלשון אם נימא דמה שאמר בקרבו קאי על ישראל ולא על מצריים יעיי"ש בטעמו. ולפי דרכינו דקאי על השרשת קדושת שבת שפיר מתפרש בקרבו על בני ישראל, אולם אפשר לפרשו גם על המצריים, דע"י שראו בהארבה כח שמירת שבת, ראו מעלתן של ישראל שמכוונים נגד השבתות ונגד אותיות התוה"ק, ומבואר במדרש שהמצריים רצו לבטל מהם את שבת, וכשראו בהארבה כח שמירת שבת הי' זה לאות בקרבם, גם אמר ע"ז ולמען תספר וגו' וידעתם כי אני ה' כי עיקר הסיפור להשריש ידיעה זו שאני ה' וזה תלוי בשמירת שבת, דמה"ט שבת חמורה כ"כ יען שהשבת מעיד על האמונה שהקב"ה ברא העולם ושבת בשביעי כנודע.
translation: And I brought that the locusts rested and observed the Sabbath, which was not the case with the other plagues. Therefore, from the plague of locusts, they were given a stronger power of Sabbath observance, and every Sabbath is called a sign, which is connected with a letter in the Torah. Thus, it is said regarding the plague of locusts, "for the sake of these two signs of Mine," meaning the power of the Sabbaths, which are called signs, and they are each connected with a letter in the Holy Torah. And these signs of the Sabbaths, along with the letters of the Holy Torah, will be placed in their mouths and in their hearts through the plague of locusts, so that they will see the power of the sanctity of the Sabbath. And as it is explained in K.Z. in "And Moses rejoiced" (in this section at the end), in the verse "for the sake of these two signs of Mine in their midst," it is more settled in the language if we say that what is said "in their midst" refers to Israel and not to Egypt, as explained there in its reasoning. According to our approach, which relates to the rooting of the sanctity of the Sabbath, it is well interpreted "in their midst" regarding the Children of Israel. However, it can also be interpreted regarding the Egyptians, that by seeing in the locusts the power of Sabbath observance, they recognized the greatness of Israel, who are aligned with the Sabbaths and the letters of the Holy Torah. It is explained in the Midrash that the Egyptians wanted to abolish the Sabbath from them, and when they saw in the locusts the power of Sabbath observance, it was a sign in their midst. It is also said regarding this, "and for the sake of telling..." and "you shall know that I am the Lord," for the essence of the telling is to instill this knowledge that I am the Lord, and this is dependent on Sabbath observance. This is why the Sabbath is so severe, because the Sabbath testifies to the faith that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world and rested on the seventh, as is known.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the plague of locusts as a means to reinforce the sanctity of Shabbat among the Israelites, highlighting that each Shabbat is associated with a specific letter in the Torah. It emphasizes that the experience of the locusts served as a reminder of the power of Shabbat, both for the Israelites and the Egyptians, who recognized the importance of Shabbat in affirming the belief in God as the Creator. The text underscores that the observance of Shabbat is crucial for instilling the knowledge of God's existence, linking it to the broader theme of faith and divine creation. Ultimately, it conveys that the observance of Shabbat is a profound testament to the belief in God's sovereignty over the world.

passage_content: ומהשאמר אשר התעללתי ופירש"י ז"ל שחקתי אפשר לפרש עפימ"ד במכילתא (בשלח פ"א סוף סי' י"ח) דרשעי ישראל מתו בשלשת ימי אפילה וקברו מתיהם בעת שהמצריים לא ראו איש את אחיו, והודו ושבחו להקב"ה שלא ראו אויביהם וששו במפלתם, הרי דאף שהמצריים כבר הכו במכות נמרצות זאח"ז, מ"מ אם ראו איזה צרה גם בישראל הי' זה להם לשמחה, ובכל המכות עד מכת הארבה לא הי' כלל בישראל, אלא במכת הארבה ראו שהי' המכה גם אצל ישראל ומזה הי' להם עכ"פ קצת שמחה, אך אח"כ כשנגאלו ישראל ונשארו כל השדות להמצריים ראו שאך בשבילם הי' כל הצרה הזאת של הארבה לא לישראל, ולזה אמר את אשר התעללתי כי בתחלה בעת שבא הארבה לשם הי' להם מזה גם שמחה ושחוק במה שראו את הארבה גם בישראל, אלא שלבסוף נתגלה שהיא שחוק מכאיב למצריים וליהודים היתה אורה.
translation: And from what I have said, that I have tormented, and Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explained that I laughed, it is possible to interpret according to the Midrash (in Beshalach, chapter 1, end of section 18) that the wicked of Israel died during the three days of darkness, and they buried their dead while the Egyptians did not see one another. And they praised and glorified the Holy One, blessed be He, that their enemies did not see them and rejoiced in their downfall. Thus, even though the Egyptians had already struck each other with fierce plagues, if they had seen any trouble among the Israelites, it would have been a cause for their joy. And in all the plagues until the plague of locusts, there was no trouble at all for Israel, but in the plague of locusts, they saw that the plague also affected Israel, and from this, at least they had some joy. However, afterwards, when Israel was redeemed and all the fields remained for the Egyptians, they saw that all this trouble of the locusts was only for them, not for Israel. Therefore, I said, "that I have tormented," for at first, when the locusts came there, they had some joy and laughter in seeing the locusts also among Israel, but in the end, it became clear that it was a painful laughter for the Egyptians, while for the Jews, it was light.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the suffering of the Egyptians during the plagues and the contrasting experience of the Israelites. He notes that even amidst their own afflictions, the Egyptians found a perverse joy in witnessing the suffering of the Israelites, particularly during the plague of locusts. However, the ultimate revelation is that the plagues served as a means of redemption for the Israelites, transforming their suffering into light, while the Egyptians faced the consequences of their actions. This highlights the Hasidic concept of divine justice and the idea that true joy and redemption can emerge from suffering.

passage_content: ולדרךהקדום שכתבתי שהי' להם ממכת הארבה אח"כ ברכה גדולה עד סוף כל הדורות, שאין הארבה מזיק כלל במצרים כמ"ש הר"ח, שפיר מיתפרש הלשון שחקתי שהי' להם מזה שמחה ושחוק, וגם יש בזה סיפור לדורותלזכור עי"ז נסי מצרים כנז"ל, גם יש להם מזה הפסד יותר על השכר אף שמצד א' הי' להם מזה ברכה שאין מזיק להם הארבה לעולם, אבל כיון שמזה יוודע לכל ישראל גבול מצרים שלא לדור שם, הרי זה להם הפסד גדול כמבואר (במד"ר (פר' כ' סי' ב') ובמכילתא ריש פ' בשלח) שפרעה צווח ווי במה שיצאו ישראל ממצרים, שכל זמן היותם שם הי' להם תועלת גדול והשפעה מרובה מן השמים עבור ישראל, והביאו שם חכז"ל במדרש הרבה משלים וטעמים על הצער וההפסד שנגרם להם על ידי יציאת ישראל משם, וכן הוא בכל הדורות שתועלת גדול למדינה שדרים שם ישראל והפסד גדול ביציאתם משם, וע"כ הי' מזה למצרים שחוק וגם הפסד יותר על השכר כנ"ל ומיושב בזה לשון הקרא.
translation: And according to the earlier path I wrote, that they had from the plague of locusts afterwards a great blessing until the end of all generations, for the locust does not harm at all in Egypt, as the Rach explains, it is well understood that the language "I laughed" refers to the joy and laughter they had from this. There is also a story for generations to remember through this the miracles of Egypt, and they also have from this a greater loss than gain, even though on one hand they had from this a blessing that the locust does not harm them at all. However, since from this it will be known to all Israel the boundary of Egypt not to dwell there, this is a great loss for them, as is explained (in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Ki Tisa, Section 2) and in Mechilta at the beginning of Parashat Beshalach) that Pharaoh cried out woe at the fact that Israel left Egypt, for as long as they were there, they had great benefit and abundant influence from the heavens for Israel. And there, our sages brought in the Midrash many parables and reasons for the suffering and loss that was caused to them by the departure of Israel from there. And so it is in all generations that there is great benefit to the state where Israel dwells and a great loss in their departure from there. Therefore, there was for Egypt laughter and also a greater loss than gain, as mentioned above, and this clarifies the language of the verse.
summary: The passage discusses the paradoxical relationship between the plagues in Egypt, particularly the locusts, and the subsequent blessings for the Israelites. It highlights that while the locusts did not harm the Egyptians, they served as a reminder of the miracles of the Exodus, leading to joy and laughter for the Israelites. However, the text also notes that the departure of the Israelites from Egypt resulted in a significant loss for the Egyptians, as their presence brought divine favor and benefits. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the interconnectedness of suffering and redemption, emphasizing the dual nature of blessings and losses in the divine plan.

passage_content: עודיש לפרש לשון למען שתי אותותי וגו', כי הכבדת הלב הנאמר במכת הארבה, קאי על הכבדת הלב שהי' לו אחר מכת הארבה, כי במכת הארבה התוודה על חטאתו ואמר שא נא חטאתי אך הפעם, ולולא הכבדת הלב שהי' לו אח"כ, הי' שולח את בני ישראל תיכף אחר מכת הארבה, ולא הי' מקום אח"כ למכת החושך. אבל החושך הוכרח להיות משני הטעמים שהביא רש"י ז"ל, והנה החושך הי' ביום ובלילה ונלקה עבורם אור שני המאורות החמה והלבנה, ובבריאת המאורות (בפ' בראשית) כתב רש"י ז"ל עה"כ והיו לאותות כשהמאורות לוקין סימן רע הוא לעולם שנאמר (ירמי' י') מאותות השמים אל תחתו וגו' בעשותכם רצון הקב"ה אין אתם צריכים לידאג מן הפורענות עכ"ל, הרי שקרא הכתוב ללקוי המאורות אותות השמים, וע"כ הוצרך לומר למען שתי אותותי וגו' בשליחות מכת הארבה, דאף שיביא עליהם הארבה שעי"ז יתוודה ויאמר שא נא חטאתי אך הפעם, מ"מ יכבד עוד אח"כ לבו כדי שיביא עליו מכת החושך שיש בו הכרח, ונתן טעם להכבדת הלב למען שיתי אותותי אלה, ע"י מכת החשך שהיא לקוי שני המאורות שקראו הכתוב אותות השמים, ולכל בני ישראל הי' אור במושבותם, ולפניהם לא הי' שום לקוי אף באחד מן המאורות, ואמרו בגמרא לקוי חמה סימן רע לאוה"ע ולקוי לבנה סימן רע לשונאי ישראל, אבל בכאן הי' למצרים כל האותות של שני המאורות לרע, ולישראל היו כל האותות לטובה שהכל הי' מאיר לפניהם בתוספות אורה. (ע"כ מכתי"ק).
translation: It is further explained regarding the phrase "for the sake of My signs" etc., that the hardening of the heart mentioned in the plague of locusts refers to the hardening of the heart that he had after the plague of locusts, for during the plague of locusts he confessed his sin and said, "I have sinned this time," but had it not been for the hardening of his heart afterwards, he would have sent the Children of Israel immediately after the plague of locusts, and there would have been no room afterwards for the plague of darkness. However, darkness was necessary for the two reasons that Rashi brings down. And behold, the darkness was both by day and by night, and the two luminaries, the sun and the moon, were struck because of them. And in the creation of the luminaries (in the chapter of Genesis), Rashi writes on the verse "and they shall be for signs" that when the luminaries are struck, it is a bad sign for the world, as it is said (Jeremiah 10) "Do not be dismayed by the signs of heaven" etc. When you do the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, you do not need to worry about calamity. Thus, the scripture calls the stricken luminaries "signs of heaven," and therefore it was necessary to say "for the sake of My signs" etc. in the context of the plague of locusts, for even though the locusts would come upon them, causing him to confess and say, "I have sinned this time," nevertheless, his heart would still be hardened afterwards so that the plague of darkness would come upon him, which was necessary. And he gave a reason for the hardening of the heart "for the sake of My signs," through the plague of darkness, which is the striking of the two luminaries that the scripture called "signs of heaven." And for all the Children of Israel, there was light in their dwellings, and before them, there was no striking of any of the luminaries. And it is said in the Gemara that the striking of the sun is a bad sign for the nations of the world, and the striking of the moon is a bad sign for the enemies of Israel. But here, for the Egyptians, all the signs of the two luminaries were for evil, while for Israel, all the signs were for good, as everything shone before them with added light.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "hardening of the heart" in relation to Pharaoh's response to the plague of locusts, emphasizing that despite his initial confession of sin, his heart was hardened afterward, leading to the subsequent plague of darkness. This darkness served as a sign, as the sun and moon were afflicted, symbolizing divine judgment, while the Israelites experienced light in their dwellings, illustrating the distinction between the fate of the Egyptians and the favor shown to the Israelites. The text highlights the idea that divine signs can serve both as warnings and as affirmations of faith, with the righteous receiving illumination amidst darkness. Ultimately, it underscores the theological principle that adherence to God's will protects one from calamity.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר מ"ש הכתוב ולכל בני ישראל הי' אור במושבותם, ולכאורה הי"ל לומר דבר והיפוכו, ויהי חשך ואפלה בכל ארץ מצרים ובארץ גושן לא הי' חשך, וכמ"ש במכת הברד רק בארץ גושן וגו' לא הי' ברד וכן בערוב, ומדוע הוסיף להודיע הוית האור וסגי בהודעת העדר החשך לבד, ויתבאר לדרכנו הנ"ל כי לקוי המאורות סימן רע לשונאי ישראל, ולמצרים היו האותות של שני המאורות מורים לרע אבל לישראל היו מורים אותות אלו לטובה, ולזה דייק לומר ולכל בנ"י הי' אור וגו', דלא רק שניצולו מן המכה כמו בברד ואחריני, אבל עוד ניתוסף להם השפעת אורה.
translation: And in this it is explained what the verse means, "And for all the children of Israel there was light in their dwellings." At first glance, it could have been said the opposite, that there was darkness and gloom throughout the land of Egypt, but in the land of Goshen there was no darkness, as it is stated regarding the plague of hail, "only in the land of Goshen... there was no hail," and similarly with the plague of the wild beasts. And why did it add to inform us of the existence of light and not just the absence of darkness? It can be explained according to our earlier path that the celestial bodies are a bad sign for the enemies of Israel, and for the Egyptians, the signs of the two luminaries indicated evil, but for Israel, these signs indicated goodness. Therefore, it is precise to say, "And for all the children of Israel there was light," not only that they were saved from the plague as with the hail and others, but they were also granted an additional influence of light.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between the experiences of the Egyptians and the Israelites during the plagues, particularly the darkness in Egypt contrasted with the light in Goshen. It emphasizes that while the signs of the celestial bodies were ominous for the Egyptians, they served as a source of blessing and illumination for the Israelites. This highlights a key Hasidic concept that divine providence manifests differently based on one's relationship with God, where the same events can signify judgment for some and grace for others. Ultimately, the text underscores the idea that the Israelites not only escaped the plagues but were also endowed with an additional spiritual light.

passage_content: עודאפ"ל ברמז הפסוק דהנה מלת במושבותם מיותר ויספיק שיאמר ולכל בנ"י הי' אור, ואפ"ל עפימ"ש בדברנו (פ' נח קמ"ה.) דמכת החשך הי' נסיון גדול לישראל, שהיו המצרים כולם ככפותים עומד לא יכול לישב וכו', והי' ביכולתם של ישראל לצאת מארצם באין מפריע, אבל עמדו בנסיונם ולא עברו השבועה שהשביעם יע"א ויוסף שלא יצאו עד שיבוא גואל אמיתי בסימן של פקודה כפולה, ועי"ז זכו לגאולה ויצאו מאפילה לאור גדול ונשפע עליהם הארת הקדושה ונתעלו לרום המעלות כנודע, וזה ירמוז הכתוב שע"י מכת החשך זכו ישראל לאור גדול, ולכל בני ישראל הי' אור במושבותם, על כי נתעכבו במושבותם ולא יצאו ברשות עצמם.
translation: Furthermore, it can be said in allusion to the verse that behold, the word "in their dwellings" is superfluous, and it would suffice to say "and for all the children of Israel there was light." And it can be said according to what we discussed (Parashat Noach, 145) that the plague of darkness was a great trial for Israel, as all the Egyptians were like bound ones, unable to sit, etc. And it was within the power of the Israelites to leave their land without hindrance, but they stood firm in their trial and did not transgress the oath that he (may his memory be blessed) and Joseph swore to them, that they would not leave until a true redeemer would come with a sign of a double command. And through this, they merited redemption and went from darkness to great light, and the light of holiness shone upon them, and they were elevated to great heights, as is known. This is hinted at in the verse that through the plague of darkness, the Israelites merited great light, and for all the children of Israel there was light in their dwellings, because they delayed in their dwellings and did not leave on their own accord.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the plague of darkness served as a significant test for the Israelites, who had the opportunity to leave Egypt but chose to remain in their places, adhering to the oath made to Joseph. Their patience and faithfulness in waiting for the true Redeemer led to their eventual redemption, transforming their experience of darkness into a profound light. This reflects the Hasidic concept that enduring trials with faith can lead to spiritual elevation and divine illumination. Ultimately, the darkness became a catalyst for the Israelites to receive a greater spiritual light in their dwellings.

passage_content: ויאמרה' אל משה בא אל פרעה כי אני הכבדתי את לבו ואת לב עבדיו למען שיתי אותותיאלה בקרבו, צ"ב נתינת טעם זה כי אני הכבדתי את לבו, דלכאורה אדרבה ה"ז נתינת טעם למנוע ביאתו, גם אותותי אלה צ"ב דתיבת אלה מיותר, ולעיל אמר למען רבות מופתי ולא אמר אלה.
translation: And Hashem said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart and the heart of his servants, in order that I may place My signs among them." There is a question regarding this reason, "for I have hardened his heart," as it seems, on the contrary, that this is a reason to prevent his coming. Also, regarding "My signs," there is a question about the word "these," as it is superfluous; previously it was said "in order to multiply My signs," and it did not say "these."
summary: In this passage, the author explores the divine intention behind hardening Pharaoh's heart, suggesting that it serves to manifest God's signs and wonders more profoundly within him. The phrase "אותותי אלה" is examined for its significance, indicating that the specific mention of "אלה" emphasizes the unique nature of these signs. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of divine providence, where even seemingly negative actions are ultimately directed towards a greater purpose in revealing God's glory. The inquiry into the rationale behind God's actions highlights the complexity of divine justice and mercy in the unfolding of redemption.

passage_content: ב)הקשו המפורשים מנין ידע מרע"ה מכת הארבה ולא מצינו שאמר לו ה' מכת הארבה, ובבעה"ת תירצו שהיו חקוקות על המטה דצ"ך עד"ש באח"ב, אמנם הקשו דא"כ במכות אחרונות אמאי הוצרך להודיעו, ותירצו דהבין משה מדא"ל הקב"ה ולמען תספר, ודרך הוא לספר על מכת הארבה וכו', והרמב"ן ז"ל הביא כן מדברי המד"ר (פ' י"ג סי' ד') ולמען תספר באזני בנך וגו' זו מכת הארבה כמה דתימר (יואל א') עלי' לבניכם ספרו ובניכם לבניהם וגו' אמנם גם תירוץ זה צ"ב דאם ממה שהשיג העתידות בנבואה דיואל ידע, א"כ אצ"ל מפני שדרך לספר על מכת הארבה, ויותר יתכן לומר בפשטות שראה התורה כמו שהוא כתובה ומשם ידע מכת ארבה.
translation: B) The commentators asked how did Moshe Rabbeinu know about the plague of locusts, and we do not find that Hashem told him about the plague of locusts. In the Ba'al HaTurim, they answered that they were inscribed on the staff of "Dtzach, Adash, Be'achav." However, they questioned that if so, why did he need to be informed about the last plagues? They answered that Moshe understood from what the Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "and so that you may tell," and it is customary to recount the plague of locusts, etc. The Ramban, of blessed memory, brought this from the words of the Midrash (Parashat Yitro, section 4), "and so that you may tell in the ears of your son," etc., this refers to the plague of locusts, as it is stated (Joel 1) "Tell your children about it, and let your children tell their children," etc. However, this answer is also questionable, for if he knew the future through the prophecy of Joel, then it is unnecessary to say that it is customary to recount the plague of locusts. It is more plausible to simply say that he saw the Torah as it is written, and from there he knew about the plague of locusts.
summary: The passage discusses the question of how Moses knew about the plague of locusts, given that God did not explicitly inform him of it. It suggests that the plagues were inscribed on the staff, yet raises the issue of why God needed to inform Moses about the later plagues. The text emphasizes the importance of storytelling in passing down the knowledge of these events, as indicated by the verse from Joel, which highlights the generational transmission of divine experiences. Ultimately, it suggests that Moses may have seen the Torah as it was written, gaining insight into the future plagues from that understanding.

passage_content: ד)(פר' י"ג סי' ב') כי אני הכבדתי את לבו הה"ד (דברים ל"ב) אמרתי אפאיהם אמרתי באף שהכעיסו לפני אי' הם, לא יהיו אלא אשביתם מאנוש זכרם, ומי גרם להם שיצאו משם לולי כעס אויב עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב קישור דרשא זו למכת הארבה דייקא.
translation: (Section 13, Chapter 2) For I have hardened his heart, as it is written (Deuteronomy 32), "I said, I will hide My face from them," I said in anger because they provoked Me, they will not be but I will obliterate their memory from man. And who caused them to leave there if not the anger of the enemy? Thus concludes the Midrash, and it is necessary to clarify the connection of this teaching specifically to the plague of locusts.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine hardening of Pharaoh's heart, emphasizing that it was a response to the Israelites' provocations, which ultimately led to their destruction. It highlights the theological idea that human actions can provoke divine reactions, illustrating the interplay between free will and divine intervention. The reference to the locust plague serves as a specific example of this dynamic, suggesting that the consequences of angering God can lead to severe repercussions. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of understanding the relationship between human behavior and divine will.

passage_content: ה)נשאר ארבה א' בכל גבול מצרים, כתב רבינו חננאל מעת עתירת מרע"ה ועד עכשיו אין ארבה מפסיד בכל גבול מצרים, ואם יפול בא"י ויכנס בגבול מצרים אינו אוכל מיבול הארץ כלום וכו', ופי' בזה הכלי יקר דע"כ כתיב בארבה דייקא למען תספר באזני בנך וגו' ולא בשאר המכות, כי רק מזה נשאר זכר לדורות משא"כ שאר המכותיעיי"ש, אולם הא גופא טעמא בעי מדוע במכת הארבה דייקא היתה הסרת המכה נצחי וקיום לדורות משא"כ בשאר המכות.
translation: 5) The locusts remained in the entire border of Egypt, wrote our teacher Chananel, from the time of the plea of Moshe Rabbeinu until now, locusts do not cause loss in the entire border of Egypt, and if they fall in Eretz Yisrael and enter the border of Egypt, they do not eat from the produce of the land at all, etc. The Kli Yakar explains that this is why it is specifically written about the locusts, so that you may tell in the ears of your son, etc., and not about the other plagues, for only this has a remembrance for generations, unlike the other plagues, see there. However, this itself requires explanation: why was the removal of the plague of locusts specifically eternal and a lasting existence for generations, unlike the other plagues?
summary: The passage discusses the enduring impact of the plague of locusts in Egypt, as noted by Rabbi Chananel, emphasizing that this plague serves as a lasting reminder for future generations. The text highlights that unlike other plagues, the locusts' removal was permanent, symbolizing a unique divine intervention. The mention of locusts specifically in the context of teaching future generations underscores the importance of memory and continuity in Jewish tradition. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of recognizing the divine presence in historical events and their implications for spiritual growth and education.

passage_content: ו)בא אל פרעה בא גימטריא ג', רמז לו ג' מכות שיביא עוד עליו, ראוי להבין מדוע במכת הארבה דייקא רמז לו כן, וכמו"כ הי"ל לרמז במכה החמישית שעוד חמש מכות יביא עליו, ועפ"י סודן של דברים יש בזה טעם נכון. כי נודע שהעשר מכות הם נגד הי' ספירות מתתא לעילא, וג' האחרונות נגד ג' ספירות הראשונות כדאי' בספה"ק, לכן אלו דייקא נפרעו בפ"ע אולם עפ"י פשוטן של דברים צ"ב.
translation: And) when he came to Pharaoh, the gematria is 3, hinting to him about the 3 plagues that would come upon him. It is fitting to understand why specifically in the plague of locusts he hinted to him this way, and likewise, he should have hinted in the fifth plague that five more plagues would come upon him. According to the secret of the matter, there is a valid reason for this. For it is known that the ten plagues correspond to the ten sefirot from below to above, and the last three correspond to the first three sefirot as stated in the holy books. Therefore, these specifically were exacted upon him individually; however, according to the simple meaning of the words, it is puzzling.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "בא אל פרעה," which has a gematria value of three, hinting at the three plagues yet to come. It questions why this specific reference is made to the locust plague rather than the fifth plague, suggesting a deeper connection to the ten plagues corresponding to the ten sefirot. The last three plagues are particularly emphasized as they relate to the higher three sefirot, indicating a distinct spiritual dimension to the plagues' unfolding. This reflects a Hasidic understanding of divine justice and the interplay between the spiritual and physical realms.

passage_content: ז)במכת ברד כתיב כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפותי אל לבך, פרש"י ז"ל למדנו שמכת בכורות שקולה כנגד כל המכות, ותמהו המפורשים מה ענין התראת מכת בכורות אצל מכת ברד, גם דקדקו מ"ש כי בפעם הזאת מה בא למעט בזה, גם אל לבך צ"ב.
translation: In the plague of hail it is written, "For this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart." Rashi, of blessed memory, teaches us that the plague of the firstborn is equivalent to all the plagues. The commentators wonder what the connection is between the warning of the plague of the firstborn and the plague of hail. They also scrutinize the phrase "For this time" to understand what it is coming to exclude, and the term "upon your heart" is also a question.
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the verse regarding the plague of hail, emphasizing that the plague of the firstborn is considered equivalent to all the plagues. This raises questions about the connection between the warning of the firstborn plague and the hail, as well as the significance of the phrase "this time" and the expression "to your heart." The discussion highlights the Hasidic concept of divine communication and the inner spiritual implications of the plagues, suggesting a deeper understanding of God's intentions and the need for introspection in the face of divine judgment.

passage_content: ח)כל ענין מכת הארבה יפלא, דהרי את הכל הכה הברד, ורק החטה והכסמת לא נכו כי אפילות הנה, ודרז"ל (תנחומא וארא סי' ט"ז) פלאי פלאות נעשו להם שלא נכו וזה אשר נשאר לארבה, וצ"ב מדוע הי' צורך לנס שאח"כ יאכל אותם הארבה, ולא עביד קוב"ה ניסא למגנא.
translation: All matters regarding the plague of locusts are wondrous, for the hail struck everything, and only the wheat and the spelt were not harmed, for they were in the fields. And our sages of blessed memory said (Tanchuma Va'era, section 16) that wondrous wonders were done for them that they were not struck, and this is what remained for the locusts. It is puzzling why there was a need for a miracle that afterwards the locusts would eat them, and the Holy One, blessed be He, did not perform a miracle for their protection.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous nature of the locust plague, noting that while the hail destroyed much of the crops, the wheat and spelt were spared, which is seen as a wondrous act. It raises the question of why a miracle was necessary for the locusts to later consume these spared crops, suggesting a deeper divine purpose. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the hidden workings of God in the world, where even seemingly negative events can serve a greater good. Ultimately, it emphasizes the idea that God's actions, even in the face of destruction, are part of a divine plan that transcends human understanding.

passage_content: ולבארהענין נקדים מה שהבאנו לעיל כי לא מצינו רמז בכתוב שהובדלו וניצולו ישראל ממכת הארבה כמו שניצולו משאר המכות לדברי רוב המפורשים, והראב"ע ז"ל כתב בפי' ששלט הארבה בשל ישראל ומסתבר כדבריו, כי הארבה הי' בניסן סמוך ליציאתם לפי חשבונו של הרמב"ן ז"ל, ואלמלי לא שלט הארבה בתבואתן של ישראל, הי' נשאר הכל להמצריים, כי לא נעלו ישראל עמהם כלום בצאתם וגם צדה לא עשו להם וא"כ הי' הנס הזה להפליא בין מצרים לישראל למגנא ורק לטובתן של המצרים, ע"כ מסתבר בזה דברי הראב"ע ז"ל, ובפרט שלא מצינו חולק על דבריו.
translation: To clarify the matter, we will precede with what we have brought above, that we do not find a hint in the scripture that Israel was separated and saved from the plague of locusts, as they were saved from the other plagues according to the words of most of the commentators. And the Ra'avad, of blessed memory, wrote in his commentary that the locusts ruled over Israel, and it is reasonable according to his words, for the locusts were in Nisan, close to their departure according to the calculation of the Ramban, of blessed memory. And had the locusts not ruled over the produce of Israel, everything would have remained with the Egyptians, for Israel did not take anything with them upon their departure, nor did they prepare provisions for themselves. Therefore, this miracle was to distinguish between Egypt and Israel for their protection, and only for the benefit of the Egyptians. Thus, the words of the Ra'avad, of blessed memory, are reasonable in this matter, especially since we do not find anyone who disagrees with his words.
summary: The passage discusses the absence of a biblical indication that the Israelites were spared from the plague of locusts, unlike the other plagues. It references the commentary of Rabbi Avraham Ibn Ezra, who suggests that the locusts affected the crops of the Israelites, implying that the miracle of their survival was particularly significant. This distinction highlights the divine protection afforded to the Israelites, emphasizing the unique relationship between God and His people during their exodus from Egypt. The text underscores the theological concept of divine intervention as a means of safeguarding the Israelites amidst their trials.

passage_content: ובזהיובן ג"כ מה שנעשו פלאי פלאות שלא נכו החטה והכסמת בברד, כי מאחר שהי' הכרח שיאכל הארבה גם תבואתן של ישראל כדי שלא להשאיר להמצריים כנ"ל, מעתה אלמלי לא נשאר במכת ברד מתבואת המצריים כלום, הי' נראהדלא עליהן בא הארבה, דהרי אין להן מה שיפסידו אצלם, ויאמרו שנשלח המכה רק לישראל בלבד ויראתם עשתה זאת, ואין זה לכבוד שמים ולכבוד ישראל, וכמ"ש רז"ל (מד"ר פ' י"ד סי' ג') בטעם מכת חושך כדי שלא יראו. המצרים שגם ישראל לוקין כמותם ויאמרו שיראתם עשתה זאת, ע"כ הי' הכרח שישאר מן הברד גם להמצריים כדי שיהי' מקום שישלוט הארבה גם אצלם, ולא יהי' כ"כ העדר כבוד שמים כשישלוט גם בשל ישראל, ובאמת מה ששלטה הארבה גם בשל ישראל הי' לטובתן, דהנה הי' קטרוג גדול על ישראל וכמ"ש רז"ל (ילקוט ראובני פ' בשלח) שטען שר של מצרים הללו עובדי ע"ז והללו וכו', וגם הם ראויים ללקות כמוני, ויתכן דמה ששלט הארבה אף בשלהן הי' כדי להשתיק הקטרוג, כי עי"ז חשבו המקטריגים שלא יזכו ישראל לגאולה, והראי' שגם הם לוקין כהמצריים, והקב"ה לבדו ידע התכלית שהוא לטובתם.
translation: And in this, it is also understood why such wondrous miracles occurred, that the wheat and the spelt were not struck by the hail, for since it was necessary for the locusts to consume the produce of Israel so as not to leave anything for the Egyptians, therefore, had there been nothing left of the Egyptian produce after the hail, it would have appeared that the locusts came only upon them, for they would have nothing to lose, and they would say that the plague was sent only to Israel, and their fear caused this. And this is not for the honor of Heaven or for the honor of Israel, as our sages have said (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Yud-Daled, Section 3) regarding the reason for the plague of darkness, so that the Egyptians would not see that Israel was suffering like them and would say that their fear caused this. Therefore, it was necessary that some of the hail remain for the Egyptians so that there would be a place for the locusts to also rule over them, and it would not be such a lack of honor for Heaven when they also ruled over Israel. And indeed, the fact that the locusts also ruled over Israel was for their benefit, for there was a great accusation against Israel, as our sages have said (Yalkut Reuven, Parashat Beshalach) that the ministering angel of Egypt claimed that these are idol worshippers and those are etc., and they too are worthy of punishment like me. And it is possible that the reason the locusts also ruled over their produce was to silence the accusation, for through this, the accusers thought that Israel would not merit redemption, and the proof was that they too were suffering like the Egyptians, and only the Holy One, blessed be He, knew the ultimate purpose, which was for their good.
summary: The passage discusses the divine wisdom behind the plagues in Egypt, particularly the hail and locusts, emphasizing that the hail spared both the Israelites' and Egyptians' crops to prevent the perception that the plagues were solely directed at Israel. This was necessary to maintain the honor of God and Israel, as it would not be fitting for the Egyptians to believe they were unaffected. The presence of the locusts among the Egyptians served to silence accusations against Israel, demonstrating that both nations faced divine judgment, ultimately leading to Israel's redemption. The text highlights the complexity of divine justice and mercy, where even apparent suffering serves a greater purpose for the benefit of the faithful.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבאר במאמה"כ אמרתי אפאיהם אשביתה מאנוש זכרם לולי כעס אויב אגור פן ינכרו צרימו פן יאמרו ידינו רמה ולא ה' פעל כל זאת, דלכאורה קשה מאוד לומר כן שהקב"ה הי' עושה כלי' ח"ו לולי כעס אויב אגור, ולא עלתה מחשבה כזאת לפניו ית', דהלא עיקר הבריאה הי' אך בשביל בנ"י, ונמצא כוונת הבריאה בטלה כמ"ש הרמב"ן הק', אמנם יל"פ עפ"י אמרם ז"ל דכשרצה יע"א לברך את בניו וראה שיש קטרוג גדול מהשטן, התחיל לקנטרן וכשראה השטן כן, אמר מעתה אין אני צריך לקטרג עוד שהרי אף הוא עצמו מקנטרן, ועי"ז חדל מלקטרג ושוב הי' יכול לברכם, נמצא דמה שאמר להם דברי קנטורין הי' לטובתן שעי"ז חדל השטן מלקטרג, ועד"ז לענינינו כי השטן מקטרג תמיד על ישראל, ולזה אומר הקב"ה אמרתי אפאיהם אשביתה מאנוש זכרם, כדי שישתתק המסטין ויחדל מלקטרג, דמאחר ששומע שהקב"ה בעצמו אומר שבמחשבתו לכלותן ח"ו, א"כ אינו צריך לקטרג יותר כנ"ל, ואח"כ אומר הקב"ה לולי כעס אויב אגור וגו' פן יאמרו ידנו רמה ולא ה' פעל כל זאת, א"כ מוכרח אני להצילם בשביל כבוד שמים שלא יחולל, ובע"כ שיודו לזה גם המקטריגים, אבל באמת אף מעיקרא לא היתה מחשבה זו לפניו ית' לכלות את ישראל ח"ו.
translation: And similarly, it is explained in the holy writings: I said, "Where are they? I will cause their remembrance to cease from man, were it not for the anger of the enemy; I fear lest they should become adversaries, lest they say, 'Our hand is high, and it was not the Lord who did all this.'" It seems very difficult to say that the Holy One, blessed be He, would create vessels, Heaven forbid, were it not for the anger of the enemy. Such a thought has not arisen before Him, blessed be He, for the essence of creation was solely for the sake of the Children of Israel, and thus the intent of creation would be nullified, as the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, states. However, it can be explained according to what our sages, of blessed memory, said: When the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted to bless His sons and saw that there was a great accusation from the Satan, He began to provoke him. When the Satan saw this, he said, "From now on, I no longer need to accuse, since he himself is provoking." And as a result, he ceased to accuse, and then he was able to bless them. Thus, what he said to them were words of provocation, which were for their benefit, as through this the Satan ceased to accuse. Similarly, in our matter, the Satan constantly accuses Israel. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, says, "I said, 'Where are they? I will cause their remembrance to cease from man,'" so that the accuser should be silenced and cease from accusing. Since he hears that the Holy One, blessed be He, Himself says in His thought to destroy them, Heaven forbid, then he no longer needs to accuse, as stated. And afterwards, the Holy One, blessed be He, says, "Were it not for the anger of the enemy, I fear lest they say, 'Our hand is high, and it was not the Lord who did all this,'" therefore I must save them for the sake of the honor of Heaven, so that it should not be desecrated, and consequently, even the accusers should acknowledge this. But in truth, even from the beginning, this thought was not before Him, blessed be He, to destroy Israel, Heaven forbid.
summary: The passage discusses the tension between divine intention and the accusations of the adversary (Satan) against the Jewish people. It suggests that God's declaration of potentially destroying Israel is a strategic move to silence the accuser, as the adversary would cease to argue if he hears God contemplating their demise. Ultimately, God's true intention is to protect Israel for the sake of His honor, ensuring that even the accusers acknowledge His sovereignty. The text emphasizes that the creation's purpose is centered on the Jewish people, and any notion of their destruction is contrary to God's ultimate plan.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר דברי המד"ר (הנ"ל קושיא ד') כי אני הכבדתי את לבו הה"ד אמרתי אפאיהם וכו' דהנה במכת ברד שנעשו להם פלאי פלאות בהצלת החטה והכוסמת, שמחו פרעה והמצריים ותלו נס הצלתן בכח הטומאה והכשפים, וכן במכת הארבה כשראו ששלט גם בישראל, הי"ל לשמחה שגם הם לוקין כמוהם ועי"כ הכביד לב פרעה, אמנם לבסוף נתגלה שכ"ז הי' רק לרעתן של מצרים ולטובתן של ישראל להצילם מן הקטרוג, וא"ש קישור דברי המדרש הה"ד אמרתי אפאיהם וכו' לכוונה זו להצילם מהקטרוג, לולי כעס אויב אגור ומוכרח הצלתם בעבור כבוד שמים, וכמו"כ הנסים שנעשו לפרעה וגרמו להכביד לבבו הי' ג"כ לתכלית זה לסתום פי המקטריגים
translation: And in this, the words of the Midrash are clarified (the aforementioned question D') that I have hardened his heart, as it is said, "I have said, 'They are lost,' etc." For behold, in the plague of hail, wonders upon wonders were done for them in the saving of the wheat and the barley, Pharaoh and the Egyptians rejoiced and attributed their salvation to the power of impurity and sorcery. Likewise, in the plague of locusts, when they saw that it also affected Israel, they should have rejoiced that they too were suffering like them, and thus the heart of Pharaoh was hardened. However, in the end, it was revealed that all this was only for the detriment of Egypt and for the benefit of Israel, to save them from the accuser. And this explains the connection of the words of the Midrash, as it is said, "I have said, 'They are lost,' etc." for this intention, to save them from the accusation, were it not for the anger of the enemy, I would gather and compel their salvation for the sake of the honor of Heaven. And likewise, the miracles that were done for Pharaoh, which caused his heart to be hardened, were also for this purpose, to silence the mouths of the accusers.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine providence in the context of the plagues in Egypt, emphasizing that the miracles performed for the Egyptians ultimately served to protect the Israelites from accusations. It highlights that Pharaoh's hardened heart was a result of his misinterpretation of these wonders, believing they were due to the power of impurity and sorcery. Ultimately, the text reveals that these events were orchestrated by God to ensure the honor of Heaven and to silence the accusers, demonstrating a profound interplay between divine intervention and human agency.

passage_content: ולדרכינואפ"ל במאמה"כ ראו כי רעה נגד פניכם ובת"א פי' חזו ארי בישא דאתון סבירין למעבד לקבל אפיכון לאסתחרא, ולפירושו אינו מתיישב הלשון "ראו" דהאיך בירר להם זאת בראי' מוחשית, גם מדוע אמר כן במכת הארבה דייקא, גם יל"ד במאמה"כ ויגרש אותם מאת פני פרעה, מדוע העיז פניו כ"כ במכת הארבה דייקא, ולדרכינו יתבאר דעל כי ראה שגם ישראל לוקין במכת הארבה כמוהם, גם שנעשה להם נסים בהשארת הברד,תלה כ"ז בכח הכשפים, ובא בטענה ראו כי רעה נגד פניכם, וכדברי הת"א חזו ארי בישא דאתון סבירין למעבד להביא מכות על המצריים, לקבל אפיכון לאסתחרא, המכה בעצמו סובב גם עליכם, וע"כ העיז פניו ויגרשם.
translation: And according to our way, it is explained that in the verse, "See, for evil is before you," the Targum interprets it as "Behold, it is bad for you," meaning that you are worthy of receiving plagues upon the Egyptians, to receive your punishment. The plague itself also affects you, and therefore he was bold and drove them away. The language "See" does not settle well, as how did he clarify this to them with a tangible sight? Also, why did he say this specifically regarding the plague of locusts? Additionally, it is asked in the verse, "And he drove them away from before Pharaoh," why was he so bold specifically in the plague of locusts? According to our understanding, it can be explained that he saw that Israel was also suffering from the plague of locusts like them, and that miracles were done for them with the preservation of the hail. He attributed all this to the power of sorcery, and came with the claim, "See, for evil is before you," and as the Targum states, "Behold, it is bad for you," meaning that you are worthy of bringing plagues upon the Egyptians, to receive your punishment. The plague itself also affects you, and therefore he was bold and drove them away.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores the theological implications of the plagues, particularly the plague of locusts, emphasizing that both the Egyptians and the Israelites suffered during this event. The text suggests that Pharaoh's boldness in confronting the Israelites stemmed from his belief in the power of sorcery, as he perceived the plagues as a direct challenge to his authority. The mention of miraculous protection for the Israelites amidst their suffering highlights the theme of divine intervention and the struggle between faith and the forces of evil. Ultimately, the passage reflects on the interconnectedness of suffering and redemption within the context of divine justice.

passage_content: ועפ"יהקדמות אלו יתבארו דברי רבינו חננאל זלה"ה שמעת עתירת משרע"ה ועד עכשיו אין ארבה מפסיד בכל גבול מצרים וכו', ולכאורה מדוע במכת הארבה דייקא היתה הסרת המכה נצחית וקיים לעד משא"כ בשאר המכות (עיין קושיא ה') אמנם שאר כל המכות לא שלטו כ"א על המצריים ולא בישראל כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל ורוב המפורשים, לכן כשהתפלל משרע"ה על הסרתם הסכימו לזהשרי מעלה של כל ע' האומות שרוצים בטובתן של רשעים, ע"כ הי' אפשר להיות הסרתן ע"י שליח, והנעשה ע"י שליח אינו נצחי ואפשר שיחזור לשלוט בהם מכות אלו עוה"פ, משא"כ במכת הארבה ששלטה גם בישראל, הי' התנגדות גדול מצד שרי האומות על הסרתן, ובהכרח הי' הסרת הארבה ע"י הבוי"ת ולא ע"י שליח, ופעולתו ית' נצחי וקיימת לעד, לכן מאז ועד עולם אין ארבה מפסיד בכל גבול מצרים
translation: And according to these introductions, the words of our teacher Chananel, may his memory be blessed, will be clarified: from the time of Moshe Rabbeinu's prayer until now, there is no locust that causes loss in all the borders of Egypt, etc. At first glance, one might wonder why the removal of the locust plague specifically was eternal and lasting forever, whereas this is not the case with the other plagues (see the question in the footnote). However, all the other plagues only ruled over the Egyptians and not over Israel, as the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, and most of the commentators explain. Therefore, when Moshe Rabbeinu prayed for their removal, the ministers of all seventy nations, who desire the good of the wicked, agreed to this. Thus, it was possible for their removal to be through a messenger, and what is done through a messenger is not eternal, and it is possible that these plagues could return to rule over them in the future. In contrast, with the plague of locusts, which also ruled over Israel, there was great opposition from the ministers of the nations regarding its removal. Therefore, the removal of the locusts had to be through the Blessed One Himself and not through a messenger, and His action is eternal and lasting forever. Thus, from then until eternity, there is no locust that causes loss in all the borders of Egypt.
summary: The passage discusses the unique nature of the plague of locusts in Egypt, emphasizing that its removal was a permanent act of divine intervention, unlike other plagues that were limited to the Egyptians. It highlights that while other plagues affected only the Egyptians and could be removed by intermediaries, the locust plague also impacted the Israelites, leading to significant opposition from the heavenly powers. Consequently, the removal of the locusts required direct divine action, ensuring its lasting effect and establishing that locusts would no longer harm Egypt. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine authority and the permanence of God's interventions in the world.

passage_content: ועתהנבוא לתרץ קושית המפורשים ז"ל (קושיא ב') דמנין ידע מרע"ה מכת הארבה, ולא מצינו שא"ל הקב"ה שיביא הארבה על מצרים וכן הקשו בבעה"ת, ובאמת אין זה קושיא כ"כ, שהרי אמרז"ל במד"ר (פ' ט' סי' י') שכל המכות באו על המצריים מדה כנגד מדה שהרעו וציערו לישראל, ולפי"ז יתכן שמשרע"ה מקור החכמה השיג בחכמתו איזה מכה ראוי שימדד להם כמידתם, גם בסודן של דברים השיג כל דבר בשרשו, גם השיג כל התורה טרם שניתנה ול"ק מנין ידע, אך עיקר הקושיא דא"כ כמו"כ השיג כל המכות בחכמתו, ומדוע הוצרך הקב"ה להודיעו בכולן ולא עשה כן בארבה.
translation: And now let us come to resolve the question of the commentators, of blessed memory (question 2), from where did Moshe Rabbeinu know of the plague of locusts, and we do not find that the Holy One, Blessed be He, told him to bring the locusts upon Egypt, and thus they also questioned in the Ba'al HaTurim. In truth, this is not such a question, for it is stated in the Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Va'era, section 10) that all the plagues came upon the Egyptians measure for measure, as they harmed and distressed Israel. According to this, it is possible that Moshe Rabbeinu, the source of wisdom, understood through his wisdom which plague was appropriate to measure against them according to their deeds. Also, in the secret of things, he comprehended everything in its root, and he understood the entire Torah before it was given, and it is not a question of how he knew. However, the main question is that if so, he also comprehended all the plagues through his wisdom, and why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, need to inform him of all of them, and did not do so regarding the locusts?
summary: In the passage, the author addresses a question regarding how Moses knew about the plague of locusts, given that it is not explicitly stated that God informed him of it. The text suggests that all the plagues were a measure-for-measure response to the suffering inflicted upon the Israelites by the Egyptians, implying that Moses, as a source of wisdom, could intuitively understand which plague was appropriate. Furthermore, it raises the theological insight that Moses had a profound understanding of the Torah and the underlying principles of divine justice, yet questions why God needed to inform him about the locust plague specifically, unlike the others. This reflects a deeper exploration of the relationship between divine revelation and human understanding in the context of suffering and justice.

passage_content: ואפ"לדהנה אמרז"ל שאחר ה' מכות הראשונות הכביד ה' את לב פרעה שלא ישלח את ישראל, כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל (פ' וארא) עה"פ ואני אקשה את לב פרעה עיי"ש, והרמב"ן ז"ל העתיק דברי המדרש (פ' י"ג סי' ג') א"ר יוחנן מכאן פתחון פה למינין לומר לא היתה ממנו שיעשה תשובה, א"ר שמעון ב"ל יסתם פיהם של מינין אלא אם ללצים הוא יליץ, מתרה בו פעם ראשונה ושני' ושלישית ואינו חוזר בו והוא נועל בו דלת מן התשובה כדי לפרוע ממנו מה שחטא, כך פרעה הרשע כיון ששגר הקב"ה אצלו ה' פעמים ולא השגיח על דבריו, א"ל הקב"ה וכו' הריני מוסיף לך טומאה על טומאתו וכו' עכ"ד המדרש עיי"ש, אמנם עכ"ז לא נמנע ממנו התשובה בהחלט, ואלמלי הי' דוחק עצמו ליכנס בתשובה היו מקבלין אותו עיי"ש, ויתכן שמה שניתוסף לו טומאה על טומאתו הי' רק להכביד עליו התשובה, כי לא הי' ראוי לזה לפי רוע מפעלו, אבל מ"מ לא נמנע בחירתו לגמרי, ויש דיעה בדברי המפרשים ז"ל שמה שהכביד ה' את לבו, הי' רק להחזירו אל קו המשקל, לפי שנתרכך לבבו ממכות הראשונות, והי' נמלך לשלחם מכובד המכות שנלאה לסובלו, לזה הכביד ה' לבבו שיחזור לבחירתו, (ונרמז כן בדברי הרמב"ן ז"ל עיי"ש) ומעתה אף שהשיג משרע"ה בידיעת חכמתו כל המכות, גם ידע ממה שהיו חקוקות על המעה, מ"מ לא סמך על ידיעתו להתרות המצריים עליהם, כי עדיין הי' תליא בבחירה, ואם יעשה תשובה וישלח את ישראל ימנעו ממנו, ע"כ המתין עד שהודיעו הקב"ה ונצטוה בהתראתן, דמילתא דתליא בבחירה אין בדעת האדם לדון בעתידות, ותליא במשקל ק"ל דיעות, והודיעו הקב"ה בכל מכה ומכה מתי הגיע שעתו למדוד לו כרשעתו ולא יחזור בזו עוד.
translation: And although it is said that after the first five plagues, God hardened Pharaoh's heart so that he would not send Israel away, as Rashi explains (in Parashat Va'era) regarding the verse "And I will harden Pharaoh's heart," and the Ramban quotes the words of the Midrash (in Parashat Yitro, section 3) that Rabbi Yochanan said from here is an opening for heretics to say that he had no opportunity to repent, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said that the mouths of heretics should be sealed, except if it is for scoffers, for He warns him the first time, the second time, and the third time, and he does not turn back, and He locks him out from repentance in order to exact from him what he has sinned. Thus, the wicked Pharaoh, since the Holy One, blessed be He, sent to him five times and he did not heed His words, God said to him, etc., "I will add to your impurity upon your impurity," etc., thus concludes the Midrash. However, despite this, he was not completely prevented from repentance, and had he forced himself to enter into repentance, they would have accepted him, as stated there. It is possible that the additional impurity upon his impurity was only to make repentance harder for him, for he was not worthy of this according to the evil of his deeds. Nevertheless, his choice was not entirely removed. There is an opinion among the commentators that the hardening of his heart by God was only to bring him back to the balance, since his heart had softened from the first plagues, and he was considering sending them away due to the severity of the plagues that he could no longer bear. For this reason, God hardened his heart so that he would return to his choice (and this is hinted at in the words of the Ramban, as stated there). From now on, even though he received from Moses, through the knowledge of his wisdom, all the plagues, and he knew from what was inscribed on the staff, nevertheless, he did not rely on his knowledge to warn the Egyptians about them, for it was still dependent on choice, and if he would repent and send Israel away, they would be prevented from him. Therefore, he waited until the Holy One, blessed be He, informed him and commanded him regarding their warning, for a matter that is dependent on choice cannot be judged by human intellect regarding future events, and it depends on weighing a multitude of opinions. And the Holy One, blessed be He, informed him with each plague when the time had come to measure him according to his wickedness, and he would not return to this again.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of free will in relation to Pharaoh's hardened heart after the initial plagues, emphasizing that despite God's intervention to increase Pharaoh's stubbornness, he still had the opportunity for repentance. It suggests that the additional hardness was meant to prevent him from easily returning to his previous state of compassion, thus maintaining the balance of choice. The text highlights that even with divine foreknowledge, the ultimate decision to repent remained with Pharaoh, illustrating the complex interplay between divine will and human agency in the context of redemption.

passage_content: אמנםנשתנו ג' האחרונות ארבה חושך מכת בכורות שהיו כולן הכרחיות גם בשביל תועלתן של ישראל, וכמ"ש לעיל בתועלת הארבה לסתום פי המקטריגים, ובמכת חשך אמרז"ל במד"ר (פ' י"ד סי' ג') ב' טעמים לתועלת ישראל, שלא יראו המצריים במיתתן של רשעי ישראל ויאמרו גם הם לוקין כמוני, גם מפני המטמוניות עיי"ש, ובמכת בכורים כתב ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' שמות) דעי"ז נגאלו ישראל קודם זמנם, דכל ישראל בכלל בכורים וגם הם היו בכלל הגזירה, וקיי"ל דהמציל מזוטו של ים לעצמו הציל וקנויים אנו אליו ית', ופי' בזה כל בכוריהם הרגת ועי"ז ובכורך ישראל גאלת עיי"ש, נמצא מעתה שלא הי' תלויים בבחירתו של פרעה כי היו מוכרחים בלא"ה, ובזה א"ש מה שלא הודיעו הקב"ה למשרע"ה מכת הארבה, ול"ק קושית המפרשים דמנין ידע, שהשיג כמו"כ כל המכות בחכמתו, גם ידע ממה שהיו חקוקות על המטה, אך בכולן לא סמך ע"ז לטעם הנ"ל, אבל מארבה ואילך מספיק הידיעה בלבד כי הי' מוחלט בכל אופן.
translation: Indeed, the last three plagues—locusts, darkness, and the plague of the firstborn—were all necessary for the benefit of Israel, as mentioned above regarding the benefit of the locusts to silence the accusers. And concerning the plague of darkness, our sages of blessed memory said in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Yud-Daled, section 3) that there are two reasons for its benefit to Israel: so that the Egyptians would not see the death of the wicked among Israel and say, "They too are suffering like me," and also because of the hidden treasures, as stated there. And regarding the plague of the firstborn, it is written by the holy Rabbi Moshe (in Parashat Shemot) that through this, Israel was redeemed before their time, for all of Israel is included in the firstborn, and they too were part of the decree. And we hold that one who saves even a small amount from the sea saves himself, and we are purchased to Him, blessed be He. The explanation here is that all their firstborns were killed, and through this, "and by the firstborn of Israel, You redeemed," as stated there. It follows that they were not dependent on Pharaoh's choice, for they were compelled regardless. This clarifies why the Holy One, blessed be He, did not inform Moshe of the plague of locusts, and it is not a question of the commentators regarding how he knew, for he understood all the plagues through his wisdom, and he also knew from what was inscribed on the staff. However, in all of them, he did not rely on that for the reason mentioned above, but from the locusts onward, mere knowledge was sufficient because it was determined in any case.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of the last three plagues—locusts, darkness, and the death of the firstborn—highlighting their essential role in the redemption of Israel. It emphasizes that these plagues served to protect the Israelites from the judgment of the Egyptians and to fulfill God's plan, as the Israelites were inherently part of the firstborn decree. The text suggests that God's intervention was predetermined, and thus the outcome was not dependent on Pharaoh's choices. Ultimately, it reflects on the divine wisdom and certainty in the unfolding of redemption, illustrating the profound connection between divine will and the fate of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ובזהיובן הרמז שבבעה"ט בא בגימטריא ג', רמז לו ג' מכות שיביא עוד עליו, ולא בא רמז כזה במכות הקודמין (עיין קושיא ו') ומדוע לא נרמז כמו"כ במכה ה' שעוד ה' מכות יביא עליו או באחריני, אמנם כולהו היו תלויין בבחירתו, וע"כ הודיעו ית' כאו"א באפי נפשי' כשהגיע זמנו וכנ"ל,אבל אלה היו הכרחיים שלשתן, ואין טעם למנוע הידיעה, וע"כ רמז לו כולן בפ"א במלת בא אל פרעה, ואמר לו הטעם כי אני הכבדתי את לבו ונמנע בחירתו לגמרי, למען שתי אותותי "אלה" בקרבו שהם הכרחיים, אלה פוסל את הראשונים שהיו תלויים בבחירתו, ואפשר דלטעם זה לא התרה בו על מכת חושך, על כי הי' מוכרח בלא"ה, ומה תועלת להתרותו אם לא ימנע ממנו בשום פנים. ומה שהתרה על הארבה ומכת בכורות אולי מפני שהם ענין נסיי, וכדי שיכיר בכח הנס ולא יתלה במקרה, משא"כ חשך הי' טבעי כמ"ש הרמב"ן והראב"ע ז"ל, ולצד שלא ימנע ממנו בשום פנים ע"כ לא התרהו עליו.
translation: And in this is understood the hint that in the plague of the firstborn, it came with the gematria of three, hinting to him three plagues that would come upon him further, and such a hint did not come in the previous plagues (see question 6). And why was it not hinted similarly in the fifth plague, that five more plagues would come upon him, or in others? However, all of them were dependent on his choice, and therefore He informed each one in a personal manner when his time arrived, as mentioned above. But these three were necessary, and there is no reason to withhold the knowledge, and therefore He hinted to him all of them at once in the phrase "Come to Pharaoh," and told him the reason that "I have hardened his heart" and he is completely prevented from choosing, in order to perform these signs "in him" which are necessary. These invalidate the earlier ones that were dependent on his choice, and it is possible that for this reason He did not warn him about the plague of darkness, since it was necessary anyway, and what benefit would there be in warning him if he would not be prevented in any way? And the warning about the locusts and the plague of the firstborn was perhaps because they are of a miraculous nature, so that he would recognize the power of the miracle and not attribute it to chance, whereas darkness was natural, as the Ramban and the Ra'avad, may their memory be blessed, said, and since he would not be prevented in any way, therefore He did not warn him about it.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the number three in relation to the plagues brought upon Pharaoh, indicating that these three were necessary and predetermined by God, unlike the earlier plagues which depended on Pharaoh's free will. It emphasizes that God's hardening of Pharaoh's heart removed his ability to choose, making the subsequent plagues inevitable. The text suggests that the nature of the plagues, particularly the darkness, was such that it did not warrant a warning, as it was a natural occurrence rather than a miraculous one, contrasting with the more miraculous plagues that required acknowledgment of divine intervention.

passage_content: ובזהיתבארו דברי רש"י ז"ל עה"פ כי בפעם הזאת אני שולח את כל מגפתי אל לבך, למדנו מכאן שמכת בכורות קשה מכולן, ולכאורה מה ענין התראה על מכת בכורות במכת ברד דייקא, (עיין קושיא ז') אמנם פרעה כבר ידע ממכת בכורות, שבה התרהו תחילה כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל (בפ' שמות) עה"פ הנה אנכי הורג את בנך בכורך, אלאשהכביד לבבו ולא נפחד, ואולי חשב שינצל בדרך נס, וע"כ הודיעו הקב"ה בהתראת הברד שהוא מכה האחרונה התלוי' בבחירתו, שמכאן ואילך כולם הכרחיים וננעלו בפניו דרכי התשובה, ולז"א לו כי בפעם הזאת דייקא אני שולח את כל מגפתי זו מכת בכורות הקשה מכולן, אל לבך ע"י הכבדת הלב שתהי' מוחלטת וישלול בחירתו לגמרי.
translation: And in this, the words of Rashi, may his memory be blessed, on the verse "For this time I will send all My plagues upon your heart," are clarified. We learn from here that the plague of the firstborn is the hardest of all. And seemingly, what is the connection of a warning about the plague of the firstborn specifically in the plague of hail? (See the question in Zohar.) However, Pharaoh already knew about the plague of the firstborn, for he was warned about it first, as Rashi, may his memory be blessed, explains (in Parashat Shemot) on the verse "Behold, I will kill your firstborn son." Yet he hardened his heart and did not fear, and perhaps he thought he would be saved by a miracle. Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, informed him with the warning of the hail, which is the last plague dependent on his choice, that from here on all will be necessary and the paths of repentance will be completely closed to him. And this is why it says to him, "For this time specifically I will send all My plagues," this being the plague of the firstborn, the hardest of all, to your heart, through the hardening of the heart, which will be absolute and will completely negate his choice.
summary: The passage discusses the severity of the plague of the firstborn, emphasizing that it is the hardest of all plagues. It highlights that Pharaoh was warned about this plague, yet he hardened his heart and did not fear, possibly hoping for a miraculous escape. The warning of the hail plague serves as a final opportunity for Pharaoh to choose repentance, but after this, his choices become constrained, leading to the inevitable consequence of the firstborn's death. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of divine justice and the interplay between free will and predestination.

passage_content: באופןאחר אפ"ל קושית המפרשים הנ"ל, דמנין ידע משרע"ה מכת הארבה, ועל תירוצם של בעה"ת שידע ממה שראה חקוקות על המטה דצ"ך עד"ש באח"ב, הקשו הם עצמם דא"כ כמו"כ באחריני ראה וידע ומ"ט הוצרך הקב"ה להודיעו בכאו"א ולא עשה כן בארבה, ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הרב חיד"א זלה"ה (בשמחת הרגל על הגש"פ) ד"ה ריה"ג אומר וכו' שהביא דברי מהר"ש פרימו ז"ל (ברמזיו סדר שמות) בטעם ד' גאולות, דישראל יש להם דין עבד עברי, והמצריים חבלו בהם ונעשו בעלי מומין חגרים ופסחים וסומין וכיוצא, מחמת שנתאכזרו עליהם לשעבדם שעבוד קשה מר ממות וכו', וא"כ השתא שחבלו בעבד עברי, דינא היא דחייבים בד' דברים בשת צער רפוי נזק ולכן הם ד' גאולות זת"ד ז"ל, ועפי"ז יל"פ פסוק ויאמר ד' אל משה ואל אהרן באמ"צ לאמר החדש הזה לכם ראש חדשים, ויש לחקור מה טעם זו המצוה של קידוש החדש היתה לראש פנה, והוא מצוה הראשונה, בזמן שנשתעבדו ישראל לעבוד את ה', ואפשר דזה צורך גדול שיהיו משה ואהרן סמוכים לקנוס המצריים במה שחבלו בישראל, וחייבין בשת צער רפוי ונזק דבעינן סמוכים וכו', וז"ש החדש הזה לכם וגו' לכם שאתם סמוכים תקדשו החדש וכו', וזה עיקר גדול וכו' להסמיך למשה ולאהרן שיוכלו לדון דיני קנסות במצרים וכו' עכ"ד החיד"א זלה"ה.
translation: In another way, one could say the question of the aforementioned commentators, how did Moshe Rabbeinu know about the plague of locusts? And regarding their answer that he knew from what was inscribed on the staff of "C" (צ) "K" (כ) "D" (ד) "A" (א) "S" (ש) "B" (ב) "A" (א) "C" (ג) "H" (ח), they themselves asked, if so, why did he not see and know about other plagues, and why did the Holy One, blessed be He, need to inform him about each one, and did not do so regarding the locusts? It will be clarified by first bringing the words of Rabbi Chida, may his memory be blessed (in the joy of the festival on the last day of Passover), where he says that Rabbi Yochanan said, etc., who brought the words of Maharash Primo, may his memory be blessed (in his hints regarding the order of names) about the reason for the four redemptions, that Israel has the status of a Hebrew servant, and the Egyptians harmed them and became maimed, lame, blind, and the like, because they were cruel to them, enslaving them with a hard servitude worse than death, etc. Therefore, now that they harmed the Hebrew servant, it is a law that they are liable for four things: pain, suffering, healing, and damage, and thus they are the four redemptions, as he said. According to this, one can explain the verse, "And the Lord said to Moshe and to Aharon in the land of Egypt, saying, 'This month shall be to you the head of months.'" And one must investigate what the reason for this commandment of sanctifying the new month was at the beginning, and it is the first commandment at the time when Israel was enslaved to serve the Lord. It is possible that this was a great necessity for Moshe and Aharon to be close to impose penalties on the Egyptians for harming Israel, and they are liable for pain, suffering, healing, and damage, as we need them to be close, etc. Therefore, it says, "This month shall be to you," etc., to you who are close, you shall sanctify the month, etc. This is a great principle, etc., to empower Moshe and Aharon so that they can adjudicate the laws of penalties in Egypt, etc. Thus said Rabbi Chida, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the theological implications of Moses' knowledge of the plague of locusts, questioning why God needed to inform him when he could have learned from the signs on his staff. It references the concept of the four redemptions of Israel, linking their suffering as "Hebrew slaves" to the divine obligation for the Egyptians to compensate for their inflicted pain. The text emphasizes the importance of Moses and Aaron being empowered to impose penalties on the Egyptians for their cruelty, highlighting the significance of the commandment to sanctify the new month as a foundational act of justice and divine retribution.

passage_content: ולכאורהדבה"ק צ"ב, דהרי פרשת החדש נאמרה בר"ח ניסן כמ"ש רז"ל (מד"ר פ' ט"ו סי' ר"ד) הראהו לבנה בחידושה, ולפי"ד הרמב"ן ז"ל הי' מכת הארבה בתחלת ניסן, א"כ תינח בג' מכות אחרונות ממכת ארבה ואילך דנו משה ואהרן בהם דיני קנסות, אבל עדיין טעמא בעו בז' הראשונות איך נעשו משה ואהרן שלוחים לדון דיני קנסות במצריים ועדיין לא היו סמוכים באותה שעה, ואפשר דקושיא א' מתורצת בחיק חבירתא במ"ש בעה"ת שידע משרע"ה מכת הארבה ממה שראהו חקוק על המעה דצ"ך עד"ש באח"ב, א"כ כמו"כ באחריני ידע ומ"ל הוצרך הקב"ה להודיעו ולצוותו בכל מכה ומכה, ואפשר דבז' הראשונות אף שידעו וראו אותן חקוקות על המטה, לא יכלו משה ואהרן לדון דיני קנסות בעצמם, דעדיין לא היו סמוכים עד ר"ח ניסן ע"כ הוצרך הקב"ה לצוותם בכאו"א ולעשות אותם שלוחים, משא"כ במכת הארבה שהי' אחר ר"ח וכבר היו סמוכים באותה שעה לא הוצרך הקב"ה לצוותן, וא"ש תירוצם של בעה"ת שידעו ממה שראו חקוקות על המטה דצ"ך עד"ש באח"ב, ומה שהודיעם הקב"ה חשך ומכת בכורות אף שכבר היו סמוכים באותה שעה, אולי מפני שמרובים פרטיהם, שהי' ב' מיני חשך וא' שונה מחבירו, ובמכת בכורות מת אף הגדול שבבית אםאין שם בכור ואף בכור בהמה, וכ"ז לא נשמע מהרמז שעל המטה.
translation: And seemingly, the question is difficult, for the section of the new month was said on Rosh Chodesh Nisan, as our sages have said (Midrash Rabbah, Parashat Va'era, Section 74), "He showed him the moon in its renewal." According to the opinion of the Ramban, the plague of locusts occurred at the beginning of Nisan. Therefore, it is understandable that regarding the last three plagues, from the plague of locusts onward, Moshe and Aharon discussed the laws of fines, but the reason is still needed for the first seven plagues, how Moshe and Aharon became agents to adjudicate the laws of fines in Egypt when they were not yet ordained at that time. It is possible that one question is answered in the words of the Ba'al HaTurim, that Moshe Rabbeinu knew of the plague of locusts from what he saw inscribed on the staff, "Dam, Tz'far'dea, Kinim, Arov, Dever, Shechin, Barad, Arbeh," thus he also knew about the others. And why did the Holy One, Blessed be He, need to inform him and command him for each plague? It is possible that for the first seven, even though they knew and saw them inscribed on the staff, Moshe and Aharon could not adjudicate the laws of fines themselves, for they were not yet ordained until Rosh Chodesh Nisan. Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, needed to command them in each case and make them agents, whereas in the plague of locusts, which was after Rosh Chodesh and they were already ordained at that time, the Holy One, Blessed be He, did not need to command them. This explains the resolution of the Ba'al HaTurim that they knew from what they saw inscribed on the staff. And regarding what the Holy One, Blessed be He, informed them about darkness and the plague of the firstborn, even though they were already ordained at that time, perhaps it is because of the many details involved, as there were two types of darkness, and one was different from the other, and in the plague of the firstborn, even the eldest in the house dies if there is no firstborn present, and even a firstborn animal, and all this was not heard from the hint on the staff.
summary: The passage discusses the timing and divine instruction of the plagues in Egypt, particularly focusing on the first seven plagues and the role of Moses and Aaron as agents of divine justice. It highlights that although they were aware of the plagues through signs, they could not act as judges until they were formally appointed, which occurred at Rosh Chodesh Nisan. The text emphasizes the necessity of divine communication for the first plagues, while later plagues required less direct instruction due to their established authority. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine will, human agency, and the unfolding of redemption.

passage_content: ויאמרד' אל משה בא אל פרעה כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וגו' למען שתי אותותי אלה בקרבו, ראוי להבין מה נתינת טעם הזה, במ"ש כי אני הכבדתי וגו', ואדרבה ה"ז טעם למנוע ביאתו, גם אותתי אלה אינו מבואר הכוונה, ואם קאי על מכת הארבה דעסיק בי', מדוע אמר אלה בל' רבים.
translation: And G-d said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart, etc., in order to place these signs of Mine within him." It is fitting to understand the reason for this statement, in that He said, "for I have hardened," etc. On the contrary, this is a reason to prevent his coming. Also, the phrase "these signs of Mine" does not clarify the intention, and if it refers to the plague of locusts that I am dealing with, why did He say "these" in the plural form?
summary: בקטע זה מדבר ה' עם משה על הכבדה של לב פרעה, ומסביר כי הכבדה זו נועדה לאפשר את הופעת האותות בקרבו. השאלה המועלת היא מדוע יש צורך בהכבדה זו, שכן היא עשויה למנוע את בואו של פרעה. בנוסף, ישנה תהייה על השימוש בלשון רבים כאשר מדובר באותות, מה שמעורר שאלות על משמעותם ותכליתם. הקטע מדגיש את הקשר בין רצון ה' לבין התהליכים ההיסטוריים והניסיים המתרחשים, תוך כדי חקירה של הכוונה האלוהית מאחורי האירועים.

passage_content: ב)כל ענין הכבדת הלב כבר עמדו בה מפוה"ת, דנראה כנשלל בחירתו, וא"כ במה יתוסף פשעו אם לא הי' עוד לבו ברשותו, ובמד"ר (פ' י"ג סי' ג') א"ר יוחנן מכאן פ"פ למינין לומר לא היתה ממנו שיעשה תשובה, ותירצו במדרש שלא הי' אלא בבחי' מוסיף טומאה על טומאתו, ולא נמנע ממנו התשובה בהחלט, אלא שלגודל טומאתו הי' כבד עליו לעשות תשובה, אמנם אף לפי"ד צ"ב דאף בלא"ה היתה טומאתו גדולה עד אין שעור ומדוע הי' צורך להוסיף עוד, ואם בשביל להשלים עליו כל המכות עד תומם, כבר הי' ראוי אליהם בעונותיו הקודמים ומה צורך להכבדת הלב.
translation: B) Regarding the matter of the hardening of the heart, the commentators have already addressed this, as it seems to imply a negation of free will. If so, how would his sin increase if his heart were no longer in his control? And in the Midrash (Parashat Yitro, Section 3), Rabbi Yochanan said from here a proof for the types of people who say that he was not given the opportunity to repent. The Midrash answers that he was only in a state of adding impurity to his impurity, and he was not completely prevented from repentance, but due to the magnitude of his impurity, it was hard for him to repent. However, according to this explanation, it is questionable why his impurity was already so great beyond measure, and why there was a need to add more. And if it was to complete upon him all the plagues to their fullness, he was already deserving of them due to his previous sins, so what was the need for the hardening of the heart?
summary: The passage discusses the concept of a "heavy heart" in relation to free will and repentance, suggesting that even when one's heart is burdened by sin, the possibility of repentance remains. It references a Midrash that indicates the heaviness of the heart does not completely prevent one from returning to God, but rather makes it more challenging due to the accumulation of sin. The text raises questions about the necessity of additional burdens of sin if one is already weighed down, emphasizing the complexity of sin, repentance, and divine justice in Hasidic thought. Ultimately, it highlights the enduring potential for redemption despite the overwhelming nature of one's transgressions.

passage_content: ג)ולמען תספר באזני בנך וגו' ולמען יאריכון ימיך וצ"ב.
translation: "And in order that you may tell in the ears of your son, etc., and in order that your days may be prolonged, and so forth."
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of storytelling and the transmission of faith from one generation to the next, highlighting the role of parents in imparting spiritual wisdom to their children. This act of sharing not only strengthens familial bonds but also serves to prolong life and enhance spiritual fulfillment. It reflects the Hasidic belief in the power of narrative as a means of connecting with the divine and ensuring the continuity of Jewish tradition. Ultimately, it underscores the significance of living a life imbued with purpose and faith, which is essential for both individual and communal well-being.
