passage_content: אואפשר דמתחלה חשב פרעה שאין הכרח שילכו גם הטף לעבוד את ה', כי אין חיוב החינוך מדאורייתא כ"א לתלמוד תורה, ולשאר מצות החינוך רק מדרבנן, ופרעה וודאי לא הי' מודה בדרבנן, וע"כ אמר לכו נא הגברים והטף ישארו במצרים, אבל אחר שראה בלקיחת הפסח שמחנכין בו גם הקטנים, וע"ד שפי' האוהחה"ק איש לפי אכלו תכסו על השה, ע"ד אומרם ז"ל ו)פסחים דף פ"ח ע"א) שוחט אדם ע"י בנו ובתו הקטנים וגם ע"י אשתו וכו' עיי"ש, א"כ נתברר לו מנהג ישראל שמחנכים גם הקטנים בכל המצות, לזה חזר מטענתו ואמר גם טפכם ילך עמכם, כי השיג שלא יתרצו בלא"ה, רק צאנכם ובקרכם יצג לערבון.
translation: And it is possible that initially Pharaoh thought that there was no necessity for the children to go and serve Hashem, because the obligation of education is only a rabbinic decree and not a biblical one, and Pharaoh certainly would not have acknowledged rabbinic law. Therefore, he said, "Go now, you men, and let the children remain in Egypt." But after he saw that in the taking of the Passover, they educate even the little ones, as explained by the holy teachings, "A man according to what he can eat, so shall you cover for the lamb," and as our sages say (Pesachim 88a) that a person can slaughter through his young son and daughter, and also through his wife, etc., as mentioned there, it became clear to him that the custom of Israel is to educate even the little ones in all the commandments. For this reason, he retracted his claim and said, "Also your little ones may go with you," because he realized that they would not agree otherwise, only your flocks and your herds shall be left as collateral.
summary: In this passage, the author discusses Pharaoh's initial belief that only adult males were required to serve God, as he did not recognize the rabbinic obligation to educate children in the commandments. However, upon witnessing the Jewish practice of including children in the Passover observance, he realized that the tradition of educating even the youngest in all mitzvot was integral to Jewish identity. This led him to retract his stance and allow the children to leave with the adults, highlighting the importance of communal education and the transmission of faith across generations. The text emphasizes the significance of nurturing spiritual growth in children as a fundamental aspect of Jewish life.

passage_content: ומ"שגם אתה תתן בידינו זבחים ועולות ועשינו לה' אלקינו, והקשה האוהחה"ק איך שאול ישאל עבד ה' זבחי אלקים מאיש בזוי וטמא אשר הרים פיו בקדוש ישראל וכו', החפץ לה' בזבח רשעים עכ"ד, ואפ"ל שנתכוין מרע"ה לרמוז לו עפ"י אמרם ז"ל דרבים מן המצריים נצטרפו עם ישראל, ואף מן החרטומים ואנשי עצתו של פרעה עזבוהו והלכו עם ישראל, ובוודאי הוליכו עמהם צאנם ובקרם וכל אשר להם, ומהם יכלו ישראל להקריב, כי עכו"ם המבטל ע"ז שלו הוי בטול גמור, וז"א גם אתה תתן בידינו זבחים ועולות ר"ל ע"י אנשיך ואנשי בריתך, שהם עצמם ימסרו בידינו לבטל הע"ז, ועשינו לד' אלקינו כי זהו ביטול גמור.
translation: And what is meant by "also you will give into our hands sacrifices and burnt offerings, and we will make them to the Lord our God," and the holy question arises how Saul, a servant of God, would ask for the sacrifices of God from a despised and impure man who raised his mouth against the Holy One of Israel, etc. The desire of the Lord is in the sacrifice of the wicked, thus it is said. And it can be said that Moshe intended to hint to him according to what our sages of blessed memory said, that many from the Egyptians joined with Israel, and even from the magicians and the men of Pharaoh's counsel left him and went with Israel. And certainly, they brought with them their flocks and cattle and all that they had, and from them Israel could offer sacrifices, for a gentile who nullifies his idolatry is considered a complete nullification. Therefore, it is said, "also you will give into our hands sacrifices and burnt offerings," meaning through your people and the people of your covenant, they themselves will hand over to us to nullify the idolatry, and we will make to the Lord our God, for this is a complete nullification.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author addresses the paradox of Moses asking for sacrifices from the Egyptians, who are deemed impure and contemptible. He suggests that Moses alludes to the fact that many Egyptians, including magicians and advisors of Pharaoh, joined the Israelites and brought their livestock with them. This implies that the sacrifices offered by these former idolaters, who have renounced their idolatry, represent a complete nullification of their previous worship, thus allowing the Israelites to offer genuine sacrifices to God. The theological insight emphasizes the transformative power of repentance and the potential for redemption even among those who were once considered wicked.

passage_content: ומ"שנלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים במדבר ונזבחה לד' אלקינו והאוחה"ק נדחק בזה וכתב כי ה' לא אמר פרט זה אלא ישראל והי' צורך לזה להטעות לב פרעה שירדוף אחריהם עיי"ש, ול"נ שאמת יהגה חכו של משרע"ה, כי לא אמר שאחר ג' ימים יחזרו, רק שאחר הליכת ג' ימים יעבדו את ד', ובאמת כן הי' שאז נתעלו ישראל וזכו לעבדות ה' בבחי' יותר מעולה וגבוה, דכל זמן שהיו במצרים אף שנתעלו בעשור לחדש שמשכו ידיהם מע"ז וקבלו עליהם עול מלכותו ית', מ"מ עדיין היו משוקעים עד רגע אחרונה ליציאתם כמאמה"כ ולא יכלו להתמהמה, ורק כשיצאו התחילו בעבודה האמיתית ונקי' מכל זוהמת טומאת מצרים, וידוע שעבודת יום השבת מקודשת יותר, ואינו דומה עבודת יום חול לעבודת יום השבת, וישראל יצאו ממצרים בחמישי בשבת, נמצא יום שלישי להליכתם הי' שבת ולז"א נלכה נא דרך ג' ימים ונזבחה לד' אלקינו, כי אז יזכו ישראל לשלימות העבודה מה שא"א להשיג להם בעודם במצרים ואף אחר שיצאו כ"א ליום השלישי מיציאתם והבן.
translation: And when they said, "Let us go three days' journey into the wilderness and sacrifice to the Lord our God," the Holy One, blessed be He, was troubled by this and wrote that the Lord did not mention this detail except for Israel, and it was necessary for this to mislead the heart of Pharaoh so that he would pursue them, as is explained there. And it seems to me that the truth is that Moshe Rabbeinu was hinting, for he did not say that after three days they would return, but that after walking three days they would serve the Lord. And indeed, it was so that then Israel was elevated and merited to serve the Lord in a more exalted and higher manner, for as long as they were in Egypt, even though they were elevated on the tenth of the month when they withdrew their hands from idolatry and accepted upon themselves the yoke of His kingdom, nevertheless, they were still immersed until the very last moment of their departure, as it is written, and they could not delay. Only when they left did they begin the true service, free from all the impurity of Egypt. And it is known that the service of the Sabbath day is more sanctified, and the work of a weekday is not comparable to the work of the Sabbath day. And Israel left Egypt on the fifth of the Sabbath, thus the third day of their journey was a Sabbath. Therefore, they said, "Let us go three days' journey and sacrifice to the Lord our God," for then Israel would merit the completeness of the service, which they could not achieve while still in Egypt, and even after they left, only on the third day of their departure. Understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' journey into the desert to serve God, emphasizing that their request to travel three days was a strategic move to mislead Pharaoh. It highlights that true worship and spiritual elevation could only begin after their departure from Egypt, as they were still tainted by its impurities. The text notes that the third day of their journey coincided with the Sabbath, a day of heightened sanctity, allowing the Israelites to achieve a more profound level of divine service that was unattainable while in Egypt. Thus, their liberation marked the beginning of a more elevated and pure form of worship.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד עפ"י דרכנו הראשון דברי הזוה"ק הנ"ל ר"י פתח אשרי העם יודעי תרועה וגו', עפי"מ שפי' הנוע"מ זלה"ה בספה"ק אמרות טהורות (תהלים פ"ט) אשרי העם יודעי תרועה, שיודעים וזוכרים הדין, בעת שבאור פניך יהלכון בעת טובתם, ומקדימיןרצון לצרה ועושין תשובה בזמן הטובה עכ"ל, והנה כבר ביארנו לעיל דהכבדת לב פרעה הי' ע"י שנעשה לו נס בהשארת החטה והכוסמת, גם כתבו התוס' (בכורות מ"א ע"א) דשחין מצרים יבש מבפנים הי' ולא מתסי, ואם נתרפאו ממנו המצריים שמא מעשה נס הי' עכ"ל, ובראותם הצלתם בדרך נס נתחזק לבם יותר, והוא ית' משחק בהם מראה להם הרוחה, כדי לתת מקום שיחולו עליו יתר המכות כולן, דאלמלא נשארו החטה והכוסמת בברד, במה תחול מכת הארבה וכן כולן עד"ז, אמנם פרעה הרשע נתגדל בלבבו והתפאר שהקב"ה עושה לו נסים ומגין עליו להצילו מן הפורעניות ועי"ז נתוסף לו טומאה על טומאתו, לכן הסמיכו בזוה"ק לכאן אשרי העם יודעי תרועה ד' באור פניך יהלכון, שאיש ישראל צריך שיהי' לבו נשבר בקרבו בכגון דא, ואף אם יש רגלים לדבר שנעשו לו נסים מצד הקדושה, מ"מ מפחד מחרדת הדין אף בעת שבאור פניך יהלכון ועושים תשובה בזמן הטובה ועי"ז זוכים להיות טובתן נצחית.
translation: And yet, according to our first approach, the words of the Zohar mentioned above, Rabbi Yoel opened with "Blessed is the people that know the sound of the shofar," etc. As explained by the holy Noda B'Yehuda in the holy book "Amarot Tahorot" (Psalms 89), "Blessed is the people that know the sound of the shofar," who know and remember the judgment, at the time when they walk in the light of Your countenance during their good times, and they precede desire to trouble and do repentance in the time of goodness. Thus far the quote. And behold, we have already explained above that the hardening of Pharaoh's heart was due to the miracle of the preservation of the wheat and the spelt. The Tosafot also wrote (Baba Kamma 41a) that the boils of Egypt were dry from within and not from the outside, and if the Egyptians were healed from it, perhaps it was a miracle. Thus far the quote. When they saw their salvation through a miracle, their hearts were strengthened even more, and He, blessed be He, played with them, showing them relief, in order to give room for all the other plagues to fall upon them. For if the wheat and the spelt had remained intact in the hail, how would the plague of locusts come upon them, and so on similarly. However, the wicked Pharaoh grew proud in his heart and boasted that the Holy One, blessed be He, was performing miracles for him and protecting him from calamities, and thereby he added impurity to his impurity. Therefore, the Zohar connects here "Blessed is the people that know the sound of the shofar," that in the light of Your countenance they walk, for a Jew's heart needs to be broken within him in such matters, and even if there are grounds to say that miracles were done for him from the side of holiness, nevertheless, out of fear of the dread of judgment, even at the time when they walk in the light of Your countenance and do repentance in the time of goodness, and thereby they merit to have their goodness be eternal.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of humility and awareness of divine judgment, as illustrated by the example of Pharaoh, who became arrogant due to experiencing miracles. It highlights that true understanding and remembrance of God's laws lead to a broken heart and repentance, even during times of divine favor. The Zohar's reference to "happy is the nation that knows the sound of the shofar" underscores the need for spiritual vigilance and the recognition of one's shortcomings, ensuring that one remains connected to God’s will and grace. Ultimately, this awareness allows individuals to attain lasting goodness and spiritual elevation.

passage_content: ועד"זיתבאר במאה"כ כל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך כי אני ד' רופאך שהקשו במכילתא אם אין בהם מחלה מפני מה צריכים רפואה, גם מדוע שלל הכתוב מחלה אשר שמתי במצרים דייקא, וכמו"כ יצילנו הקב"ה מכל המחלות, אולם לפי דרכנו הנ"ל המחלה אשר שם ד' במצרים הי' בסיבת הרפואה שקדמה לה, דע"י שנתרפאו משחין בדרך נס הי' באפשרותם לקבל עוד מחלות וכן כולם עד"ז, אמנם אם הבוי"ת מרפא, רפואתו נצחית ולא יוסיף עצב עמה לגרום עוד מחלה, רק רפואתו של פרעה והמצרים הי' בשליחות השטן להוסיף טומאה על טומאתו ולהכביד לבו וסופו לגרום להם אבדון, ולז"א אם שמוע תשמע לקול ד' אלקיך והישר בעיניו תעשה וגו' כל המחלה אשר שמתי במצרים לא אשים עליך, שהי' המחלה ע"י סיבת הרפואה שקדמה לה כי אני ד' רופאך ויהי' רפואתך נצחי ולא יגרום אחרי' מחלה.
translation: And similarly, it is explained in the verse, "All the sickness that I placed in Egypt I will not place upon you, for I am the Lord your Healer." The Mechilta questions why, if there are no sicknesses among them, they need healing. It also asks why the verse specifically excludes the sickness that I placed in Egypt. Likewise, may the Holy One, blessed be He, save us from all sicknesses. However, according to our aforementioned approach, the sickness that the Lord placed in Egypt was due to the healing that preceded it. For by being healed from the boils in a miraculous way, it was possible for them to receive further sicknesses, and so on. However, if the Blessed One heals, His healing is eternal and does not bring sorrow with it to cause further sickness. Rather, the healing of Pharaoh and the Egyptians was through the agency of the Satan to add impurity to their impurity and to harden his heart, ultimately leading to their destruction. Therefore, it is said, "If you will listen to the voice of the Lord your God and do what is right in His eyes... all the sickness that I placed in Egypt I will not place upon you," for the sickness was due to the healing that preceded it, for I am the Lord your Healer, and your healing will be eternal and will not cause further sickness afterward.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the illnesses inflicted in Egypt were ultimately for the purpose of healing, highlighting God's role as the eternal healer. It contrasts divine healing, which is permanent and does not lead to further affliction, with the temporary and corrupting remedies of Pharaoh and the Egyptians, which were influenced by evil. The text underscores the idea that true healing from God is free from sorrow and leads to lasting wellness, reinforcing the importance of obedience to God's voice for spiritual and physical health.

passage_content: היוצאלנו מזה שאיש ישראל צריך להיות תמיד לבו נשבר בקרבו, אף בעת שזוכה להיות באור פניך יהלכון כבחי' שכתב בספה"ק נוע"מ הנ"ל, ובעוה"ר רחוקים אנו מבחי' זו של באור פניך יהלכון וההסתרת פנים גדולה מאוד, השי"ת ירחם על עמו וישפיע בלבבות בנ"י קדושה וטהרה ויאיר עינינו שנזכה לראות האמת, ונזכה לעשות תשובה שלימה וכל אחד ישתדל להשריש האמונה בלב בניו וב"ב ועי"ז יתחזק גם הוא באמונתו והשגתו בידיעת ה', וז"פ הסמיכות ולמען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך וגו' ועי"ז וידעתם כי אני ד' וחלילה להיפך גם בעצמו לא ידע ויסוג אחורר"ל, הבוכ"ע יעזור שנזכה לקבל אור פניו ית"ש, בהתרוממת קרן התורה וישראל ובישועה שלימה ואמיתית בהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: The text states: "It is known that a Jew must always have a broken heart within him, even at the time when he is privileged to be in the light of Your countenance, as written in the holy book Nefesh HaChaim mentioned above. And, alas, we are far from this state of being in the light of Your countenance, and the concealment of the face is very great. May the Holy One, blessed be He, have mercy on His people and instill in the hearts of the Jewish people holiness and purity, and may He illuminate our eyes so that we merit to see the truth, and may we merit to make complete repentance. Each one should strive to instill faith in the hearts of his children and household, and through this, he will also strengthen himself in his faith and understanding of the knowledge of God. And this is the meaning of the proximity to 'and you shall tell your son and your son's son' etc., and through this 'and you shall know that I am the Lord,' and God forbid the opposite, for if he himself does not know, he will turn away, as it is said. May the Blessed One help us to merit to receive the light of His countenance, with the elevation of the crown of the Torah and Israel, and with complete and true salvation through the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, speedily and in our days."
summary: The passage emphasizes the necessity for a Jew to maintain a broken heart, even when experiencing the divine light of God's presence. It acknowledges the current distance from this state and the significant concealment of God's face, calling for divine mercy to inspire holiness and purity in the hearts of the Jewish people. The text highlights the importance of instilling faith in one's children, which in turn strengthens one's own belief and understanding of God. Ultimately, it expresses a yearning for the revelation of God's glory and a complete redemption for Israel.

passage_content: ויאמרד' אל משה בא אל פרעה כי אני הכבדתי את לבו וגו' למען שתי אתתי אלה בקרבו, יל"ד דכבר הודיע השי"ת למשה כ"פ בפרשיות הקודמת שיחזק את לב פרעה, כמ"ש (בפ' שמות) ואני ידעתי כי לא יתן אתכם מלך מצרים להלוך וגו' והכיתי את מצרים בכל נפלאתי ואח"כ ישלח אתכם, ועוד א"ל השם ואני אחזק את לבו ולא ישלח את העם, ובפ' וארא ואני אקשה את לב פרעה והרבתי את אתתי וגו', ולמה הי' הצורך לכפול עוד ולהודיעו במכת הארבה בפרטיות כי אני הכבדתי את לבו, והרי כבר ידע משה רבינו בזה.
translation: And G-d said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart, etc., in order to place these signs of Mine in his midst." It is known that the Holy One, Blessed be He, had already informed Moses multiple times in the previous sections that He would strengthen Pharaoh's heart, as it is written (in Parashat Shemot), "And I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go, etc., and I will strike Egypt with all My wonders, and afterwards he will send you." Furthermore, G-d said to him, "And I will strengthen his heart, and he will not send the people." And in Parashat Va'era, "And I will harden Pharaoh's heart and I will multiply My signs, etc." So why was there a need to reiterate and inform him specifically regarding the plague of locusts that "I have hardened his heart," when Moses already knew this?
summary: בקטע זה מדגיש ה' למשה את הכוונה מאחורי הכבדה של לב פרעה, כדי להראות את כוחו ונפלאותיו של ה' בקרב מצרים. יש כאן חזרה על הרעיון שה' מחזק את לב פרעה כדי להוביל את המכות, ובכך להדגיש את תהליך הגאולה והצורך בהכנה רוחנית. הכפלת ההודעה על הכבדה זו מצביעה על חשיבותה של ההבנה העמוקה של משה לגבי תכלית המכות והגאולה, ומביאה לידי ביטוי את האמונה בהשגחה הפרטית של ה' על עם ישראל.

passage_content: ב)יש לשאול דהול"ל למען שתי מכותי או מופתי, ולמה אמר הכתוב אתתי, וכתב רש"י ז"ל (בפ' ואתחנן) באותות הם סימנין להאמין שהוא שלוחו של מקום כגון מה זה בידך, במופתים הם נפלאות שהביא עליהם מכות מופלאות, וא"כ יצדק על המכות לומר מופתי ולא אותתי, וכן הקשה האריז"ל בס' הלקוטים עיי"ש.
translation: B) One should ask why it should have said "for the sake of two of my signs" or "my wonders," and why the scripture states "I have given signs." Rashi, of blessed memory (in Parashat Va'etchanan), wrote that "signs" are indications to believe that it is the messenger of the Holy One, Blessed be He, such as "What is this in your hand?" In contrast, "wonders" are the miraculous plagues that He brought upon them. Therefore, it would be more appropriate to refer to the plagues as "my wonders" rather than "my signs." Thus, the Arizal also posed this question in the book of Likutim; see there.
summary: The passage discusses the distinction between "אותות" (signs) and "מופתים" (wonders) in the context of divine communication and miracles. It references Rashi's interpretation that signs serve as indicators of God's messenger, while wonders refer to extraordinary plagues. The text raises a theological question about why the term "אתתי" (I have come) is used instead of "מופתי," suggesting a deeper understanding of divine intervention and the nature of miracles in the Hasidic tradition. This reflects the belief in the significance of recognizing God's presence and authority through both signs and wonders.

passage_content: ג)מ"ש אתתי אלה צ"ב, דידוע דכ"מ שנא' אלה פוסל את הראשונים, ומה בא הכתוב למעט במ"ש אתתי אלה ולא אחרים.
translation: 3) Regarding "I have come to these," it is known that wherever it says "these" it disqualifies the earlier ones, and what does the verse come to exclude in "I have come to these and not others."
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the phrase "אתתי אלה" (I have come these) in the context of Hasidic thought, emphasizing that the term "אלה" serves to disqualify previous interpretations or authorities. It suggests that the divine message is unique and distinct, highlighting the importance of direct revelation and personal connection to the divine. This reflects a broader theological insight that prioritizes individual experience and understanding of God over established traditions or teachings. Ultimately, it underscores the idea that each encounter with the divine is fresh and transformative, inviting a deeper engagement with faith.

passage_content: ד)תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך וגו', הקשה הכלי יקר למה נאמר במכת הארבה למעןתספר יותר מבשאר המכות, והרי כמו"כ נצטווינו לספר בכל הנסים שעשה ד' בהוציאנו ממצרים שנא' והגדת לבנך וגו', ותירץ הכלי יקר עפימ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בש"ר חננאל עה"פ לא נשאר ארבה א' בכל גבול מצרים, כי מעת עתרת תפלת משה רבינו שיוסר הארבה מאמ"צ ועד היום הזה, אין ארבה מפסיד בכל גבול מצרים, ואם יפול בא"י ויכנס בגבול מצרים אין אוכל מן יבול מצרים כלום וזה ידוע לכל, וע"ז נאמר שיחו בכל נפלאותיו עכ"ל ר"ח ז"ל, וכתב הכלי יקר ז"ל כי בזה יובן הפסוק למען תספר באזני בנך וגו', כי יראו הדורות דבר חידוש כזה, כי יבא הארבה ולא יאכל כלום מכל גבול מצרים וישאלו הבנים על נס זה, ויצטרכו להשיב להם סיפור כל הקורות באמ"צ, וזהו שמסיים ר"ח בדבריו פסוק שיחו בכל נפלאותיו, כי בלי ספק לכך השאיר הקב"ה רושם זה לדורות, שעל ידו יזכרו יצ"מ, וז"ש למען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך ופי' זה יקר ונכון מאוד. עכת"ד הכלי יקר ז"ל. אמנם לכאורה עדיין אין הדעת מתיישבת בזה, כי איך יסובב נס זה לידי סיפור בני ישראל, ונס זה יהי' ידוע רק למצריים הגרים שם, אבל לא לבנ"י שהזהירם הכתוב בלא תשוב מצרימה והכתוב אומר למען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך והוא ציווי על דורות ישראל, ולא מצינו שיספרו ישראל בנס זה ואינו מפורסם כלל, ואלולי הר"ח גילה לנו דבר זה, לא היינו יודעין בו כלל, ואיך יובן שע"ז אמה"כ למען תספר באזני בנך וצ"ב.
translation: D) "You shall tell your son and your grandson, etc." The Kli Yakar asks why it is stated regarding the plague of locusts that you should tell more than about the other plagues, and indeed, we are also commanded to recount all the miracles that God performed in taking us out of Egypt, as it is said, "And you shall tell your son, etc." The Kli Yakar answers according to what Ramban, may his memory be blessed, said in the Midrash Chananiel on the verse, "There remained not one locust in all the borders of Egypt," for from the time of the fervent prayer of our teacher Moses that the locusts be removed from Egypt until this day, locusts do not destroy anything in all the borders of Egypt. And if they fall in the Land of Israel and enter the borders of Egypt, they do not eat anything from the produce of Egypt, and this is known to all. And concerning this, it is said, "Speak of all His wonders," thus said Rabbi Chaim, may his memory be blessed. The Kli Yakar, may his memory be blessed, wrote that this explains the verse "that you may tell in the ears of your son, etc.," for the generations will see such a novelty, that locusts will come and eat nothing from all the borders of Egypt, and the children will ask about this miracle, and they will need to respond to them with the story of all that happened in Egypt. This is what Rabbi Chaim concludes in his words with the verse "Speak of all His wonders," for without a doubt, this is why the Holy One, blessed be He, left this mark for the generations, by which they will remember the Exodus from Egypt. Therefore, it is said, "that you may tell in the ears of your son and your grandson," and this explanation is precious and very correct. Thus far the Kli Yakar, may his memory be blessed. However, at first glance, the mind does not settle with this, for how will this miracle lead to the recounting by the children of Israel? This miracle will only be known to the Egyptians living there, but not to the children of Israel, who were warned by the scripture not to return to Egypt. And the scripture says, "that you may tell in the ears of your son and your grandson," and this is a commandment for the generations of Israel, and we do not find that Israel recounts this miracle, and it is not publicized at all. Were it not for Rabbi Chaim revealing this matter to us, we would not know of it at all. How then can it be understood that this is the reason for the verse, "that you may tell in the ears of your son," and this requires further investigation.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of recounting the miracles of the plagues, particularly the plague of locusts, as a means to instill faith and memory in future generations. The "Kli Yakar" explains that the unique nature of the locust plague, which left no harm in Egypt, serves as a lasting reminder of God's wonders, prompting questions from children that lead to the retelling of the Exodus story. This emphasizes the importance of storytelling in Jewish tradition, ensuring that the miraculous events are passed down through generations. The text highlights the divine intention behind these miracles, as they are meant to foster a continuous awareness of God's intervention in history.

passage_content: ה)הענין צ"ב, דלמה זכו מצרים לברכה זו שיוסר מהם עונש הארבה לדורות עולם, הלא הסרת הארבה מהם הי' ע"צ העונש ולרעתם, כמ"ש במדרש ששמחו המצרים במכת הארבה, אמרו נקבוץ ונמלא מהם חביות, אמר הקב"ה במכה שהבאתי עליכם בה אתם שמחים, מיד ויהפוך ד' רוח ים וגו' לא נשאר ארבה א' בכל גבול מצרים. אף המלוחים פרחו והלכו להם ע"כ המדרש. והנה לטעם זה יספיק הסרת הארבה הנמצא בגבולם באותה שעה כדי שלא יהנו מהם, אבל מדוע זכו שיוסר מהם עונש הארבה לדורות וטעמא בעי. והגם שבודאי תפלת משרע"ה כוחו נצחי ועומדת לעד, אבל הי"ל למשה רבינו להתפלל באופן שיוסר מהם עתה ויחזור עליהם לאח"ז ע"צ העונש. ולפי"ז השתכרו עוד ממכת הארבה, ולמה הגיע עליהם ככה.
translation: The matter is difficult to understand, for why did Egypt merit this blessing that the punishment of the locusts would be removed from them for all generations? After all, the removal of the locusts from them was a punishment and for their detriment, as it is stated in the Midrash that the Egyptians rejoiced in the plague of locusts, saying, "Let us gather and fill barrels with them." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said, "In the plague that I brought upon you, you rejoice," and immediately He turned the wind of the sea, and there was not a single locust left in all the borders of Egypt. Even the salted ones flew away and left, as the Midrash states. Now, for this reason, the removal of the locusts that were in their borders at that time would suffice so that they would not benefit from them, but why did they merit that the punishment of the locusts be removed from them for generations, and the reason is needed. And although certainly the prayer of Moshe Rabbeinu has eternal power and stands forever, he could have prayed in such a way that it would be removed from them now and return upon them later as a punishment. According to this, they would have still profited from the plague of locusts, so why did it come upon them in this manner?
summary: הקטע עוסק בשאלה מדוע מצרים זכו להסרת עונש הארבה לדורות, למרות ששמחו במכה זו. המדרש מציין שהמצרים ניצלו מהארבה כדי שלא יהנו ממנו, אך יש לתמוה מדוע לא חזר העונש עליהם לאחר מכן. המסקנה היא שהתפילה של משה רבינו היא בעלת כוח נצחי, אך יש להבין מדוע לא התפלל באופן שיביא להסרת העונש רק לעת עתה. זה מעורר שאלות על צדק אלוהי ועל ההשפעה של תפילה על הגורל של עמים.

passage_content: ו)התעללתי פרש"י שחקתי, הקשה האלשיך הק' למה יקרא המכה בשם שחוק.
translation: "And I have played, as Rashi explains; the Alshich asks why the blow is called 'laughter'."
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author reflects on the concept of divine playfulness, as indicated by the term "שחוק" (laughter) used to describe God's actions. The question posed by the Alshich highlights the paradox of calling a painful experience a form of laughter, suggesting that even in suffering, there is a deeper, joyful purpose orchestrated by the Divine. This illustrates the Hasidic belief in finding meaning and spiritual elevation within life's challenges, emphasizing that God's ways, though sometimes incomprehensible, ultimately lead to redemption and joy. The passage invites readers to perceive trials as part of a divine play that fosters growth and connection to the Creator.

passage_content: ז)את עין הארץ ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ. פרש"י לשון קצרה דבר, שהול"ל ולא יוכל הרואה לראות את הארץ: לכאורה כל המאמר ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ מיותר, דכבר אמר שיהי' הארץ מכוסה, ומה לו להכתוב להודיע עוד שלא יוכל לראות את הארץ, ומובן מאליו.
translation: This is the eye of the land, and he will not be able to see the land. Rashi explains that it is a brief expression, as it could have said, "and the seer will not be able to see the land." At first glance, the entire statement "and he will not be able to see the land" seems superfluous, for it has already been stated that the land will be covered, and what need is there to write to inform that he will not be able to see the land, which is self-evident.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual perception and the limitations of human understanding in relation to divine truths. It highlights that even when the land (representing spiritual insight) is concealed, the inability to see it signifies a deeper spiritual blindness. This reflects the Hasidic idea that true vision requires divine illumination, and without it, one remains unaware of the spiritual realities that lie beyond the surface. The redundancy in the statement emphasizes the profound disconnect between the material world and the higher spiritual realms.

passage_content: ח)צ"ב משפרש"י וכסה את עין הארץ את מראה הארץ, ובתרגום אונקלס עין שמשא דארעא, וכוונת הכתוב לפי"ז דמראה הארץ יהי' מכוסה, וגם ניצוץ וזריחת השמש הנופל על הארץ יהי' מכוסה מרוב הארבה, וקשה דהול"ל וכסה את הארץ ומלת עין מיותר לגמרי, דמה נפק"מ אם מראה הארץ ומראה זריחת השמש מכוסה, או הארץ עצמה מכוסה מרוב הארבה, ואדרבה זו קללה גרוע יותר שכל הארץ יהי' מכוסה בארבה, ולהלן הוא אומר ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ, וכן ותחשך הארץ ולא אמר עין הארץ ומשמע דהארץ עצמה יהי' מכוסה, ולמה יאמר כאן עין הארץ ויותר יצדק לומר עין הרואה, כמשפרש"י ז"ל ולא יוכל לראות הרואה וכו', הרי שהכתוב מדבר בעין הרואה, ועין הארץ אין לו ענין לכאן וצ"ב.
translation: (8) It is to be understood from Rashi's explanation that "and He covered the eye of the land" refers to the appearance of the land, and in Onkelos' translation, "the eye of the sun that shines upon the land." The intent of the verse, according to this, is that the appearance of the land will be covered, and also the spark and rising of the sun that falls upon the land will be covered due to the abundance of the locusts. It is difficult, however, as it could have simply said "and He covered the land," and the word "eye" is entirely superfluous. What difference does it make if the appearance of the land and the appearance of the rising sun are covered, or if the land itself is covered due to the abundance of locusts? On the contrary, this is a worse curse, that the entire land will be covered with locusts. Furthermore, later it says, "and he will not be able to see the land," and similarly, "and the land was darkened," and it does not say "the eye of the land," which implies that the land itself will be covered. So why does it say here "the eye of the land"? It would be more fitting to say "the eye of the seer," as Rashi explains, "and the seer will not be able to see," etc. Thus, the verse speaks of the eye of the seer, and the eye of the land has no relevance here, and it is to be understood.
summary: The passage discusses the phrase "וכסה את עין הארץ" from the Torah, questioning the significance of the term "עין" (eye) in relation to the land being covered by locusts. It suggests that the use of "עין" implies a deeper meaning, indicating not just the physical covering of the land, but also the obscuring of perception and spiritual insight. This reflects a Hasidic understanding that the challenges and calamities in the world can hinder one's ability to see and recognize divine presence and truth. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of spiritual vision in perceiving reality beyond mere physical appearances.

passage_content: ט)(פרשה זו רמז קפ"ו) והוא במד"ר קהלת, (פ' א' סי' ט') אמר ר"ל כל מה שברא הקב"ה באדם ברא בארץ. אדם יש לו ראש והארץ יש לה ראש שנא' וראש עפרות תבל, אדם יש לו עינים והארץ יש לה עינים שנא' ויכס את עין כל הארץ וכו' עכ"ד המדרש, לכאורה לא שמעינן מהא מידי דהארץ יש לה עינים, דא"א לומר כוונתהכתוב על עין הארץ ממש, דא"כ מה דסמיך לי' ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ קאי ג"כ על עין הארץ, ואדרבה עין הארץ יראה הארבה שהרי מונח עליו, אלא ע"כולא יוכל לראות קאי על עין הרואה כמו שפי' ז"ל, וע"כ עין הארץ פירושו מראה הארץ או עין שמשא דארעא ולא עין הארץ ממש, ואיך נלמד מכאן דרשתם דהארץ יש לה עינים.
translation: This section hints at 116 (Kaf-Vav) and is found in the Midrash Kohelet (Chapter 1, Section 9). R. Levi said: Everything that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created in man, He created in the earth. Man has a head, and the earth has a head, as it is said, "And the head of the dust of the earth." Man has eyes, and the earth has eyes, as it is said, "And He covered the eye of all the earth," etc. Thus far the Midrash. At first glance, we do not hear anything from this that the earth has eyes, for it cannot be said that it refers to the eye of the earth itself, for if so, what is meant by "and he will not be able to see the earth" also applies to the eye of the earth. On the contrary, the eye of the earth will see the locust, as it is laid upon it. Rather, "he will be able to see" refers to the eye that sees, as explained by our sages. Therefore, the eye of the earth means the appearance of the earth or the eye that carries the earth, and not the eye of the earth itself. And how do we learn from here that the earth has eyes?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores the connection between humanity and the earth, emphasizing that just as a person has physical attributes like a head and eyes, so too does the earth possess analogous qualities. The reference to the earth having "eyes" is interpreted not as literal vision but as a metaphor for the earth's ability to perceive and reflect the actions of humanity. This insight highlights the interconnectedness of creation, suggesting that the earth is responsive to human behavior and serves as a witness to our deeds. Ultimately, the passage underscores a Hasidic understanding of the divine presence in both man and nature, revealing a profound relationship between the two.

passage_content: י)לא הי' כן ארבה כמוהו ואחריו לא יהי' כן, הקשה רש"י ז"ל דהרי בארבה שהי' בימי יואל כתיב כמוהו לא נהי' מן העולם, למדנו שהי' כבד משל משה, ותירץ דאותו של יואל הי' של מינים הרבה ארבה וילק וחסיל וגזם, אבל הארבה שבימי משה לא הי' אלא של מין א', וכמוהו לא הי' ולא יהי' רבוי ארבה ממין א', והרמב"ן ז"ל הקשה על פירושו שהרי כתיב ויתן לחסיל יבולם ויגיעם לארבה, ועוד כתיב אמר ויבא ארבה וילק ואין מספר, הרי דגם אותו שבימי משה הי' של מינים הרבה, והדרא קושיא לדוכתי' למה נאמר ואחריו לא יהי' כן. ותירץ הרמב"ן ז"ל עפ"י דברי ר"ח הנ"ל דמעת תפלת משרע"ה לא יהי' ארבה עוד בגבול מצרים, ומ"ש הכתוב ואחריו לא יהי' קאי על גבול מצרים אבל יהי' בכל העולם, אולם לפי"ד יקשה למה אמה"כ ואחריו לא יהי' כן הרי לא יהי' בכלל מכה זו לא כיו"ב ולא שלא כיו"ב, והול"ל ואחריו לא יהי' וכבר פירשנו בזה אופנים שונים ועוד לאלקי מילין.
translation: 1) "There will not be such a locust as this, nor will there be such after it." Rashi, of blessed memory, asked: Since it is written regarding the locust in the days of Joel, "like it there will not be in the world," we learn that it was heavier than that of Moses. He answered that the locust of Joel was of many species: locust, grasshopper, and bald locust, but the locust in the days of Moses was only of one species, and there will not be and has not been an abundance of locusts of one species. Ramban, of blessed memory, challenged this explanation, for it is written, "And He gave to the bald locust its yield and to the locust its harvest," and it is also written, "And He said, and the locust came and the grasshopper, and there is no number," thus indicating that even that of Moses was of many species. The question returns to its place: why is it said, "and after it there will not be such"? Ramban, of blessed memory, answered according to the words of R' Chaim mentioned above, that from the prayer of Moshe Rabbeinu, there will not be locusts anymore in the border of Egypt, and what the verse means by "and after it there will not be" refers to the border of Egypt, but there will be throughout the world. However, according to this explanation, it is difficult to understand why it says, "and after it there will not be such," since there will not be at all from this plague, neither similar nor dissimilar, and it should have said, "and after it there will not be." We have already explained this in various ways, and there is still more to say on the matter.
summary: The passage discusses the unique nature of the locust plague during the time of Joel, emphasizing that it was more severe and diverse than the one in Moses' time, which was limited to a single type. This distinction highlights the theological concept of divine judgment and the specific historical context of each plague. The text also reflects on the permanence of God's decrees, suggesting that while certain plagues may not recur in specific locations, their essence can manifest elsewhere in the world. Ultimately, it underscores the complexity of divine intervention and the multifaceted nature of God's actions in history.

translation: 11) "Only this death," it is known that the "Achin" and "Rakin" are few, and what does it come to exclude by saying "only this death"? Also, that there are two exclusions here: "only" and "this." It requires clarification for what purpose it comes.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of "only this death," emphasizing the idea that death is a limited and specific experience. It suggests that the term "only" serves to highlight the uniqueness of this death, distinguishing it from other forms of mortality. The mention of "two limited aspects" indicates a deeper exploration of the nature of existence and the spiritual implications of death within Hasidic thought. Ultimately, it invites reflection on the significance of mortality in the context of divine purpose and the soul's journey.

passage_content: יב)זש"ה אמרו לאלקים מה נורא מעשיך ברוב עוזך יכחשו לך אויביך, ישקרו ויעשו כחשים בדבריהם וכו', פרעה אמר לא ידעתי את ד', נעשה כחשן והודה ואמר ה' הצדיק, הוא אמר גם את בנ"י לא אשלח, א"ל הקב"ה למשה בא אל פרעה ועל ידך ישלח, שנא' שלח משה עבדו וגו' ויוצא עמו בששון עכ"ל, ובמד"ר (פ' כ' סי' י') איתא מאמר זה עה"פ ויהי בשלח פרעה עיי"ש, ולכאורה צ"ב דאין זה בגדר כחש וכזב, דבשעה שאמר לא ידעתי את ד' נתכוין כן באמת בדבריו, כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל דפרעה הי' חכם גדול ויודע את האלקים ומודה בו אבל לא הי' יודע את השם המיוחד וכעי"ז איתא בזוה"ק, ואח"כ נתוודע לו ע"י המכות כמשה"כ וידעו מצרים כי אני ד' בנטותי את ידי על מצרים וגו'. וכן מ"ש את ישראל לא אשלח, באותה שעה הי' פיו ולבו שוין ולא רצה לשלחם ברצונו, ואח"כ שלחם מחמת ההכרח ע"י שנלקה במכות גדולות ואין זה בגדר כחש וכזב אלא בגדר רשעות, וצ"ב דרשתם ז"ל.
translation: 11) As it is said, "Say to God, how awesome are Your deeds; in the abundance of Your might, Your enemies will feign submission to You, they will lie and speak falsehoods in their words," etc. Pharaoh said, "I do not know the Lord," he was deceitful and acknowledged, saying, "The Lord is righteous." He also said, "I will not send the Children of Israel." The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh, and through you he will send them," as it is stated, "Moses, His servant, was sent out with joy," etc. And in the Midrash (Parashat Bo, Section 10), this saying is found on the verse "And it was when Pharaoh sent out," see there. However, it seems difficult to understand, for this does not fall under the category of deceit and falsehood, since when he said, "I do not know the Lord," he truly meant it in his words, as Nachmanides, of blessed memory, writes that Pharaoh was a great wise man and knew God and acknowledged Him, but he did not know the special Name. Similarly, it is stated in the Zohar. And afterwards, he was made aware through the plagues, as it is written, "And Egypt will know that I am the Lord when I stretch out My hand over Egypt," etc. Likewise, when he said, "I will not send Israel," at that moment his mouth and heart were in agreement, and he did not want to send them willingly. Later, he sent them out due to necessity, after being struck by great plagues, and this does not fall under the category of deceit and falsehood, but rather under the category of wickedness. This is the difficulty in your interpretation, blessed be their memory.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's denial of God, highlighting the tension between his true knowledge of God and his refusal to acknowledge Him. It emphasizes that Pharaoh's statements were not mere lies but stemmed from a place of wickedness, as he initially did not want to release the Israelites despite knowing God's power. The text illustrates the concept of divine revelation through suffering, as Pharaoh ultimately recognizes God's authority only after experiencing the plagues. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of free will, acknowledgment of God, and the consequences of obstinacy.

passage_content: יג)את משה ואת אהרן אל פרעה ויאמר אלהם לכו עבדו את ד' וגו' מי ומי ההולכים, אבא מארי זלה"ה בקדושת יו"ט הביא מדרש בשם ס' עיר דוד וז"ל, אמר פרעה מי ומי ההולכים, עתידים אתם אומרים מי יעלה בהר ד' ומי יקום במקום קדשו וזה מי ומי ההולכים, וצ"ב דמה ענין הך קרא להכא.
translation: 13) "And Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh, and he said to them, 'Go, serve the Lord,' etc. Who are the ones going?" My father, may his memory be a blessing, in the sanctity of the festival, brought a Midrash in the name of the Book of the City of David, and it says: Pharaoh said, "Who are the ones going?" You are destined to say, "Who may ascend the mountain of the Lord, and who may stand in His holy place?" And this is "Who are the ones going?" And it is to be questioned what the connection of this verse is to here.
summary: In this passage, the dialogue between Pharaoh and Moses and Aaron highlights the spiritual significance of the question "Who is going?" This reflects a deeper theological inquiry about the nature of those who approach holiness and divine service. The reference to the verse "Who shall ascend the hill of the Lord?" emphasizes the importance of purity and intention in one's quest for spiritual elevation. The connection made by the Rebbe suggests that true service to God requires understanding one's own spiritual readiness and the communal aspect of worship.

passage_content: יד)ראוי להבין בתשובת משרע"ה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, דלמה כפל לומר בנערינו בבנינו והיינו הך, וגם נלך נלך ב' זימני למה ויספיק בחדא, והאברבנאל הקשה דהול"ל לשון קצרה כולנו נלך, ולמה הי' הצורך לפרוט כל סוג לבדו. ובבעה"ט כתב אמר פרעה למשה וכי סבורים אתם ליכנס לארץ והלא כולם ימותו במדבר, ולא יכנסו לארץ כ"א שנים בלבד יהושע וכלב, ועליהם אמר פרעה מי ומי ההולכים, והאברבנאל הביא מאמר זה בשם מדרש, ומשה השיבו בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, כי לא נגזרה גזירה לא על פחות מבן כ' ולא על יותר מבן ס' עיי"ש. ולפי"ז מ"ש בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך הכוונה על הפחותים מבן כ' בשעת הגזירה, אולם אלו הרי כבר נכללו במ"ש בנערינו, והכפל בדבריו למה.
translation: It is fitting to understand in the response of Moshe Rabbeinu, "With our young and with our old we will go, with our sons and with our daughters we will go," why it is repeated to say "with our young" and "with our sons," as they are essentially the same. Also, why does it say "we will go" twice; one would suffice? And the Abarbanel questioned why it was not stated in a shorter form, "we will all go," and what was the need to specify each category separately. In the Be'er Haitev, it is written that Pharaoh said to Moshe, "Do you think you will enter the land? But all will die in the desert, and only Yehoshua and Kalev will enter the land." And concerning them, Pharaoh asked, "Who are the ones going?" The Abarbanel brought this saying in the name of a Midrash, and Moshe replied, "With our young and with our old we will go," for there was no decree against those under twenty or over sixty, as noted there. According to this, what is meant by "with our sons and with our daughters we will go" refers to those under twenty at the time of the decree; however, these are already included in what is stated about "with our young," so why the repetition in his words?
summary: The passage discusses the repetition of phrases in Moses' response to Pharaoh regarding the inclusion of both young and old in their journey, questioning the necessity of specifying "our sons and our daughters." It highlights the theological insight that the decree of death in the desert did not apply to those under twenty or over sixty, suggesting a divine mercy in the categorization of the people. The emphasis on both youth and elders reflects the importance of every generation in the spiritual journey, underscoring the unity and continuity of the Jewish people in their quest for redemption.

passage_content: טו)בפ' קרבן פסח דברו אל כל עדת ישראל לאמר בעשור לחדש הזה ויקחו להם איש שה לבית אבות וגו', ובמכילתא לאמר צא ואמור אליהם מיד דברי ר' ישמעאל, שנא' ויצא ודבר אל בנ"י את אשר יצוה, וצ"ב דלמה צריך לימוד ע"ז, ומהיכי תיתי ימנע משה רבינו הדיבור, ובודאי שיודיע לישראל מצות השי"ת בלי איחור.
translation: 15) In the portion of the Paschal Offering, it speaks to the entire congregation of Israel, saying, "On the tenth of this month, they shall take for themselves a lamb, each man according to his father's house," etc. And in the Mekilta, it says, "Go and tell them immediately," the words of Rabbi Yishmael, as it is stated, "And he went out and spoke to the children of Israel that which he was commanded." And it is questioned why there is a need for this teaching, and how could Moshe Rabbeinu possibly withhold the message, when certainly he would inform Israel of the commandments of the Holy One, Blessed be He, without delay.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the commandment given to the Israelites regarding the Paschal lamb, emphasizing the importance of communication in fulfilling divine commandments. The reference to Rabbi Yishmael highlights the necessity of teaching and conveying God's instructions, suggesting that even Moses, despite his prophetic status, needed to articulate the commandments to ensure their proper observance. This underscores the Hasidic concept of the significance of human agency in the divine plan and the role of leaders in guiding their communities in spiritual practices. The passage reflects a deep theological insight into the interplay between divine command and human responsibility.

passage_content: טז)במכילתא (הובא ברש"י ז"ל) מפני מה הקדים הכתוב לקיחתו של פסח לשחיטתו ד' ימים, מה שלא צו' כן בפסח דורות, הי' ר' מתיא בן חרש אומר, ה"ה אומר ואעבור עליך ואראך והנה עתך עת דודים (יחזקאל ט"ז), הגיע שבועתו שנשבע הקב"ה לאברהם שיגאל את בניו, ולא הי' בידם מצות כדי שיגאלו כמ"ש ואת ערום וערי' וכו', ולפי שהיו שטופים בע"ז במצרים, וע"ז שקולה כנגד כל המצות וכו', אמר להם משכו ידיכם מע"ז והדבקו במצות עכ"ד המכילתא, ובמד"ר (פ' ט"ז סי' ג') איתא א"ל הקב"ה למשה חייך אין ישראל יוצאין מכאן, עד שישחטו את אלהי מצרים לעיניהם, שאודיע להם שאין אלהיהם כלום. עכ"ד המדרש. ולכאורה קשה הרי בר"ח נצטוו ישראל במצו' זו, כמ"ש ז"ל הראהו הלבנה בחידושה וכו' והצווי הי' שיקיימו המצו' בעשור לחדש, ולפי טעם המכילתא דהקדים לקיחתו ד' ימים כדי לפרוש מע"ז, למה לא נצטוו ישראל לקיים מצו' זו מיד בר"ח, ולמה ימתינו לפרוש מע"ז עד בעשור לחדש, וכל רגע ורגע הוי פסידא דלא הדר וצ"ב.
translation:
16) In the Mechilta (brought by Rashi, may his memory be blessed), it asks why the Torah preceded the taking of the Paschal lamb by four days before its slaughter, which is not commanded in the Paschal observance of future generations. Rabbi Mattia ben Charash would say, "He (God) says, 'And I passed over you and saw you, and behold, your time is the time of love' (Ezekiel 16)." The time of His oath, which the Holy One, blessed be He, swore to Abraham to redeem his children, had arrived, and they did not have the commandments to be redeemed, as it is said, "And you were naked and bare," etc. Since they were immersed in idolatry in Egypt, and idolatry is equivalent to all the commandments, He said to them, "Withdraw your hands from idolatry and cling to the commandments," thus concludes the Mechilta. And in the Midrash (Parashat 16, section 3), it is stated that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, "By your life, Israel will not leave here until they slaughter the gods of Egypt before their eyes, so that I will make known to them that their gods are nothing." Thus concludes the Midrash. 

And at first glance, it is difficult, for on Rosh Chodesh, Israel was commanded in this commandment, as it is said, "He showed him the moon in its renewal," etc., and the command was that they should fulfill the commandment on the tenth of the month. According to the reasoning of the Mechilta, that the taking was preceded by four days in order to distance themselves from idolatry, why were the Israelites not commanded to fulfill this commandment immediately on Rosh Chodesh? And why would they wait to distance themselves from idolatry until the tenth of the month? Every moment that passes is a loss that cannot be recovered, and this is a question.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' preparation for the Passover sacrifice, emphasizing the need to distance themselves from idolatry before performing the commandment. It highlights God's promise to Abraham regarding the redemption of his descendants and the necessity for the Israelites to reject their Egyptian idols, which are equated with all commandments. The text raises a question about the timing of the commandment, suggesting that the delay in performing the sacrifice until the 10th of Nisan was to ensure a complete separation from idolatry. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the relationship between divine commandments and the need for spiritual readiness.

passage_content: יז)משה לכל זקני ישראל ויאמר אלהם משכו וקחו לכם צאן וגו', ולכאורה הרי היתה מצות השם אליו דברו אל כל עדת ישראל לאמר, ומדוע אמר לזקני ישראל, ובמכילתא איכא פלוגתא בזה, ר' יאשי' ס"ל הדבר יצא מפי משה לישראל אלא שעשאן להזקנים בית דין, ור' יונתן ס"ל הדבר יצא מפי משה לזקנים והזקנים לכל ישראל, ובמדרש רבה (פ' ט"ז סי' א') ויקרא משה לכל זקני ישראל הה"ד בישישים חכמה ואורך ימים תבונה, למה זכו הזקנים שיגאלו ישראל על ידיהן, בשעה שבא משה למצרים וא"ל אלקי אבותיכם שלחני אליכם, אילו לא קבלוהזקנים את דבריו של משה, אף כל ישראל לא היו מקבלים אותה, אלא הזקנים קבלו תחלה ומשכו כל ישראל אחריהם, אמר הקב"ה הריני פורע לזקנים ויהי' גאולת מצרים על ידיהן. שיהיו ישראל שוחטין פסחיהן על ידם של זקנים שנאמר ויקרא משה לכל זקני ישראל ויאמר אליהם משכו וקחו וגו' עכ"ד המדרש, ועדיין צ"ב כי למה הוצרכו להיות נעשית מצוה זו ע"י הזקנים, ולא סגי שיצוה משה לבני ישראל, כאשר א"ל השי"ת דברו אל כל עדת ישראל וגו' ומה הוסיפו כח הזקנים בעשייתן.
translation: 17) Moses called all the elders of Israel and said to them, "Draw out and take for yourselves sheep," etc. At first glance, it seems that the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, was to speak to the entire congregation of Israel, so why did he speak to the elders of Israel? And in the Mekhilta, there is a dispute about this: Rabbi Yashiyah holds that the matter came from the mouth of Moses to Israel, but he made the elders a court. Rabbi Jonathan holds that the matter came from the mouth of Moses to the elders, and the elders to all of Israel. And in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat 16, Section 1), it states, "Moses called all the elders of Israel," as it is written, "In the aged is wisdom, and length of days understanding." Why did the elders merit that Israel be redeemed through them? When Moses came to Egypt and said to them, "The God of your fathers has sent me to you," if the elders had not accepted the words of Moses, then all of Israel would not have accepted them either. Rather, the elders accepted first and drew all of Israel after them. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I will repay the elders, and the redemption from Egypt will be through them," so that Israel would slaughter their Passover offerings through the hands of the elders, as it is said, "And Moses called all the elders of Israel and said to them, 'Draw out and take...'" Thus concludes the Midrash. Yet, it is still puzzling why this commandment needed to be performed by the elders, and it would not have sufficed for Moses to command the children of Israel, as the Holy One, blessed be He, told him to speak to the entire congregation of Israel, and what additional power did the elders contribute to its performance?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses addressing the elders of Israel when commanding the Passover sacrifice, highlighting the role of the elders as intermediaries in the redemption process. It emphasizes that the acceptance of Moses' message by the elders was crucial for the collective acceptance by the entire nation, illustrating the importance of leadership and authority in spiritual matters. The text reflects on the theological concept that divine redemption is facilitated through established leaders, underscoring the value of wisdom and experience in guiding the community. Ultimately, it raises questions about the necessity of the elders' involvement in fulfilling God's commandments, suggesting a deeper connection between leadership and communal faith.

passage_content: יח)והובא ברש"י ז"ל וילכו ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ד' את משה ואהרן כן עשו, וכי כבר עשו והלא מראש חודש נאמר להם מצוה זו ולא עשו עד בעשור לחודש, אלא מכיון שקבלו עליהם מעלה עליהם כאילו עשו, ומהו כן עשו אף משה ואהרן כן עשו, וצ"ב דמאי למימרא, וכי ס"ד שמשה ואהרן לא קיימו ח"ו מצות השי"ת ולא עשו הפסח אשר צוה השי"ת לכל ישראל, ולמה צריך יתור קרא להורות על זה.
translation: 18) And it is brought in Rashi, may his memory be blessed, "And the children of Israel went and did as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron; so they did." But did they already do it? Wasn't this command given to them from the beginning of the month, and they did not do it until the tenth of the month? Rather, since they accepted upon themselves, it is as if they had done it. And what does it mean "so they did"? Even Moses and Aaron did so. And it is difficult to understand what this is coming to teach us. Is it possible to think that Moses and Aaron did not fulfill, Heaven forbid, the commandments of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and did not perform the Passover as commanded by the Holy One, Blessed be He, to all of Israel? And why is there a need for an extra verse to indicate this?
summary: The passage discusses the concept of intention and spiritual elevation in fulfilling commandments, highlighting that the Israelites' acceptance of the mitzvah of Passover, even before its actual performance, is considered as if they had already fulfilled it. It emphasizes that both Moses and Aaron also adhered to God's command, reinforcing the idea that spiritual readiness and commitment can elevate one's status in the eyes of God. The text questions the necessity of reiterating that Moses and Aaron fulfilled the commandment, suggesting a deeper understanding of their spiritual role and the importance of intention in religious observance.

passage_content: טרםשנבוא אל הביאור נקדים לפרש מאמר פלא בדברי חז"ל בסנהדרין (קי"א ע"א) עה"פ (זכרי' י"ג) והי' בכל הארץ נאם ד' פי שנים בה יכרתו יגועו והשלישית יותר בה, והבאתי את השלישית באש וצרפתים כצרוף את הכסף ובחנתים כבחון את הזהב וגו' (והוא נבואה על גאולה העתידה וחבלי משיח), אמר ריש לקיש שלישי של שם, פרש"י ששני חלקים של כל העולם יהיו נכרתים, וחלק שלישי יוותר בה, ואיזהו חלק שלישי, כל שלישיות שיש לשלש אנו משלשין, שמנח נפרדו כל העולם וג' בנים היו לו, הרי שליש בניו הוא שם, ושלישי של שם הוא ארפכשד, ושלישי של ארפכשד שהי' אברהם מבני בניו יוותר וכל העולם יכרת, ולדברי ר"ל נמצאו ישראל מתמעטין ביותר ושמא יהיו נכללין בפי שנים אשר יכרתו, א"ל ר' יוחנן לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת להו הכי, פרש"י לא ניחא להקב"ה שאתה ממעט אותם כ"כ, אלא אפי' שלישית של נח דהיינו מכל ב"נ ומכל העולם כולו יוותר השליש, וכל ישראל ישארו ואם אין ישראל מרובין כ"כ, להיות אחד משליש העולם, יהיו הגרים וחסידי עובד כוכבים משלימין לשליש עיי"ש.
translation: Before we come to the explanation, we will precede with a wondrous statement from the words of our Sages in Sanhedrin (91a) regarding the verse (Zechariah 13:8) "And it shall be in all the land, says the Lord, two parts therein shall be cut off and die, but the third part shall be left therein. And I will bring the third part through the fire and will refine them as silver is refined and will test them as gold is tested," etc. (and this is a prophecy about the future redemption and the birth pangs of the Messiah). Rish Lakish said: "The third part refers to Shem." Rashi explains that two parts of the entire world will be cut off, and a third part will remain. And what is this third part? All thirds that we have, we divide. Since Noah separated the entire world and had three sons, a third of his sons is Shem, and the third of Shem is Arpachshad, and the third of Arpachshad, who was Abraham from his grandchildren, will remain, while the entire world will be cut off. According to Rish Lakish, it turns out that Israel is diminishing greatly, and perhaps they will be included in the two parts that will be cut off. Rabbi Yochanan said to him: "It is not pleasing to the Holy One, Blessed be He, that you diminish them so much." Rather, even the third of Noah, meaning from all the children of man and from the entire world, the third will remain, and all of Israel will remain. And if Israel is not so numerous, to be one of the third of the world, the converts and the pious among the idol worshippers will complete the third, as stated there.
summary: The passage discusses a prophetic interpretation of Zechariah 13:8, focusing on the fate of humanity during the Messianic era. It highlights that two-thirds of the world will be cut off, while a third will remain, symbolizing the survival of the Jewish people. Rish Lakish suggests that this third includes the descendants of Shem, specifically through Arpachshad and Abraham, emphasizing the enduring nature of Israel. Rabbi Yochanan counters that even if the Jewish population is small, they will be joined by righteous converts and pious non-Jews to fulfill the remaining third, underscoring the inclusivity of divine salvation.

passage_content: עודפליגי ר"י ור"ל על משה"כ (בנבואת ירמי' ג') שובו בנים שובבים נאם ד' כי אנכי בעלתי אתכם, ולקחתי אתכם אחד מעיר ושנים ממשפחה, והבאתי אתכם ציון ונתתי לכם רועים כלבי ורעו אתכם דעה והשכל, אמר ר"ל דברים ככתבן, פרש"י שלא ימלטו אלא אחד מעיר וב' ממשפחה ח"ו, א"ל ר"י לא ניחאלי' למרייהו דאמרת עלייהו הכי, אלא א' מעיר מזכה כל העיר כולה, ושנים ממשפחה מזכין כל המשפחה כולה, פרש"י בשביל חסיד א' שיש בעיר אקח את כל העיר כולה, ובסוף הסוגיא שם, תניא ר' סימאי אומר נאמר ולקחתי אתכם לי לעם ונאמר והבאתי אתכם, מקיש יציאתן ממצרים לביאתן לארץ, מה ביאתן לארץ שנים מס' רבוא, פרש"י שלא נשתיירו אלא יהושע וכלב מכל דור המדבר, אף יציאתן ממצרים שנים מס' רבוא, (פרש"י שהשאר מתו כולן בג' ימי אפילה) אמר רבא וכן לימות המשיח שנאמר וענתה שמה כימי נעורי' וכיום עלותה מארץ מצרים, פרש"י ז"ל וכן לימות המשיח שלא ישארו מכל ס' רבוא אלא שנים עכ"ד ז"ל
translation: They further disputed Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Elazar regarding the verse (in the prophecy of Jeremiah 3): "Return, wayward children, says the Lord, for I have married you," and "I took you one from a city and two from a family, and I brought you to Zion, and I gave you shepherds according to My heart, and they will shepherd you with knowledge and understanding." Rabbi Elazar said the words are to be taken literally, explaining that they will not be saved except for one from a city and two from a family, Heaven forbid. Rabbi Yochanan replied that it does not follow from what you said, but rather that one from a city merits the entire city, and two from a family merit the entire family, as it is explained that because of one righteous person in the city, I will take the entire city. And at the end of the discussion there, it is taught that Rabbi Simai says: "It is stated, 'And I took you to be My people,' and it is stated, 'And I brought you,' linking their exodus from Egypt to their entry into the land. Just as their entry into the land was two out of hundreds of thousands, as it is explained that only Joshua and Caleb remained from the entire generation of the desert, so too their exodus from Egypt was two out of hundreds of thousands" (as it is explained that the rest all died during the three days of darkness). Rava said, "And so it will be in the days of the Messiah," as it is stated, "And it will answer there as in the days of your youth and as in the day you went up from the land of Egypt," explaining that in the days of the Messiah, there will not remain from the six hundred thousand except for two, thus concludes the explanation.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption and the significance of individual righteousness within the collective. Rabbi Yochanan emphasizes that one righteous person can merit salvation for an entire city, while two righteous individuals can uplift their entire family. This idea is linked to the exodus from Egypt and the future redemption, suggesting that just as only a few were saved from the generation of the desert, so too in the Messianic era, only a small remnant will remain. The text highlights the profound impact of individual piety on communal destiny in the context of divine mercy and redemption.

passage_content: והנההמאמר הזה מרפסן איגרא, וכל השומע תצלנה אזניו, והיתכן שלא ישארו ח"ו לימות המשיח אלא ב' מס' רבוא, וא"א להעלות על הדעת שיהיו דברי רבא הנ"ל ככתבן וכפשוטן, ויותר תמיה על מ"ש המהרש"א וז"ל ואולי שאלו השנים שנשארו שהם כלב מיהודה ויהושע מאפרים, הוא רמז על הב' דלעתיד משיח בן דוד מיהודה ומשיח בן יוסף מאפרים עכ"ל, ואיך יעלה על הדעת שלא ישארו לעתיד מישראל כ"א תרין משיחין, ובודאי לא ניחא לי' למרייהו למימר הכי.
translation: And behold, this statement is a great wonder, and all who hear it will have their ears tingle. Is it possible that there will only remain, Heaven forbid, two out of six hundred thousand for the days of the Messiah? It is impossible to conceive that the words of Rava mentioned above should be taken literally and simply. It is even more astonishing regarding what the Maharsha wrote, and I quote: "And perhaps the two that remain, which are Caleb from Judah and Joshua from Ephraim, hint at the two in the future: Messiah son of David from Judah and Messiah son of Joseph from Ephraim." How can it be conceived that there will remain in the future from Israel only two Messiahs? Certainly, it would not be pleasing to them to say such a thing.
summary: The passage discusses the seemingly paradoxical idea that only two individuals, representing the Messianic figures of Mashiach ben David from Judah and Mashiach ben Yosef from Ephraim, might remain for the Messianic era. It questions the interpretation of earlier sages, suggesting that it is implausible to believe that such a limited number of individuals would survive to witness the redemption. The text reflects a deep concern for the continuity of the Jewish people and the fulfillment of Messianic prophecies, emphasizing the importance of a broader survival beyond just two figures.

passage_content: עודקשה דכמו דפליג ר' יוחנן בב' פלוגתות הנ"ל, ואמר דלא ניחא לי' למרייהו למימר הכי, מכ"ש דהו"ל לאפלוגי הכא, ומדוע אין כאן חולק על דברי רבא שלא ישארו כ"א שנים מס' רבוא, שהוא פחות הרבה מחשבון השלישית שאמר ר"ל, ואף מחשבון א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה, ואיך יתכן שכ"ע יודו לדברי רבא ואין חולק על דבריו כלל.
translation: It is further difficult, as Rabbi Yochanan argues in the two aforementioned disputes, and says that it is not pleasing to him for them to say this, how much more so that they should argue here. And why is there no one who disputes the words of Rava, that no one should remain for more than a hundred years, which is much less than the calculation of the third that R' Elazar said, and even less than the calculation of one in a city and two from a family? And how is it possible that everyone would agree with the words of Rava and there is no one who disputes his words at all?
summary: The passage discusses a disagreement among scholars regarding the interpretation of certain teachings, particularly focusing on Rabbi Yochanan's reluctance to engage in disputes over specific points. It emphasizes the consensus on Rabbi's assertion that no more than a certain number of years should remain, which is significantly less than the calculations proposed by others. This highlights the importance of unity in understanding divine teachings and the acknowledgment of authoritative voices within the tradition, reflecting a deeper theological commitment to harmony and consensus in Jewish thought.

passage_content: עודקשה עמ"ש המהרש"א ז"ל דדברי ר"ל א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה דברים ככתבן. לשיטתו אזיל דס"ל שלישית של שם ויתמעטו ישראל ח"ו, ור' יוחנן אזיל לשיטתו שלא יתמעטו עיי"ש, ואינו מובן דבריו דלפי האמת אין זה לשיטתו, ואדרבה דבריו סותרין דברי עצמו, דאיך שיהי' חשבון של שלישית הוא הרבה יותר מא' בעיר וב' ממשפחה, ומ"ש ר"ל א' מעיר וב' ממשפחה אינו בסוג חשבון שלישית לד"ה, ולפעמים לא יעלה אפי' לא' מני אלף, ואיך אפשר שיחלוק ר"ל על דברי עצמו.
translation: It is further difficult regarding what the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, said that the words of R' Eliezer are one from a city and two from a family, as they are written. According to his reasoning, he holds that a third of them will diminish Israel, Heaven forbid, while R' Yochanan follows his reasoning that they will not diminish, as stated there. His words are not understood, for in truth this is not according to his reasoning; on the contrary, his words contradict themselves. For however the calculation of a third may be, it is much more than one from a city and two from a family. And what R' Eliezer says, one from a city and two from a family, is not in the category of the calculation of a third according to the law, and at times it may not even reach one in a thousand. How is it possible that R' Eliezer would argue against his own words?
summary: The passage discusses a theological debate regarding the population of Israel, referencing the views of the Maharsha and Rabbi Yochanan. It highlights the tension between the idea of a diminishing Jewish population and the belief that it will not decrease. The author critiques the Maharsha's reasoning, suggesting that his interpretation contradicts itself, as the calculations of population decline do not align with the more optimistic view of Rabbi Yochanan. This reflects a deeper Hasidic theme of faith in divine providence and the resilience of the Jewish people despite challenges.

passage_content: וע"קדאין החשבון מכוון ומדוקדק משה"כ א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה, דהרי בעיר ימצא עפ"י רוב הרבה משפחות, ויספיק לדברי ר' יוחנן הגנת צדיק א' על כל העיר ועל הרבה משפחות שבתוכה, ואיך משפחה שעפ"י הרוב אנשי' מועטין מעיר, יצטרכו ב' צדיקים להגין עליהם שימלטו בזכותם, ואינו מובן עפ"י פשוטו והסברא יורה ההיפך, וראיתי שהרי"ף בעין יעקב הקשה כן, ותירץ דהכי קאמר דא' מגין על כל העיר ועל כל המשפחות אשר בתוכה, אבל אם חלק ממשפחתו בעיר אחרת אין כח זכותו מגין על אלו שהם בעיר אחרת, ע"כ צ"ל להיות שנים, דזכות הצדיק השני מגין על אלו שהם בעיר האחרת עכ"ד. אבל תירוצו דחוק קצת דלפי"ז עיקר חסר מן הספר, דהו"ל לר' יוחנן למימר דא' ממשפחה מזכה כל המשפחה כולה לאותם שהם בתוך העיר, אבל לאותם שהם מחוץ לעיר צריך להגנתם זכות עוד צדיק, ואינו מוזכר כלל תוך העיר וחוץ לעיר במימרא דר' יוחנן וצ"ב.
translation: And the calculation is precise and meticulous as it is written: one in the city and two from the family, for in the city, according to the majority, there will be many families, and it suffices for the words of Rabbi Yochanan that the merit of one righteous person protects the entire city and many families within it. And how can it be that a family, which according to the majority has few people from the city, would need two righteous individuals to protect them so that they may be saved through their merit? This is not understood according to its simple meaning, and reason would indicate the opposite. I have seen that the Rif in Ein Yaakov posed this question and answered that this is what he means: that one protects the entire city and all the families within it, but if part of his family is in another city, his merit does not protect those who are in another city. Therefore, there must be two, for the merit of the second righteous person protects those who are in the other city. Thus far his words. However, his answer is somewhat strained, for according to this, a fundamental point is missing from the text. Rabbi Yochanan should have said that one from the family merits the entire family for those who are within the city, but for those who are outside the city, another righteous person's merit is needed for their protection, and the distinction between within the city and outside the city is not mentioned at all in Rabbi Yochanan's statement, and this requires further investigation.
summary: The passage discusses the protective power of a righteous individual (tzaddik) over a community, emphasizing that one tzaddik can defend an entire city and its families. It raises a question about the necessity of multiple tzaddikim for families located outside the city, suggesting that their merit does not extend beyond their immediate locale. The text critiques the explanation provided by the Rif, arguing that it lacks clarity regarding the distinction between those within and outside the city. Ultimately, it highlights the interconnectedness of community and righteousness in Hasidic thought, where the merit of the tzaddik is crucial for collective protection.

passage_content: ועודדאפי' לפי תירוצו של הרי"ף לא יונח אלא לדברי ר' יוחנן, אבל לפי דברי ר"ל ורב כהנא דס"ל דברים ככתבן, וכפרש"י שלא ימלטו ח"ו אלא א' מעיר וב' ממשפחה, הרי אין חשבון זה צודק, דאיך יתכן דמעיר שאנשי' מרוביםלא ימלט אלא א', וממשפחה ימלטו שנים, ואינו מובן המאמר כפשוטו כלל, ובודאי שאין פירוש המאמר הזה כפי פשטות המשמעות.
translation: And according to his explanation of the Rif, it will only be established according to the words of Rabbi Yochanan, but according to the words of Rabbi Levi and Rav Kahana, who hold that things are as they are written, and as Rashi explains that they will not be saved, Heaven forbid, except for one from a city and two from a family, this calculation is not correct. For how is it possible that from a city where there are many people, only one will be saved, and from a family, two will be saved? The statement is not understood literally at all, and certainly, the interpretation of this statement is not according to the simple meaning of the text.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of a Talmudic statement regarding the survival of individuals from a city and a family, highlighting the inconsistency in the numbers presented. It emphasizes that according to certain authorities, the literal understanding of the text is flawed, suggesting a deeper, non-literal meaning. This reflects a Hasidic approach to scripture, where the surface meaning may conceal profound theological insights that require contemplation and interpretation beyond the obvious. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of understanding the spiritual implications behind the text rather than adhering strictly to its literal interpretation.

passage_content: ועודדאיך אפשר דכללא כייל ר"ל, לחשוב כל העיירות בדרגא חדא, וכל המשפחות בדרגא חדא. והחוש והמציאות יכחיש דבר זה, דישנם הרבה עיירות שאין בהם אפי' א' שומר תומ"צ בעו"ה, וישנם עיירות שנמצא בהם לאלפים שומרי תומ"צ, וכן לא כל המשפחות שוות, ואיך אפ"ל שמכל עיר ימלט רק א' ומכל משפחה ב'. גם לא הגביל ר"ל מדת העיר כמה יהי' בה וישאר ממנה א', וכמה יהי' המשפחה שישאר ממנה ב' וצ"ב.
translation: And I wonder how it is possible to generalize, so to speak, to consider all the towns as one level, and all the families as one level. The senses and reality contradict this statement, as there are many towns that do not have even one observer of Torah and mitzvot, God forbid, while there are towns that have thousands of observers of Torah and mitzvot. Likewise, not all families are equal, so how can it be said that from each town only one will be saved and from each family two? Furthermore, it does not specify, so to speak, the measure of the town, how many will remain from it as one, and how many will remain from the family as two, and so on.
summary: המחבר מדגיש את הקושי בהבנה של מושג הכלליות בהקשר של הצלת נפשות, כאשר הוא מצביע על הפערים בין ערים ומשפחות שונות מבחינת שמירת תורה ומצוות. הוא שואל כיצד ניתן לקבוע כי מכל עיר תצא נפש אחת ומכל משפחה שתיים, כאשר המציאות מראה שיש ערים עם אלפים שומרי מצוות ואחרות שאין בהם אף אחד. בכך הוא מציע שההבנה של כלליות אינה יכולה להתבסס על מדדים חיצוניים, אלא יש להבין את הקשר הפנימי והעמוק בין הנפשות והקב"ה.

passage_content: וראיתישהרד"ק ז"ל יש לו פי' אחר בפסוק הנ"ל, וכתב שקאי על עיירות הגוים ועל משפחות הגוים, וז"ל א' מעיר אפי' יהודי א' יהי' לבדו בעיר מערי הגוים משם אקחנו, וכן אם יהיו אפי' שניםלבדם באומה אחת של גוים משם אקחם, ואומה נקרא משפחה כמשה"כ ואם משפחת מצרים לא תעלה, וכמ"ש לכל משפחות ממלכות צפונה עכ"ד, אולם גם על פירושו קשה דלמה הגביל בעיר סכום הא' ובמשפחה אמר שנים, ובודאי שלא יודח ממנו ית' נידח, ואפי' א' מישראל שיהי' באומה של גוים יקבצהו השי"ת משם, ועוד דאין סוגית הגמ' סובל פירושו כלל, דא"כ למה אמר ר' יוחנן לא ניחא למרייהו וכו', וע"כ שאין סוגית הגמ' אזלא כפירושו.
translation: And you will see that the Radak, may his memory be blessed, has another interpretation on the above verse, and he wrote that it refers to the cities of the nations and to the families of the nations. He said that even if there is one Jew alone in a city among the cities of the nations, from there I will take him, and likewise, if there are even two alone in one nation of the nations, from there I will take them. And a nation is called a family, as it is written, "And if the family of Egypt does not ascend," and as it is said, "to all the families of the kingdoms of the north," thus far his words. However, even according to his interpretation, it is difficult why he limited it to one in a city and said two in a family, and certainly, no one will be cast away from Him, and even if there is one from Israel who is in a nation of the nations, the Holy One, blessed be He, will gather him from there. Furthermore, the topic of the Gemara does not support his interpretation at all, for if so, why did Rabbi Yochanan say, "It is not pleasant for them," etc., and therefore the topic of the Gemara does not go according to his interpretation.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of a biblical verse regarding the gathering of Jews from among the nations. It highlights the idea that even a single Jew, or two Jews together, can be redeemed from their exile, emphasizing God's commitment to not abandon any of His people. The text critiques the limitations of a specific interpretation that distinguishes between individuals and families, asserting that God's ability to gather His people transcends such distinctions. Ultimately, it underscores the belief in divine providence and the assurance of redemption for every Jew, regardless of their circumstances.

passage_content: ורש"יז"ל פי' בזכרי' פסוק הנ"ל והבאתי את השלישית באש, דקאי על גירי האומות, שיסבלו בצרת חבלי משיח ובמלחמות גוג ומגוג עם ישראל, ומשם יבחנו אם גרי אמת הם, והרבה מן המתיהדים תחלה ישובו לסורם ויתחברו עם גוג, ולפי"ז לא קאי השלישית על ישראל, ואפשר דישראל ישארו כולם חיים וקיימים, אבל הצירוף יהי' בגירי האומות. אמנם שיטת הגמ' לא אזלא כפי פירושו, ועדיין דברי הגמ' הנ"ל צ"ב.
translation: And the Rashi, may his memory be for a blessing, explains in Zechariah the above verse, and I brought the third one in fire, which refers to the converts of the nations, who will suffer in the tribulations of the birth pangs of the Messiah and in the wars of Gog and Magog with Israel. From there, it will be tested whether they are true converts, and many of those who initially become Jewish will return to their former ways and join with Gog. According to this, the third one does not refer to Israel, and it is possible that all of Israel will remain alive and enduring, but the joining will be among the converts of the nations. However, the approach of the Gemara does not align with his interpretation, and the words of the aforementioned Gemara still require clarification.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the concept of the "third" group mentioned in the context of the trials of the Messianic era and the wars of Gog and Magog. He suggests that this group refers to the converts from the nations who will suffer during these tribulations, and their true commitment to Judaism will be tested. Many who initially convert may revert to their former ways and align with Gog, implying that the Jewish people may remain intact and survive these challenges. The author notes a divergence from the Talmudic interpretation, indicating a need for further exploration of these ideas.
