passage_content: ואפשרלומר הערה בדרך רמז על משה"כ א' בעיר ושנים במשפחה, עפימ"ש הרד"ק ז"ל (ירמי' ה') עה"פ שוטטו בחוצות ירושלים וראו נא ודעו ובקשו ברחובותי' אם תמצאו איש, אם יש עושה משפט מבקש אמונה וגו' והקשה הרד"ק ז"ל כי הנה היו בירושלים חסידים ועבדי ד' כמבואר בפסוקים בכ"מ, ואיך אמר ירמי' אם תמצאו איש עושה משפע מבקש אמונה, ופי' אדוני אבי ז"ל כי ירמי' אמר בחוצות ירושלים ואמר ברחובותי', כי החסידים שהיו בירושלים היו מתחבאים בבתיהם, ולא היו יכולים להתראות ברחובות ובחוצות מפני הרשעים עיי"ש, וכן פי' השלה"ק שלכן אמר הכתוב בחוצות וברחובות, כי אלמלי לא היו יראים מן העם לעשות משפט ולבקש אמונה ברחובה של עיר, אז היו בכוחם להגין עליהם וז"ש ירמי' שוטטו בחוצות ירושלים ובקשו ברחובותי' אם תמצאו שם איש עושה משפט מבקש אמונה ואסלח לכל העיר בזכותם. וכעי"ז פירש האבן עזרא בפ' וירא עה"פ אם אמצא בסדום חמשים צדיקים בתוך העיר ונשאתי לכל המקום בעבורם, וז"ל וטעם בתוך העיר, שהם יראים את השם בפרהסיא, וכן שוטטו בחוצות ירושלים עכ"ל, (והארכתי בזה בהקדמת ספרי ויואל משה עמוד ט"ו) ולזה לא התפלל אברהם אלא על אותן הצדיקים שהן בצדקתן בתוך העיר, אבל באלו שיראים להגיד האמת ולהוכיח בשער בת רבים, ידע אברהם שאין בהם כח הגנה להיות העיר נמלט בזכותם, ולא ניסה להתפלל בזכותם, ומילתא דמסתבר הוא, כי אם אין מתקשר עמהם להטיב דרכיהם אין זכותו מצטרף להגין עליהם ג"כ. ולפי"ז אפשר לומר בכוונת חז"ל דא' מהעיר מזכה כל העיר כולה, היינו בצדיק שהוא בתוך העיר ומוכיח בשער בת רבים, אז יש לו כח הגנה להציל את כל העיר כמ"ש הרד"ק ז"ל, ושנים ממשפחה מיירי בצדיקים שמוכיחים רק לבני משפחתם, ואין להם התקשרות עם בני העיר להטיב מעשיהם, ע"כ אין בהם כח הגנה להציל את כל העיר רק את בני משפחתם, גם כח זכותם מועטת משל הראשונים, וצריך זכות שני צדיקים להגין על בני המשפחה, ואם גם בני משפחתם לא יוכיחו, אין להם כח הגנה כלל שיצילו אחרים בזכותם, כ"ז אפשר לומר בדרך רמז בגמרא הנ"ל.
translation: And it is possible to say a note in a hint regarding the verse, "One in the city and two in the family," according to what the Radak, may his memory be blessed, says (Jeremiah 5) on the verse "Roam the streets of Jerusalem and see now and know and seek in its squares if you can find a man, if there is one who does justice, who seeks faith," and the Radak asked, may his memory be blessed, that behold, there were pious ones and servants of God in Jerusalem, as is explained in the verses everywhere, and how did Jeremiah say, "If you can find a man who does justice, who seeks faith?" My father, may his memory be blessed, explained that Jeremiah spoke in the streets of Jerusalem and said in its squares, because the pious ones who were in Jerusalem were hiding in their homes, and they could not be seen in the streets and squares because of the wicked, as is noted there. And so the Shelah HaKadosh explained that is why the verse said in the streets and in the squares, for if they were not afraid of the people to do justice and seek faith in the public square, then they would have the power to defend them. And this is what Jeremiah meant when he said, "Roam the streets of Jerusalem and seek in its squares if you can find there a man who does justice, who seeks faith, and I will forgive the entire city for their sake." And similarly, the Ibn Ezra explained in Parashat Vayera on the verse, "If I find in Sodom fifty righteous within the city, I will spare the whole place for their sake," and he said, "And the reason for 'within the city' is that they fear the Name in public," and so "Roam the streets of Jerusalem." I have elaborated on this in the introduction to my book "Yoel Moshe," page 15. Therefore, Abraham did not pray except for those righteous ones who are righteous within the city, but for those who are afraid to speak the truth and to reprove in the public square, Abraham knew that they do not have the power to defend for the city to be saved for their sake, and he did not attempt to pray for their sake. And it is reasonable to say that if one does not connect with them to improve their ways, their merit does not combine to defend them either. According to this, it is possible to say in the intention of our Sages that "one from the city" merits the entire city, meaning a righteous person who is within the city and reproves in the public square, then he has the power to defend to save the entire city, as the Radak, may his memory be blessed, said. And "two from the family" refers to the righteous who only reprove their family members, and they do not have a connection with the people of the city to improve their deeds; therefore, they do not have the power to defend to save the entire city, only their family members. Also, their merit is lesser than that of the first ones, and two righteous ones are needed to defend the family members. And if even their family members do not reprove, they have no power to defend at all to save others for their sake. All this can be said as a hint in the aforementioned Gemara.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of righteous individuals and their ability to protect their communities through their actions and faith. It emphasizes that true righteousness requires public acknowledgment and advocacy for justice, as exemplified by the prophets Jeremiah and Abraham. The text suggests that a single righteous person in a city can merit protection for the entire community, while those who only advocate within their families lack the same power to shield the broader society. Ultimately, the strength of one's righteousness is linked to their willingness to confront wrongdoing openly.

passage_content: וליישבסוגית הגמ' הנ"ל בדרך קרוב לפשוטו אפ"ל, בהקדם מ"ש בגמ' במס' שבת (ס"ג ע"א) לא יצא האיש לא בסייף ולא בקשת ולא ברומח ואם יצא חייב חטאת, ר"א אומר תכשיטין הן לו, וחכ"א אינן אלא לגנאי וכו', ופי' בגמ' מ"ט דר"א דאמר תכשיטין הן לו, דכתיב חגור חרבך על ירך גבור הודך והדרך (תהלים מ"ה) א"ל רב כהנא ההוא בדברי תורה כתיב, פי' דהפסוק מיירי בד"ת כפרש"י שם: ולא בשבח החרב והגבור ואין ראי' מכאן לדברי ר"א, א"ל אין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו, א"ר כהנא כד הוינא בר תמני סרי שנין והו' גמירנא לכולי' הש"ס ולא הוי ידענא דאין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו עד השתא וכו'. וכתב הענף יוסף כי בודאי חלילה לומר שבדורות תנאים ואמוראים לא הי' ידוע להם דבר פשוט כזה דאין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו, ואפי' תשב"ר יודעים אותו, וחס לן מלחשוב כזאת, אלא כך פירושו שזה לא ידע שאף במקום שנראה לעין שהכתוב מדבר רק דרך חידה ומשל כמו כאן חגור חרבך על ירך גבור הודך והדרךשגלוי וברור לכל שאין הכתוב מספר בשבחו של בעל מלחמה, ועכ"ח הדרש עיקר שהכתוב מדבר בד"ת, וע"כ הקשה רב כהנא על דברי ר"א שאין ראי' מכאן על פשוטן של דברים שהחרב הוא תכשיט, וסבר לעקור הפסוק לגמרי מפשטי'. ע"ז השיבו שאין המקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו, אף שהדרש הוא העיקר כאן בכוונת הפסוק, אבל הכתוב לא יביא משל וחידה מה שאינו אמיתי בפשטן של דברים וכמ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל בהקדמתו לס' המורה, תפוחי זהב במשכיות כסף דבר דיבור על אופניו, שאף המשכיות שהוא המשל הוא ג"כ כסף צרוף עיי"ש.
translation: And to explain the Gemara's discussion mentioned above in a way close to its simple meaning, it can be said, by first mentioning what is said in the Gemara in Tractate Shabbat (S.G. 71a): A man does not go out with a sword, nor with a bow, nor with a spear, and if he goes out, he is liable for a sin-offering. Rabbi Eliezer says they are ornaments for him, and the Sages say they are only for disgrace, etc. The Gemara explains the reason of Rabbi Eliezer, who says they are ornaments for him, as it is written, "Gird your sword upon your thigh, O mighty one, your glory and your majesty" (Psalms 45). Rav Kahana said to him, "That is written in the context of Torah," meaning that the verse deals with Torah, as Rashi explains there: and not in praise of the sword and the warrior, and there is no proof from here to the words of Rabbi Eliezer. He said, "A verse does not depart from its simple meaning." Rav Kahana said, "When I was a boy of eighteen years, I learned the entire Talmud and did not know that a verse does not depart from its simple meaning until now," etc. And the author of the Yefeh Toar wrote that it is certainly a disgrace to say that in the generations of the Tannaim and Amoraim they did not know such a simple thing that a verse does not depart from its simple meaning, and even the Teshubot Rabbah know it, and may it be far from us to think such a thing. Rather, this is its interpretation: that he did not know that even in a place where it seems to the eye that the text speaks only through riddle and parable, like here, "Gird your sword upon your thigh, O mighty one," it is clear and evident to all that the text is not speaking in praise of the warrior. And thus, the main interpretation is that the text speaks of Torah, and therefore Rav Kahana challenged the words of Rabbi Eliezer, that there is no proof from here to the simple meaning of things that the sword is an ornament. He intended to uproot the verse entirely from its simple meaning. To this, they responded that a verse does not depart from its simple meaning, even though the interpretation is the main point here in the intention of the verse, but the text will not bring a parable and riddle that is not true in the simple meaning of things, as the Rambam, may his memory be blessed, wrote in the introduction to the Guide for the Perplexed, "Apples of gold in settings of silver, a word spoken in its proper context," that even the settings, which are the parable, are also pure silver, see there.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of a verse from Psalms regarding the sword as a metaphorical adornment, contrasting the views of Rabbi Eliezer and the sages. Rabbi Eliezer sees the sword as a legitimate ornament, while the sages argue it is a source of disgrace. The dialogue emphasizes that scriptural interpretation must remain true to its plain meaning, even when deeper, metaphorical insights are drawn, reflecting a fundamental Hasidic principle that the divine message is layered yet rooted in truth. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of balancing literal and allegorical readings of scripture in understanding its theological implications.

passage_content: וכ"כהחת"ס סופר זלל"ה בדרשותיו לשבה"ג (ח"ב דף רנ"ג ע"ב) בפי' דברי הגמ' הנ"ל, דכ"ע לא פליגי בין ר"א ובין רבנן דהדרשה עיקר בהאי קרא, וחגור חרבך על ירך בדברי תורה נאמר, אלא דר"א ס"ל דיתפרש המקרא גם עפ"י פשוטו, ומדבר במלך המשיח, דמלבד כח תורתו יהי' ג"כ חגור חרב כגבור ואיש מלחמה ומפליא גבורות,ואימתו מוטל על האומות מחמת גבורתו, שלא יאמרו אין כוחו אלא בפה, אבל לא יצטרך לחרבו, והוא חגור על יריכו לכבודו, וברוח שפתיו ימית רשע, ועכ"פ נשמע דתכשיטין הם אף לע"ל, וחכמים אומרים דגנאי הוא לו וא"א לומר פסוק זה עפ"י פשוטו, ורק הדרש עיקר כאן ובד"ת כתיב, א"ל אעפ"כ אין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו אף דהדרש עיקר כאן, אבל גם פשוטו של מקרא מורה דרך התורה ומיני' לא תזוע עכת"ד הח"ס זלל"ה.
translation: And the "Chasam Sofer" (may his memory be blessed) in his sermons on the "Shulchan Aruch" (Part 2, page 253b) explains the words of the aforementioned Gemara, that all agree, both Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis, that the interpretation is primary in this verse, "Gird your sword upon your thigh," as it is said in the words of Torah. However, Rabbi Eliezer holds that the verse should also be interpreted according to its simple meaning, and it speaks of the Messiah, for besides the strength of his Torah, he will also be girded with a sword like a mighty man and a warrior, and his might will be feared by the nations because of his strength, so that they will not say that his power is only in speech, but that he will not need his sword, and it is girded upon his thigh for his honor. "And by the breath of his lips he will slay the wicked," and in any case, it is heard that these are ornaments even for the World to Come. And the sages say that it is a disgrace for him, and it is impossible to interpret this verse according to its simple meaning, and only the interpretation is primary here, and in the words of Torah it is written. He said to him, nevertheless, the verse does not depart from its simple meaning, even though the interpretation is primary here, but also the simple meaning of the verse indicates the way of the Torah, and from it, one should not deviate. Thus is the word of the Chasam Sofer, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the interpretation of a verse regarding the Messiah, emphasizing that while both Rabbi Eliezer and the sages agree on the importance of the drash (interpretation), Rabbi Eliezer believes the verse also conveys a straightforward meaning. He posits that the Messiah will possess both the power of Torah and the might of a warrior, instilling fear in the nations through his strength. In contrast, the sages argue that interpreting the verse literally is inappropriate, asserting that the drash is the primary focus, yet acknowledging that the simple meaning still holds significance in understanding the Torah.

passage_content: אמנםלפעמים מצינו בדברי חז"ל, דמפקי' לי' לקרא מפשטי' לגמרי', כמ"ש ביבמות (דף כ"ד ע"א) והי' הבכור אשר תלד יקום ע"ש אחיו המת לנחלה, אתה אומר לנחלה או אינו אלא לשם, יוסף קורין אותו יוסף, יוחנן קורין אותו יוחנן, נאמר כאן על שם אחיו, ונאמר להלן ע"ש אחיהם יקראו בנחלתם, מה להלן נחלה, אף שם האמור כאן נחלה, אמר רבא אע"ג דבכל התורה אין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו, הכא אתאי גז"ש אפיקתי' מפשטי' לגמרי, ופרש"י שא"צ לקרות לבנו בשם אחיו המת כפשוטו של מקרא. וכן אמרי' ביבמות (י"א ע"ב) לרבנן אחרי אשר הוטמאה האמור במחזיר גרושתו, כיון דאיתעקר מפשוטו לדרוש על סוטה שנסתרה איעקר לגמרי עיי"ש. וכן עין תחת עין קבלו חז"ל שהוא ממון, והוציאוהו מפשוטו של מקרא לגמרי, וכתב האבן עזרא בש"ר סעדי' גאון, לא נוכל לפרש זה הפסוק כמשמעו, כי אם אדם הכה עין חבירו וסרה שלישית אור עיניו איך יתכן שיוכה, מכה כזאת בלי תוס' ומגרעת, ואם אדם עור יעור עיני הפיקח מה יעשה לו, והכלל העולה דלא נוכל לפרש ע"ד מצות התורה פירוש שלם אם לא נסמוך על דברי חז"ל, כי כאשר קבלנו התורה מן האבות, כן קבלנו תורה שבע"פ אין הפרש ביניהם. ואח"כ כתב דפי' הכתוב עין תחת עין, דראוי להיותו עינו תחת עינו אם לא יתן כפרו עכ"ד הראב"ע ז"ל והביא הרמב"ן ז"ל דבריו ונראה שהסכים עמו, וכעי"ז כתב הספורנו דכפי שורת הדין הגמור כך הי' ראוי לענוש מדה כנגד מדה, ובאה הקבלה שישלם ממון בדרך פדי' וכופר עיי"ש. וכן בוקצותה את כפה, קבלו חז"ל להוציאו מפשוטו ולחייבה בממון, וגם שם כתב הראב"ע ז"ל דאם לא תפדה כפה תקוץ, דס"ל דבעיקר הדין כפשוטו של מקרא, אלא שקבלת חז"ל לפדותו בממון כעין כופר.
translation: Indeed, sometimes we find in the words of our Sages that they derive a verse from its simple meaning entirely, as it is stated in Yevamot (24a), "And the firstborn that she bears shall rise up upon the name of his dead brother, to inherit." You say "to inherit," or is it only for the name? Joseph is called Joseph, Yohanan is called Yohanan. It is stated here in the name of his brother, and it is stated elsewhere, "In the name of their brothers they shall be called in their inheritance." Just as there it refers to inheritance, so too here it is referred to as inheritance. Rava said, although throughout the Torah a verse does not depart from its simple meaning, here it comes from a verbal analogy, completely removing it from its simple meaning, and Rashi explains that one does not need to name his son after his deceased brother according to the simple meaning of the verse. Similarly, it is stated in Yevamot (11b) regarding the Rabbis, "After she has been defiled," mentioned in the context of returning a divorced wife, since it has been uprooted from its simple meaning to be interpreted regarding a Sotah who has secluded herself, it is uprooted entirely, as stated there. Likewise, "an eye for an eye" was accepted by our Sages to mean monetary compensation, and they removed it entirely from the simple meaning of the verse. The Aben Ezra wrote in his commentary that we cannot interpret this verse literally, for if a person struck out his friend's eye and a third of his eyesight was lost, how could he be struck in such a way without addition or subtraction? And if a blind person were to blind the eyes of a wise person, what would be done to him? The general principle that arises is that we cannot interpret according to the commandments of the Torah a complete interpretation unless we rely on the words of our Sages, for just as we received the Torah from the Patriarchs, so too we received the Oral Torah; there is no distinction between them. Afterwards, he wrote that the interpretation of the verse "an eye for an eye" is that it is fitting for his eye to be under his eye if he does not pay his compensation. Thus said the Aben Ezra, and the Ramban brought his words and it seems he agreed with him. Similarly, the Sforno wrote that according to the strict letter of the law, it would be appropriate to punish measure for measure, and tradition came that he should pay money as a form of redemption and atonement, as stated there. Likewise, "and if she cuts off her hand," our Sages accepted to remove it from its simple meaning and to obligate her to pay money. There too, the Aben Ezra wrote that if she does not redeem her hand, it will be cut off, for he holds that according to the primary law it is according to the simple meaning of the verse, but the acceptance of our Sages is to redeem it with money, similar to atonement.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that certain biblical verses can be interpreted beyond their literal meaning, as demonstrated by various examples from the Talmud. It emphasizes the importance of the Oral Torah and the teachings of the sages, which provide deeper insights and interpretations that are essential for understanding the written Torah. The text illustrates that while the literal interpretation may suggest one understanding, the rabbinic tradition often reveals a more nuanced application, particularly in matters of justice and compensation. Ultimately, it underscores the unity of the Written and Oral Torah as a cohesive framework for Jewish law and ethics.

passage_content: ועפי"זיבואר אצלינו פלוגתא דר"י ור"ל הנ"ל, דהנה מ"ש ר"ל א' בעיר ושנים ממשפחה דברים ככתבן, זהו פשוטו של מקרא ומשמעות הכתוב כן הוא, ודברי ר' יוחנן שא' מעיר מזכה את כל העיר כולה וב' ממשפחה מזכה את כל בני המשפחה זהו דרשת חז"ל, ומצאתי כן מפורש בפי' מהר"י קרא זלל"ה וז"ל, ולקחתי אתכם א' מעיר וגו' אמר הקב"ה אלו הייתי ממתין שיהיו כל בני הדור צדיקים, לא הי' מדת הדין נותנת שתהיו נגאלין עולמית, אלא בזכות צדיק א' שימצא בעיר ובזכות ב' צדיקים שימצאו במשפחה והבאתי אתכם ציון זה הוא מדרשו, ופשוטו של מקרא אני עתיד ללקט אתכם א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה והבאתי אתכם ציון וכו'
translation: And according to this, we will explain the dispute between Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer mentioned above. Behold, what Rabbi Eliezer said, "One from the city and two from the family, the words are as they are written," this is the simple meaning of the verse and the significance of the text is indeed so. And the words of Rabbi Yochanan, that "one from the city merits for the entire city and two from the family merit for all the members of the family," this is the interpretation of our Sages. I found this explicitly stated in the commentary of Rabbi Yitzchak Karo, may his memory be blessed, and he said: "And I took you, one from the city, etc.," said the Holy One, Blessed be He, "if I were to wait until all the members of the generation were righteous, the attribute of justice would not allow you to be redeemed forever, but rather through the merit of one righteous person found in the city and through the merit of two righteous people found in the family, and I brought you this sign, this is its interpretation. And the simple meaning of the verse is that I will gather you, one from the city and two from the family, and I brought you this sign, etc.
summary: The passage discusses the differing interpretations of a biblical verse by Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Elazar, highlighting the significance of individual righteousness in the context of communal redemption. Rabbi Yochanan emphasizes that one righteous person in a city can merit salvation for the entire city, while two righteous individuals from a family can redeem their entire lineage. This reflects a Hasidic belief in the power of individual piety to influence the collective, suggesting that even a few righteous individuals can invoke divine mercy and facilitate redemption. Ultimately, it underscores the importance of each person's spiritual standing in the broader context of community and divine justice.

passage_content: מבוארדאם ידין הקב"ה אותנו כפי שורת הדין הגמור, לא ימצא זכאי בדינו וראוי להגאל בזכות עצמו כ"א א' מעיר וב' ממשפחה, ומועטין המה אשר יכלו לעמוד נגד דין הקשה, כי החשכות והתגברות כוחות הטומאה יהי' גדול מאוד בדור האחרוןבעוקבתא דמשיחא, ומי יוכל לעמוד בנסיונות הקשים האלו, וזהו פשוטו של מקרא ודברים ככתבן שאמר ר"ל, שלא ימצא אלא א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה שימלטו בזכותן, אבל לא מיירי הכתוב מכריתה ח"ו, וח"ו לומר שהשאר יכרתו, דע"כ גם ר"ל סובר דדרשת חז"ל מוכרח וקיים, דאותו הא' שימצא זכאי יגין על כל העיר והב' יגינו על כל המשפחה, אלא שלא ינצלו השאר בזכות עצמן. ונפק"מ כמ"ש חז"ל דמאן דאכיל דלאו דילי' בהית לאסתכולי' באפי', ואותם שיזכו בזכות עצמן לא יהיו בושים, ויקבלו פני משיח צדקנו והישועה האמיתית בנחת ובשמחה, משא"כ האחרים יהיו בושים מצד מעשיהם, אבל עכ"פ אחרי כל הצירופים ישארו חלק גדול מישראל, ואפי' לר"ל דס"ל דדברים ככתבן ע"כ אית לי' דרשת חז"ל דא' מגין על כל העיר כנ"ל. וכמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בהשגותיו לספר המצות (ש"ב), דלא אמרו חז"ל אין המקרא אלא כפשוטו, אבל אמרו אין המקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו, ויש לו פשוטו ומדרשו, ואינו יוצא מכל א' ויסבול הכתוב את הכל ושניהם אמת עכ"ל.
translation: It is explained that if the Holy One, blessed be He, judges us according to the strict letter of the law, there will not be a righteous person in His judgment who is worthy of redemption by his own merit, except for one from a city and two from a family, and they are few who could stand against the harsh judgment, for the darkness and the strengthening of the forces of impurity will be very great in the last generation, in the footsteps of the Messiah. Who will be able to withstand these difficult trials? This is the simple meaning of the verse and the words as they are written, as it is said, that there will be found only one in a city and two from a family who will be saved by their merit, but the verse does not refer to a cutting off, God forbid, nor to say that the rest will be cut off. Therefore, even R' Eliezer agrees that the interpretation of our Sages is necessary and valid, that the one who is found righteous will protect the entire city and the two will protect the entire family, but the others will not be saved by their own merit. And the practical difference, as our Sages said, is that one who eats and is not of his own will is not to be looked at in the face, and those who will merit by their own merit will not be ashamed, and they will receive the face of our righteous Messiah and the true salvation with ease and joy, whereas the others will be ashamed because of their deeds. However, after all the combinations, a large part of Israel will remain, and even according to R' Eliezer who holds that the words are as they are written, therefore he has the interpretation of our Sages that one protects the entire city as mentioned. And as the Ramban, may his memory be blessed, wrote in his comments on the Book of Commandments (Second Book), that our Sages did not say that the verse is only according to its simple meaning, but they said that the verse does not depart from its simple meaning, and it has its simple meaning and its interpretation, and it does not depart from any one and the text will bear all, and both are true.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that in the final generation before the Messiah, few individuals will be found righteous enough to merit redemption on their own. It emphasizes that while only one from a city and two from a family may be saved, these individuals will protect their communities, highlighting the interconnectedness of merit within the Jewish people. The text underscores the importance of collective responsibility and the idea that those who achieve redemption will do so without shame, while others may face embarrassment due to their actions. Ultimately, it affirms that both the simple meaning of the text and its deeper interpretations coexist, reflecting the complexity of divine justice and mercy.

passage_content: ורבייוחנן ס"ל לא ניחא להו למרייהו דאמרת להו הכי, ובאמת גם ר' יוחנן סובר דפשוטו של מקרא כן הוא כמ"ש ר"ל, ולפי שורת הדין הגמור לא יצאו זכאי כ"א א' מעיר וב' ממשפחה, אבל ס"ל דהדרש עוקר פשוטו של מקרא ומפיק לי' ממשמעותי' לגמרי, ולא ירצה הקב"ה להשתמש בפשוטו של מקרא ולהתנהג ח"ו בדין הקשה, וכמשפרש"י לא ניחא להו למרייהו, לא ניחא להקב"ה שאתה ממעט אותם כ"כ, אלא ידון הקב"ה אותנו במדת הרחמים, ובערך מצב הדור ונסיונות העצומות אשר יהיו בימים ההם יהי' לימוד זכות גדול על ישראל, ואם ימצאו עובדי השי"ת והולכי בדרך האמת למרות הנסיונות הקשים, אע"פ שלא יהיו נקיים לגמרי מחטאים ועונות, כי מי יאמר זכיתי לבי טהרתי מחטאי, אעפ"כ אם ידין הקב"ה אותם במדת הרחמים, חלק גדול מישראל יצאו זכאי בדינם, ויזכו בדין בזכות עצמן, וכמ"ש ז"ל בעין תחת עין שלפי שורת הדין הגמור ראוי להיות כפשוטו, כאשר עשה כן יעשה לו, אלא דחס רחמנא עלי' וקבלו חז"ל שיתן כפרו, ויתקיים פשוטו של מקרא עפ"י דרשתם ז"ל ויהי' עין תחת עין בדרך פדי' וכופר.
translation: And Rabbi Yochanan holds that it is not pleasing to them that you said to them like this, and indeed Rabbi Yochanan also believes that the simple meaning of the verse is as R' Eliezer said. And according to the strict letter of the law, only one from the city and two from the family would be found innocent, but he holds that the interpretation uproots the simple meaning of the verse and derives from its implications entirely. And the Holy One, blessed be He, would not want to use the simple meaning of the verse and to act, Heaven forbid, according to the harsh law, and as Rashi explains, it is not pleasing to them, nor is it pleasing to the Holy One, blessed be He, that you diminish them so much. Rather, the Holy One, blessed be He, will judge us with the measure of mercy, and in relation to the state of the generation and the tremendous trials that will be in those days, there will be a great merit for Israel. And if there are found those who serve the Holy One, blessed be He, and walk in the path of truth despite the difficult trials, even if they are not completely free from sins and transgressions, for who can say, "I have been righteous; I have purified my heart from my sins," nevertheless, if the Holy One, blessed be He, judges them with the measure of mercy, a large portion of Israel will be found innocent in their judgment, and they will merit in judgment through their own merit. And as our Sages of blessed memory said regarding "an eye for an eye," that according to the strict letter of the law it is fitting to be taken literally, as he has done, so shall be done to him, but the Merciful One has compassion on it and our Sages accepted that he should give atonement, and the simple meaning of the verse will be fulfilled according to their interpretation, and it will be "an eye for an eye" in the way of redemption and atonement.
summary: רבי יוחנן סובר כי למרות שפשוטו של מקרא מצביע על דין קשה, הקב"ה מעדיף לנהוג במידת הרחמים ולא להחמיר את הדין על ישראל. הוא מדגיש את החשיבות של לימוד זכות על עם ישראל, במיוחד בימים קשים, כאשר גם אם יש חטאים, הקב"ה יראה את מאמציהם להחזיק בדרך האמת. כך, ייתכן שיצאו זכאים בדינם בזכות רחמי ה' ולא לפי דין פשוט. המושג של "עין תחת עין" מדגיש את העיקרון של פדיון וכפרה, שבו הקב"ה מקבל את כפרת החטאים במקום להחמיר את הדין.

passage_content: וכמו"כלעניננו מודה ר' יוחנן דפשוטו של מקרא הוא כדברי ר"ל, אלא דס"ל דלא יתנהג הקב"ה בדין הקשה וכפי פשוטו של מקרא, אלא ידון את ישראל במדת הרחמים ולפי מצב הדור ונסיונות הקשים, וא"כ יהיו הרבה מישראל הזוכים בדין ומזכין אחרים להיות ניצולים בזכותם, ומ"ש ר' יוחנן א' מעיר מזכה כל העיר ושנים ממשפחה מזכין כל המשפחה, אין החשבון מצומצם דרק א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה יהיו מן המזכין, ובאמת יהיו הרבה בעיר ובמשפחהאשר יזכו בדין ומזכין אחרים להמלט בזכותם, והכתוב להקל בא דיהי' כח ההגנה גדול מאוד וירצה הקב"ה לזכות את ישראל, וע"כ אפילו יהי' רק צדיק אחד בעיר יגין על כל העיר, ובאמת לא יצטרכו כולם אל זכות הא', דרבים יהיו הזוכים בדין ויהיו בכוחם לזכות את האחרים, אלא שהכתוב להפליג בא ועל צד הרחוק כתב א' בעיר, לומר דאפילו בעיר גדולה ויהי' בה צדיק א', יהי' זכותו מספיק להגין על כל העיר, דהקב"ה יהפוך בזכותנו בכל אופן ואופן, כי יראה כי אזלת יד ואפס עצור ועזוב, והנסיונות עצומים וקשים ובערך הנסיונות יהי' נחשב מיעוט עבודתינו להרבה, וכן שנים במשפחה לאו כללא כייל לכל המשפחות כן, דיהיו הרבה במשפחות אשר יזכו להיות מן הזוכים והמזכין, אלא בדרך הפלגה אמר הכתוב כן, שאפילו משפחה היותר גדולה ונחלקת בהרבה עיירות יספיקו לה זכות ב' צדיקים, אבל לאו כללא הוא ולא בא הכתוב לעשות חשבון מצומצם, ובאמת יהיו רבים במשפחה הזוכים לזה, והראי' שלא הגביל הכתוב מדת העיר כמה יהי' גדולה שיספיק לה זכות צדיק א', וכמה יהי' המשפחה אשר יספיק אלי' זכות ב' צדיקים, אלא ודאי שעל צד הרחוק יאמר הכתוב, שבכל אופן שאתה יכול לרחק ולגדל מדת העיר וגודל המשפחה, יספיק אלי' זכות הא' לעיר וב' למשפחה, ואף לא יצטרכו כולם לזכותו, כי יהיו הרבה מן הזוכים בדין לעתיד.
translation: And as for our matter, Rabbi Yochanan agrees that the simple meaning of the verse is as Rabbi Levi said, except that he holds that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not conduct Himself with strict judgment and according to the simple meaning of the verse, but rather judges Israel with the measure of mercy and according to the state of the generation and the difficult trials. Therefore, there will be many among Israel who will merit in judgment and enable others to be saved through their merit. And when Rabbi Yochanan says that one from a city merits for the entire city, and two from a family merit for the entire family, the calculation is not limited to just one in the city and two from the family being among the meriting ones. In truth, there will be many in the city and in the family who will merit in judgment and enable others to escape through their merit. The verse is to emphasize that the power of protection is very great, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, desires to merit Israel. Therefore, even if there is only one righteous person in the city, he will protect the entire city. In truth, not everyone will need to rely on the merit of that one, for many will be meriting in judgment and will have the power to merit others. However, the verse speaks in an exaggerated manner, and on the side of the extreme, it writes one in the city, to say that even in a large city, if there is one righteous person, his merit will be sufficient to protect the entire city, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, will turn in our merit in every way possible, when He sees that there is a lack of strength and no one is holding on or abandoned, and the trials are immense and difficult, and in relation to the trials, our little service will be considered much. Similarly, two in a family is not a general rule applicable to all families, for there will be many in families who will merit to be among the meriting ones. Rather, the verse states this in an exaggerated manner, that even the largest family, which is divided among many towns, will suffice for it the merit of two righteous ones. But it is not a general rule, and the verse does not come to make a limited calculation. In truth, there will be many in the family who will merit this, and the proof is that the verse does not limit the measure of the city to how large it must be for the merit of one righteous person to suffice, nor how large the family must be for the merit of two righteous ones to suffice. Rather, certainly, on the side of the extreme, the verse says that in any case you can distance and increase the measure of the city and the size of the family, the merit of one will suffice for the city and two for the family, and not everyone will need to rely on their merit, for there will be many who will merit in judgment in the future.
summary: The passage emphasizes the concept of divine mercy in judgment, suggesting that God evaluates Israel not solely by strict justice but through compassion, considering the challenges of each generation. It highlights that even a single righteous individual can protect an entire city, and two can safeguard a family, indicating that many will merit salvation and can intercede for others. The text reassures that God's willingness to grant mercy is vast, and the potential for righteousness exists widely among the people, transcending limitations in numbers or circumstances. Ultimately, it conveys a profound hope in the power of collective merit and divine grace.

passage_content: ורישלקיש ס"ל דברים ככתבן ואין מקרא יוצא מידי פשוטו, דגם פשוטו של מקרא קיים,דכפי שורת הדין הגמור לא ימצא זכאי בדינו וראוי להגאל בזכות עצמו, כ"א א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה, ולא הגביל הכתוב לומר באיזה עיר אמרו כן, וכמה יהי' מדת המשפחה, דע"צ הפלגה אמר הכתוב כן, וכמ"ש הפייטן דמצוי הדין אם תמתח, גם שמים בעיניו לא זכו, וע"כ כפי שורת הדין הגמור, כל כך שאתה יכול להגדיל את העיר לא תמצא בה אלא א', וכ"כ שתגדיל מדת המשפחה ואפילו יהי' המשפחה נחלקת בכמה עיירות לא תמצא בה יותר משני צדיקים הזוכים בזכות עצמם, אבל באמת לא יתקיים הדין כן, דחלק גדול יתקיימו וישארו לעתיד, ולא מיירי הכתוב מכריתה ח"ו, וגם ריש לקיש ס"ל דרשת הכתוב דא' מגין על כל העיר וב' על כל המשפחה, אלא שלא יזכו כולם בזכות עצמם, ורק א' מעיר וב' במשפחה יזכו בזכות עצמן.
translation: And Rabbi Shlakesh holds that the words are as they are written, and the scripture does not depart from its simple meaning, for the simple meaning of the scripture exists, that according to the strict letter of the law, one will not find a righteous person in his judgment who is worthy of redemption by his own merit, except for one in a city and two from a family. And the scripture did not limit to say in which city this applies, and how great the measure of the family should be, for due to the degree of separation, the scripture says so, and as the poet wrote, "If you stretch the law, even the heavens in His eyes did not merit." Therefore, according to the strict letter of the law, as much as you can enlarge the city, you will find only one in it, and so too, if you enlarge the measure of the family, even if the family is divided among several towns, you will not find more than two righteous ones who merit by their own merit. But in truth, the law will not be established this way, for a large portion will be established and remain for the future, and the scripture does not speak of destruction, Heaven forbid. And Rabbi Shlakesh holds that the interpretation of the scripture is that one protects the entire city and two protect the entire family, but not all will merit by their own merit, and only one from the city and two from the family will merit by their own merit.
summary: ריש לקיש ס"ל כי הדברים במקרא הם כפשוטם, והדין הגמור מראה שאין אדם זכאי בזכות עצמו אלא רק אחד מעיר ושניים ממשפחה. עם זאת, הוא מדגיש שהמציאות אינה מתיישבת תמיד עם הדין, וכי רבים יזכו בזכותם בעתיד. הכתוב אינו מתייחס למצב של כריתה, אלא מציע שהצדיקים יזכו בזכות עצמם, אך לא כולם. זה מבטא את הרעיון שהצדיקות והזכויות אינן תמיד נראות לעין, ויש תקווה לעתיד שבו יתקיימו זכויות רבות.

passage_content: ובזהפליגי ר"י ור"ל, דלריש לקיש דברים ככתבן ולא יהי' רק א' בעיר וב' ממשפחה הזוכין בזכות עצמן, ולר"י זכות ההגנה יהי' גדולה מאוד ויהיו הרבה בעיר ורבים במשפחה הזוכין ומזכין אחרים, ולא בא הכתוב אלא להגדיל כח ההגנה, דאפי' א' בעיר יהי' זכותו מספיק לכל העיר וכן ב' במשפחה כנ"ל, אבל למעשה לא פליגי ושניהם מודים דרבים מישראל ימלטו בדין, אלא דנפק"מ ביניהם דלר"י יהיו זוכין בזכות עצמן ולר"ל יהיו זוכין בזכות אחרים, ומאן דאכיל דלאו דילי' בהית לאסתכלי כנ"ל.
translation: And in this, Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer disagree, for according to Rabbi Eliezer, the words are as they are written, and there will only be one in the city and two from the family who merit by their own merit. And according to Rabbi Yochanan, the merit of protection will be very great, and there will be many in the city and many in the family who merit and cause others to merit. And the verse comes only to enhance the power of protection, for even one in the city will have his merit sufficient for the entire city, and likewise two in the family as mentioned. However, in practice, they do not disagree, and both agree that many from Israel will be saved in judgment. The difference that emerges between them is that according to Rabbi Yochanan, they will merit by their own merit, and according to Rabbi Eliezer, they will merit by the merit of others. And whoever eats, it is not his to look upon, as mentioned.
summary: The passage discusses a debate between Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Elazar regarding the nature of merit and protection in a community. Rabbi Elazar believes that merit is based on individual righteousness, with only one person in a city or two in a family being sufficient for protection. In contrast, Rabbi Yochanan emphasizes the power of collective merit, suggesting that many can benefit from the merit of a few, thereby highlighting the importance of communal support and intercession. Ultimately, both agree that many Israelites will be saved in judgment, but they differ on the source of that merit—individual versus communal.

passage_content: ומעתהיתורץ קושית הרי"ף הנ"ל, וא"ש תירוצו בין לדעת ר"ל ובין לדעת ר' יוחנן, דלפי דרכנו הנ"ל גם ר"ל מודה דיהי' כח ההגנה מרובה לעתיד, וסוכ"ס חלק גדול מישראל ימלטו, וע"כ לא חש הכתוב להאריך בחילוקים, בין אם יהי' כל המשפחה בתוך העיר, או אם יהי' נתחלקה המשפחה בכמה עיירות וחלק ממנה יהי' מחוץ לעיר, דאין נפק"מ לדינא בכל אלו החילוקים, דסוכ"ס חלק גדול מישראל ימלטו, ובין ר"י ובין ר"ל שניהם מודים דמשה"כ א' בעיר יהי' זכותו מגין על כל העיר, וב' במשפחה יספיק זכותם לכל המשפחה, ואפשר שעל צד הפלגה שיערו בכך, שכל כמה שתתרחק המשפחה, אף אם יהיו מפוזרים בכמה עיירות יספיקו להם זכות ב' צדיקים.
translation: And from now on, the question of the aforementioned Rif is resolved, and I understand his answer both according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer and according to the opinion of Rabbi Yochanan. According to our earlier explanation, even Rabbi Eliezer agrees that the power of protection will be great in the future, and ultimately a large part of Israel will be saved. Therefore, the text did not consider it necessary to elaborate on the distinctions, whether the entire family is within the city or if the family is divided among several towns and part of it is outside the city, as there is no practical difference in law regarding all these distinctions, since ultimately a large part of Israel will be saved. Both Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer agree that as it is written, if one is in the city, his merit protects the entire city, and if it is a family, their merit suffices for the entire family. It is possible that they estimated this in a manner of distinction, that the further the family is spread out, even if they are scattered among several towns, the merit of two righteous individuals will suffice for them.
summary: The passage discusses the theological concept of divine protection for the Jewish people, emphasizing that a significant portion will be saved in the future, regardless of their geographical distribution. It highlights the idea that the merit of righteous individuals can provide protection not only for their immediate family but also for those who are distanced, suggesting that the spiritual connection remains strong even when families are spread across different towns. Both Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer agree on the efficacy of this protective merit, illustrating a profound belief in the power of righteousness to safeguard the community as a whole.

passage_content: ומעתהאין שום סתירה בדברי ר"י ור"ל, דס"ל לעיל דשלישית יוותר בה, וכאן אמרו דא' בעיר וב' ממשפחה, ולפי דרכנו פלוגתתם כאן בענין אחר לגמרי, דלעיל מיירי הכתוב מכריתה ח"ו כמשה"כ פי שנים יכרתו, ופליגי ר"י ור"ל בחשבון השלישית הנשאר כנ"ל. אבל בפלוגתתם כאן לא מיירי מכריתה כלל, אלא כמה יהיו הזוכין בזכות עצמן, והשאר יחיו וישארו בזכות הצדיקים כנ"ל. ויתבארו דברי המהרש"א ז"ל דלשיטתם אזלי ר"י ור"ל, דכמו דס"ל לר' יוחנן בחשבון השלישית שיתנהג הקב"ה לדון את ישראל במדת הרחמים וישארו בחשבון השלישית כל ישראל, כמו"כ ס"ל בפלוגתא זו דיהיו זוכין בזכות עצמן רבים מישראל, ור"ל לשיטתו דלפי מדת הדין לא יזכו אלא יחידים כנ"ל, אבל סוכ"ס ישארו וימלטו בזכות הצדיקים כפי חשבון שלישית לשיטתו, ואין כאן סתירה בין המאמרים ור"י לטעמי' ור"ל לטעמי'.
translation: And from now on, there is no contradiction between the words of Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer, as it is understood above that a third will remain in it, and here they said that one is in the city and two are from the family. According to our approach, their dispute here is about a completely different matter, as above the text discusses the cutting off, Heaven forbid, as it is written, "twice they will be cut off," and Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer argue about the account of the third that remains, as mentioned. However, in their dispute here, it does not discuss cutting off at all, but rather how many will merit by their own merit, and the rest will live and remain by the merit of the righteous, as mentioned. The words of the Maharsha will be clarified, that Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer follow their own reasoning, that just as Rabbi Yochanan holds in the account of the third that the Holy One, Blessed be He, will judge Israel with the attribute of mercy and all of Israel will remain in the account of the third, so too he holds in this dispute that many of Israel will merit by their own merit, while Rabbi Eliezer, according to his reasoning, holds that according to the attribute of justice, only individuals will merit, as mentioned, but ultimately they will remain and be saved by the merit of the righteous according to the account of the third according to his reasoning, and there is no contradiction between the statements of Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer according to their reasoning.
summary: The passage discusses the differing views of Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Elazar regarding the fate of the Jewish people, emphasizing that their disagreement is not about divine punishment but rather about the merits individuals hold. Rabbi Yochanan believes that many will be saved through their own merits, while Rabbi Elazar maintains that only a few will achieve this, with the rest relying on the merits of the righteous. Ultimately, both perspectives align in the belief that God's judgment operates with mercy, allowing for the possibility of salvation through the intercession of the righteous. This reflects a core Hasidic concept of the interplay between individual merit and communal grace.

passage_content: ובדרךהנ"ל יתפרש גם דברי רבא שאמר וכן לימות המשיח יהי' שנים מס' רבוא, והכוונה דרבא מיקל יותר מכולהו אמוראי הנ"ל, וס"ל דיספיק הגנת ב' צדיקים לס' רבוא ולמד כן ממשה"כ וענתה שמה כימי נעורי' וכיום עלותה מאמ"צ, הקיש הכתוב ימות המשיח לדור המדבר ולדור שיצא ממצרים. דבאמת כתב האריז"ל דאותן שמתו במצרים ולא יצאו לא ידחו ח"ו עולמית, ועתידין לבוא בגלגול בדרא בתראה וחלק גדול מהם יהי' להם תיקון במשך הדורות ויזכו לימות המשיח, וכמשה"כ והנידחים בארץ מצרים, אלא שנדחו לפי שעה, דלא הי' רצונו ית' שילכו עם ישראל במדבר, פן יגרמו הריסות כמו הערב רב שהלכו אתם גרמו נסיונות וחטאים גדולים ר"ל, אבל סוכ"ס יתבררו כל אלה הנשמות ע"י שיבואו בגלגולו בנ"י, ויזכו חלק גדול מהם לימות המשיח. ובדור המדבר מבואר בדברי חז"ל בפירוש שיזכו כולם לימות המשיח, והאריז"ל בס' הלקוטים בפ' שמות כתב, דאין לך דור ודור שמשה רבינו לא יהי' בתוכו, להשלים הדור ההוא של המדבר כי גם דור המדבר יחזרו להתגלגל בדורנו זה דרא כ' דף י"ט ע"ב).
translation: And in the aforementioned way, the words of Rava will also be explained, who said that in the days of the Messiah there will be years of a hundred thousand. The intention of Rava is that he is more lenient than all the other Amoraim mentioned above, and he holds that the merit of two righteous ones suffices for a hundred thousand, and he learned this from the verse "and she will answer there as in the days of her youth and as in the day of her ascent from the land of Egypt." The verse compares the days of the Messiah to the generation of the wilderness and the generation that left Egypt. In truth, the Arizal wrote that those who died in Egypt and did not go out will not be rejected, Heaven forbid, eternally, and they will come in a reincarnation in the last generation, and a large part of them will have rectification throughout the generations and will merit the days of the Messiah, as it is written, "and the outcasts in the land of Egypt," but they were temporarily rejected, for it was not the will of the Blessed One that the Jewish people should go into the wilderness, lest they cause destruction like the mixed multitude that went with them, causing great trials and sins, Heaven forbid. However, ultimately, all these souls will be clarified through their reincarnation among the Jewish people, and a large part of them will merit the days of the Messiah. And it is explained in the words of our Sages that all of them will merit the days of the Messiah in the generation of the wilderness, and the Arizal in the book of Likutim in Parashat Shemot wrote that there is no generation in which Moses our Rabbi will not be among them, to complete that generation of the wilderness, for even the generation of the wilderness will return to be reincarnated in our generation, as it is written in the 19th page of the Talmud, tractate Yitro.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption in the context of the Messianic era, emphasizing that even those who died in Egypt without entering the Promised Land will ultimately be resurrected and receive their rectification through reincarnation in future generations. It connects the Messianic times to the experiences of the Israelites in the desert and highlights that all souls from that generation will return to fulfill their purpose. The teachings of the Arizal reinforce the idea that Moses will always be present to guide each generation, ensuring that the souls of the desert will achieve their redemption in the Messianic age.

passage_content: ומעתהאותן שנים מס' רבוא שעלו ממצרים, על ידיהם נשלמו ונתקנו כל הס' רבוא, ע"י שנתגלגלו בבניהם ונתבררו ויזכו כולם לימות המשיח, וכן בבאי הארץ דאותן השנים שנכנסו זיכו לכל דור המדבר תיקון לעתיד, וז"שרבא וכן לימות המשיח שהקב"ה ידון אותנו ברחמים גמורים, ולפי המצב הקשה ונסיונות העצומים יהי' כח ההגנה גדולה כ"כ, עד ששנים מס' רבוא יהיו זוכים ומזכים לכל הדור ההוא ויצילו את כולן בזכותן, ויהושע וכלב עצמן יעמדו בתחי' לעתיד ויגין זכותם כמו שהגין אז בביאת הארץ, וא"ש מ"ש המהרש"א דאותן השנים ירמוז על ב' משיחין, והכוונה דזכותם יגין על כל הדור, וא"ש דלא אמרו בגמ' על דברי רבא לא ניחא לי' למרייהו דאמרת הכי, דודאי ניחא וניחא, ולפי דברי רבא יהי' רחמים מרובים על ישראל לימות המשיח בב"א.
translation: And from now on, those years of the myriad that ascended from Egypt, through them were completed and rectified all the myriad, by the fact that they were reincarnated in their children and were clarified, and they will all merit the days of the Messiah. Likewise, those who entered the land in those years granted a rectification for all the generation of the desert for the future. And so it is that Rava said, and likewise for the days of the Messiah, that the Holy One, blessed be He, will judge us with complete mercy. And according to the difficult situation and the tremendous trials, the power of protection will be so great that two of the myriad will merit and grant merit to that entire generation and will save them all through their merit. And Joshua and Caleb themselves will stand at the resurrection for the future and will protect their merit just as they protected then at the coming into the land. And it is understood what the Maharsha said, that those years hint at the two Messiahs, and the intention is that their merit will protect the entire generation. And it is understood why they did not say in the Gemara regarding the words of Rava that it is not pleasing to him, for surely it is pleasing and pleasing. And according to the words of Rava, there will be abundant mercy upon Israel in the days of the Messiah, may it be soon.
summary: The passage discusses the spiritual legacy of the generation that left Egypt, emphasizing that their merits will be passed down to their descendants, ultimately leading to redemption in the Messianic era. It highlights the belief that the righteous of that generation, particularly Joshua and Caleb, will intercede for future generations, ensuring divine mercy and protection during challenging times. The text also suggests that the merits of these ancestors will serve as a shield for the entire generation, reinforcing the idea of collective redemption through the righteousness of the past. Additionally, it alludes to the concept of two Messiahs, whose merits will safeguard the Jewish people in the future.

passage_content: ולדרכנומ"ש רבא וכן למות המשיח יהי' שנים מס' רבוא, אין הכוונה שלא יהיו אלא ב' צדיקים מס' רבוא, דודאי יהי' הרבה יותר דהקב"ה ידון אותנו ברחמים מרובים, אלא רבותא קמ"ל דיהי' כח ההגנה מרובה עד שיספיק זכות שנים לכל ישראל, וס' רבוא ישראל ימלטו בזכות השנים אבל באמת לא יצטרכו כולם אל זכות השנים דיהיו מרובין הזוכים בדין, ומה שאמר הכתוב א' בעיר וב' במשפחה נצטרך לומר דרבא יסבור כדברי ר"ל בזה, דכפי שורת הדין הגמור ודברים ככתבן לא יזכו בזכות עצמן כי אם א' בעיר וב' במשפחה, אלא שלא יתקיים כן ויהי' כח ההגנה מרובה, וזכות שני צדיקים יהי' מגין על כל ישראל, ובזה הוא מקיל יותר מדברי שניהם. ונתבאר כל השקלא וטריא.
translation: And according to what Rabbi said, so too for the death of the Messiah, there will be two from a myriad. The intention is not that there will only be two righteous ones from a myriad, for certainly there will be many more, as the Holy One, blessed be He, will judge us with abundant mercy. Rather, the novelty is that the power of protection will be so great that the merit of two will suffice for all of Israel, and sixty myriads of Israel will be saved through the merit of the two. However, in truth, not all will need the merit of the two, as there will be many who will merit in judgment. And what the scripture says, "one in a city and two in a family," we must say that Rabbi will hold according to the words of Rabbi Levi in this matter, for according to the strict letter of the law and the words as they are written, they would not merit by their own merit except for one in a city and two in a family. However, this will not be the case, and the power of protection will be great, and the merit of the two righteous ones will be a shield for all of Israel, and in this, it is more lenient than the words of both. And all the discussion has been clarified.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of redemption and the role of righteous individuals in the protection of the Jewish people during the Messianic era. It emphasizes that while the strict judgment may suggest only two righteous individuals can merit salvation for their community, in reality, God's mercy will allow for a greater number of the righteous to intercede on behalf of all Israel. The text highlights the idea that the merit of even a few can provide significant protection, reflecting a deeper understanding of divine compassion and the interconnectedness of the community's righteousness. Ultimately, it conveys a message of hope and the potential for widespread redemption through the merit of the few.

passage_content: ועתהנבוא לבאר מדרש הנ"ל, אמר פרעה מי ומי ההולכים, עתידים אתם לומר מי יעלה בהר ד' ומי יקום במקום קדשו וכו' ויובן עפימ"ש הבעה"ט וכעי"ז כתב האברבנאל בשם מדרש שצפה פרעה באצטגנינותו שמכל יוצאי מצרים לא יכנסו אלא שנים בלבד והם יהושע וכלב, ועליהם אמר מי ומי ההולכים, ולמה אתם מתאוים לצאת והלא אין סופכם ליכנס לארץ, ונקדים עוד מ"ש הערבי נחל זלל"ה (פ' שלח), בענין המרגלים בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק וכתבי האריז"ל שהקשו דאיך הקריבו ישראל קרבנות במדבר, הלא ידוע דאין חו"ל סובל קדושת הקרבן, ואין מקום להקריב קרבן כ"א בביהמ"ק שעומד בא"י, ושם עשר הקדושות המבוארים בכלים, ותירצו שכמו שמצינו ביעקב אבינו שקיפל הקב"ה את כל א"י והניחו תחתיו, כך הי' הענין מעת צאתם ממצרים בכל מקום חנייתם הי' שם כל עשר קדושות של א"י, ומקום המשכן הי' ממש בקדושת מקום המקדש, וא"ש שהקריבו שם קרבנות, ולא רק במקום חנייתם לבד הי' שם כל קדושת א"י אלא גם בעת נסיעתם נסע קדושת א"י עמהם, ופירש בזה הערבי נחל מ"ש חז"ל במס' שבת (ל"א ע"ב) כיון דכתיב עפ"י ד' יחנו ועפ"י ד' יסעו כסותר ע"מ לבנות במקומו דמי, דאותו מקום שסתרו וגם המקום שבנו בו הי' בא"י ומקודש בקדושת המקדש והוי סותר ע"מ לבנות במקומו עייש"ד ז"ל.
translation: And now let us explain the aforementioned Midrash. Pharaoh said, "Who are the ones going?" You are destined to say, "Who will ascend the mountain of the Lord, and who will stand in His holy place?" etc. This will be understood according to what the Baal HaTanya wrote, and similarly the Abarbanel wrote in the name of a Midrash that Pharaoh foresaw in his astrology that from all the ones who left Egypt, only two would enter, and they are Joshua and Caleb. About them he said, "Who are the ones going?" And why are you desiring to leave if your end is not to enter the land? We will also precede what the Aravi Nachal Z"L (Parashat Shelach) wrote regarding the spies, by bringing forward the words of the Zohar and the writings of the Arizal, who questioned how the Israelites offered sacrifices in the desert, for it is known that outside of the Land, the sanctity of the sacrifice cannot be sustained, and there is no place to offer a sacrifice except in the Holy Temple that stands in the Land of Israel, where the ten sanctities are explained in the vessels. They answered that just as we find with our forefather Jacob that the Holy One, blessed be He, folded all of the Land of Israel and placed it beneath him, so it was from the time they left Egypt; wherever they camped, there were all ten sanctities of the Land of Israel. And the place of the Tabernacle was indeed in the sanctity of the place of the Temple, and it is understood that they offered sacrifices there. And not only at their place of encampment was there all the sanctity of the Land of Israel, but also during their travels, the sanctity of the Land of Israel traveled with them. The Aravi Nachal explained this regarding what our Sages said in Tractate Shabbat (31b), since it is written, "According to the word of the Lord they camped, and according to the word of the Lord they traveled," as contradicting in order to build in its place is like, for that place which they destroyed and also the place where they built was in the Land of Israel and sanctified with the sanctity of the Temple, and it is considered as destroying in order to build in its place, as is explained there, may his memory be blessed.
summary: The passage discusses the prophetic insight of Pharaoh regarding the limited entry into the Promised Land, emphasizing that only Joshua and Caleb would enter from the Exodus generation. It connects this to the concept of divine presence, explaining that the sanctity of the Land of Israel was present even in the wilderness, allowing the Israelites to offer sacrifices there. The text highlights that the holiness of the Land accompanied the Israelites throughout their journey, reinforcing the idea that God's presence transcends physical locations. This reflects a deep theological understanding of the relationship between the divine, the land, and the people.

passage_content: ופירשתיבזה דברי המדרש (פ' ואתחנן) ואתחנן אל ד' בעת ההוא וגו', ואתחנן למה כדי שיכנס לארץ, ולכאורה הרי מפורש בפסוק דתפילתו הי' כדי שיכנס לארץ, ומאי קושיא ומאי פירוקא, אמנם מיושב לפי"ד הזוה"ק והאריז"ל הנ"ל, כי בכל מקום חנייתם ומסעם במדבר נעקר קדושת א"י לבוא אצלם, ומקום המשכן הי' מקודשת בקדושת המקדש, וע"כ הי' אפשר להם להקריב קרבנות כנ"ל, וא"כ קשיא לי' למדרש ואתחנן למה, כי למה הי' מתפלל ומתאו' כ"כ אעברה נא. הלא הי' שרוי בקדושת א"י גם במדבר. ותירצו כדי שיכנס לארץ, כי אינה דומה קדושת א"י במקומה הראוי' לה, לקדושת א"י שנעקר ממקומה למדבר, דזו אינה נצחי וקדושת א"י שם היא בבחי' גלות, וע"כ הי' משרע"ה מתאו' שהוא יכנס לא"י במקום קדושתה, ולא שקדושת הארץ תבוא אליו
translation: And this is the explanation of the Midrash (Parashat Va'etchanan): "And I pleaded with the Lord at that time," etc. Why did I plead? In order to enter the Land. At first glance, it is explicitly stated in the verse that his prayer was in order to enter the Land, so what is the question and what is the answer? However, it is resolved according to the teachings of the Zohar and the Arizal mentioned above, that in every place of their encampment and journey in the desert, the sanctity of the Land of Israel was uprooted from them, and the place of the Tabernacle was sanctified with the sanctity of the Temple. Therefore, it was possible for them to offer sacrifices as mentioned above. Thus, the Midrash's question of why he pleaded arises, for why was he praying and yearning so much, "Please let me cross over"? Was he not dwelling in the sanctity of the Land of Israel even in the desert? The answer is that it is not the same sanctity of the Land of Israel in its proper place as the sanctity of the Land of Israel that has been uprooted from its place to the desert. The latter is not eternal, and the sanctity of the Land of Israel there is in a state of exile. Therefore, Moshe Rabbeinu yearned to enter the Land of Israel in the place of its sanctity, and not that the sanctity of the Land would come to him.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores the significance of Moshe's prayer to enter the Land of Israel, emphasizing that the sanctity of the land is diminished when it is removed from its rightful place. The text highlights that while the Israelites experienced a form of holiness in the desert, it was not the same as the true, eternal sanctity of the land itself. Therefore, Moshe's yearning to enter the land reflects a deep desire for the ultimate spiritual elevation that comes from being in the land in its proper context, rather than merely experiencing a transient holiness in exile. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the importance of place and the inherent connection between physical space and spiritual fulfillment.

passage_content: ואפשרשפרעה ראה באצטגנינתו שגם בכל מקום חנייתם ונסיעתם במדבר יזכו אל קדושת ארץ ישראל, ע"י שתעקור ממקומה לבוא אצליהם, אבל ידע והשיג ג"כ שאין זה קדושה המתקיימת, ונצחיות קדושתה א"א שיהי' כ"א במקום הקודש בא"י, ושםיתקיים לדור ודור ולנצח נצחים, וע"כ טען פרעה מי ומי ההולכים שלא יכנסו לא"י כל דור המדבר כ"א יהושע וכלב, ומה שיזכו לקדושת א"י במדבר אין זה קדושה המתקיימת ונצחיות, וז"ש עתידים אתם לומר מי יעלה בהר ד' ומי יקום במקום קדשו, שא"א שיהי' קיום נצחי לקדושתה כ"א במקום קדשו ולקדושה זו לא זכו ישראל כי כולם ימותו במדבר, וזה מי ומי ההולכים, ולמה אתם מתאוים לצאת ממצרים הואיל ואין סופכם ליכנס לא"י, וע"ז השיב לו משה רבינו בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, בבנינו ובבנותינו נלך, וב' תשובות הם, חדא שלא נגזרה גזירה על פחות מבן כ' ועל יותר מבן ס', והנערים והזקנים יכנסו לא"י מיד, וז"ש בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך כמ"ש הבעה"ט והאברבנאל בשם המדרש כנ"ל, ועוד אמר לו משרע"ה שאפי' אותם שימותו במדבר לא ידחו עולמית, וסוכ"ס יכנסו לא"י ע"י שיתגלגלו בבניהם כמ"ש לעיל, ולא קשה מה שכפל מלת נלך ב' פעמים, כי יהי' ההליכה בכמה אופנים ובכמה זמנים כמ"ש האריז"ל דיתגלגלו בכל דור ודור עד שיתקנו, וכמו שדרשו ז"ל נתן תתן אפילו מאה פעמים, כן נכלל במ"ש כאן נלך נלך הליכות הרבה וא"ש.
translation: And it is possible that Pharaoh saw in his astrology that in every place of their encampment and journey in the desert, they would merit the sanctity of the Land of Israel, by the fact that it would uproot from its place to come to them. However, he also knew and understood that this is not a sanctity that is enduring, and the eternity of its holiness cannot be except in the holy place in the Land of Israel, where it will be established for generation after generation and for eternity. Therefore, Pharaoh argued, who are the ones going that they will not enter the Land of Israel? Only Joshua and Caleb. And what they will merit of the sanctity of the Land of Israel in the desert is not a sanctity that is enduring and eternal. And this is what is meant by, "You will say, who will ascend the mountain of the Lord, and who will stand in His holy place," for there cannot be an eternal existence for its holiness except in its holy place, and for this holiness, Israel did not merit, for they will all die in the desert. And this is who are the ones going. And why do you desire to leave Egypt since your end is not to enter the Land of Israel? To this, Moses our Rabbi replied, "With our young and with our old we will go, with our sons and with our daughters we will go." And there are two answers: one, that there was no decree against those under twenty and those over sixty, and the young and the old will enter the Land of Israel immediately. And this is what is meant by, "With our young and with our old we will go," as mentioned by the Baal HaTurim and the Abarbanel in the name of the Midrash, as stated above. Furthermore, Moses said to him that even those who will die in the desert will not be pushed away forever, and ultimately they will enter the Land of Israel through their children, as mentioned above. And it is not difficult why the word "we will go" is repeated twice, for the going will be in several ways and at several times, as the Arizal explained that they will be reincarnated in every generation until they rectify, and as our Sages have expounded, "You shall surely give," even a hundred times, so it is included in what is said here, "We will go, we will go," many journeys, and it is understood.
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's realization that the sanctity of the Land of Israel cannot be fully attained outside of its borders, as true and eternal holiness exists only within the land itself. He argues that only Joshua and Caleb will enter the Promised Land, while the rest of the generation will die in the desert. Moses responds that both the young and the old will enter, emphasizing that there is no decree preventing those under twenty or over sixty from entering, and that even those who die in the desert will ultimately be reincarnated through their descendants to fulfill the promise of entering the land. This reflects the Hasidic belief in the cyclical nature of spiritual journeys and the enduring connection to the Land of Israel across generations.

passage_content: ועתהנבוא לפרש הפסוק וכסה את עין הארץ ולא יוכל לראות וגו' ומ"ש במד"ר קהלת הארץ יש לה עינים וכו' (עיין לעיל קושיא ז' ח' ט'), והנ"ל בביאור הענין עפימ"ש המהרש"א ז"ל במס' מגילה (דף כ"ט ע"א) על מ"ש בגמ' שם למה תרצדון הרים וגו', שבשעת מתן תורה באו ההרים לעשות דין עם הר סיני שינתן התורה עליהם, עוד אמרו בגמ' שם שבאו תבור וכרמל ללמוד תורה בשעת מ"ת, וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל נראה דההרים אינם בעלי בחירה לבוא לשמוע תורה, אלא ששר ההרים בא, וכ"כ התוס' בריש פ"ק דחולין גבי גינאי נהרא שהשיב לרפב"י, ששר של ים השיב לו כן. והגאון רבינו סעדי' כתב כי הנחש וגם האתון לא דברו רק מלאך דיבר בשבילם עיי"ש. והרדב"ז כתב בענין פרו של אליהו שאמרו חז"ל במדרש פר שעלה בגורל לשם הבעל לא רצה להמסר ביד נביאי הבעל ודבר הפר עם אלי', וכתב הוא ז"ל דהשר של פר דבר עם אלי' והוא עכבו מלילך, דאין בפר כח הדיבור ואינו בעל בחירה למנוע מן הרע, ואם הי' כן בדרך נס הי"ל להכתוב לומר ויפתח ד' את פי הפר כמ"ש באתון, אלא ודאישהשר דיבר עם אלי' עיי"ש. ועד"ז אפ"ל לעניננו שמ"ש במד"ר קהלת הנ"ל שהארץ יש לה עינים ואזנים, הכוונה על שר הארץ שרואה ומשגיח בכל עניני הארץ.
translation: And now we will come to explain the verse "And He covered the eye of the earth, and it could not see, etc." and what is stated in the Midrash on Ecclesiastes, "The earth has eyes, etc." (see above, question 7, 8, 9), and the above regarding the explanation of the matter according to what the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote in Tractate Megillah (29a) on what is stated in the Gemara there, "Why do you tremble, O mountains, etc.," that at the time of the giving of the Torah, the mountains came to argue with Mount Sinai that the Torah should be given upon them. Furthermore, it is said in the Gemara there that Tabor and Carmel came to learn Torah at the time of the giving of the Torah. The Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote that it seems the mountains do not have free will to come to hear the Torah, but rather the ministering angel of the mountains came, and so too the Tosafot write at the beginning of the first chapter of Hullin regarding the river Ginei that responded to Rabbi Papi, that the ministering angel of the sea responded to him thus. And the Gaon Rabbi Saadia wrote that the serpent and the she-ass did not speak, but an angel spoke on their behalf, see there. And the Radbaz wrote regarding the bull of Elijah, which our Sages said in the Midrash that the bull that was chosen by lot for Baal did not want to be handed over to the prophets of Baal, and the bull spoke with Elijah. He wrote, may his memory be blessed, that the ministering angel of the bull spoke with Elijah and prevented him from going, for it does not have the power of speech and does not have free will to prevent from evil, and if it were so, it would have been appropriate for the text to say, "And the Lord opened the mouth of the bull," as it is said regarding the she-ass, but rather it was the ministering angel that spoke with Elijah, see there. Similarly, it can be said regarding our matter that what is stated in the Midrash on Ecclesiastes, that the earth has eyes and ears, refers to the ministering angel of the earth who sees and oversees all matters of the earth.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that natural elements, such as mountains and the earth, are influenced by spiritual forces or angels rather than possessing free will themselves. It references the idea that during the giving of the Torah, these entities sought to engage with divine teachings, indicating their connection to higher spiritual realms. The text emphasizes that the "eyes and ears" of the earth symbolize the overseeing presence of its spiritual guardian, who observes and governs earthly matters. This reflects a broader Hasidic theme of the interplay between the physical and spiritual worlds, highlighting the significance of divine oversight in all aspects of creation.

passage_content: ובדרךזה יתפרש הכתוב וכסה את עין הארץ ולא יוכל לראות וגו', ויובן עפימ"ש רש"י ז"ל במגילת איכה (ב' ב') עה"פ חלל ממלכה ושרי', במדרש שבשעת החורבן החליף הקב"ה שרי מעלה, והשר שהי' ממונה על האור מינה על המים וכן כולם, ושינה את שמותם, לפי שהיו ברשעי ישראל בעלי שם המפורש, והיו בוטחים בהם שישביעו את שרי מעלה להצילם מאש וממים ומחרב, ועכשיו כשהי' משביע את שר האש בשמו, הוא השיב אין ממשלה זו בידי וכן כולם, וז"ש חלל ממלכה ושרי' עכ"ל, ולכאורה הרי הקב"ה הוא כל יכול, והיכולת בידו ית' ליקח מרשעים הכח הזה, ע"י שישכחו ידיעתם בשם המפורש, או באופן אחר למנוע אותם מעשי' זו. אמנם נראה דיותר נייחה לפניו ית' לשנות סדרי הבריאה, ולשנות תפקידתם של שרי מעלה שנתמנו כן בבריאת העולם, ואין רצונו ית' למנוע הבחירה מבני אדם, וע"כ בחר הוא ית' יותר להחליף את השרים, מליקח מאתם היכולת וכח ההשבעות.
translation: And in this way, the verse is explained: "And He covered the eye of the earth, and it could not see," etc. It will be understood according to what Rashi, of blessed memory, says in the Book of Lamentations (2:2) regarding the verse "He has made the kingdom desolate and its princes." In the Midrash, it is stated that at the time of the destruction, the Holy One, blessed be He, exchanged the princes of the upper realms, and the prince who was in charge of fire was appointed over water, and so on for all of them, and He changed their names, because they were the wicked of Israel who had the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, and they relied on them to swear to the princes of the upper realms to save them from fire, water, and the sword. And now, when he was swearing to the prince of fire by His name, he replied, "This authority is not in my hands," and so on for all of them. And this is what is meant by "He has made the kingdom desolate and its princes." However, it seems that the Holy One, blessed be He, is all-powerful, and the ability is in His hands to take this power from the wicked, either by causing them to forget their knowledge of the Holy Name, or in another way to prevent them from this action. Nevertheless, it appears that it is more pleasing before Him, blessed be He, to change the order of creation and to alter the roles of the princes of the upper realms who were appointed as such at the creation of the world, and He does not wish to remove free will from human beings. Therefore, He preferred to exchange the princes rather than take from them the ability and power of swearing.
summary: The passage discusses the divine intervention during the destruction of the Temple, where God replaced the celestial ministers to prevent the wicked from invoking their powers through the ineffable name. This act illustrates God's preference for altering the natural order rather than stripping the wicked of their abilities, emphasizing the importance of human free will. The text highlights the tension between divine omnipotence and the necessity of allowing individuals to exercise their choices, even in the face of evil. Ultimately, it reflects a profound theological insight into the relationship between God, creation, and human agency.

passage_content: והנההמצריים הי' כוחם גדול בכשפים מאוד כידוע, ואמרו חז"ל (סנהדרין דף ס"ז ע"ב) כשפים מכחישין פמליא של מעלה, ופי' הרמב"ן ז"ל דהכוונה פמליא של מעלה היינו השרי מעלה, שיש כח בכשפים למשול בהם, אבל אעפ"כ אין עוד מלבדו כתיב, ואם רצונו ית' למנוע הכח מהם, אין ביכולתם לעשות כלום, אלא שמחוקי ויסודות הבריאה נמסר תפקיד הנהגת הטבעיים לשרי מעלה, ואין ברצונו ית' למנוע הבחירה מבנ"א, וע"י כשפים מכריחים בשרי מעלה לעשות כרצונם, ומעתה הי' החשש כאן במכת הארבה שע"י כשפים יכריחו מצרים את שר הארץ, והוא ימנע את הארבה מלבוא, ולכך החליף הקב"ה את שר הארץ, ונטל ממנו כחתפקידו, ואפשר שזה כוונת הכתוב וכסה את עין הארץ, שעין שר הארץ המפקיח על הארץ יכוסה וינטל כוחו, ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ, כי ימנע הכוח ממנו ולא יראה ולא ישלוט עלי' כלל, וזה הי' התראת משה ואהרן לפרעה במכת הארבה, שאל יבטחו בכח כשפיהם למנוע הארבה מהם ע"י שליטתם בשרי מעלה, כי השי"ת יכסה את עין הארץ ולא יוכל לראות וגו' ולא יפעלו כלום בכח כשפיהם. ובזה יבואר מ"ש הכתוב ואחריו לא יהי' כן, והכוונה לדרכנו דלא יהי' בבחי' זו לשנות סדרי הבריאה ולמנוע כוחם של שרי מעלה. דבארבה שהי' בימי יואל לא הוצרכו לזה, כי לא נחשדו ישראל להשתמש בכשפים, וגם לא השתמשו בשם המפורש נגד רצונו ית' בימי יואל, זולת בעת החורבן אמרו רז"ל שהיו רשעי ישראל רוצים לעשות כן, עכ"פ הארבה שהי' בימי יואל הי' מלובש בטבע וע"י הנהגת שרי מעלה ולא נשתנו בו סדרי בריאה, וז"ש ואחריו לא יהי' כן, לא על רבוי הארבה נאמרה, ואפשר שהי' הארבה שבימי יואל מרובה וכבד משל משה כקושית רש"י ז"ל, אלא שלא הי' בבחי' זו במניעת הטבע ובהשתנות סדרי הבריאה.
translation:
And behold, the Egyptians had great power in sorcery, as is known, and our Sages said (Sanhedrin 67b) that sorcery contradicts the heavenly entourage. And the Ramban, of blessed memory, explained that the heavenly entourage refers to the ministers of the higher realms, who have the power to be ruled by sorcery. However, despite this, it is written, "There is none besides Him." If the Holy One, blessed be He, wishes to prevent their power, they can do nothing. Rather, by the laws and foundations of creation, the task of governing the natural order is entrusted to the ministers of the higher realms, and it is not His will to take away free will from human beings. Through sorcery, they compel the ministers of the higher realms to act according to their desires. Therefore, there was concern here during the plague of locusts that through sorcery, Egypt would compel the minister of the land, and he would prevent the locusts from coming. For this reason, the Holy One, blessed be He, changed the minister of the land and took away his position. It is possible that this is the intent of the verse, "And He covered the eye of the land," meaning that the eye of the minister of the land, who oversees the land, would be covered and his power would be taken away, so that he would not be able to see the land, for the power would be withheld from him, and he would not see or have any control over it at all. This was the warning of Moses and Aaron to Pharaoh during the plague of locusts, that he should not rely on the power of their sorcery to prevent the locusts from them through their control over the ministers of the higher realms, for the Holy One, blessed be He, would cover the eye of the land and he would not be able to see, etc., and they would accomplish nothing through the power of their sorcery. 

And this explains what the verse says, "And after him it will not be so," meaning in our way that there will not be in this manner to change the order of creation and prevent the power of the ministers of the higher realms. For in the locust plague during the days of Joel, they did not need this, because Israel was not suspected of using sorcery, and they did not use the Ineffable Name against His will during the days of Joel, except at the time of the destruction, when our Sages said that the wicked of Israel wanted to do so. Nevertheless, the locusts that were in the days of Joel were clothed in nature and governed by the ministers of the higher realms, and the order of creation was not changed in them. This is what is meant by "And after him it will not be so," which was not said regarding the abundance of locusts. It is possible that the locusts in the days of Joel were more numerous and heavier than those of Moses, as Rashi, of blessed memory, questioned, but they were not in this manner of preventing nature and changing the order of creation.
summary: The passage discusses the power of sorcery in Egypt and its ability to influence the celestial powers, as noted by the sages. However, it emphasizes that ultimately, God's will prevails, and He can prevent sorcery from having any effect. The text highlights that during the plague of locusts, God intervened by removing the power of the earthly ruler, ensuring that the sorcerers could not manipulate the natural order. It contrasts this with the events in the time of Joel, where the natural order remained intact, and Israel did not resort to sorcery against God's will.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד רמז בכוונת הכתוב וכסה את עין הארץ וגו', בהקדם מה שהקשה האוהחה"ק עה"פ הטרם תדע וגו' דלכאורה יפלא היתכן שהיו פרעה ומצריים טפשים כ"כ, שיסבלו כל הרעות והצרות ההמה, והכניסו את עצמם בסכנת נפשות, ולא אבו לשמוע בקול ד' לשלח את ישראל מארצם, הגם כי הקשה ד' את רוחו, עכ"ז צריך שתהי' לו איזה סברא שבה יתלה טפשותו, ותירץ הוא ז"ל דטעותם הי' באופן השליחות אשר שלח השי"ת, לשלוח את ישראל לחוג במדבר על ג' ימים, וע"כ חשבו מחשבות און, כי כביכול אין כח בו ח"ו להוציא בהחלט ולהכריחם ע"ז הכרח גדול, ולכך מאנו שמוע בדבר ד' עכת"ד ז"ל. אמנם אין תירוצו מספיק כ"כ, דכ"ז יצוייר אלולי לא נלקה במכות גדולות ונוראות כאלה, אבל אחרי שנלקה במכות שלא כדרך הטבע, ובהשתנות סדרי הבריאה במכת הארבה ובמכת חשך, והשתמשות שני הפכים במכת ברד כמבואר בדברנו בפ' וארא ונתברר לו בירור גמור שהמכות האלה הם מאלקי היכולת ולא ע"י כשפים, וכמ"ש התרגום יוב"ע והאוהח"ק בפ' ברד, א"כ כבר ידע שהיכולת בידו ית' לעשות כרצונו, ולא יצדק עוד טעותו כתירוצו של האוהח"ק, ואעפ"כ החציף את רוחו ולא נכנע גם אחר מכת הארבה ודיבר בעזות נגד משה וא"ל ביום ראותך פני תמות, ואיך סר שכלו ממנו ולא נשאר בו דעת כלל.
translation: And I will add another hint regarding the intention of the text, "And He covered the eye of the land," etc. First, addressing the difficulty raised by the holy author on the verse "Before you know," etc., it seems astonishing that Pharaoh and Egypt could be so foolish as to endure all the evils and troubles, putting themselves in danger of life, and yet refuse to heed the voice of the Lord to send Israel out of their land, even though the Lord hardened his spirit. Nevertheless, there must be some reasoning that he could attribute his foolishness to. He explained that their mistake was in the manner of the mission that the Holy One, blessed be He, sent to send Israel to celebrate in the wilderness for three days. Therefore, they thought vain thoughts, as if He, Heaven forbid, did not have the power to decisively and forcefully take them out, and thus they refused to listen to the word of the Lord, as he stated. However, his explanation is not entirely sufficient, for all this could be imagined had they not been struck by such great and terrible plagues. But after they were struck by plagues that were not according to the natural order, with the alteration of the laws of creation in the plague of locusts and the plague of darkness, and the use of two opposites in the plague of hail, as explained in our discussion in Parashat Va'era, it became clear to him with complete clarity that these plagues were from the God of might and not through sorcery, as the translation states and the holy author in the section of hail. Therefore, he already knew that the power was in His hand to do as He wishes, and his foolishness could no longer be justified as per the explanation of the holy author. And yet, he hardened his spirit and did not submit even after the plague of locusts, and spoke boldly against Moses, saying to him, "On the day you see my face, you shall die." How did he lose his mind and not have any understanding left in him at all?
summary: The passage discusses the perplexity of Pharaoh and the Egyptians' refusal to heed God's command to release the Israelites, despite experiencing severe plagues that defied natural order. It suggests that their stubbornness stemmed from a misunderstanding of God's power, believing that the divine threat was not absolute. Even after witnessing miraculous signs, Pharaoh's arrogance led him to dismiss the warnings, illustrating a profound theological insight into the nature of free will and the human capacity for denial in the face of divine intervention. Ultimately, it highlights the tension between divine authority and human obstinacy.
