passage_content: אולםבאמת תמיהות כאלו נמצא גם אצלינו, ונראים בחוש בכל דור ובכל יום, וכמו שאומרים בתפלה זכה מתמיהים אנחנו על נפשינו איך נעשתה התועבה הזאת וכו', ואחר החטא שכבר הוסרה הנגיעה יפלא בעיני החוטא, איך בא לידי סמיות עינים כ"כ, ואיך סר שכלו ממנו בעת החטא. אבל ההסבר הברור בענין זה כבר נתבאר בדברנו בכ"מ, דכח הנגיעה והרצון המוחלט משחד דעתו של אדם, ואין בכוחו לראות ולהשיג האמת, כי השוחד יעור עיני חכמים, וע"כ עושה גם מעשים אשר הם זר ורחוק משכל האנושי, ולא ירגיש בהם לצד אבדון נפשו ושכלו ע"י כח הנגיעה, ואח"כ כשיוסר ממנו הנגיעה יראה למפרע בטפשותו, ויתמה על נפשו ועל דעתו, איך הסכימה דעתו לעשות כזאת, אבל כל זמן שאש הנגיעה תבער בו, הוא משוחד אלי' בכל חושיו ואבריו, ולא יראה ולא ישמע ולא יבין בשכלו כלל, עיין בדברנו (פ' וישלח עמוד ר"ג) שפירשנו בזה ענין חטא שכם, שעשו מעשה זר ורחוק משכל אנושי, בהמולו כל אנשי עירם נערים וזקנים ללא תועלת, אלא שלצד גודל רשעתם הי' להם נגיעה לכלות אומה הישראלית, וע"כ נאבדה עצתם, ועשו כנגד השכל עיי"ש בדברינו באריכות.
translation: However, in truth, such wonders are also found among us, and they are perceptible in every generation and every day, as we say in prayer, "We are amazed for our souls how this abomination was done," etc. And after the sin, when the taint has already been removed, it is astonishing in the eyes of the sinner how he came to such blindness of eyes, and how his intellect departed from him at the time of the sin. But the clear explanation regarding this matter has already been elucidated in our words elsewhere, that the power of the taint and the absolute desire corrupts a person's mind, and he is unable to see and grasp the truth, for "bribery blinds the eyes of the wise." Therefore, he also performs actions that are strange and far from human intellect, and he does not feel them due to the destruction of his soul and mind by the power of the taint. And afterwards, when the taint is removed from him, he will see in retrospect his foolishness, and he will wonder about his soul and his mind, how his intellect consented to do such a thing. But as long as the fire of the taint burns within him, he is corrupted by it in all his senses and limbs, and he will not see, hear, or understand with his intellect at all. See our words (Parashat Vayishlach, page 203) where we explained the matter of the sin of Shechem, that they performed a strange act far from human intellect, by circumcising all the men of their city, young and old, without any benefit, except that due to the greatness of their wickedness, they had a taint to annihilate the Jewish nation. Therefore, their counsel was lost, and they acted against reason; see there in our words at length.
summary: המחבר מתאר את התופעה שבה אדם חוטא מבלי להבין את מעשיו, בשל כוח הנגיעה והרצון המוחלט שמסנוור את דעתו. הוא מסביר שכאשר הנגיעה שוררת, האדם מאבד את יכולתו לראות את האמת ולעשות הבחנות רציונליות, וכאשר היא מוסרת, הוא מתמיה על מעשיו הקודמים. דוגמת חטא שכם מדגימה כיצד רשעות יכולה להוביל לפעולות בלתי הגיוניות, כאשר הנגיעה שואבת את האדם למעשים שמנוגדים לשכל האנושי.

passage_content: עכ"פטבעו של אדם כן הוא, דע"י הנגיעה ורצון המוחלט יתעלם ממנו כח הראות וחוש ההבדל להבחין דרך האמת, ויראה ההיפך וידמה על החשך שהוא אור, ואלולא דבר זה הי' בעוכרינו הי' אפשר להשמר מעצת יצה"ר עפ"י רוב, וכמ"ש ז"ל אין אדם חוטא אא"כ נכנס בו רוח שטות. ומעתה יתורץ קושית האוהח"ק הנ"ל, דבאמת הי' פרעה חכם גדול כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל דחכם גדול הי' אלא שלא ידע בחי' שם הוי' וע"כ אמר לא ידעתי אתד', אבל ידע את אלקים ומודה בו עייש"ד. וכפי המושג בשכל אנושי הי' לו לירא מפחד ד' ומהדר גאונו, כי ידע בשם אלקים כמו שהביא הרמב"ן ז"ל ראיות מכתובים, ובפרט אחרי שהוכה במכות גדולות בהשתנות סדרי בריאה ובשנוי הטבע אבל לפי שהי' משוחד לתוקף הרצון להרע לישראל מגודל רשעתו, ורצה לכלות ח"ו זרע ישראל שיהיו משוקעים אצלו בנ' שערי טומאה שלא יוכלו לצאת משם לעולם, ע"כ הי"ל סמיות עינים ולא ראה האמת, ועוד דימה בדעתו על השקר שהוא אמת ועל הטפשות שהוא חכמה גדולה, ולא יקשה קושית האוהחה"ק הנ"ל, ויונח בתירוצו שהי"ל לפרעה חשבון מוטעת מפני שא"ל משרע"ה בשליחות השי"ת דרך ג' ימים נלך, חשב כי ח"ו כביכול אין בידו להציל בהחלט, ואע"פ שהוא דבר זר וטפשות לחשוב כן, אחרי שראה יכולת ד' באותות ובמופתים, אבל אין שום קושיא כי ע"י תוקף הנגיעה יעשה האדם אפי' דבר זר ורחוק מן השכל, כי לא יראה ולא יבין.
translation: The nature of man is such that through desire and absolute will, the power of sight and the sense of distinction to discern the truth becomes obscured, and he sees the opposite and imagines that darkness is light. Were it not for this, we could have been spared from the counsel of the evil inclination in most cases, as our sages have said, "No man sins unless a spirit of folly enters him." From this, the question of the holy author mentioned above is resolved, for indeed Pharaoh was a great wise man, as the Ramban has said, that he was a great wise man, but he did not know the aspect of the Name Havayah, and therefore he said, "I do not know the Lord." However, he knew of God and acknowledged Him, as is stated. According to human understanding, he should have feared the fear of God and the majesty of His glory, for he knew the Name of God, as the Ramban brought proofs from the scriptures, especially after he was struck with great plagues, with a change in the order of creation and a change in nature. But since he was biased by the force of his desire to do evil to Israel due to his great wickedness, and he wanted to annihilate, Heaven forbid, the seed of Israel so that they would be sunk in the fifty gates of impurity and could never escape from there, therefore he had blindness of eyes and did not see the truth. Moreover, he imagined in his mind that falsehood was truth and that foolishness was great wisdom. The question of the holy author mentioned above will not be difficult, and it will be placed in its resolution that Pharaoh had a mistaken calculation because Moshe said to him, "We will go three days' journey," he thought that, Heaven forbid, he had no power to save at all. And although it is a strange and foolish thing to think so, after he saw the power of God in signs and wonders, there is no question at all, for through the force of desire, a person can do even something strange and far from reason, for he will not see or understand.
summary: The passage discusses the concept that a person's desires and intentions can obscure their ability to perceive truth, leading them to mistake darkness for light. It highlights the case of Pharaoh, who, despite being wise and aware of God's power, was blinded by his evil intentions towards the Israelites, causing him to misinterpret reality. This illustrates the Hasidic idea that a strong desire for wrongdoing can distort one's understanding and judgment, making even the most irrational thoughts seem plausible. Ultimately, it emphasizes the importance of aligning one's will with divine truth to avoid such spiritual blindness.

passage_content: ובזהיבואר המדרש הנ"ל זש"ה ברוב עוזך יכחשו לך אויביך וכו', מתחלה אמר לא ידעתי את ד' וגם את ישראל לא אשלח נעשה כחשן והודה ואמר ד' הצדיק ואמר קומו צאו מתוך עמי וכו' (עיין לעיל קושיא י"ב), כי באמת היו כל דבריו מתחלה כחש ושקר, ומ"ש לא ידעתי את ד' הי' שקר בפיו, כי הי"ל לירא מפחד ה' אחרי שידע שם אלקים, וגם מ"ש את ישראל לא אשלח הי' מתחלה כחש וכזב, כי הי"ל לידע במושג שכל אנושי כי לא יעלה בידו ולא יצליח נגד רצונו ית', אלא שהנגיעה מדמה ומכחש ונדמה לו שלא ידע את ד', ולולי הנגיעה הי"ל ידיעה, אלא שנעלמה ידיעתו מחמת הנגיעה, ואחרי שהוכרח לשלח ראה למפרע שהי' שטות וכחש ושקר כל מה שאמר, וז"ש יכחשו לך אויביך שע"י גודל השנאה באים לידי כחש ושקר ע"י סמיות עינים, וברוב עוזך יכחשו לך אויביך, שע"י המכות שהוכה הודה אח"כ בעצמו על כחשותו ואמר ד' הצדיק.
translation: And in the aforementioned Midrash, it is explained, "In the greatness of Your strength, Your enemies will lie to You," etc. Initially, he said, "I do not know the Lord," and "I will not send Israel," he acted deceitfully and acknowledged, saying, "The Lord is righteous," and "Arise, go out from among My people," etc. (see above, question 12). For indeed, all his words were initially lies and falsehoods, and when he said, "I do not know the Lord," it was a falsehood in his mouth, for he should have feared the fear of the Lord after he knew the name of God. And also, when he said, "I will not send Israel," it was initially a lie and deception, for he should have known, by human understanding, that he would not prevail nor succeed against His will, blessed be He. Rather, the influence of his heart caused him to lie and he imagined that he did not know the Lord. Had it not been for this influence, he would have had knowledge, but his knowledge was hidden due to the influence. And after he was compelled to send, he saw retrospectively that all he had said was folly, falsehood, and lies. Therefore, it is said, "Your enemies will lie to You," for through the intensity of hatred, they come to lies and falsehoods through blindness of eyes. "In the greatness of Your strength, Your enemies will lie to You," for through the plagues he was struck, he later acknowledged himself his foolishness and said, "The Lord is righteous."
summary: The passage discusses the theme of denial and falsehood in the context of Pharaoh's refusal to acknowledge God and release the Israelites. It emphasizes that Pharaoh's initial claims of ignorance about God were rooted in deception, as he should have recognized God's power and authority. The text highlights that his hatred and stubbornness led to a blindness that obscured his understanding, ultimately resulting in his acknowledgment of God's righteousness after experiencing divine punishment. This reflects a broader Hasidic insight into the nature of human resistance to divine truth and the transformative power of suffering in leading to recognition and repentance.

passage_content: ועד"זאפ"ל מאמה"כ וכסה את עין הארץ ולא יוכל לראות וגו', עפי"מ דאיתא במדרש (ילקוט רמז תתקמ"ב) האזינו השמים ואדברה ותשמע הארץ וגו', שקרא משה ליושבי השמים וליושבי הארץ, וא"ל הרי גזר הקב"ה עלי שאמות ואיני יודע להיכן נפשי הולכת וכו' תנו דעתכם שתהיו מקבלין אותי בכבוד ומסתכלין בי כאלו אני חי ומדבר את דברי תורה לעולם עכ"ד המדרש, וכמו"כ אפשר לפרש לעניננו וכסה את עון הארץ על עין יושבי הארץ, אלו שכל מחשבתם שקועים בעניני ארציות, ואינם חושבים מה למעלה ממך, ועינם מכוסה מלראות דרך האמת, וז"ש ולא יוכל לראות את הארץ, וה"ז מקרא קצר ולא פי' מי הרואה, דבדרך כלל כן הוא, דמי שמשוחד לתאוותיו וכל רצונו להשיג רק עניני גשמיות, אינו יכול לראות האמת ורואה ההיפך ומדמהו לאמת, וא"א לכוין האמת כ"א מי שכל רצונו לעשות רצון אבינו שבשמים ואין לו רצון אחר זולתו. וזה ירמוז הכתוב שגם אחר המכות לא ישמע פרעה ולבו לא יבין, והטעם דמכוסה עין הרואה את הארץ ולא יוכל לראות האמת, וע"כ יתחזק ברשעו.
translation: And similarly, it is stated in the verse, "And He covered the eye of the land, and it could not see," as it is explained in the Midrash (Yalkut, Remez 866) "Give ear, O heavens, and I will speak; and let the earth hear the words of my mouth," that Moses called to the inhabitants of the heavens and the inhabitants of the earth, and said to them, "Behold, the Holy One, blessed be He, has decreed upon me that I shall die, and I do not know where my soul is going," etc. "Take heed that you receive me with honor and look at me as if I am alive and speaking the words of Torah to the world," thus concludes the Midrash. Likewise, it is possible to interpret in our context, "And He covered the sin of the land from the eyes of the inhabitants of the land," those whose thoughts are immersed in earthly matters and do not consider what is above you, and their eyes are covered from seeing the path of truth. Therefore, it is said, "and it could not see the land," and this is a brief verse, and it does not explain who is the one seeing. Generally, it is so that one who is swayed by his desires and whose entire will is to attain only material matters cannot see the truth and sees the opposite, and he confuses it with the truth. One can only align with the truth if his entire will is to do the will of our Father in heaven and he has no other desire besides that. This hints that even after the plagues, Pharaoh will not hear, and his heart will not understand, and the reason is that the eye that sees the land is covered and cannot see the truth, and therefore he will strengthen himself in his wickedness.
summary: The passage discusses the concept of spiritual blindness caused by earthly desires, emphasizing that those who are consumed by materialism cannot perceive the truth. It references a Midrash where Moses calls upon the heavens and the earth, highlighting the importance of recognizing divine authority and the need for respect in spiritual matters. The text suggests that true understanding and alignment with God's will can only be achieved by those who prioritize spiritual over material pursuits. Ultimately, it illustrates that even after experiencing divine signs, individuals like Pharaoh remain blind to the truth due to their attachment to worldly desires.

passage_content: ועתהנבוא לבאר פרשת קרבן פסח והדקדוקים שבענין (עיין לעיל קושיות ט"ו י"ח) ולתרץ קושיתנו הנ"ל מדוע לא נצטוו ישראל לעשות הפסח מיד בר"ח, דלפי טעם המדרש והגמ' שתכלית וטעם המצו' הי' להפרישם מע"ז שהיו שטופים בה, א"כ בכל יומא ויומא זמני', וכל רגע ורגע הוי פסידא דלא הדר, והו"ל להתחיל במצו' זו בר"ח ומדוע נצטוו להמתין עד בעשור לחדש. ואפ"ל בהקדם דברי המדרש בפ' וארא (פ' ו' סי' ה') ולא שמעו אל משה מקוצר רוח וגו' שהי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז, והנה הסיבה לזה היתה מפני שהיו משוקעים ומורגלים בע"ז וטומאת מצרים, ולפרוש מעבירה שמורגל האדם בה גדול הנסיון וקשה מאוד להשיגו, גם מפני שהי' ביניהם רשעי ישראל מרובים, עד שאמרו חז"ל במס' סנהדרין לחד מ"ד שלא יצאו אלא א' מס' רבוא והשאר מתו בג' ימי אפילה מפני שלא רצו לצאת ממצרים, ואלו היו רשעים ודבוקים בע"ז, וכתב הרמב"ם ז"ל (בפ"ו מה' דיעות), דדרך ברייתו של אדם להיות נמשך בדיעותיו ובמעשיו אחר ריעיו וחביריו ונוהג כמנהג אנשי מדינתו וכו', לפיכך אם הוא דר במדינה שמנהגותי' רעים ואין אנשי' הולכים בדרך ישרה, יעזוב את המדינה וילך למקום שאנשי'צדיקים וכו' עכ"ל, ולטעם זה הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז ולעשות תשובה גמורה, כיון שהיו מסובבים ברוב רשעים ועוע"ז, ודרך האדם להיות נמשך אחר ריעיו ולנהוג מנהג בני מדינתו.
translation:
And now let us explain the section of the Passover offering and the nuances regarding the matter (see above questions 15 and 18) and to resolve our question above as to why Israel was not commanded to bring the Passover immediately on the first of the month, for according to the reasoning of the Midrash and the Gemara, the purpose and reason for the commandment was to separate them from idolatry in which they were immersed. Therefore, every day and every moment would be a loss if they did not return, and they should have begun this commandment on the first of the month. Why then were they commanded to wait until the tenth of the month? 

One could say, in advance, the words of the Midrash in Parashat Va'era (Parashat 6, section 5) that they did not listen to Moses because of shortness of spirit, etc., which was difficult for them to separate from idolatry. The reason for this was because they were sunk and accustomed to idolatry and the impurity of Egypt, and to separate from a sin that a person is accustomed to is a great trial and very difficult to achieve. Also, because there were many wicked among them, as our Sages said in Tractate Sanhedrin, according to one opinion, that only one out of six hundred thousand left, and the rest died in three days of darkness because they did not want to leave Egypt. These were the wicked and clung to idolatry. And the Rambam, may his memory be blessed (in chapter 6 of the Laws of Knowledge), wrote that it is the nature of a person to be drawn in his beliefs and actions after his friends and companions and to act according to the customs of his community, etc. Therefore, if he lives in a place where the customs are bad and the people do not walk in a straight path, he should leave that place and go to a place where the people are righteous, etc. Thus, for this reason, it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry and to make complete repentance, since they were surrounded by many wicked and idolaters, and it is the way of a person to be drawn after his friends and to follow the customs of his community.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Passover sacrifice and the delay in its observance until the 10th of the month, emphasizing the challenge for the Israelites to separate from idolatry ingrained in their lives in Egypt. It highlights the difficulty of breaking free from habitual sins, particularly when surrounded by wicked influences, as many Israelites were reluctant to leave Egypt due to their attachment to idolatry. The text reflects on the nature of human behavior, suggesting that individuals are often swayed by their peers and societal norms, which complicates the process of genuine repentance and spiritual elevation. Ultimately, it underscores the profound struggle between the desire for holiness and the pull of familiar, sinful practices.

passage_content: ונקדיםעוד מ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בפ' הארבה, כי לפי החשבון הי' מכת ברד בחודש אדר לא קודם לכן, כי אז השעורה אביב והחטה אפילה, ואח"כ בחודש ימים עד ניסן צמחה החטה והכוסמת והתחילו העצים להוציא פרח, והארבה הי' בניסן, וזה טעם הכתוב ואכל את כל העץ הצומח לכם וגו' עכ"ל, נמצא לפי חשבונו דשלש המכות היו בניסן ארבה חושך ומכת בכורות, ומכת ארבה נמשך עד ז' בניסן, כי כל מכה היתה משמשת ז' ימים, ומכת חשך מפורש בקרא שהי' ו' ימים, ואפשר דבשבת לא הי' מכת החשך משמשת, לפי הטעם שנזכר במדרש שיהיו ישראל מקברים מתיהם, דטעם זה לא שייך בשבת, ולפי"ז נשלמה מכת חשך בערב פסח, ובלילה הי' מכת בכורות, נמצא דבעשור לחודש שהוא שבת הגדול הי' בתוך ימי החושך, ורבינו בחיי חולק על הרמב"ן ז"ל, וס"ל דמכת ארבה הי' באדר, ובר"ח ניסן התחילה מכת חשך והיתה משמשת ז' ימים, ואחריו ז' ימים היו ימי הרוחה שבין מכה למכה, ולפי"ד היתה עשור לחודש אחר תשלום ימי החשך עיי"ש.
translation: And we will further precede what the Ramban, of blessed memory, wrote in Parashat Arbeh, that according to the calculation, the plague of hail occurred in the month of Adar, not before, for then the barley was in its spring and the wheat was in its ripening, and afterwards, a month until Nisan, the wheat and buckwheat grew, and the trees began to blossom, and the locusts were in Nisan. This is the meaning of the verse, "And it ate all the trees that sprouted for you," etc. Thus, according to his calculation, the three plagues were in Nisan: locusts, darkness, and the plague of the firstborn. The plague of locusts lasted until the 7th of Nisan, for each plague lasted for 7 days, and the plague of darkness is explicitly stated in the verse to have lasted for 6 days. It is possible that on Shabbat, the plague of darkness did not serve, according to the reason mentioned in the Midrash that the Israelites would be burying their dead, for this reason does not apply on Shabbat. According to this, the plague of darkness was completed on the eve of Passover, and at night was the plague of the firstborn. Thus, on the tenth of the month, which is the Great Shabbat, it was within the days of darkness. And Rabbeinu Bachaye disagrees with the Ramban, of blessed memory, and holds that the plague of locusts was in Adar, and on Rosh Chodesh Nisan the plague of darkness began and lasted for 7 days, and after that, 7 days were the days of rest between plague and plague. According to his opinion, the tenth of the month was after the completion of the days of darkness, as stated there.
summary: The passage discusses the timing of the plagues in Egypt, particularly focusing on the plague of locusts, darkness, and the death of the firstborn. It highlights the significance of the month of Nisan, where the plagues are seen as a divine orchestration, with each plague lasting seven days. The text reflects on differing opinions regarding the timing of these plagues, emphasizing the theological concept of divine intervention in the natural order and the importance of the Jewish calendar in understanding these events. Ultimately, it illustrates the connection between the plagues and the liberation of the Israelites, reinforcing themes of redemption and divine justice.

passage_content: והנהנצטוו ישראל משכו וקחו לכם, ודרשו חז"ל במד"ר (פ' ט"ז סי' ב') משכו ידיכם מע"ז, והי' צורך לזכות גאולתם תשובה ופרישה מע"ז, בצירוף שמירת שבת כמ"ש (בדברנו פ' בשלח) מדברי הירושלמי (תענית פ"א) דע"י זכות שמירת שבת ותשובה ישראל נגאלין, ויליף לה מדכתיב בשובה ונחת תושעון, וע"כ הי' הצווי של משכו וקחו לקיימה בעשור לחדש שהי' שבת הגדול, כדי שיהי' להם זכות השבת וזכות התשובה, ופירשנו בזה דברי המדרש (שם) משכו וקחו הה"ד בשובה ונחת תושעון עיי"ש. וכתב הטו"ז (או"ח סי' רמ"ב) דמ"ש חז"ל כל המשמר שבת כהלכתהאפי' עוע"ז כדור אנוש מוחלין לו, היינו שמירת שבת בצירוף התשובה, אלא דתשובה לחוד לא מהני כמ"ש ז"ל בד' חלוקי כפרה, עבר על כריתות ומיתות ב"ד תשובה תולה ומיתה ממרקת, ע"כ קמ"ל כאן דתשובה עם שמירת שבת אפי' עוע"ז כדור אנוש שיש בה מיתת ב"ד, מ"מ נמחל לו חטאו לגמרי עכת"ד הטו"ז ז"ל, ומעתה ישראל במצרים שהיו עוע"ז הוצרכו לשני הזכותים גם יחד, דהיינו זכות שמירת שבת וגם זכות התשובה.
translation: And behold, the Israelites were commanded, "Take for yourselves," and our Sages expounded in the Midrash (Parashat 16, Section 2) that "Withdraw your hands from idolatry," and there was a need for them to merit their redemption through repentance and separation from idolatry, along with the observance of Shabbat, as it is stated (in our discussion on Parashat Beshalach) from the words of the Jerusalem Talmud (Taanit 1:1) that through the merit of observing Shabbat and repentance, Israel is redeemed. This is derived from the verse, "In repentance and rest you shall be saved." Therefore, the command of "Take for yourselves" was given on the tenth of the month, which was the Great Shabbat, so that they would have the merit of Shabbat and the merit of repentance. We explained this in the words of the Midrash (there) that "Take for yourselves" corresponds to "In repentance and rest you shall be saved," as mentioned there. And the Taz (Orach Chaim 152) wrote that what our Sages said, "Whoever observes Shabbat according to its laws, even if he worships idols like the generation of Enosh, his sins are forgiven," refers to the observance of Shabbat in conjunction with repentance. However, repentance alone is not effective, as our Sages stated regarding the four categories of atonement: if one transgresses the prohibitions of excision and the death penalty of the court, repentance suspends (the punishment) and death atones. Therefore, it is taught here that repentance with the observance of Shabbat, even for idol worship like the generation of Enosh, which carries the death penalty of the court, nonetheless, his sin is completely forgiven, thus said the Taz. And from now on, the Israelites in Egypt, who were idol worshippers, needed both merits together, namely the merit of observing Shabbat and the merit of repentance.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity for the Israelites in Egypt to engage in both repentance and the observance of the Sabbath as prerequisites for their redemption. It emphasizes that the command to "take" and "draw" was given on the Shabbat before their liberation, linking the merit of Sabbath observance with the act of repentance. The text highlights that while repentance alone may not suffice for atonement, when combined with the observance of the Sabbath, it can lead to complete forgiveness, even for those who have committed severe transgressions. Thus, both the observance of the Sabbath and sincere repentance are essential for achieving redemption.

passage_content: ומעתהאפשר לומר דע"כ לא נצטוו במצו' זו עד בעשור לחדש, כי עד שהיו מסובבים בעובדי ע"ז ורשעי ישראל, הי' קשה להם לעשות תשובה גמורה ולפרוש מע"ז לגמרי, ולהרחיק מלבם ומדעתם תאוות וטומאת מצרים, כי היו רשעי ישראל מרובים עליהם, ובלי ספק הי' ביניהם הרבה מן הצבועים, והי' החשש פן יעכבו עליהם מלפרוש מע"ז פרישה גמורה ע"י כח ההסתה, או ע"י שיכניסו דיעות נפסדות ופשטים שאינם אמת בצווי הבוי"ת ובאופן הפרישה מע"ז, וע"כ לא הי' אפשר לפרוש מע"ז פרישה גמורה עד בעשור לחודש, שהיו ימי החשך משמשים ולדעת רמב"ן ז"ל הי' בעשור לחודש אחר ג' ימים הראשונים של ימי החושך, ולדעת רבינו בחיי הי' אחר תשלום ימי החושך, עכ"פ אפשר שאז כבר מתו כל רשעי ישראל, ונשארו רק בני ישראל הכשרים, שהי' רצונם לפרוש מע"ז ולקיים צווי הבוי"ת באמת, ואז הי' מציאות שתתקיים צווי הבוי"ת משכו ידיכם מע"ז בשלימות גמור, ולא קודם לכן.
translation: And from now on, it is possible to say that they were not commanded in this mitzvah until the tenth of the month, because until they were surrounded by idol worshippers and the wicked of Israel, it was difficult for them to make a complete repentance and to completely separate from idol worship, and to distance from their hearts and minds the desires and impurities of Egypt. For the wicked of Israel were numerous among them, and without a doubt there were many hypocrites among them, and there was a concern that they would hinder them from completely separating from idol worship through the power of incitement, or by introducing false ideas and interpretations that are not true regarding the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and the manner of separating from idol worship. Therefore, it was not possible to completely separate from idol worship until the tenth of the month, which were the days of darkness, and according to Ramban, it was on the tenth of the month after the first three days of darkness, and according to Rabbeinu Bachaye, it was after the completion of the days of darkness. In any case, it is possible that by then all the wicked of Israel had already died, and only the righteous children of Israel remained, who desired to separate from idol worship and to fulfill the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, in truth. Then there was a reality that the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, would be fulfilled, "Withdraw your hands from idol worship" in complete perfection, and not before that.
summary: The passage discusses the timing of the commandment to separate from idolatry, suggesting that it was only possible after the death of the wicked among Israel, who hindered true repentance. It emphasizes that prior to the tenth of the month, the presence of these evildoers and their corrupting influences made it difficult for the righteous to fully detach from idolatry. The text highlights the importance of a pure intention and the necessity of a complete separation from idolatrous practices to fulfill God's commandments authentically. Ultimately, it reflects a Hasidic understanding of spiritual readiness and the transformative power of removing negative influences to achieve true devotion.

passage_content: ועודטעם בדבר דעד שלא נתקיים אצלם פרישה וביטול גמור בע"ז, לא הי' אפשר להם לקיים מצות ק"פ, עפימ"ש הפנים יפות ז"ל לפרש דברי המכילתא משכו ידיכם מע"ז וקחו לכם צאן של מצו', דלכאורה איך אפשר שיקחו מן המצרים שה לקרבן פסח, והרי יש בו איסור משום נעבד שמצריים היו עובדין לצאנם, אלא דאמרינן דע"ז שמכרו עכו"ם או משכנו מסתמא ביטלו, ודוקא שמכרו לישראל אבל מכרו לנכרי לא ביטלו, ע"כ היו צריכין ישראל למשוך ידיהם מע"ז תחלה, ואז נתבטל הע"ז ע"י מכירה עיי"ש, ומעתה א"ש מה שהיתה צווי השי"ת להיות מקחו בעשור דוקא ולא קודם לכן, כי הי' עליו חשש נעבד עד עתה, דלא אמרינן דעכו"ם בטולי' בטלי' אא"כ מכרה לישראל הפרוש מע"ז, ולא הי'הפרישה בשלימות אלא אחר ימי החשך כנ"ל. גם שהוצרכו ישראל לזכותא דשבת בצירוף התשובה ופרישה מע"ז כמ"ש לעיל, ובעשור לחדש הי' השבת היחידה ממכת חושך עד יצ"מ בין לדברי הרמב"ן ז"ל ובין לשיטת הרבינו בחיי ז"ל, ומעתה יובן הטעם שלא יכלו לקיים מצות פרישה זו מר"ח ניסן, והוצרכו להמתין עד בעשור לחדש.
translation: And another reason for this is that until they had a complete separation and total nullification of idolatry, it was not possible for them to fulfill the commandment of the Paschal lamb, as explained by the Pnei Yehoshua, who interprets the words of the Mechilta: "Withdraw your hands from idolatry and take for yourselves sheep for the mitzvah." It seems, how could they take from the Egyptians for the Paschal offering, when there is a prohibition due to the fact that the Egyptians were worshipping their sheep? However, we say that the idolatry sold by a non-Jew or mortgaged is certainly nullified, specifically when sold to a Jew, but if sold to a non-Jew, it is not nullified. Therefore, the Jews needed to withdraw their hands from idolatry first, and then the idolatry was nullified through the sale, as mentioned there. And now it is clear why the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, was to take it specifically on the tenth and not before, because there was a concern of it being worshipped until now, for we do not say that the idolatry is nullified unless it is sold to a Jew who is separated from idolatry, and the separation was not complete until after the days of darkness, as mentioned above. Also, the Jews needed to merit the aspect of Shabbat in conjunction with repentance and separation from idolatry, as stated above, and on the tenth of the month was the only Shabbat from the plague of darkness until the Exodus, according to both the opinion of the Ramban and the opinion of Rabbeinu Bachaye. Therefore, it will be understood why they could not fulfill this commandment of separation from the first of Nissan, and they had to wait until the tenth of the month.
summary: The passage discusses the necessity of complete separation from idolatry before the Israelites could fulfill the commandment of taking a Paschal lamb. It emphasizes that the idolatry must be nullified through specific actions, such as selling to a Jew, to ensure the lamb is not considered "consecrated" to idols. The timing of this commandment is significant, as it aligns with the Sabbath before the Exodus, highlighting the importance of repentance and distancing from idolatry in achieving spiritual readiness for redemption. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of the interplay between divine commandments, human actions, and the process of spiritual purification.

passage_content: ומעתהא"ש מה שהוצרך המצו' הזאת להיות נעשית ע"י הזקנים דוקא כמבואר בדברי המדרש לפי שהזקנים הכניסו האמונה בלב כל ישראל, בשעה שבא משה למצרים וא"ל אלקי אבותיכם שלחני אלכם, וקבלו הזקנים את דבריו של משה, ועי"ז הכניסו אמונת הגאולה בלב כל ישראל, ובזכות האמונה נגאלו ישראל ממצרים, אמר הקב"ה הריני פורע לזקנים ויהי' גאולת מצרים על ידן שנא' ויקרא משה לזקני ישראל ויאמר אלהם משכו וקחו וגו', וגם עכשיו הי' צורך לכח הזקנים, שיסייעו לישראל להפרישם מע"ז פרישה גמורה, כי הי' קשה להם לפרוש מע"ז כמ"ש במדרש הנ"ל, נמצא כי היתה גאולת ישראל על ידיהן של הזקנים, כי אלולי הפרישה מע"ז לא היתה אפשר להן להגאל, וז"ש במדרש שאמר הקב"ה הריני פורע לזקנים מידה כנגד מידה על שהמשיכו את ישראל להאמין בבשורת הגאולה, ע"כ תהי' גאולת ישראל על ידיהן (ומתורץ קושיא י"ז הנ"ל).
translation: And from the time of the evening, what was necessary for this mitzvah to be performed specifically by the elders, as explained in the words of the Midrash, is because the elders instilled faith in the hearts of all Israel when Moses came to Egypt and said to them, "The God of your forefathers has sent me to you." The elders accepted Moses' words, and through this, they instilled the faith of redemption in the hearts of all Israel. And by virtue of this faith, Israel was redeemed from Egypt. The Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I will reward the elders, and the redemption from Egypt will be through them," as it is said, "And Moses called for the elders of Israel and said to them, 'Draw out and take...'" And even now, there was a need for the strength of the elders to assist Israel in completely separating themselves from idolatry, for it was difficult for them to separate from idolatry, as stated in the aforementioned Midrash. Thus, the redemption of Israel was through the elders, for without the separation from idolatry, it would not have been possible for them to be redeemed. Therefore, it is said in the Midrash that the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I will reward the elders measure for measure for having encouraged Israel to believe in the tidings of redemption; therefore, the redemption of Israel will be through them" (and this resolves the aforementioned question).
summary: The passage emphasizes the crucial role of the elders in instilling faith in the redemption among the Israelites during their time in Egypt. It highlights that their acceptance of Moses' message was instrumental in fostering a collective belief in the impending redemption, which ultimately led to their liberation. The text underscores the idea that the elders' efforts in guiding the people away from idolatry were essential for the redemption to occur, illustrating a reciprocal relationship between faith and divine intervention. Thus, the elders are rewarded for their role in nurturing this faith, as the redemption is realized through their leadership.

passage_content: וא"שמ"ש במכילתא לאמר צא ואמור להם מיד דברי ר' ישמעאל, (עיין לעיל קושיא ע"ו) דהנה אע"פ שלא הי' אפשר לקיים מצות פרישה מע"ז אלא בעשור לחודש כנ"ל, ולטעם זה לא נצטוו לעשותה בר"ח, אעפ"כ היתה הצווי לאמר להם מיד. כדי שעכ"פ יקבלו עליהם קבלה אמיתית בלב שלם לפרוש מע"ז מיד בהקדם זמן שאפשר, ושלימות הפרישה לא הי' אפשר עד בעשור לחודש. אבל לפי שלא הי' החסרון מצידם, ע"כ דרשו חז"ל משקבלו עליהם מעלה עליהם הכתוב כאלו כבר עשו. וא"ש מ"ש במכילתא הנ"ל אף משה ואהרן כן עשו, דבאמת משה ואהרן לא הוצרכו להמתין מלקיים המצו' עד בעשור לחדש, כי היו קדושים וטהורים ומוכנים אל המצו' מיד, ולא היו צריכים לטעם הפרישה מע"ז, וא"כ למה לא יקיימו מצות ד' תיכף בר"ח בשעת שנצטוו עלי' כי זריזים מקדימין למצות, ע"כ אמרו במכילתא אף משה ואהרן כן עשו והמתינו עד בעשור לחדש, לפי שהכלל ישראל היו צריכים להמתין עד בעשור לחדש והי' צווי הבוי"ת כן, אין להתחכם על גזירתו ית', ע"כ השמיענו הכתוב דאף משה ואהרן כן עשו והמתינו עד בעשור לחדש. וא"ש.
translation: And it is explained in the Mechilta to say, "Go and tell them immediately," the words of Rabbi Yishmael (see above the question on 76). Behold, although it was not possible to fulfill the commandment of separation from idolatry except on the tenth of the month, as mentioned, and for this reason they were not commanded to do it on Rosh Chodesh, nevertheless, the command was to tell them immediately. This was so that they would at least accept upon themselves a true commitment in a complete heart to separate from idolatry as soon as possible, even though the completeness of the separation could only be achieved on the tenth of the month. However, since there was no shortcoming on their part, therefore our Sages taught that once they accepted it upon themselves, the verse considers it as if they had already done it. And it is explained what is stated in the aforementioned Mechilta, that even Moshe and Aharon did so, for in truth, Moshe and Aharon did not need to wait to fulfill the commandment until the tenth of the month, because they were holy and pure and ready for the commandment immediately, and they did not need the reason for the separation from idolatry. So why did they not fulfill the commandment immediately on Rosh Chodesh at the time they were commanded about it, since the zealous are quick to perform commandments? Therefore, it was said in the Mechilta that even Moshe and Aharon did so and waited until the tenth of the month, because the entire Jewish people needed to wait until the tenth of the month, and the command of the Blessed One was so; one should not be clever against His decree. Therefore, the verse informs us that even Moshe and Aharon did so and waited until the tenth of the month. And it is explained.
summary: The passage discusses the commandment to separate from idolatry, emphasizing that although the full observance could only occur on the tenth of the month, the Israelites were instructed to accept this obligation immediately. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the importance of sincere intention and readiness to fulfill commandments, even if the actual performance is delayed. The text highlights that both Moses and Aaron, despite their purity and readiness, also waited to align with the collective timing for the sake of the community, illustrating the value of communal adherence to divine commandments. Ultimately, it underscores the principle that accepting a commandment with a full heart is regarded as if it has already been fulfilled.

passage_content: נחזורבמה שהתחלנו לבאר מקראי קודש בפרשת הארבה, והדקדוקים שבענין שנפרטו לעיל, בהקדם דברי הכלי יקר ז"ל בפ' וארא עה"פ הנה אנכי מכה במטך וגו' וז"ל בקיצור, בעשר מכות רבו בהם הדיעות, למה זה ועל מה זה היו המכות האלו לעונש על מצרים, וחז"ל נתנו טעם על כל המכות שהיו מידה כנגד מידה על המצריים, והוא ז"ל כתב ג"כ טעמים על כל המכות מדעתי' דנפשי', ובמכת הארבה נתן טעם, דארבה בא עליהם לפי שרצו לבטל מישראל ברכת הרבה ארבה את זרעך ואמרו פן ירבה, ע"כ שלח הקב"ה עליהם מכת הארבה, כי לשון ארבה משמש על הרבוי, כמו שמצינו כן בכמה פסוקים עכת"ד ז"ל, ומצאתי סעד וסמך לטעם זה בש"ך עה"ת, וז"ל מעולם לא הי' ארבה במצרים, ואם בא אינו מזיק ואינו נח, לפי שנתן פרעה את הגר בתו לשרה, ונאמר לה הרבה ארבה את זרעך עכת"ד ז"ל, ואפ"ל בצירוף דברי הכלי יקר ודברי הש"ך ז"ל, דמעולם לא הי' ארבה ע"צ העונש למצרים, מפני שהי' להם ברכת הרבה ארבה שאמר המלאך להגר, וכיון שהיו אותיות אלו מצטרפים להם לברכה, ברכת ד' לא יוסיף עצב עמה, ע"כ לא הצטרפו אותיות אלה להם לקללה ועונש. אבל עתה בא עליהם מכת הארבה ע"צ העונש לפי שרצו לבעל מישראל ברכת הרבה ארבה, ע"כ נצטרפו אותיות אלו להם לקללה וע"צ העונש, גם נפסקמהם ברכת הרבה ארבה מדה כנגד מדה, לפי שרצו לבטל מישראל ברכה זו ואמרו פן ירבה, ואחר שהתפלל משרע"ה להסיר מהם הארבה, הוסר מהם לגמרי צרופי אותיות של ארבה, ולא הי' להם עוד אחיזה באותיות אלו, ומעתה לא הי' עוד ארבה בכל גבול מצרים עד עולם, וגם ברכת הרבה ארבה הוסר מהם,וא"ש מ"ש רבינו חננאל עה"פ לא נשאר ארבה א' בכל גבול מצרים, כי מעת תפלת משרע"ה ועד היום הזה אין ארבה מפסיד בכל גבול מצרים, והי' כ"ז ע"י כח תפלתו של משה שיוסר מהם הארבה עד עולם, אבל לא ע"צ הברכה הגיע להם ככה כ"א ע"צ העונש, כי לא רצה משרע"ה שיהי' להם עוד אחיזה בברכת הרבה ארבה, ולא יתרבו עוד רשעים בעולם, ע"כ הוסר מהם לגמרי הכח באותיות אלו של ארבה, ונתבטל מהם הארבה וגם ברכת הרבה ארבה (ומתורץ קושיא ה' הנ"ל).
translation: We will return to what we began to explain regarding the holy scriptures in the portion of the locust, and the nuances concerning the matter that were detailed above, by prefacing the words of the Kli Yakar, of blessed memory, in Parashat Va'era on the verse "Behold, I will strike with my staff," etc. He writes briefly that there are many opinions regarding the ten plagues, why they were and for what reason these plagues were a punishment for Egypt. Our Sages provided a reason for each of the plagues, that they were measure for measure against the Egyptians. He, of blessed memory, also wrote reasons for each of the plagues according to my understanding and my soul. And regarding the plague of locusts, he gave a reason that the locust came upon them because they wanted to nullify the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed," and they said, "Lest it multiply." Therefore, the Holy One, blessed be He, sent upon them the plague of locusts, for the term "locust" is associated with multiplication, as we find in several verses, as he stated. And I found support for this reason in the Shach on the Torah, who stated that there was never locust in Egypt, and if it came, it did not harm and did not settle, because Pharaoh gave his daughter Hagar to Sarah, and it was said to her, "I will greatly multiply your seed," as he stated. And it can be said, in conjunction with the words of the Kli Yakar and the words of the Shach, that there was never locust as a punishment for Egypt, because they had the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed" that the angel said to Hagar. And since these letters were joined to them for a blessing, the blessing of the Lord does not add sorrow with it, therefore these letters did not join to them for a curse and punishment. But now the plague of locusts came upon them as a punishment because they wanted to nullify the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed," therefore these letters joined to them for a curse and as a punishment, and also the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed" was removed from them measure for measure, because they wanted to nullify this blessing for Israel and said, "Lest it multiply." And after Moses prayed to remove the locust from them, the combinations of the letters of locust were completely removed from them, and they no longer had a hold on these letters. From then on, there was no locust in all the borders of Egypt forever, and also the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed" was removed from them. And this explains what our teacher Chananel stated on the verse that not a single locust remained in all the borders of Egypt, for from the time of Moses' prayer until this day, locust does not harm in all the borders of Egypt, and all this was through the power of Moses' prayer that the locust would be removed from them forever. But it did not come to them because of the blessing; rather, it came to them because of the punishment, for Moses did not want them to have any hold on the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed," and that the wicked should not multiply in the world anymore. Therefore, the power in these letters of locust was completely removed from them, and the locust was nullified from them, as well as the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed" (and the fifth question above is resolved).
summary: The passage discusses the theological significance of the plague of locusts (arbeh) as a divine punishment for Egypt's desire to diminish the blessings bestowed upon Israel. It emphasizes the concept of "measure for measure" (midah k'neged midah), where Egypt's attempt to negate the blessing of abundance for Israel resulted in their own suffering from locusts. The text highlights that, following Moses' prayer, the power of locusts was permanently removed from Egypt, symbolizing the complete withdrawal of the blessing of abundance from them. This reflects a deeper Hasidic insight into the interplay between divine justice and the power of prayer in shaping reality.

passage_content: והנהכל המכות היו מדה כנגד מדה לפי המעשים, ומכת הארבה הי' מדה כנגד מדה באותיות, לפי שרצו לבטל ברכת הרבה ארבה נענשו במכת הארבה, והוסר מהם ברכת הרבה ארבה, ובזה יובן הכתוב למען שתי אותותי אלה בקרבו, שהאותיות אשר בו הרעו לישראל, מדה כנגד מדה באותיות אלו יענשו ויבא אליהם הארבה ויוסר מהם ברכת הרבה ארבה. וא"ש מ"ש אותותי אלה, דכ"מ שנא' אלה פוסל הראשונים, דנפסלו אותיות הראשונים אשר הי' משתמשים להם לברכת הרבה ארבה את זרעך, ונתחלפו ונצטרפו האותיות לקללה ע"צ העונש, וז"ש אותותי אלה פוסל הראשונים (וסרו קושיות ב' וג').
translation: And behold, all the plagues were measure for measure according to the deeds, and the plague of locusts was measure for measure in letters, for they wished to nullify the blessing of "abundant" (locusts), and they were punished with the plague of locusts, and the blessing of "abundant" (locusts) was removed from them. And in this, the verse is understood: "For the sake of these two signs in his midst," that the letters which harmed Israel, measure for measure in these letters, they will be punished, and the locusts will come upon them, and the blessing of "abundant" (locusts) will be removed from them. And it is clear what is meant by "these signs," for wherever it says "these," it disqualifies the first ones, that the letters of the first ones which they used for the blessing of "abundant" (locusts) of your seed were disqualified, and the letters were exchanged and combined for a curse as a consequence of the punishment. Therefore, it is said "these signs" disqualify the first ones (and the questions of B and G are resolved).
summary: The passage discusses the concept of divine retribution, emphasizing that the plagues in Egypt were measures corresponding to the actions of the Egyptians, particularly highlighting the plague of locusts as a punishment for their attempt to negate the blessing of abundance. It explains that the letters associated with the blessing of fertility were transformed into letters of curse, illustrating the principle of "measure for measure" in divine justice. The phrase "these signs" indicates that the original letters used for blessing were rendered ineffective, reinforcing the idea that the very means by which they sought to harm Israel became the source of their own punishment.

passage_content: והנהפרעה הי' חכם גדול כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל, והי' חושש שכאשר יתפלל משה להסיר ממנו הארבה, יסיר מהם כח אותיות אלו ויתבטל מהם גם ברכת הרבה ארבה כאשר הי' באמת כן, ע"כ אמר פרעה העתירו אל ד' ויסר ממנו רק את המות הזה, כוונתו למעט במלת רק ותיבת הזה, שלא יוסר ממנו לגמרי אותיות של ארבה, אלא שלא ישמשו ע"צ העונש, וז"ש רק את המות הזה, אבל כח הברכה בתיבת ארבה ישאר לו. אבל משרע"ה לא עשה כן אלא התפלל שיוסר ממנו לגמרי אותיות אלו ולא נשאר ארבה בכל גבול מצרים עד עולם, וגם ברכת הארבה נתבטלה מהם עד עולם. (ומתורץ קושיא י"א).
translation: And behold, Pharaoh was a great wise man, as the Ramban, of blessed memory, writes, and he was concerned that when Moses would pray to remove the locusts, the power of these letters would be removed from them, and the blessing of the locusts would also be nullified, as it indeed was. Therefore, Pharaoh said, "Entreat the Lord for me, and let Him remove from me only this death," his intention being to minimize with the word "only" and the phrase "this death," so that the letters of locusts would not be completely removed from him, but rather that they would not serve as a punishment. This is what he meant by "only this death," but the power of the blessing in the word "locust" would remain for him. However, Moses did not do this; rather, he prayed that these letters be completely removed from him, and there remained no locusts in all the borders of Egypt forever, and the blessing of the locusts was nullified from them forever. (And the question is resolved).
summary: The passage discusses Pharaoh's wisdom and his concern that if Moses prayed to remove the locusts, the power of the letters associated with them would also be diminished, thus affecting the blessing of abundance. Pharaoh's request to remove "only this death" reflects his intention to retain the potential for blessing while avoiding punishment. In contrast, Moses prayed for the complete removal of the locusts and their associated letters, resulting in their permanent absence in Egypt and the nullification of the blessing of abundance. This highlights the Hasidic theme of the transformative power of prayer and the importance of seeking total spiritual redemption.

passage_content: ובזהמתורץ משה"כ התעללתי במצרים ופרש"י שחקתי, דעד עכשיו הי"ל אותיות אלו של ארבה לברכה, ועכשיו שחקתי בהם ונהפכה לצרה ותוגה עליהם, או אפשר לפי שנשאר להם עכ"פ קצת ריוח ממכה זו, שלא והי' עוד ארבה בגבולם עד עולם, ע"כ קורא הכתוב למכה זו שחוק. ויבואר מה שאמר הכתוב למען תספר באזני בנך וגו' במכת הארבה דייקא, כי הכלל הוא דזה לעומת זה עשה אלקים, וכשזה נופל זה קם, כמו שלמדו חז"ל (פסחים דף מ"ב ע"ב) ממה שאמר הכתוב ולאום מלאום יאמץ, וממ"ש אמלאה החרבה, וע"כ מפני שע"י מכת הארבה הוסר מהם ברכת הרבה ארבה, נתחזק אצל ישראל ברכה זו, וז"ש במדרש למען תספר באזני בנך ובן בנך וגו' מכאן בשורה על הבנים, ר"ל שנתבשרו בברכת הרבה ארבה שיזכו לבנים ובני בנים ואפ"ל עוד כוונה בזה דלכאורה מה צורך לבשורה זו, וכי אפשר שאומה שלימה לא יהי' להם בנים, אמנם הבשורה הי' שיהי' להם בנים ובני בנים מאמינים בד' ובתורתו ויהי' בהם אמונת אומן בנסי ד', וז"ש למען תספר באזני בנך וגו' ולא אמר והגדת לבנך כמ"ש במקו"א, דעצם הבשורה הי' כאן שיכנסו הדברים באזניהם, וזו הברכה האמיתיות של בשורת הבנים.
translation:
And in this it is clarified what is written, "I have dealt harshly with Egypt," and Rashi explains, "I have laughed," for until now these letters of locusts were for a blessing, and now I have laughed at them, and they have turned into trouble and sorrow for them. Or it is possible that since they at least had some relief from this plague, that there would no longer be locusts in their borders forever, therefore the scripture calls this plague "laughter." 

And it will be explained what the scripture says, "so that you may tell in the ears of your son," specifically regarding the plague of locusts, for the general principle is that "this corresponds to that which God has made," and when this falls, that rises, as our Sages learned (Pesachim 42b) from what the scripture says, "and nation shall be strong against nation," and from what is said, "I will fill the desolate." Therefore, because through the plague of locusts the blessing of "many locusts" was removed from them, this blessing was strengthened among Israel. 

And this is what is said in the Midrash, "so that you may tell in the ears of your son and your son's son," from here is the good news about the children, meaning that they were informed of the blessing of "many locusts," that they would merit children and grandchildren. And it can also be said that there is another intention here, for seemingly what need is there for this good news, and is it possible that a whole nation would not have children? However, the good news was that they would have children and grandchildren who believe in God and His Torah, and they would have a true faith in God's miracles. This is why it says, "so that you may tell in the ears of your son," and it does not say "and you shall tell your son," as mentioned elsewhere, for the essence of the good news here was that these words should enter their ears, and this is the true blessing of the good news of children.
summary: The passage discusses the transformation of the locust plague from a potential blessing to a source of suffering for Egypt, highlighting the Hasidic concept that divine actions are often dual in nature, where one event can lead to both downfall and elevation. It emphasizes the importance of storytelling in passing down the legacy of faith and the promise of future generations, specifically that the children of Israel will be blessed with faithful descendants who believe in God and His teachings. The text underscores the idea that true blessing lies in the continuity of faith and the transmission of belief in God's miracles through generations.

passage_content: עודאפ"ל בענין הנ"ל עפ"י המבואר בספה"ק דבכח הצדיקים לבטל גזירה רעה ולהפך הדין לרחמים ע"י שמהפכין צרופי אותיות של הגזירה לטובה, עד"מ צרה לרצה נגע לענג ופי' בזה והנה הנגע לא הפך את עינו, דאם נהפך העי"ן לבוא בראש התיבה נעשה מנגע לענג ונהפך לרחמים ולטובה, וכמו"כ פירשו (תהלים ל"ג י"ח) הנה עין ד' אל יריאיו למיחלים לחסדו להציל ממות נפשם, שאם נגזר ח"ו גזירת מות על המיחלים לחסדו, הבוי"ת מצרף אות עי"ן לתיבת מות ונעשה מעות, וזהו הנה עי"ן ד' אל יריאיו וגו' ועי"ז להציל ממות נפשם ולהחיותם ברעב ונתהפך הגזירה לטובה, ועד"ז מבואר בספה"ק שפרשת התוכחה רמוזים בה ברכות וטובות לישראל, ואם יזכו יתהפכו כולם לברכות ע"י התהפכות צירופי האותיות מקללה לברכה, ועד"ז בתיבה שיש לה ב' משמעות לטובה ולהיפך ח"ו, בכח הצדיקים וברצונו ית' מהפך המשמעות לטובה ומהדין עצמו נעשה רחמים גמורים לישראל ולהיפך לשונאי ישראל. ועד"זיתבאר לענינו דהמצרים מפני שרצו לבטל מישראל ברכת הרבה ארבה את זרעך ואמרו פן ירבה, ע"כ נהפך להם משמעות ארבה לקללה במכת הארבה והוסר מהם ברכת הרבוי ולישראל נעשה ממכת הארבה ברכה ונתחזק אצלם ברכת הרבוי
translation: Furthermore, it can be said regarding the above matter according to what is explained in the holy books, that the power of the righteous is to annul a bad decree and to transform judgment into mercy by reversing the combinations of the letters of the decree for good. For example, the word "tzara" (trouble) can be transformed into "ratzon" (will) and it is explained that the affliction did not change its "ayin" (eye), for if the "ayin" is transformed to come at the beginning of the word, it becomes "oneg" (delight) and is turned into mercy and goodness. Likewise, it is explained (Psalms 33:18) "Behold, the eye of the Lord is upon those who fear Him, upon those who hope for His kindness, to save their souls from death," that if a decree of death is, Heaven forbid, issued against those who hope for His kindness, the Blessed One combines the letter "ayin" with the word "mavet" (death) and it becomes "ma'ot" (money), and this is "the eye of the Lord is upon those who fear Him," and through this, He saves their souls from death and revives them in famine, and the decree is transformed for good. Similarly, it is explained in the holy books that the section of the rebuke contains hints of blessings and goodness for Israel, and if they merit it, they will all be transformed into blessings through the transformation of the combinations of the letters from curse to blessing. Likewise, in a word that has two meanings, for good and the opposite, Heaven forbid, through the power of the righteous and His will, He transforms the meaning for good, and from the judgment itself, complete mercy is made for Israel and the opposite for the enemies of Israel. And similarly, it can be explained regarding the Egyptians, because they wanted to annul the blessing of "I will greatly multiply your seed," and said, "lest they multiply," therefore the meaning of "arbeh" (to multiply) was turned into a curse in the plague of locusts, and the blessing of multiplication was removed from them, while for Israel, from the plague of locusts, a blessing was made, and the blessing of multiplication was strengthened among them.
summary: The passage discusses the Hasidic concept that the righteous have the power to transform negative decrees into positive outcomes by rearranging the letters of the words associated with those decrees. It illustrates this idea through examples from scripture, such as changing "negev" (plague) to "oneg" (delight) and the transformation of death into life for those who trust in God. The text emphasizes that through the merit of the righteous and divine will, curses can be turned into blessings, as seen in the case of the Egyptians who sought to diminish Israel's fertility, only to have their own intentions reversed against them. Ultimately, it highlights the dynamic interplay between divine justice and mercy, where the righteous can invoke a shift from judgment to compassion.

passage_content: ובזהיל"פ דברי הזוה"ק בפתיחת פ' הארבה, ר"י פתח ואמר אשרי העם יודעי תרועה ד' באור פניך יהלכון ע"כ וצ"ב הקישור ויתבאר עפי"ד הגמ' (ר"ה ט"ז ע"ב) וא"ר יצחק כל שנה שאין תוקעין לה בתחילתה מריעין לה בסופה מ"ט דלא איערבב שטן עכ"ד הגמ' וכתב הטו"ז (ה' ר"ה סי' תקפ"ה) שנתגלה לו בחלום פי' הכתוב בחצוצרות וקול שופר הריעו לפני המלך ד', עפי"ד הגמ' הנ"ל, שיהיו נזהרים לקיים התרועה ע"י שופר, קודם שתהי' התרועה ח"ו בסוף השנה מאתו ית', ובזה אמר לפני המלך ד' כלומר קודם תרועת המלך ב"ה עכ"ל, וע"ד הרמז נל"פ עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל דהנה מלת תרועה יש לה ב' משמעות, כמ"ש המהרש"א ז"ל בח"א (ר"ה ל"ב ע"ב) דמלת תרועה מורה על מדת הדין מלשון שבר עכ"ל, ובפ' בלק פרש"י ז"ל עה"פ ותרועת מלך בו לשון חבה וריעות וכו' וכן פי' הרשב"ם כמו איש רעים להתרועע וכן ת"א ושכינת מלכהון ביניהון, ומסגולת השופר להפך מדת הדין לרחמים ונעשה מתרועהשהוא לשון שבר תרועה של חבה ורעות, וז"פ הריעו לפני המלך ד' קודם תרועת המלך וכו', ר"ל שע"י סגולת השופר יתהפך הגזירה לטובה וימתק הדין בשרשו.
translation: And in this, the words of the Zohar are explained in the opening of Parashat Ha'arvah, Rabbi Yoel opened and said, "Blessed is the people who know the sound of the shofar; O Lord, in the light of Your countenance they walk." Therefore, the connection is questioned and will be explained according to the words of the Gemara (Rosh Hashanah 16b), and Rabbi Yitzchak said, "Every year that we do not blow the shofar at its beginning, we will sound it at its end. Why? Because the accuser does not mix in." Thus said the Gemara. And the Taz wrote (Orach Chaim, Rosh Hashanah 585) that it was revealed to him in a dream the interpretation of the verse, "With trumpets and the sound of the shofar, shout before the King, the Lord," according to the aforementioned Gemara, that we should be careful to fulfill the teruah by means of the shofar, before the teruah, Heaven forbid, at the end of the year from Him, blessed be He. And in this, it is said, "Before the King, the Lord," meaning before the teruah of the King, blessed be He. Thus far is his statement. And according to the hint, it seems to me, based on our previous path, that behold, the word teruah has two meanings, as the Maharsha, of blessed memory, explained in his commentary (Rosh Hashanah 32b) that the word teruah indicates the attribute of judgment, from the language of breaking. Thus far is his statement. And in Parashat Balak, Rashi, of blessed memory, explained on the verse, "And the teruah of the King is in it," as a language of affection and friendship, etc. Similarly, the Rashbam explained, like "a man of friends to befriend," and so too the Targum, "and the Shechinah is among them." And it is the quality of the shofar to transform the attribute of judgment into mercy, and it becomes from the teruah, which is a language of breaking, a teruah of affection and friendship. And this is the meaning of "Shout before the King, the Lord," before the teruah of the King, etc., meaning that through the quality of the shofar, the decree will be turned to good, and the judgment will be sweetened at its root.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the shofar's sound, particularly in relation to the Jewish New Year and the themes of judgment and mercy. It emphasizes the dual meaning of "teruah," which can signify both a breaking (associated with judgment) and a joyful call (associated with love and friendship). By sounding the shofar, one can transform the harshness of divine judgment into mercy, thereby invoking a favorable decree from God. This act is seen as a preemptive call to God, ensuring that the year begins with a positive spiritual tone before any potential harsh judgments are pronounced.

passage_content: ובזהיל"פ מאמה"כ אשרי העם יודעי תרועה ד' באור פניך יהלכון, ר"ל שישראל ניתן להם הכח להפוך התרועה לטובה, כמו שדרשו רז"ל (ויק"ר פ' כ"ט סי' ד') יודעי תרועה שיודעים לרצות את בוראם בתרועה, ומהפכים הדין לרחמים, ונתן טעם ד' באור פניך יהלכון שנשפעים מאורו ית', ובחי' האור משמשת ג"כ לב' פנים כמ"ש רז"ל ריש פסחים דאור משמעותי' יממא ומשמעותי' נגהי עיי"ש, והגה"ק מברדיטשוב זלה"ה פי' בזה כיתרון האור מן החשך כן יתרון לחכם מן הכסיל, כמו שהאור משמשת לב' פנים משא"כ החשך, כן יתרון לחכם מן הכסיל, כי החכם יכול לשנות את טעמו כמ"ש לדוד בשנותו וגו' משא"כ הכסיל עיי"ש וא"ש קישור דברי הזוה"ק לפ' הארבה, דגם בארבה הי' בחי' זו שע"י עתירת משרע"ה הוסר מכת הארבה ונתחלף לישראל לברכת הרבה ארבה ולמצרים להיפך, כן יעזור השי"ת בכל הדורות להמשיך השפעות טובות על ישראל רחמים וחסדים, ובמהרה נזכה לראות בישועת כל ישראל ושמחתן בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו בב"א.
translation: And in this context, as it is written, "Blessed is the people that know the sound of the shofar; they walk, O Lord, in the light of Your countenance," meaning that Israel has been given the power to transform the sound of the shofar for good, as our Sages have expounded (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashah 29, Section 4), "those who know the sound of the shofar" are those who know how to appease their Creator with the sound of the shofar, and they transform judgment into mercy. And He gave the reason, "for in the light of Your countenance they walk," as they receive from His blessed light. And the aspect of light also serves two faces, as our Sages have said at the beginning of Pesachim, "Light signifies day and signifies brightness," see there. And the holy Rabbi from Berdichev, may his merit protect us, explained this: just as the advantage of light over darkness is so is the advantage of the wise over the fool, for light serves two faces, whereas darkness does not. So too, the advantage of the wise over the fool, for the wise can change his taste, as it is said of David, "when he changed his behavior," whereas the fool cannot, see there. And it is clear how this connects to the words of the Zohar regarding the locusts, that also in the case of the locusts, through the prayer of Moshe Rabbeinu, the plague of locusts was removed and transformed for Israel into a blessing of "many locusts," and for Egypt the opposite. So may the Holy One, blessed be He, help in all generations to continue to bring forth good influences upon Israel, mercy and kindness, and may we soon merit to see the salvation of all Israel and their joy in the uplifting of the horn of the Torah and Israel, and in the revelation of the glory of Heaven upon us, amen.
summary: The passage emphasizes the unique ability of the Jewish people to transform their cries (teruah) into a means of favor with God, thereby converting judgment into mercy. It highlights the dual nature of divine light, which can illuminate and elevate the wise while contrasting with the darkness of foolishness. The text draws parallels to the biblical story of the locust plague, illustrating how through prayer, negative decrees can be reversed into blessings. Ultimately, it expresses a hopeful vision for the future, anticipating divine mercy and the revelation of God's glory among the Jewish people.

passage_content: באופןאחר נל"פ דברי הזוהר הקדוש, בהקדם לבאר עוד בדברי הגמ' דסנהדרין הנ"ל, על פי המבואר בדבריהם ז"ל כי יש ששים רבוא אותיות לתורה, וכנגדן ס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל, ישראל נוטריקון יש ששים רבוא אותיות לתורה, וכל נשמה נאצל מאות א' שבתורה הקדושה, ובני ישראל שבכל דור ודור כולן שורשם וגזעם מאותן הששים רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל שקבלו התוה"ק, נמצא כל א' מישראל מקושר באות א' בתורה, וק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה (בפ' תשא) הביא מ"ש השלה"ק בשם מגלת סתרים כי ס' רבוא נשמות לישראל וס' רבוא שבתות, שי"ן אלפים בשית אלפי שנין, וש' אלפים ביום שכולו שבת דהוא אלף השביעי, וכל נשמה נחצבה משבת א' עיי"ש, ופי' ק"ז זלה"ה בזה הפסוק כי אות היא ביני וביניכם, דס' רבוא אותיות לתורה וכל נשמה יש לה אות, וכמו"כ כל שבת ג"כ נחצב מאות א' שבתוה"ק, וא"כ כל שבת ושבת הוא ממש איזה אות בהתורה כל שבת אות אחר, וז"ש כי אות היא, ונמצא לפי"ז אותו האדם שהשבת מתייחס לו ביום השבת ההוא והבן, אם מחלל ח"ו השבת ההוא עונשו גדול מכל מחללי שבתות שהיו בעולם ושיהיו בעולם, דהרי הוא פוגם בעצם אותו השבת במקומו ובשעתו וכו', ופוגם בכל ישראל שסותם עצם האור שלא תוכל להאיר לישראל, וההיפך באם שמרו שכרו גדול יותר מכל שומרי שבתות שהיו ושיהיו, דהרי נותן הארה לשבת בהעצם ומאיר לכל ישראל בהארה יפה וברה, ומקבל הארה מכולם בסוד אור חוזר עכ"ל ק"ז זלל"ה, וכן הוא ממש באותיות התוה"ק אם ח"ו פוגם באותהזה המתייחס אליו ולשרשו גדול עונו מנשוא ר"ל וה"ה פוגם בכל ישראל למנוע הארת הקדושה ח"ו, להיפך באם שמרו מאיר לכל ישראל וכנ"ל, נמצא דע"י התוה"ק מתקשרין ומתאחדין כל נשמות ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות, דכולם נכללים בס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל שקבלו התוה"ק, וכל א' מהם נאצל מאות א' שבתוה"ק, וכל אותיות שבתוה"ק מתקשרין ומתאחדין כחדא, דס"ת שחסר ממנה אפי' אות א' פסולה, והמגיה בה אפי' אות א' כאילו כתבה כולה, ועד"ז כל ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות מקושרים באותן ס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל ובתוה"ק,
translation: In another way, we can understand the words of the holy Zohar, by first explaining further the words of the Gemara in Sanhedrin mentioned above, according to what is explained in their words, that there are six hundred thousand letters in the Torah, corresponding to six hundred thousand roots of the souls of Israel. "Israel" is an acronym for "there are six hundred thousand letters in the Torah," and each soul is derived from one letter of the holy Torah. The children of Israel in every generation are all rooted and stem from those six hundred thousand roots of the souls of Israel who received the Torah. Thus, each one of Israel is connected to one letter in the Torah. And this is what Moshe, peace be upon him, rejoiced (in Parashat Tisa) when he brought what is said in the Shlah HaKadosh in the name of the Megillat Setarim, that there are six hundred thousand souls for Israel and six hundred thousand Shabbatot, which are sixty thousand in six thousand years, and sixty thousand on the day that is entirely Shabbat, which is the seventh millennium. And every soul is hewn from one Shabbat, as stated there. The explanation of this is that the verse "for a sign is between Me and you" means that there are six hundred thousand letters in the Torah, and each soul has a letter. Likewise, every Shabbat is also hewn from one letter of the holy Torah. Therefore, each Shabbat is indeed a letter in the Torah, each Shabbat a different letter. This is what is meant by "for a sign it is." According to this, the person to whom the Shabbat relates on that Shabbat, if he, Heaven forbid, desecrates that Shabbat, his punishment is greater than all those who have desecrated Shabbat in the world and will do so in the future, for he is damaging the essence of that Shabbat in its place and at its time, etc., and he damages all of Israel by blocking the essence of the light so that it cannot shine for Israel. Conversely, if he observes it, his reward is greater than all those who have observed Shabbat in the past and will do so in the future, for he gives illumination to the Shabbat in its essence and shines for all of Israel with a beautiful and clear light, and receives illumination from all in the secret of the returning light, as stated by the holy Kabbalist. And it is indeed the same with the letters of the holy Torah; if, Heaven forbid, he damages that which relates to him, his sin is greater than can be borne, God forbid, and the same applies to damaging all of Israel, preventing the illumination of holiness, Heaven forbid. Conversely, if he observes it, he brings light to all of Israel, as mentioned above. Thus, through the holy Torah, all the souls of Israel are connected and united until the end of all generations, for they are all included in the six hundred thousand roots of the souls of Israel who received the holy Torah, and each of them is derived from one letter of the holy Torah. All the letters of the holy Torah are connected and united as one, for a Torah scroll that is missing even one letter is invalid, and one who corrects it even with one letter is as if he wrote the entire scroll. Similarly, all of Israel until the end of all generations are connected to those six hundred thousand roots of the souls of Israel and to the holy Torah.
summary: The passage emphasizes the profound connection between the letters of the Torah and the souls of the Jewish people, asserting that each soul is rooted in one of the 600,000 letters of the Torah. It highlights the significance of the Sabbath, stating that each Sabbath corresponds to a specific letter, and that violating the Sabbath has far-reaching consequences, affecting both the individual and the collective spiritual light of Israel. Conversely, observing the Sabbath enhances the divine illumination for all Jews. Ultimately, the text illustrates the unity of all Jewish souls through the Torah, where even a single missing letter renders the entire Torah invalid, symbolizing the interconnectedness of the Jewish people across generations.

passage_content: והנהמצינו דשורש נשמות ישראל שבדור המדבר היו כלולים כולם בס"ה משפחות, כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל בפ' פנחס עה"פ ואלה בני שותלח וז"ל צא וחשוב ותמצא בפרשה זו נ"ז משפחות ומבני לוי שמונה הרי ס"ה, וז"ש כי אתם המעט וגו' ה"א מעט, חמשה אתם חסרים ממשפחות כל העמים שהם שבעים, וכו' מיסודו של ר' משה הדרשן עכ"ל, נמצא דכל ישראל שבכל הדורות שרשם מאותן ס"ה משפחות, כל אחד משורש משפחה א' מהם אשר משם חוצבתו, ומקושרים כולם כאחד ע"י קדושת התוה"ק כנ"ל, וכענין הזה בעיירות של ארץ ישראל שנתחלקה הארץ בימי יהושע בגורל עפ"י ד', כל א' מישראל קבל חלקו המתייחס אליו ולשורש נשמתו, (ובספרי ויואל משה מאמר ישוב א"י סי' קכ"ח הארכתי בזה עיי"ש) היוצא לנו מזה דכל ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות מקושרין באותן ס' רבוא שרשי נשמות ישראל שבדור המדבר ובאותן ס"ה משפחות ובאותן עיירות שמתייחסים לשורש נשמתם ונפל בגורלם עפ"י ד' וברוה"ק.
translation: And behold, we find that the root of the souls of Israel in the generation of the desert were all included in 65 families, as Rashi, of blessed memory, writes in Parashat Pinchas on the verse "And these are the sons of Shuthelach," and he says: "Go out and count, and you will find in this section 57 families, and from the children of Levi eight, thus making a total of 65." This is what is meant by "for you are the few," etc. The "few" refers to the five that you are lacking from the families of all the nations, which are seventy, etc., based on the foundation of Rabbi Moshe the preacher, thus it is concluded that all of Israel in all generations are rooted from those 65 families, each one from the root of one family from them from which he is hewn, and they are all connected as one through the sanctity of the Torah and the commandments, as mentioned. And in a similar manner, in the towns of the Land of Israel, when the land was divided in the days of Joshua by lot according to the tribes, each one of Israel received his portion that relates to him and to the root of his soul (and in the book "Vayoeil Moshe," in the essay on the settlement of the Land of Israel, section 128, I elaborated on this, see there). What emerges from this is that all of Israel until the end of all generations are connected to those 600,000 roots of the souls of Israel in the generation of the desert, and to those 65 families, and to those towns that relate to the root of their souls, and fell to their lot according to the tribes and through the Holy Spirit.
summary: The passage discusses the connection between the souls of the Jewish people throughout all generations and the 65 families that existed during the time of the Israelites in the desert. It emphasizes that each individual is rooted in one of these families, linking them through the sanctity of the Torah. Additionally, it highlights the idea that every Jew receives their portion in the Land of Israel according to their spiritual lineage, reinforcing the unity and continuity of the Jewish people through divine providence and the Holy Spirit.

passage_content: ולפי"זאפ"ל דמ"ש הכתוב ולקחתי א' מעיר ושנים ממשפחה מיירי באותן עיירות ובאותן ס"ה משפחות שהם מתייחסים לשרשי נשמות ישראל, והעיירות של עכשיו והמשפחות של עכשיו אינם בחשבון הזה, כי איך אפשר לכייל כולם בדרגא חדא וישנם עיירות גדולות ומרובים יושבי' המחזיקים בתורת ד' וכן להיפך ח"ו, ועד"ז במשפחות, ואיך יהי' מידתם שוה לדברי ר"י ולר"ל כקושיתנו לעיל, אמנם אותן העיירות והמשפחות כולם משורש א', וכל ישראל עד סוף כל הדורות מקושרים בהם כל א' בשרשו כנ"ל, ובזה מיירי הכתוב ור"ל ס"ל דברים ככתבן, דפשוטו של מקרא כך הוא ועפ"י תוקף ודקדוק הדין לא ימצא זכאי בדינו כ"א א' מעיר וב' ממשפחה, ור' יוחנן ורב פליגי עלי' וס"ל דא' מעיר מזכה כל העיר כולה, ושנים ממשפחה מזכין כל המשפחה כולה שינצלו בזכותם שכלולים כולם בשורש א' כנ"ל.
translation: According to this, it is said that what the scripture states, "And I will take one from a city and two from a family," refers specifically to those cities and those families that are related to the roots of the souls of Israel. The cities of today and the families of today are not included in this calculation, for how can they all be measured on the same level? There are large and numerous cities inhabited by those who uphold the Torah of the Almighty, and conversely, there are those who do not, Heaven forbid. The same applies to families; how can their measure be equal according to the words of Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer, as we questioned above? However, those cities and families are all from one root, and all of Israel, until the end of all generations, are connected to them, each one to its root, as mentioned. In this, the scripture speaks, and Rabbi Eliezer holds that the words are as they are written. The simple meaning of the verse is thus, and according to the strength and precision of the law, one will not find a righteous person in his judgment except for one from a city and two from a family. Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi argue about this, and hold that one from a city merits for the entire city, and two from a family merit for the entire family, so that they may be saved by their merit, as they are all included in one root, as mentioned.
summary: הקטע עוסק בקשר בין נשמות ישראל לשורשיהם הרוחניים, ומדגיש כי העיירות והמשפחות של היום אינן נחשבות באותו אופן כמו אלו המוזכרות בתורה. כל נשמה קשורה לשורש אחד, ולכן כאשר אחד מעיר ושניים ממשפחה נחשבים זכאים, הם יכולים להועיל לכלל העיר או המשפחה בזכות הקשר הזה. המחלוקות בין ר' יוחנן לרב מצביעות על ההבנה העמוקה של הקשרים הרוחניים וההשפעה ההדדית בין הפרטים לקהילה.

passage_content: וא"לר' יוחנן לר"ל לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת להו הכי, פרש"י אין הקב"ה רוצה שתהא דן את ישראל כל כך לכף חובה, דהנה קיי"ל היכא דפליגי ר' יוחנן ור"ל הלכה כר' יוחנן וכן הלכתא כוותי' לגבי רב, ומכ"ש כאן דרב ור' יוחנן פליגי על ר"ל ושניהם ס"ל דא' מעיר מזכה כל העיר וכו', אך כבר כתב הרמב"ם ז"ל בפי' המשניות פרק חלק אצל הפלוגתא אם עשרת השבטים עתידין לחזור וז"ל, כבר כתבתי לך פעמים רבות שכל מחלוקת שיהי' בין החכמים שאינו בא לידי מעשה, אלא שהוא אמונת דבר בלבד, אין צד לפסוק הלכה כא' מהם עכ"ל, והנה בכל פלוגתת חז"ל נמסרה כח ההכרעה לחכמי הדור כמ"ש הריטב"א (ערובין י"ג ע"ב) בביאור אמרם ז"ל אלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים עיי"ש אבל בענין כזה שביד הקב"ה לעשות תליא ההכרעה במשקל ק"ל דעות ולכך א"ר יוחנן לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת להו הכי, כלומר בודאי הקב"ה לא יכריע כדבריך, דרב חסד מטה כלפי חסד והבוי"ת יסכים על ידינו להכריע לכף זכות דאחד מעיר יציל כל בני העיר וב' ממשפחה יגינו על כולן, ובלבד שיהיו מקושרים בהשורש באותן ס"ה משפחות ובאותיות התוה"ק, כי אלו שנפסקו ונעתקו ח"ו משרשם בקדושה, עליהם אמר הכתוב וברותי מכם המורדים והפושעים וגו', אבל כל א' מישראל המקושר בתוה"ק ומצותי', ה"ה מקושר בשורש נשמות ישראל ולאותן ס"ה משפחות, ושנים מהם יגינו ויצילו כולם.
translation: And Rabbi Yochanan said to Rabbi Levi, "It is not pleasing to them that you said this to them." Rashi explains that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not want you to judge Israel so harshly. Behold, we hold that where Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Levi disagree, the halacha follows Rabbi Yochanan, and similarly, the halacha is in accordance with him regarding Rav. How much more so here, where Rav and Rabbi Yochanan disagree with Rabbi Levi, and both hold that one from a city can merit the entire city, etc. However, the Rambam has already written in his commentary on the Mishnah, in the chapter on the World to Come, regarding the dispute about whether the Ten Tribes will return, and he wrote: "I have already written to you many times that any dispute among the sages that does not come to practical action, but is merely a matter of belief, there is no basis to rule halacha like one of them." Thus, in all disputes of our sages, the power of decision has been given to the sages of the generation, as the Ritva explains (Eruvin 13b) in his commentary on their saying, "These and those are the words of the Living God." However, in a matter like this, which is in the hands of the Holy One, Blessed be He, the decision depends on weighing a hundred and twenty opinions. Therefore, Rabbi Yochanan said, "It is not pleasing to them that you said this to them," meaning certainly the Holy One, Blessed be He, will not decide according to your words, for Rav leans towards kindness, and the Blessed One will agree through us to decide in favor of merit, that one from a city can save all the inhabitants, and two from a family can protect them all, provided they are connected to the root of those thirty-five families and to the letters of the Holy Torah. For those who have been severed and removed, Heaven forbid, from their root in holiness, upon them the verse says, "And I will cut off from you the rebellious and the sinners," etc. But every Jew who is connected to the Holy Torah and its commandments is also connected to the root of the souls of Israel and to those thirty-five families, and two of them will protect and save all.
summary: The passage discusses the importance of judging the Jewish people favorably, emphasizing that God prefers to lean towards mercy rather than strict judgment. It highlights the concept that even one righteous individual can save an entire community, provided they are connected to the roots of holiness and the Torah. The text also underscores the idea that those who have strayed from their spiritual roots are at risk, while those who remain connected to the Torah and its commandments are safeguarded through their inherent connection to the collective soul of Israel. Ultimately, it reflects a deep theological belief in the power of communal righteousness and divine mercy.

passage_content: ואפ"לעוד בביאור הענין דהנה בגמ' דסנהדרין הנ"ל פליגי ג"כ ר' יוחנן ור"ל בפי' הכתוב (ישעי' ה') לכן הרחיבה שאול נפשה ופערה פיה לבלי חוק, אמר ר"ל למי שמשייר אפי' חוק אחדפרש"י שמשייר אפי' חוק א' מלשמרו נדון בגיהנם, א"ר יוחנן לא ניחא למרייהו דאמרת להו הכי, אלא אפי' לא למד אלא חוק א' עכ"ד הגמ' וכתב המהרש"א ז"ל בח"א לכאורה לפי משמעו קשה לדברי ר"ל, וכי משום עבירה א' נופל בגיהנם ולר"י נמי וכי מצוה אחת מצלת האדם מן הגיהנם עיי"ש תירוצו ועוד לאלקי מילין.
translation: And furthermore, in explaining the matter, behold, in the Gemara of Sanhedrin mentioned above, Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer also argue regarding the interpretation of the verse (Isaiah 5): "Therefore Sheol has enlarged its appetite and opened its mouth without measure." Rabbi Eliezer said this refers to one who leaves even one commandment unobserved; Rashi explains that one who neglects even one commandment is judged in Gehenna. Rabbi Yochanan said that it is not pleasing to them that you say this, but even if one has only learned one commandment, so concludes the Gemara. And the Maharsha, may his memory be blessed, wrote in his first explanation that seemingly, according to its meaning, it is difficult to the words of Rabbi Eliezer. Is it because of one transgression that one falls into Gehenna? And according to Rabbi Yochanan, is it true that one commandment saves a person from Gehenna? See there for his resolution and also for the divine matters.
summary: The passage discusses a debate between Rabbi Yochanan and Rabbi Eliezer regarding the implications of a person's adherence to the commandments, as referenced in Isaiah. Rabbi Eliezer posits that even neglecting a single commandment can lead one to judgment in Gehenna, while Rabbi Yochanan suggests that even fulfilling one commandment can save a person from such a fate. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the significance of individual actions and their consequences in the spiritual realm, emphasizing the importance of both adherence to the law and the potential for redemption through even minimal observance. The discussion highlights the tension between strict justice and the possibility of mercy in divine judgment.
