passage_content: ומעתהנבוא לבאר עפ"י דברי המדרש הובא בבעה"ט שהשיב משה בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, כי לא נגזרה גזירה לא על פחות מבן כ' ועל יתר מבן ס', ולפירוש זה צ"ב המשך דברי הפסוק בבנינו ובבנותנו, דכבר נכלל במאמר בנערינו ובזקנינו (עיין לעיל קושיא ב'), ויובן עפימ"ש בש"ך עה"ת (פ' דברים) בהקדם קושית המפורשים וכן הקשה באור החיים הק' שמצינו שהוכיח משרע"ה את ישראל על מה שהמרו על ים בים סוף, ויאמר האומר והלא אותם שהמרו על ים סוף כבר מתו ונשלמו בט"ו באב של שנת המ' קודם מאמר זה של משה, וא"כ אלה הצאן מה עשו שמוכיחם עיי"ש תירוצו, ובש"ך עה"ת כתב לתרץ דשפיר הוכיחם דעכשיו כבר חזרו ונתגלגלו בהם אותם החוטאים וידעו בעצמן ולזה שתקו ע"כ, נמצא דאותו הדור שנכנסו לא"י הם בעצמן היו דור המדבר שנתגלגלו עוה"פ בבניהם.
translation: And from now on, we will explain according to the words of the Midrash brought in the Be'er Heitev, that Moses replied, "With our young and with our old we will go," for the decree was not made on less than twenty years old and not more than fifty. According to this interpretation, the continuation of the verse regarding "our sons and our daughters" is puzzling, as it is already included in the statement "with our young and with our old" (see above question 2). This will be understood according to what is stated in the Shach on the Torah (Parshat Devarim) in advance of the question of the commentators, and similarly, the holy Ohr HaChaim asked why we find that Moshe reproached Israel for rebelling at the Sea of Reeds, and he said, "But those who rebelled at the Sea of Reeds have already died and were completed on the fifteenth of Av of the fortieth year before this statement of Moses." Therefore, what did these sheep do that he reproached them? See there for his answer. And in the Shach on the Torah, he wrote to answer that he reproached them because now those sinners had returned and reincarnated in them, and they knew it themselves, and that is why they were silent. Thus, it turns out that that generation that entered the Land of Israel were themselves the generation of the desert who had reincarnated in their children.
summary: הקטע עוסק בהבנת דברי משה רבנו על כך שעם ישראל ייצא ממצרים עם כל הגילים, ומדגיש את הקשר בין הדורות. המדרש מציע שהדור שנכנס לארץ ישראל הוא למעשה גלגול של דור המדבר, מה שמצביע על המשכיות רוחנית ולקיחת אחריות על חטאים קודמים. התובנה היא שהנשמות של החוטאים מהדור הקודם חזרו בגלגול, ולכן משה יכול להוכיח את הדור הנוכחי על מעשיהם. זה מדגיש את הרעיון החסידי של תיקון ותהליך רוחני מתמשך בין הדורות.

passage_content: ולפי"זאפ"ל דעל שאלת פרעה מי ומי ההולכים ליכנס לארץ כי כולם ימותו במדבר, השיבו משרע"ה ב' תשובות בנערינו ובזקנינו נלך, כי לא נגזרה גזירה לא על פחות מבן כ' ולא על יתר מבן ס' כמ"ש בבעה"ט, ועוד השיבו בבנינו ובבנותנו נלך, שאף מתי מדבר יכנסו לא"י ע"י שיתגלגלו עוה"פ בבניהם כדברי הש"ך עה"ת, ובזה יובן מה שחלקן לשתים גם כפל מלת נלך ב"פ על שהם ב' בחי' הליכות, או אפשר שירמוז על לעתיד שאז יקומו מתי מדבר ויעמדו בגופם וע"כ כפל עוה"פ נלך. וכמו"כ בחורבן הנורא שהי' בימינו שנאבדו בעוה"ר אלפים ורבבות מישראל, מי יודע אם לא חזרו כבר ונתגלגלו בבנינו ובנותנו, והדור של עכשיו הם חלק מאותו הדור וניצוצי נשמתם, ועלינו מוטל לגדל אלו הבנים בדרך התוה"ק שיזכו לקבל פני משיח צדקינו, ועל כל אב מוטל להשגיח על בניו שיתנהגו בטהרה ולא יתלכלכו בעונות ח"ו ויהיו זכאין ובזה יהי' תיקון גם לנפשנו.
translation: According to this, it can be said that in response to Pharaoh's question of who is going to enter the land, since they will all die in the desert, Moshe Rabbeinu gave two answers: "With our young and with our old we will go," for it was not decreed that anyone under the age of twenty or over the age of sixty would die, as stated in the Ba'al HaTurim. Furthermore, he answered, "With our sons and with our daughters we will go," for even those who died in the desert will enter the Land of Israel through their children, as stated by the Shach in his commentary on the Torah. This explains why they were divided into two and why the phrase "we will go" is repeated twice, as they represent two aspects of going. Alternatively, it may hint at the future when the dead of the desert will rise and stand in their bodies, and therefore the repetition of "we will go." Similarly, in the terrible destruction that occurred in our days, when thousands and tens of thousands of Jews were lost, who knows if they have not already returned and been reincarnated in our sons and daughters? The generation of now is part of that generation, and their soul sparks are within us. It is our duty to raise these children in the way of the holy Torah so that they merit to greet the coming of our righteous Messiah. Every father is obligated to ensure that his children behave with purity and do not become tainted by sins, Heaven forbid, so that they may be worthy, and in this way, there will also be a rectification for our own souls.
summary: The passage discusses the responses of Moshe to Pharaoh's question about who would enter the Promised Land, emphasizing the distinction between the young and the old, and the belief that the souls of those who died in the desert may be reincarnated in their descendants. It highlights the importance of raising children in a holy manner to prepare for the coming of the Messiah, suggesting that the current generation may carry the sparks of the souls lost in the past. The repetition of "we will go" signifies both the dual paths of spiritual journeys and the future resurrection of those who perished in the desert. Ultimately, it underscores the responsibility of parents to ensure their children remain pure and righteous, contributing to the rectification of their own souls.

passage_content: ולבאריתר הדקדוקים עה"פ כי חג ה' לנו גם עה"כ גם אתה תתן בידינו זבחים ועולות וגו', נקדים מ"ד במד"ר (פ' וארא פ' י"א סי' ה') מהו ולא ימות מכל לבני ישראל דבר, אפי' בהמה שהיתה ביד מצרי והי' לו לישראל תרעומת עלי' שיש לו חלק בה היתה ניצולת ובכך ידעו דינן של ישראל עכ"ד המדרש, והנה האומות אומרים אם בגופן שלטו בנשותיהם עאכו"כ, אבל האמת לא כן שהיו ישראל גדורים בעריות ושמרו קדושתם במסנ"פ וכמ"ש רז"ל (ויק"ר פ' ל"ב סימן ה') אחת היתה ופרסמה הכתוב, ובזכות יוסף הצדיק נגדרו כל ישראל בעריות, אכן על מקניהם של ישראל בוודאי שלטו המצריים וגזלו מקנה ישראל, ולא הי' להם מי שיצדיק את דינם, ובערכאותיהם היו מצדיקים את המצרי ונשארו הבהמות אצלם, אבל באמת מצד הדין הרי זה מקנה ישראל אלא שהם ביד המצרי.
translation: And to explain the nuances of the verse "For the festival of the Lord is upon us," as well as "You too shall give into our hands sacrifices and burnt offerings," we will precede with what is stated in Midrash Rabbah (Parashat Va'era, Parashat 11, Section 5): What does it mean "and no one from among the children of Israel shall die"? Even an animal that was in the possession of an Egyptian, if a Jew had a grievance against it because he had a share in it, it was spared, and thus they knew the judgment of Israel. Thus far the Midrash. And behold, the nations say, if they had control over their own bodies, how much more so over their wives! But the truth is not so, for the Jews were guarded against immorality and preserved their sanctity with great diligence, as our sages have said (Vayikra Rabbah, Parashat 32, Section 5): "There was one [woman] and the scripture made it known." And by the merit of Joseph the Righteous, all of Israel were guarded against immorality. However, concerning the possessions of Israel, the Egyptians certainly had control and stole the livestock of Israel, and there was no one to justify their judgment. In their courts, they would justify the Egyptian, and the animals remained with them. But in truth, according to the law, it is indeed the property of Israel, only that they are in the hands of the Egyptian.
summary: The passage discusses the divine protection over the Israelites during their time in Egypt, emphasizing that even their animals were safeguarded from death, reflecting their spiritual purity and adherence to moral laws. It highlights the distinction between the Israelites' sanctity and the Egyptians' moral corruption, particularly in matters of sexual conduct, which was preserved through the merit of Joseph. Despite the Egyptians' control over the Israelites' possessions, the text asserts that, according to divine justice, these belongings rightfully belonged to the Israelites. This underscores the theme of divine justice and the sanctity of the Jewish people amidst oppression.

passage_content: והנהלא מצינו בכל המכות ששלח פרעה לראות אם שלטה גם בבנ"י, ומה נשתנה מכת דבר דכתיב בו וישלח פרעה והנה לא מת ממקנה ישראל עד אחד, ואפ"ל דגם במכה זו לא שלח לראות בבתי ישראל כי כבר ידע כי הפלה ה' להבדיל את ישראל ולהצילם, אבל שלח לבית המצרים לראות אם שלטה הדבר בבהמה שהיתה ביד המצרי והי' לו לישראל תרעומת עלי', וע"ז אמר והנה לא מת ממקנה ישראל עד אחד, שאף אלו לא מתו מפני שהם מקנה ישראל מצד הדין כנ"ל, ואיתא בגמ' גזל ולא נתיאשו הבעלים שניהם אינם יכולים להקדישו, זה מפני שאינו שלו וזה מפני שאינו ברשותו, ולפי"ז המקנה שגזלו המצרייםלא יכלו בנ"י להקדישם עד שלא הי' ברשותם, ובזה יובן מה שאמר משה רבינו לפרעה גם אתה תתן בידנו זבחים ועולות, הכוונה על מקנה ישראל שיחזירום לרשותם, כי משמעות ידו יתפרש ברשותו וכמ"ש ויקח את כל ארצו מידו פירש"י מרשותו, וז"ש גם אתה תתן המקנה שלנו בידינו ר"ל ברשותינו ואז נוכל להקדישו וז"ש ועשינו לה' אלקינו, ואין הכוונה שפרעה יתן משלו כי אין חפץ לה' בזבח רשעים, אלא שיחזיר לישראל את שלהם.
translation: And behold, we find in all the plagues that Pharaoh sent to see if it also affected the Children of Israel, and what is different about the plague of pestilence, as it is written, "And Pharaoh sent, and behold, not one of the livestock of Israel died." And it can be said that even in this plague he did not send to see in the houses of Israel, for he already knew that the Holy One, blessed be He, had distinguished and saved Israel. Rather, he sent to the Egyptians' houses to see if the pestilence affected the livestock that was in the hands of the Egyptians, and the Israelites would have had a grievance against Him. And concerning this, it is said, "And behold, not one of the livestock of Israel died," for even these did not die because they are considered the livestock of Israel by law, as mentioned above. And it is stated in the Gemara that if there is theft and the owners have not despaired, neither can they consecrate it, one because it is not his and the other because it is not in his possession. According to this, the livestock that the Egyptians stole could not be consecrated by the Children of Israel until it was in their possession. And this explains what our teacher Moses said to Pharaoh, "You too will give us sacrifices and burnt offerings," referring to the livestock of Israel that they should return to their possession, for the meaning of "hand" will be interpreted as "in his possession," as it is written, "And he took all his land from his hand," which Rashi explains as "from his possession." Therefore, it is said, "You too will give our livestock into our hands," meaning into our possession, and then we will be able to consecrate it, as it is said, "And we will make sacrifices to the Lord our God." The intention is not that Pharaoh should give from his own, for the Holy One, blessed be He, has no desire for the sacrifices of the wicked, but rather that he should return to Israel what is theirs.
summary: The passage discusses the plagues sent by Pharaoh and highlights that despite the severity of the plague of livestock, none of the Israelites' animals perished, demonstrating God's protection over His people. It emphasizes the concept of ownership and divine justice, explaining that the Egyptians' stolen livestock could not be consecrated by the Israelites because they were not rightfully theirs. Moses' request to Pharaoh for the return of the Israelites' livestock signifies the need for restoration of rightful ownership, allowing them to offer sacrifices to God. Ultimately, the text illustrates the distinction between the righteous and the wicked, affirming that God desires offerings from those who possess their own rightful property.

passage_content: ועפי"זיובן מה שחזר לומר וגם מקננו ילך עמנו דמיותר ומובן מאליו (עיין קושיא ה') אמנם המקנה של ישראל שהי' ביד המצריים לא נתייאשו ממנו הבעלים שהיו מצפים לישועה שיוסר מעליהם שלטנותם ויחזרוהו להם בהכרח, ואפשר שאעפ"כ לא רצו ליהנות מהם שהוא כמעשה נסים והקדישום לשמים, אבל מקניהם שברשותם איןהכרח להקדיש כולם, ואולי הספיק המקנה שהי' ביד המצריים לכך הדגיש לומר גם מקננו ילך עמנו לא תשאר פרסה כי ממנו נקח לעבוד את ה' אלקינו, שינה הלשון ולא אמר ועשינו לה' אלקינו כמו במקניהם, ואפ"ל הכוונה עפימ"ש ק"ז זלה"ה בישמח משה (פ' צו) לפרש הכתוב ואם האכל יאכל וגו' ביום השלישי לא ירצה המקריב אותו לא יחשב לו פגול יהי' וגו', ותוכן הדברים דעיקר הוא דע"י הקרבן ישים החוטא אל לבו, ויחשוב בעצמו מה זה שבשביל שחטאתי אני ישחט תמורתי בע"ח שלא חטאה ואין עול בכפה, ובוודאי אין זה כ"א השתעבדות הפחות להנכבד ממנו, ומזה יבוא החוטא ליקח ק"ו בעצמו, ומה אם הבע"ח לנגד האדם, אשר לא בראו ולא גמלו כל טוב כך, עאכו"כ איך ראוי להאדם להשתעבד ולהכנע לממ"ה הקב"ה שבראו והוציאו מאין ליש, ומזה יבוא לחשוב עם קונהו וישוב בתשובה שלימה וכו' עיי"ש.
translation: And according to this, we understand what he repeated to say, "And also our livestock will go with us," which is superfluous and self-evident (see question 5). However, the livestock of Israel that was in the hands of the Egyptians was not despaired of by the owners, who were hoping for salvation that their dominion would be removed from them, and they would necessarily return it to them. And it is possible that even so, they did not want to benefit from them, as it is like a miracle, and they consecrated them to Heaven. But their livestock that is in their possession does not necessarily have to be consecrated all of it, and perhaps the livestock that was in the hands of the Egyptians sufficed for this. Therefore, it emphasizes to say, "Also our livestock will go with us; not a hoof will remain behind," for from it we will take to serve the Lord our God. The language is changed, and it does not say, "And we will do for the Lord our God," as it does with their livestock. And it can be said that the intention is according to what is stated in Psalm 107, as it is said, "And Moses rejoiced" (Parashat Tzav) to explain the verse, "And if the meat is eaten... on the third day, the one who offers it will not be accepted; it will be considered piggul," etc. The essence of the matter is that through the offering, the sinner will place it in his heart and think to himself, "What is this that because I have sinned, I will slaughter my substitute, an animal that has not sinned and bears no guilt?" And certainly, this is nothing but the subjugation of the lesser to the greater. From this, the sinner will come to take a fortiori for himself: if the animal is before man, which he did not create and has not done any good for him, how much more so is it fitting for man to be subjugated and humbled before the King of Kings, the Holy One, blessed be He, who created him and brought him from nothing to something. And from this, he will come to think with his Creator and return in complete repentance, etc. See there.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the Israelites' livestock in the context of their liberation from Egypt, emphasizing that the owners never lost hope in reclaiming their possessions. It highlights the idea that while some livestock may be dedicated to God, not all must be, as the act of sacrifice serves as a profound reminder of the relationship between the sinner and the Creator. The act of offering a sacrifice compels the sinner to reflect on their actions and recognize their dependence on God, ultimately leading to genuine repentance and a deeper understanding of their servitude to the Divine.

passage_content: וז"שוגם מקנינו ילך עמנו אע"פ שלא נקריב כולם לה' זבחים ועולות אבל יש לנו צורך בהם, כי ממנו דייקא נקח לעבוד את ה', דממה ששוחטין בהמה לצורך אכילה יכולין ג"כ ללמוד ק"ו הנ"ל השתעבדות הפחות לנכבד, וכמ"ש ק"ז הישמח משה זלה"ה שם דזהו כוונת אמרם ז"ל (ברכות דף נ"ה ע"א) שולחנו של אדם דומה למזבח, דמה ששוחט בהמות ועופות למאכלו ע"כ מטעם השתעבד פחות לנכבד, א"כ גם מזה יקח ק"ו הנ"ל לעצמו להשתעבד לרוממות הבורא ית', וז"פ כי ממנו נקח לעבוד את ה', אף אם לא נקריבנו לה' זבחים ועולות, יש צורך לנו בהם לעבודת ה', ואנחנו לא נדע מה נעבוד את ה', לעשות חשבון הנ"ל עד בואנו שמה, וכשנבוא שמה נלמוד דרך העבודה ההוא.
translation: And this is what is meant by "even our possessions will go with us, even though we do not bring all of them as offerings and burnt sacrifices to Hashem, but we have a need for them, for from them specifically we will take to serve Hashem." For just as one slaughters an animal for the purpose of eating, one can also learn a fortiori from this the subjugation of the lesser to the greater, as it is written in the words of the holy Rabbi Moshe (may his memory be blessed) there, that this is the intention of what our sages of blessed memory said (Berakhot 55a) that a person's table is likened to the altar. For the fact that one slaughters animals and fowl for his food is indeed for the reason of the subjugation of the lesser to the greater. Therefore, from this one can also take the aforementioned a fortiori for himself to be subjugated to the exaltedness of the Creator, blessed be He. And this is the point, for from them we will take to serve Hashem, even if we do not bring them as offerings and burnt sacrifices to Hashem, we have a need for them for the service of Hashem. And we will not know how we will serve Hashem, to make the aforementioned accounting until we arrive there, and when we arrive there we will learn that way of service.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of utilizing one's possessions, even if not directly offered as sacrifices, to serve God. It draws a parallel between the act of slaughtering animals for sustenance and the concept of dedicating lesser things to the divine, highlighting the idea of subservience to the Creator. The text suggests that through our everyday actions and needs, we can find ways to elevate our service to God, even if we are unaware of the full implications of our actions until we reach a higher understanding in the spiritual realm. Ultimately, it conveys that all aspects of life can be transformed into a form of worship.

passage_content: ובזהיתבאר מ"ש רש"י ז"ל בפסוק גם צאנכם גם בקרכם קחו כאשר דברתם ולכו, מהו כאשר דברתם גם אתה תתן בידינו זבחים ועולות, (עיין קושיא ו') ולדרכינו כוונת הפסוק על מקניהם של ישראל שנטלוהו המצריים שלא כדין, ואז הודה פרעה שהאמת והצדק אתם בטענתם, ועל זה הכוונה אמר משה תחלה גם אתה תתן בידינו זבחים ועולות וכנ"ל, ועכשיו הודה לדברי משה באומרו גם צאנכם גם בקרכם קחו, ר"ל אותן השייכים באמת לכם כאשר דברתם שהי' לכם תרעומת על המצריים ולא יכולתם להוציאם בדין, עכשיו קחו אותם לכם ולכו.
translation: And in this it is clarified what Rashi, may his memory be blessed, wrote in the verse "Also your sheep, also your cattle, take as you have spoken, and go." What does it mean "as you have spoken, also you will give into our hands offerings and burnt offerings"? (See the question in Vav) And according to our path, the intention of the verse is regarding the cattle of Israel that the Egyptians took from them unjustly. Then Pharaoh admitted that the truth and justice were on their side in their claim. And this is the intention of what Moses said first, "Also you will give into our hands offerings and burnt offerings," as mentioned above. And now he acknowledged Moses' words by saying, "Also your sheep, also your cattle, take," meaning those that truly belong to you, as you have spoken, that you had a grievance against the Egyptians and could not extract them through justice. Now take them for yourselves and go.
summary: הפסוק מתאר את ההכרה של פרעה בצדקתם של בני ישראל בנוגע למקניהם שנלקחו מהם שלא כדין. משה מציין כי כעת, לאחר שהודה פרעה, הם יכולים לקחת את צאנם ובקרם, מה שמעיד על תיקון עוול שנעשה להם. זה מדגיש את עקרון הצדק האלוהי, שבו האמת מתגלה בסופו של דבר, והקשר בין בני ישראל לאלוהים, שמוביל לתהליך גאולה.

passage_content: וזהשאמר משה לפרעה בצאננו ובבקרנו נלך כי חג ה' לנו, פי' שנקח עמנו כל הצאן ובקר אשר לנו כי ממנו נקח לעבוד את ה' ללמוד חשבון השתעבדות פחות לנכבד, ואף אם לא נקריב כולן זבחים ועולות וכנ"ל, ע"כ סיים ואמר כי חג ה' לנו ר"ל אפילו ממה שנשחוט לעצמינו לצורך החג שצריך להיות חציו לכם גם מזה ניקח חשבון לעבוד את ה', ובזה יובנו שני המדרשים הנ"ל בפסוק כי חג ה' לנו זה חג הסוכות, ובמדרש רבינו בחיי כתב זה חג השבועות, כי עה"פ הנאמר בחג הסוכות עצרת תהי' לכם דרשו בגמ' (פסחים ס"ח ע"ב) שצריך להיות חציו לכם, ובשבועות הכל מודים דבעינן נמי לכם כמו שאמרו שם, ומזה ראי' שגם עבודת האכילה הוא עבודת ה', משא"כ מפסח א"א להביא ראי' כי שם כתיב עצרת לה' אלקיך, אבל מסוכות ושבועות איכא ראי' מדחייבה תורה לעשות חציו לכם ש"מ שגם זהו עבדות ה', וע"כ צריכין אנו למקננו כי ממנו נקח לעבוד את ה', ומתורץ ג"כ קושית הכלי יקר במאמה"כ כי חג ה' לנו (לעיל קושיא א') והבן.
translation: And this is what Moses said to Pharaoh: "We will go with our flocks and our herds, for we must hold a feast to the Lord." This means that we will take with us all the sheep and cattle that we have, for from them we will take to serve the Lord, to learn the accounting of servitude, which is less than honorable. And even if we do not offer all of them as sacrifices and burnt offerings, as mentioned above, therefore he concluded and said, "for we must hold a feast to the Lord," meaning that even from what we will slaughter for ourselves for the purpose of the feast, which must be half for you, we will also take into account to serve the Lord. And this will clarify the two Midrashim mentioned above regarding the verse "for we must hold a feast to the Lord," this refers to the Feast of Tabernacles, and in the Midrash of Rabbeinu Bachaye, it is written that this refers to the Feast of Weeks, for concerning the verse stated about the Feast of Tabernacles, "You shall have a solemn assembly," it is derived in the Gemara (Pesachim 68b) that it must be half for you, and regarding Weeks, everyone agrees that we also need "for you," as they said there. And from this, it is evident that even the work of eating is the work of the Lord, unlike Passover, from which one cannot bring proof, for there it is written "a solemn assembly for the Lord your God," but from Tabernacles and Weeks, there is proof from the obligation of making it half for you, which teaches us that this is also the service of the Lord. Therefore, we need to take from our livestock, for from it we will take to serve the Lord, and it also resolves the question of the Kli Yakar on the verse "for we must hold a feast to the Lord" (above, question 1), understand this.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of taking livestock for the celebration of the festivals, emphasizing that even the act of eating and enjoying the holiday is a form of divine service. It highlights the importance of balancing personal enjoyment with spiritual obligations, as seen in the requirement for offerings during Sukkot and Shavuot. The text suggests that the act of consuming food during these festivals is also a way to serve God, reinforcing the idea that all aspects of life can be integrated into one's spiritual practice. Ultimately, it underscores the connection between physical sustenance and spiritual fulfillment in the context of Jewish observance.

translation: And Moses said, "We will go with our young and with our old... for it is a festival of the Lord for us." In the Midrash, "for it is a festival of the Lord for us" refers to the Festival of Sukkot, and the question remains.
summary: In this passage, Moses emphasizes the importance of celebrating the festival of Sukkot, which symbolizes divine protection and the transient nature of life. The phrase "כי חג ד' לנו" highlights the communal aspect of the holiday, where both the young and the old participate in the spiritual experience. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of unity and inclusivity in worship, underscoring the belief that every individual, regardless of age, plays a vital role in the collective relationship with the Divine. The reference to Sukkot also signifies a deeper connection to the themes of faith, gratitude, and the recognition of God's presence in the physical world.

passage_content: ב)משה כה אמר ה' כחצות הלילה אני יוצא בתוך מצרים, בגמ' ברכות (דף ג' ע"ב) הקשו ודוד מי הו' ידע פלגא דלילא אימת, השתא משרע"ה לא ידע דכתיב כחצות לילה וגו' אלמא מספקא לי', ודוד הו' ידע, ותירצו בגמ', דוד סימנא הוה ליה וכו', כינור היה תלוי למעלה ממטתו וכו', וכיון שהגיע חצות לילה בא רוח צפונית ונושבת בו ומנגן מאליו וכו' עכ"ד הגמרא, ולכאורה קושית הגמ' חוזר וניעור, דאף לפי תירוצם אמאי מספקא לי' למשרע"ה ודוד הו' ידע, וכמו"כ הי' יכול משרע"ה לכוין ע"י סימנא דכינור ורוח צפונית.
translation: B) Moses said, "Thus says the Lord: At midnight I will go out into the midst of Egypt." In the Gemara Berakhot (page 3b), they asked, "And how did David know the exact time of midnight? Now, if Moshe did not know, as it is written 'at midnight' and so on, it implies that it was uncertain for him, while David did know." The Gemara answers, "David had a sign for himself, etc. A harp was hanging above his bed, etc. When midnight arrived, a northern wind would blow upon him and it would play by itself, etc." Thus concludes the Gemara. And at first glance, the question of the Gemara seems to return and awaken, for even according to their answer, why was it uncertain for Moshe while David did know? Similarly, Moshe could have directed himself through the sign of the harp and the northern wind.
summary: The passage discusses the timing of God's intervention in Egypt at midnight, highlighting a debate in the Talmud regarding Moses' awareness of this moment compared to King David's. It emphasizes that while David had a sign through the music of a harp played by a northern wind at midnight, Moses remained uncertain about the exact timing. This reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of divine revelation and the varying levels of awareness among different leaders in Israel. Ultimately, it suggests that even the greatest prophets may experience uncertainty in their connection to divine timing and guidance.

passage_content: ג)ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ד' את משה ואהרן כן עשו, ובמכילתא מהו כן עשו אף משה ואהרן כן עשו, והקושיא מפורסמת דמה צורך לדרשא, ובודאי שמשה ואהרן קיימו מצות הבוי"ת שצו' לכל ישראל.
translation: 3) And the children of Israel did as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron; thus they did. And in the Mekhilta, what does it mean, "thus they did"? Even Moses and Aaron did so. And the well-known question is, what is the need for the exegesis? And certainly, Moses and Aaron fulfilled the commandments of the Creator that were commanded to all of Israel.
summary: The passage emphasizes the importance of obedience to divine commandments, highlighting that the Israelites acted in accordance with God's instructions to Moses and Aaron. The reference to the Mekilta suggests that even Moses and Aaron adhered to these commandments, reinforcing the idea that all leaders must exemplify faithfulness to God's will. This underscores a key Hasidic concept of unity in fulfilling divine commandments, illustrating that true leadership is rooted in humility and adherence to God's directives. Ultimately, it reflects the theological insight that collective observance of mitzvot strengthens the bond between the community and the Divine.

passage_content: ד)הקשה עה"פ ועתה נלכה נא דרך שלשת ימים במדבר ונזבחה לה' אלקינו (שמות ג'), למה יצו ד' לעשות דרך ערמה, כי ח"ו לא קצור קצרה ידו מפדות ישראל בעל כרחם של מצרים ועיניהם רואות וכלות, ותירץ כי נתכוין ד' בזה להטעותם, כדי שירדפו אחריהם להכבד בפרעה וכו', ודקדקתי בכל הדברים הנאמרים בענין ואין בהם דבר שקר, כי לא הזכירו בלשונם החזרה כלל, ולצד מעלת קדוש אלקי ישראל, לא רצה לכנות הדברים אליו, אלא הם בני ישראל ידברו כזה ולזה אמר תיבת ועתה, פי' לומר כי הם דברי עצמם לא דברי עליון וכו' עכ"ל, אמנם עדיין צ"ב כי כל מה שנכתב בתוה"ק הוא אמת לאמיתו, ודברי משרע"ה אף אם אמרם מפי עצמו הם אמיתיים בכל אופן ואופן, מה גם שחזר ושנה טענה זו פעמים הרבה, כמ"ש שלח עמי ויחוגו לי במדבר, נלכה נא דרך ג' ימים ונזבחה, בצאננו ובבקרנו נלך כי חג ד' לנו, ולא מצינו שהי' הליכתם על מנת לזבוח במדבר, וצ"ב לקרב הענין עפ"י פשוטו.
translation: 4) The difficulty arises from the verse, "And now let us go three days' journey into the wilderness, that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God" (Exodus 3:18). Why did the Holy One, blessed be He, command them to take a deceptive route? For Heaven forbid, His hand is not too short to redeem Israel against the will of the Egyptians, and their eyes see and are consumed. The explanation is that the Holy One intended to mislead them, so that they would pursue them to burden Pharaoh, etc. I have scrutinized all the words mentioned in this matter, and there is nothing false in them, for they did not mention the return in their language at all. And due to the exaltedness of the Holy One of Israel, He did not want to attribute the words to Himself, but rather, the Children of Israel would speak in this manner. Therefore, He said the word "and now," meaning to say that these are their own words, not the words of the Supreme, etc. However, it is still puzzling because everything written in the Torah is true in its essence, and the words of Moshe Rabbeinu, even if he spoke them from his own mouth, are true in every way. Moreover, he repeated this claim many times, as it is said, "Let My people go, that they may hold a feast for Me in the wilderness," "Let us go three days' journey and sacrifice," "We will go with our flocks and our herds, for we must hold a feast to the Lord." Yet we do not find that their going was with the intention to sacrifice in the wilderness, and it is necessary to bring the matter closer according to its simple meaning.
summary: The passage discusses the divine command for the Israelites to take a circuitous route in their escape from Egypt, suggesting that this was intended to mislead the Egyptians into pursuing them, thereby intensifying their suffering under Pharaoh. It emphasizes that while the words spoken by Moses may seem to originate from the Israelites themselves, they are still rooted in divine truth, reflecting the sanctity of God's intentions. The text raises questions about the authenticity of Moses' statements regarding the purpose of their journey, highlighting the tension between human expression and divine will. Ultimately, it underscores the belief that all scripture is inherently true, regardless of its source.

passage_content: ויתבארהענין בהקדם לפרש מאמה"כ (בפ' יתרו) אתם ראיתם אשר עשיתי למצרים ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים ואביא אתכם אלי ועתה אם שמוע תשמעו בקולי וגו' והייתם לי סגולה מכל העמים כי לי כל הארץ, ובתרגום יוב"ע פי' וטענית יתכון על עננין וכו' ואובילית יתכון לאתר בית מקדשא למעבד תמן פסחא וכו', ולכאורה לפירושו צ"ב, דהרי הרבה נסים נעשו לישראל ביציאת מצרים ומדוע הזכיר נס זה דייקא, שהעננים הוליכו את ישראל למקום המקדש לעשות פסחיהן וחזרו אח"כ למצרים, ומהו הקישור אל מה דסמיך לי' ועתה אם שמוע תשמעו בקולי והייתם לי סגולה.
translation: And the matter will be clarified by first explaining from the verse (in Parshat Yitro) "You have seen what I did to the Egyptians, and I carried you on the wings of eagles and brought you to Me. And now, if you will listen to My voice, etc., you shall be a treasured people to Me from all the nations, for all the earth is Mine." And in the translation of Yov"an it is explained that "and I carried you" refers to the matter of the clouds, etc., and "and I brought you" refers to the site of the Holy Temple to perform the Passover there, etc. And at first glance, according to his explanation, it is difficult to understand, for many miracles were performed for Israel at the Exodus from Egypt, and why specifically mention this miracle that the clouds led Israel to the place of the Temple to perform their Passover and then returned to Egypt? And what is the connection to what is stated afterwards, "And now, if you will listen to My voice, you shall be a treasured people to Me"?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of God's miraculous guidance of the Israelites through the clouds during the Exodus, emphasizing the connection between this divine intervention and the covenantal relationship established at Sinai. It highlights that the purpose of the miracles was not only to liberate the Israelites but also to prepare them for their role as a treasured nation, or "sugula," among all peoples. The reference to the journey to the Temple for the Passover underscores the importance of worship and connection to the divine in the life of the Jewish people. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound relationship between divine providence, national identity, and spiritual obligation.

passage_content: ונל"פדהי' רצון הבוי"ת שישחטו ישראל פסחיהן כדינו בפסח דורות, דאין שוחטין את הפסח אלא בעזרה דכתיב לא תוכל לזבוח את הפסח באחד שעריך, אמנם לא היו ישראל ראויים עדיין ליכנס לארץ ישראל, כי לכל הוקצב זמן מאתו ית', ובפרט ביאת הארץ תליא בזמן כמשה"כ ודור רביעי ישובו הנה, וא"א להקדים אף רגע א' לפני הזמן, ואפשר דלחביבותן של ישראל עשה הקב"ה להם נס, שנעקר מקום המקדש ובא לקראתם במדבר ושם הקריבו קרבן פסח וע"ד שאמרז"ל שנעקר הר המורי' ובא לקראת יעאע"ה שיתפלל בתוכה, ואולי זהו טעם הכתוב נלכה דרך שלשת ימים ונזבחה לד' אלקינו הכוונה על זביחת קרבן פסח שהי' הכרח לפני יציאתם, כאמרז"ל במד"ר (פ' ט"ז סימן ג') אמר הקב"ה חייך אין ישראל יוצאים מכאן עד שישחטו אלהיהן וכו' והנה מצרים היתה מלאה גילולים, ומצינו שמה"ט לא התפלל משה בתוך העיר, ומכ"ש שלא הי' ראוי שיעקר מקום המקדש לתוכה, ועד מהלך ג' ימים אתחזק טומאה, וכדמצינו לגבי טומאת נדה דבג' ימים ראשונים אתחזק טומאתה, ואיתא בזוה"ק דישראל כד נפקו ממצרים הוצרכו ספירת נקיים לצאת מטומאתם כנדה.
translation: And it is our intention that the will of the Blessed Creator is that Israel should slaughter their Passover offerings as is proper during the Passover of generations, for one does not slaughter the Passover except in the Temple courtyard, as it is written, "You shall not be able to sacrifice the Passover in any of your gates." However, Israel was not yet worthy to enter the Land of Israel, for everything is appointed a time by Him, blessed be He, and especially the entry into the land is dependent on time, as it is said, "And the fourth generation shall return here," and it is impossible to advance even a single moment before the time. It is possible that for the affection of Israel, the Holy One, blessed be He, performed a miracle for them, that the place of the Temple was uprooted and came to meet them in the desert, and there they offered the Passover sacrifice, in accordance with what our Sages of blessed memory said, that the mountain of Moriah was uprooted and came to meet Abraham to pray within it. And perhaps this is the reason for the verse, "Let us go a distance of three days and let us sacrifice to the Lord our God," referring to the slaughtering of the Passover sacrifice, which was necessary before their departure, as our Sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash (Parashat 16, Siman 3), the Holy One, blessed be He, said, "I swear, Israel will not leave here until they slaughter their gods," etc. And behold, Egypt was full of idols, and we find that for this reason Moses did not pray within the city, and certainly it was not fitting for the place of the Temple to be uprooted into it. And for a distance of three days, they would become impure, as we find regarding the impurity of a menstruant, that in the first three days, her impurity is strengthened. And it is stated in the Zohar that when Israel left Egypt, they needed to count themselves clean to exit from their impurity like a menstruant.
summary: The passage discusses the divine timing and conditions surrounding the Israelites' sacrifice of the Passover lamb, emphasizing that they were not yet worthy to enter the Land of Israel until the appointed time by God. It highlights the miraculous act of God relocating the Temple's site to the desert for the Israelites to perform the sacrifice, reflecting His love for them. Additionally, it notes the spiritual necessity of purification from impurity, paralleling the Israelites' need for spiritual readiness before their exodus from Egypt. The text underscores the importance of adhering to divine commandments and the sanctity of the sacrificial process.

passage_content: ומעתהנבין כי כל טענותיו של משרע"ה במ"ש נלכה נא דרך ג' ימים ונזבחה לד' וגו', כי חג ד' לנו, ויחוגו לי במדבר, הם כולם אמת ואין בהם עקש ונפתול, ולא על הליכה המוחלטת בקשרשותו, כ"א על הליכה זמנית שילכו להקריב קרבן פסח ויחזרו למצרים, אלא שלא גילה לו פי' הדברים כדי להטעותן שירדפו אחריהם כדברי האוהחה"ק, ומדוייק בלשון התרגום יונתן שמפרש ואובילית יתכון לאתר בית מקדשא, לא אמר לבית מקדשא אלא לאתר בית מקדשא, שנעקר מקום המקדש ובא לקראת ישראל למדבר, ובאתר בית מקדשא הקריבו ישראל פסחיהן.
translation: And from now on we understand that all of Moshe's arguments in saying, "Let us go a journey of three days and we will sacrifice to the Lord," for it is a festival for the Lord for us, and "They shall celebrate for Me in the wilderness," are all true and contain no deceit or twisting. It is not about an absolute journey in his authority, but rather a temporary journey to go and offer the Passover sacrifice and then return to Egypt. However, he did not reveal to him the meaning of the matters in order to mislead them so that they would pursue them, as stated by the holy Baal Shem Tov. And it is precise in the language of the Targum Jonathan, which explains, "And I will lead you to the site of the Holy Temple." He did not say "to the Holy Temple" but "to the site of the Holy Temple," indicating that the place of the Temple was uprooted and came to meet Israel in the wilderness, and at the site of the Holy Temple, Israel offered their Passover sacrifices.
summary: The passage emphasizes that Moses' request to journey three days into the wilderness for the purpose of sacrificing to God is genuine and not a deception. It suggests that this temporary journey was intended for the offering of the Passover sacrifice, with the understanding that the ultimate goal was to return to Egypt. The text highlights the significance of the Temple's location, indicating that it was spiritually present in the wilderness, as the Israelites were able to offer their sacrifices there, reflecting a deep connection between the divine and the people during their journey.

passage_content: והנהמשה ואהרן גזרה חכמתו ית' עליהם שלא יכנסו לארץ עד ביאה העתידה, וחוץ מטעם המבואר בכתובים, כתב המגלה עמוקות עוד מאה טעמים עיי"ש, ותו"ד דלהפלגת קדושתן לא היו ראויים ליכנס כ"א בקדושת א"י דלעתיד, ומעתה הי' ס"ד, שמשה ואהרן לא נצטרפו עם ישראל בעשיית הפסח במקום המקדש, ע"כ דרשו רז"ל אף משה ואהרן כן עשו, דלא נמנע מהם הכניסה כ"א במקומה הראוי', אבל כשנעקר מקום המקדש למדבר אף הם נצטרפו עם ישראל וכן עשו מצות הפסח עם ישראל.
translation: And behold, Moses and Aaron, the wise decree of the Blessed One upon them was that they would not enter the Land until the future coming. Besides the reason explained in the scriptures, the Megaleh Amukos wrote deeply another hundred reasons, as mentioned there. Furthermore, due to the exalted sanctity of their souls, they were only worthy to enter with the sanctity of the Land of Israel in the future. From this, it was thought that Moses and Aaron did not join Israel in the observance of the Passover at the place of the Temple. Therefore, our sages taught that even Moses and Aaron did so, for their entrance was not prevented except in its proper place. However, when the place of the Temple was uprooted to the wilderness, they too joined with Israel and performed the commandments of Passover with Israel.
summary: The passage discusses the divine decree that Moses and Aaron would not enter the Promised Land until the future redemption, emphasizing their elevated sanctity that required them to enter only in the holiness of the future Land of Israel. It notes that despite their exclusion, they participated in the Passover with the Israelites in the wilderness, highlighting the connection between their spiritual status and the sacredness of the Temple's location. This reflects a deeper Hasidic understanding of the interplay between holiness, divine timing, and communal participation in religious observance.

passage_content: והנהלפי"ז העננים הוליכו את ישראל למדבר והחזירום למצרים, ואמרינן בגמ' (יבמות ע"ב ע"א) דכל מ' שנה שהיו ישראל במדבר לא נשבה להם רוח צפונית, אב"ע דלא נבדוד ענני כבוד פרש"י ז"ל משו"ה לא נשבה שלא יפזרו ענני הכבוד, ואפשר דמה"ט לא נשבה רוח צפונית גם באותו הלילה, וסימנא דכינור היתה ע"י רוח צפונית שמנשבת בחצות לילה, וא"ש דמשרע"ה לא הו"ל סימנא דכינור.
translation: And the clouds led Israel to the desert and brought them back to Egypt, and we say in the Gemara (Yevamot 72a) that for all the 40 years that Israel was in the desert, a northern wind did not blow for them. The reason is that the clouds of glory did not disperse, as Rashi explains, therefore it did not blow so that the clouds of glory would not be scattered. And it is possible that for this reason a northern wind did not blow even that night, and the sign of the harp was through the northern wind that blows at midnight, and it is understood that from Moshe Rabbeinu there was no sign of the harp.
summary: The passage discusses the significance of the clouds of glory that guided the Israelites in the desert, emphasizing their protective role in preventing the northern wind from blowing, which symbolizes divine favor and guidance. It references a Talmudic source to illustrate that during the forty years in the desert, the absence of the northern wind ensured the integrity of the divine presence. The mention of the "sign of the harp" associated with the northern wind at midnight suggests a deeper connection between divine signs and the spiritual state of the people, particularly in relation to Moses. Overall, the text highlights the interplay between divine protection, spiritual signs, and the leadership of Moses in the context of the Jewish journey.

passage_content: ולדרכנויתבאר דברי המדרש כי חג ד' לנו זה חג הסוכות, עפי"ד הגמ' (סוכה י"א ע"ב) כי בסוכות הושבתי את בנ"י וגו' ר"א אמר ענני כבוד היו, ופסקינן כוותי', נמצא כי שם סוכות ירמוז על ענני הכבוד, ועד"ז רמז לו משרע"ה בבנינו ובבנותנו בצאננו ובבקרנו נלך, לזבוח במקום המקדש, כי חג ד' לנו זה חג הסוכות, ורמז לו דרך הליכתם עם העננים, אלא שלא גילה לו פירושו כדי להטעותו כנ"ל, ובזה יבואר קישור הכתוב אתם ראיתם וגו' ואשא אתכם על כנפי נשרים, ונתקרבתם אל הקדושה בלי עמל ויגיעה ובבת אחת שלא על סדר המדריגות, אולם ועתה מזמן הזה ואילך אם שמוע תשמעו בקולי ושמרתם את בריתי אז והייתם לי סגולה מכל העמים ותזכו לביאת הארץ והכל תליא במעשיכם.
translation: And in our way, the words of the Midrash will be clarified, for the festival of the Lord for us is the festival of Sukkot, according to the Gemara (Sukkah 11b) that "I sat the children of Israel in Sukkot," etc. Rabbi Eliezer said they were clouds of glory, and we rule like him. Thus, it is found that the name Sukkot hints at the clouds of glory. Similarly, it was hinted to him by Moshe Rabbeinu, "With our sons and our daughters, with our flocks and our herds, we will go to sacrifice in the place of the Temple," for the festival of the Lord for us is the festival of Sukkot, and it hinted to him the way of their journey with the clouds, but he did not reveal to him its interpretation in order to mislead him, as mentioned above. And in this, the connection of the verse "You have seen, etc., and I bore you on the wings of eagles" will be explained, and you will draw near to holiness without toil and effort, all at once, not in the order of the levels. However, now from this time onward, if you will listen to my voice and keep my covenant, then you will be a treasured people for me from all the nations, and you will merit to enter the land, and everything depends on your deeds.
summary: The passage emphasizes the significance of the Festival of Sukkot as a time when God sheltered the Israelites with the "clouds of glory," symbolizing divine protection and closeness to holiness. It highlights the idea that the journey to spiritual elevation can occur without labor or struggle, akin to being carried on "wings of eagles." However, it also stresses the conditional nature of this divine favor, which depends on the people's adherence to God's commandments and their moral actions, linking their spiritual destiny to their behavior. Ultimately, the text reflects a deep connection between observance, divine relationship, and the promise of redemption.

passage_content: ויהיחשך וגו' פרש"י ז"ל מדברי המד"ר (פר' י"ד סי' ג') ולמה הביא עליהם חשך שהיו בישראל באותו הדור רשעים וכו' ומתו בג' ימי אפילה כדי שלא יראו מצרים במפלתם וכו', יל"ד מדוע הקשה כן במכת חשך דייקא למה הביאן עליהם, ורז"ל נתנו טעם לכל המכות, ומדוע ניחא לי' באחריני וקשיא לי' בחשך לבד.
translation: "And it was dark, etc." Rashi, of blessed memory, explains from the words of the Midrash (Parashat Yitro, section 3) why darkness was brought upon them: because there were wicked ones in Israel in that generation, etc., and they died during the three days of darkness so that the Egyptians would not see their downfall, etc. It is difficult to understand why he specifically questioned the plague of darkness, why it was brought upon them. The Sages provided reasons for all the plagues, and why is it that he is at ease with the others but finds it difficult only with darkness?
summary: The passage discusses the plague of darkness in Egypt, referencing the Midrash that explains its purpose: to prevent the Israelites from witnessing the downfall of the Egyptians, as many in that generation were wicked. The author questions why the darkness specifically raises such a concern, given that other plagues had clear reasons. This highlights a key Hasidic concept of divine justice and mercy, suggesting that even in punishment, there is a consideration for the spiritual state of the Israelites. The text emphasizes the complexity of God's actions and the moral implications of witnessing suffering.

passage_content: ואפ"לדהנה תכלית המכות הי' להודיעם גבורתו ית' כמפורש בכתובים והרבתי את אתתי ואת מופתי בארץ מצרים וגו' וידעו מצרים כי אני ד' וגו', וכן הזכיר הכתוב ברוב המכות למען תדע כי אין כד' וגומר, למען תדע כי אני ד' ועוד לשונות דוגמתו, והנה כל המכות היו דרך נסיי, ובמכת הדם כתיב ויעשו כן חרטומי מצרים בלטיהם ויחזק לב פרעה ולא שמע אליהם, וכתב הראב"ע ז"ל יש הפרש גדול בין מעשה אהרן למעשיהם, כי אהרן הפך כל היאור וכו' וכל מים שהי' בכל גבול מצרים שלא הי' רואה אותם, ועוד כי הפך מים שאינם עומדים רק רצים תמיד ומים אחרים באים, ועוד כי עמדה המכה ז' ימים, והחרטומים לא הראו שהפכו רק מים מועטים עומדים בכלי, וזה הי' רגע א' עדששב פרעה אל ביתו עכ"ל, הנה אף שהכיר פרעה שאין מעשיהם בערך מעשה אהרן, מ"מ לא שת לבו אל מופת הדם, שכבר הי' לו פ"פ.
translation: And behold, the ultimate purpose of the plagues was to make known His mighty power, as it is explicitly stated in the scriptures: "And I multiplied My signs and My wonders in the land of Egypt," and "And the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord," etc. Similarly, the scripture mentions in many of the plagues, "In order that you may know that there is none like the Lord," and "In order that you may know that I am the Lord," and other similar phrases. And behold, all the plagues were through miraculous means. And regarding the plague of blood, it is written, "And the magicians of Egypt did so with their enchantments," and Pharaoh's heart was hardened, and he did not listen to them. The Ra'avad, of blessed memory, wrote that there is a great difference between the act of Aaron and their acts, for Aaron turned all the waters of the Nile, etc., and all the waters that were throughout the borders of Egypt, which he did not see, and also because he turned waters that do not stand still but flow continuously, and other waters come in. Furthermore, the plague lasted for seven days, and the magicians did not show that they turned but only a small amount of water that stood in vessels, and this was for a moment until Pharaoh returned to his house. Thus, even though Pharaoh recognized that their actions were not comparable to the act of Aaron, nevertheless, he did not pay attention to the miracle of the blood, for he had already experienced it before.
summary: The passage emphasizes that the purpose of the plagues in Egypt was to reveal God's greatness and power, as stated in the scriptures. It highlights the miraculous nature of the plagues, particularly the plague of blood, where Aaron's act was fundamentally different from the magicians' attempts, demonstrating God's supremacy. Despite recognizing the distinction, Pharaoh's heart remained hardened, illustrating the theme of divine intervention versus human obstinacy. This reflects a key Hasidic concept of the struggle between faith and doubt in the face of clear signs of God's presence.

passage_content: והנהמכת החשך לא הי' ענין נסיי כלל כמ"ש הרמב"ן והאבן עזרא זלה"ה, וז"ל הראב"ע הנה בים אוקינוס יבא חשך עב שלא יוכל אדם להפריש בין יום ובין לילה ויעמוד זה לפעמים ה' ימים ואני הייתי שם פעמים רבות, והרמב"ן כתב חשך אפילה כלומר איד עב מאוד שירד מן השמים וכו' עיי"ש, ע"כ הקשה לרש"י ז"ל חשך למה הביא עליהם, אם לא הי' בדרך נסיי הרי לא הכירו עלידו להודות בגבורתו ית' ומ"ט הביאו עליהם ומתרץ כדי שלא יראו המצריים במפלתם ויאמרו אף הם לוקין כמונו ואין זה לכבוד שמים וכבודן של ישראל, ועוד שחפשו ישראל וראו את כליהם, וכשיצאו והיו שואלין מהן והיו אומרים אין בידינו כלום, אומר לו אני ראיתיו בביתך ובמקום פלוני הוא, ומזה נצמח כבוד שמים גדול וטובה גדולה לישראל עד סוף כל הדורות, על שעמדו בנסיונם במכת החושך, דהנה המצריים היו כולם ככפותים העומד אינו יכול לישב והיושב אינו יכול לעמוד מחמת כפילת החושך, והי' אפשר להם לישראל ליקח כל כספם וזהבם ולצאת מארצם באין מפריע, ומ"ט המתינו עד שישאלו מהם וא"ל אני ראיתיו בביתך ועי"ז נתרצו ליתן להם, אמנם בנ"י שמרו דבר ד' שלא לצאת מעצמם כי אם עפ"י משה ובעת יבא זמן פקודתם, ולא להקדים אף רגע א' לפני זמנו, גם קיימו מצות השי"ת ליקח רכושם בדרך שאלה דייקא, כמאמה"כ ובנ"י עשו כדבר משה וישאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וגו', ולא נטלו בזרוע בימי אפילה.
translation: And behold, the plague of darkness was not a miraculous matter at all, as the Ramban and the Ibn Ezra, may their memory be blessed, state. The Ibn Ezra writes, "Behold, in the ocean sea, a thick darkness will come that a person cannot distinguish between day and night, and this can last sometimes five days. I have been there many times." The Ramban wrote that darkness is a deep darkness, meaning a very thick cloud that descended from the heavens, etc. Therefore, he questioned Rashi, may his memory be blessed, why darkness was brought upon them. If it was not in a miraculous way, then they would not have recognized His hand to acknowledge His might, and why was it brought upon them? He answers that it was so that the Egyptians would not see their downfall and say, "They too are suffering like us," which would not be for the honor of Heaven and the honor of Israel. Furthermore, the Israelites searched and saw their belongings, and when they went out and were asked about them, they would say, "We have nothing," and one would say, "I saw it in your house and in such and such a place." From this, a great honor for Heaven and a great benefit for Israel arose for all generations, for they stood firm in their trial during the plague of darkness. Behold, the Egyptians were all like bound ones; the standing one could not sit, and the sitting one could not stand because of the intensity of the darkness. It would have been possible for the Israelites to take all their money and gold and leave their land without hindrance. Therefore, they waited until they were asked about them, and one would say, "I saw it in your house," and through this, they were persuaded to give it to them. However, the children of Israel kept the word of the Holy One, Blessed be He, not to leave on their own but only through Moses and at the time of their appointed redemption, and not to advance even a single moment before its time. They also fulfilled the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to take their possessions in a manner of asking, precisely as it is written, "And the children of Israel did as Moses said, and they asked the Egyptians for silver vessels, etc.," and they did not take by force during the days of darkness.
summary: The passage discusses the plague of darkness in Egypt, emphasizing that it was not a miraculous event but rather a profound spiritual experience. The darkness served to prevent the Egyptians from witnessing their own downfall, thereby preserving the honor of God and the Israelites. The Israelites, adhering to divine command, refrained from taking the Egyptians' possessions by force, instead waiting for permission to ask for their belongings, which demonstrated their faithfulness and obedience to God's will. This act of restraint and adherence to divine timing ultimately led to a greater sanctification of God's name and a lasting benefit for the Israelites.

passage_content: והזכותהזה עמדה לישראל בכל הדורות ואף לעתיד בעת הגאולה, כמשה"כ (ירמי' ב') זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך וגו' לכתך אחרי במדבר ר"ל אחרי דייקא לקיים פקודתו ית', ולא על דעת עצמם כ"א כאשר צו' ד' ולא שינו דבר, ואמרז"ל (סנהדרין ק"י ע"ב) שאף אחרים יזכו בזכותן לעוה"ב, ובזה יל"פ הפסוק ולכל בני ישראל הי' אור במושבותם, ולכאורה הרי אמרז"ל (קידושין ל"ז ע"א) שכל מקום שנא' מושב אינו אלא לאחר ירושה וישיבה, ואף למ"ד מושב כ"מ שאתם יושבים משמע אבל ארץ מצרים ודאי אינו ראוי ליקרא מושבותם שלא נתיישבו בה כ"א גרים היו בארץ לא להם, ולדרכנו הכוונה על העתיד שע"י שעמדו בנסיונם בימי החשך, זכו לאור שכינתו ית' במושבותם בביאת הארץ ויזכו בזכותו גם בביאה דלעתיד וזה ירמוז ולכל בנ"י הי' אור במושבותם, וזכו לזה במכת החשך ע"י שעמדו בנסיונם.
translation: And this merit has stood for Israel throughout all generations and even for the future at the time of redemption, as it is written (Jeremiah 2) "I remember for you the kindness of your youth," etc., "to follow after Me in the wilderness," meaning specifically to fulfill His command, and not according to their own understanding, but as commanded by the Holy One, blessed be He, and they did not change a thing. And our sages of blessed memory said (Sanhedrin 110b) that even others will merit through their merit in the World to Come. And this explains the verse "And for all the children of Israel there was light in their dwellings." At first glance, our sages of blessed memory said (Kiddushin 37a) that wherever it says "dwelling," it refers only to after inheritance and settlement. And even according to the opinion that "dwelling" means wherever you are sitting, it certainly cannot refer to the land of Egypt, which is not worthy of being called their dwellings, as they were only sojourners in a land not theirs. And in our way, the intention is towards the future, that through their standing firm in their trials during the days of darkness, they merited the light of His presence in their dwellings upon entering the land, and they will also merit through His merit in the future coming. This is hinted at in "And for all the children of Israel there was light in their dwellings," and they merited this through the plague of darkness by standing firm in their trials.
summary: הזכות של ישראל, שנשמרה בכל הדורות ובעיקר בעת הגאולה, נובעת מהחסד והנאמנות שלהם לקיום מצוות ה' במדבר, כפי שמצוין בפסוק "זכרתי לך חסד נעוריך". גם אחרים יזכו בזכותם לעולם הבא, והאור שיתגלה לישראל במושבותיהם בעתיד הוא תוצאה של עמידתם בניסיונות בימי החשך. המכות, ובפרט מכת החשך, שימשו כבחינה שהובילה לזכייתם באור השכינה בארץ ישראל ובביאה העתידית.

passage_content: ויל"פבזה דברי המדרש הים ראה וינוס ראה רכוש מצרים בידם, דהנה שר של ים הי"ל טענה שעדיין לא השלימו זמן גלותם הנגזר עליהם ת' שנה, וא"כ אין לו לקרוע בפניהם, אמנם ממה שראה רכוש מצרים בידם ר"ל ברשותם, שלא לקחוהו בגזל כ"א עפ"י ציווי השי"ת ורחמנא אפקעא מרשותם, ומזה ראי' גם על יציאתם שהי' עפ"י ה' וכך הוקצב זמנם מאתו ית', ולכך וינוס מפניהם.
translation: And it is explained in the words of the Midrash that the sea saw and fled, seeing the wealth of Egypt in their hands. Behold, the minister of the sea had a claim that they had not yet completed the time of their exile decreed upon them for 400 years, and therefore he should not part before them. However, from what he saw, the wealth of Egypt was in their possession, meaning that they did not take it by theft, but rather by the command of the Holy One, blessed be He, who removed it from their possession. And from this, it is also a proof regarding their departure, that it was by the will of the Holy One, and thus their time was decreed by Him. Therefore, he fled from before them.
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the Midrashic interpretation of the sea's reluctance to part for the Israelites during the Exodus. The sea's guardian, the minister of the sea, argues that the Israelites had not yet completed their prophesied period of enslavement. However, upon seeing the wealth of Egypt in their possession—acquired not through theft but by divine command—the sea recognizes that their departure is sanctioned by God, leading to its eventual submission. This reflects the Hasidic belief in divine providence and the fulfillment of God's promises to His people.

passage_content: דברנא באזני העם וישאלו איש מאת רעהו וגו' ויתן ד' את חן העם בעיני מצרים גם האיש משה גדול מאוד וגו' בעיני עבדי פרעה ובעיני העם, בגמ' ברכות (דף ט' ע"א) דבר נא באזני העם אין נא אלא לשון בקשה, א"ל הקב"ה למשה בבקשה ממך, לך ואמור להם לישראל בבקשה מכם, שאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב שלא יאמר אותו צדיק, ועבדום וענו אותם קיים בהם, ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם עכ"ד הגמ', ראוי להבין מה צורך להזהרה ובקשה כ"כ, ובודאי יתרצו ישראל במה שהוא לטובתם, גם מה טעם שלא יאמר אותו צדיק וכו', והלא זולת טעם זה ראוי שיקיים הבוי"ת הבטחתו ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול, והבטחתו ית' לטובה אינה חוזרת ריקם, גם דקדקו המפרשים דמלת בהם אך למותר, ויספיק במ"ש ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים ומה צורך להוסיף מלת "בהם" ומובן מאליו שמוסב על בנ"י האמור בקרא, גם הכי יעלה על הדעת שאאע"ה יתרעם על מדותיו ית"ש ומה לו לבצע כסף וחמדת הממון לא נחשב אצלו למאומה.
translation: I spoke in the ears of the people, and they shall ask each man of his neighbor, etc. And the Lord gave the people favor in the eyes of Egypt, and also the man Moses was very great in the eyes of the servants of Pharaoh and in the eyes of the people. In the Gemara Berakhot (page 9a), it says, "Speak please in the ears of the people." The word "please" is only a term of request. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses, "As a request from you, go and say to the children of Israel, 'As a request from you, ask of Egypt for silver vessels and gold vessels,' so that that righteous one should not say, 'And they shall serve them and afflict them' is fulfilled in them, and afterwards they shall go out with great wealth," which is not fulfilled in them. Thus says the Gemara. It is fitting to understand what is the need for such a warning and request, and certainly the Israelites would agree to what is for their benefit. Also, what is the reason that that righteous one should not say, etc.? And behold, aside from this reason, it is fitting that the Blessed One should fulfill His promise, and afterwards they should go out with great wealth, and His promise for good does not return empty. Also, the commentators have noted that the word "in them" is superfluous, and it would suffice to say, "and afterwards they shall go out with great wealth," which is not fulfilled. What is the need to add the word "in them," which is understood to refer to the children of Israel mentioned in the verse? Also, it would come to mind that our father Abraham would be upset with His attributes, Blessed be He, and what does it matter to Him to acquire silver and the desire for wealth, which is not considered anything to Him?
summary: In this passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author explores the divine request for the Israelites to ask the Egyptians for gold and silver, emphasizing the concept of divine providence and the importance of human agency in fulfilling God's promises. The use of the term "נא" (please) indicates a request rather than a command, highlighting the relationship between God and the people, where their cooperation is essential. The text also reflects on the theological implications of God's promises, suggesting that while He is faithful, the process of redemption involves human initiative to avoid the perception of entitlement. Ultimately, it underscores the balance between divine assurance and the necessity of human action in the unfolding of salvation.

passage_content: ב)יל"ד בסיפא דקרא גם האיש משה גדול מאוד בעיני עבדי פרעה ובעיני העם, ראוי להבין מה ענינו אל השאלת כליהם דעסיק בי', ומשרע"ה לא הי' צריך לחן שלהם כי לא עסק בזה כאמרז"ל (סוטה י"ג ע"א) גם מהו רבותי' שהי' גדול בעיני עבדי פרעה, וכבר ידענא כן מפרשיות הקודמים, ועוד מ"ש גם האיש משה, גם הרבוי צ"ב, ומי כמוהו עוד גדול.
translation: In the end of the verse, it is also stated that the man Moses was very great in the eyes of the servants of Pharaoh and in the eyes of the people. It is fitting to understand what his connection is to the question of their vessels that he was involved with, and since Moshe Rabbeinu did not need their favor because he was not engaged in this, as our Sages have said (Sotah 13a). Furthermore, what does it mean that he was great in the eyes of the servants of Pharaoh? We already know this from the previous sections, and also what is meant by "the man Moses," as the emphasis is puzzling, and who else is as great as he?
summary: The passage discusses the significance of Moses being regarded as "great" in the eyes of Pharaoh's servants and the people, highlighting his unique status and the divine favor he received. It questions the relevance of this acknowledgment in relation to the request for their vessels, suggesting that Moses did not rely on their favor as he was divinely appointed. The phrase "also the man Moses" emphasizes his unparalleled greatness, inviting deeper reflection on his role as a leader and prophet. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the importance of divine selection and the inherent greatness of true spiritual leaders.

passage_content: ג)ישראל עשו כדבר משה וישאלו ממצרים וגו', וד' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים וישאילום וגו', יל"ד מה צורך להקדמה זו ובנ"י עשו כדברמשה, ובמ"ש וישאלו ממצרים כבר ידענא שעשו כדבר משה, גם מדוע הזכיר עוה"פ וד' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים, וכבר נזכר לעיל ויתן ד' את חן העם וגו'
translation: 3) Israel did as Moses said, and they asked from Egypt, etc., and the Holy One, blessed be He, gave the people favor in the eyes of Egypt, and they lent them, etc. One might wonder what the need is for this introduction, since the Children of Israel did as Moses said, and regarding "and they asked from Egypt," we already know that they did as Moses said. Also, why does it mention here that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave the people favor in the eyes of Egypt, when it was already mentioned above that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave the people favor, etc.
summary: In this passage, the author reflects on the obedience of the Israelites to Moses' command to ask the Egyptians for valuables, emphasizing that their actions were divinely inspired. The mention of God granting favor to the Israelites in the eyes of the Egyptians highlights the theme of divine intervention and grace, suggesting that their success was not merely due to their own efforts but rather a result of God's influence. This underscores the Hasidic belief in the importance of faith and reliance on divine assistance in achieving one's goals. The repetition of God's favor serves to reinforce the idea that spiritual merit and divine kindness are intertwined in the journey of the Jewish people.

passage_content: ונל"פבהקדם דברי המדרש תנחומא (וארא סי"ג) א"ר אבין הלוי ברבי ממכת הדם העשירו בני ישראל, כיצד המצרי וישראל בבית א' והגיגית מלאה מים, והמצרי הולך למלאות את הקיתון מתוכה מוציאה מלאה דם, וישראל שותה מים ומצרי דם מתוך הגיגית וכו', וכשהי' לוקח מישראל בדמים יקרים הי' שותה מים, מכאן העשירו בניישראל עכ"ד המדרש, א"כ לפי"ז מה טעם בטענה הנ"ל ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים, וכבר הי' בידם רכוש ועשירות, ומה צורך עוד להשאלת כליהם, ואפשר ליישב עפי"מ שהקשו בעלי התוס' ז"ל (בפ' וארא) עה"פ ויעשו כן חרטומי מצרים וגו', מהיכן לקחו חרטומי מצרים מים להפכו לדם, והרי כל מימי מצרים נהפכו לדם במאמר ד' עפ"י משה, ותירצו שחפרו מים סביבות היאור, אמנם דחו תירוץ זה, כי אח"כ כתיב ויחפרו כל מצרים סביבות היאור, ובחד פרשה לא שייך למימר אין מוקדם ומאוחר בתורה, והאוהחה"ק תירץ עפ"י דבריהם ז"ל כי ישראל נתעשרו ממכת היאור, שהיו מוכרים מים למצרים וכו', כפי זה עשו ההחרטומים מהנמכר להם עכ"ל.
translation: And it is explained in advance by the words of the Midrash Tanchuma (Va'era, section 13): Rabbi Avin the Levi said in the name of Rabbi, from the plague of blood the children of Israel became wealthy. How so? The Egyptian and the Israelite were in one house, and the basin was full of water. The Egyptian went to fill the jug from it and took out blood, while the Israelite drank water and the Egyptian blood from the basin, etc. And when the Egyptian would take from the Israelite at a high price, he would drink water. From here, the children of Israel became wealthy, thus concludes the Midrash. Therefore, according to this, what is the reason for the above claim, and afterwards they went out with great wealth, which was not fulfilled? And they already had wealth and riches, so what need was there to borrow their vessels? It is possible to resolve this according to what the Tosafists asked (in Parshat Va'era) regarding the verse "And the magicians of Egypt did so," from where did the magicians of Egypt take water to turn it into blood, when all the waters of Egypt were turned to blood by the word of G-d through Moses? They answered that they dug for water around the Nile. However, this answer was rejected, for it is later written, "And all Egypt dug around the Nile," and in one section it is not appropriate to say that there is no earlier or later in the Torah. The holy teacher resolved according to their words that the Israelites became wealthy from the plague of the Nile, as they were selling water to the Egyptians, etc. Based on this, the magicians did from what was sold to them.
summary: In the passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel, the author discusses the wealth of the Israelites during the plague of blood, highlighting that while the Egyptians suffered, the Israelites were able to drink water and sell it, thus enriching themselves. This phenomenon raises questions about the necessity of borrowing vessels for their eventual exodus, as they already possessed wealth. The text emphasizes the divine orchestration of events, illustrating how the Israelites' prosperity amidst suffering serves as a testament to God's providence and the interconnectedness of their fate with that of the Egyptians. Ultimately, it reflects a deeper theological insight into the nature of redemption and divine justice.

passage_content: והנהע"י שמכרו מים לחרטומים, השתמשו בהם להכחיש נסי ד' ומעשיהם של משה ואהרן, ואמרו דכמו שעשו הם בכשפים כך מעשיהם ח"ו בכשפים, ובודאי שבנ"י השלימים באמונת הבוי"ת לא היו מתרצים למכור מים להם, אף אם היו נותנים להם כל כסף וזהב שבעולם, ועכ"ח צ"ל שקנו מים מאותן שנתחברו אליהם ולא האמינו בנסי ד', והם שהעשירו ממכת היאור, ומ"ש ז"ל ממכת הדם העשירו בנ"י יתפרש על קצתם וחלק מהם, וכמ"ש בעכן חטא ישראל אף שלא חטא אלא א' מהם, והנה מקצתם עשו תשובה סמוך ליציאתם של ישראל ונצטרפו עמהם לצאת כמו הע"ר, ואלו כבר הי' בידם רכוש רב, אבל בני ישראל הכשרים לא רצו לנגוע בממון כזה, אמנם לענין העבדות והעינוי הי' להיפך כי אותן שהתחברו להמצריים וחרטומיהם לא סבלו כלל שעבוד ועינוי, והמצריים עשו אותן פטרונים, ונתנו להם עשירות עבור שהחזיקו בידם להראות נסיהם ולהכחיש נסי משה ואהרן, אבל בני ישראל הכשרים שהתרחקו מדרכיהם והתחברותם ופנו עורף לנסיהם, הם היו מאוסים בעיני מצרים ושעבדו ועינו אותם, נמצא שאותם שנתקיים בהם ועבדום וענו אותם, לא הי' בידם רכוש לולי השאלת כליהם, ואלו שהי' בידם רכוש לא נתקיים בהם ועבדום וענו אותם.
translation: And behold, through the fact that they sold water to the magicians, they used it to deny the miracles of G-d and the deeds of Moshe and Aharon, and they said that just as they performed their acts through sorcery, so too were the deeds of Moshe and Aharon, Heaven forbid, through sorcery. And certainly, the complete Jewish people, who believed in the Creator, would not have consented to sell water to them, even if they were offered all the money and gold in the world. Therefore, it must be that they purchased water from those who had joined them and did not believe in the miracles of G-d, and they were the ones who became wealthy from the plague of the Nile. And what our sages said regarding the plague of blood applies to some of them and a portion of them, as it is said regarding Achan, "Israel has sinned," even though only one of them sinned. And behold, some of them repented close to the departure of Israel and joined them to leave like the mixed multitude. And these already had great wealth in their hands, but the righteous children of Israel did not want to touch such wealth. However, regarding the servitude and affliction, it was the opposite, for those who joined the Egyptians and their magicians did not suffer at all from servitude and affliction; the Egyptians made them patrons and gave them wealth for holding on to show their miracles and to deny the miracles of Moshe and Aharon. But the righteous children of Israel, who distanced themselves from their ways and their associations and turned their backs on their miracles, were despised in the eyes of Egypt, and they enslaved and afflicted them. Thus, those who were subjected to servitude and affliction had no wealth except for the borrowing of their vessels, while those who had wealth were not subjected to servitude and affliction.
summary: The passage discusses the contrast between the Israelites who maintained their faith in God and those who aligned themselves with the Egyptians and their sorcery. It emphasizes that the faithful Israelites rejected the wealth gained from the Egyptians, while those who engaged with the sorcerers were rewarded with riches but ultimately faced oppression. The text highlights the idea that true spiritual integrity leads to suffering in the physical realm, while compromise with falsehood may bring temporary material gain but results in spiritual degradation. Ultimately, it illustrates the profound connection between faith, suffering, and divine reward in the Hasidic worldview.

passage_content: ובזהיבואר אמרם ז"ל לך ואמור להם לישראל בבקשה מכם שאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב וכו', דע"כ הי' הצורך לבקשם ולהזהירם כ"כ, כי בנ"י הכשרים היו מתייראים מליקח רכוש מצרים, כי ראו מה שעלתה להם לאותן שנתעשרו מממונם, ועי"ז הי"ל חלק בהכחשת נסי ד' ולפרסם נסי המכשפים וכוחות הטומאה, אמנם כשהבוי"ת מצוה ליקח רכושם ה"ה ממקור הקדושה ואין זה ממונם של מצרים כי לא מרצונם ניתן להם, אלא וד' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים שלא כדרך הטבע, כי הרשע שונא לצדיק בטבע, והטעם שהזהירם הבוי"ת על ככה, כדי שלא יאמר אותו צדיק ועבדום וענו אותם קיים "בהם" במיעוט הכשרים ואח"כ יצאו ברכוש גדול לא קיים בהם, כי אלו הי' בדחקות ועוני במצרים, ויצטער אאע"ה על כובד הנסיונות של בנ"י הכשרים ועל העדר כבוד שמים, שבנ"י המאמינים המה בלחץ ועוני, ועבדום וענו אותם נתקיים בהם, והרכוש לא נתקיים בהם, ואיך יוכלו להתקיים ולעמוד בנסיון שלא ליהנות מממון הרשעים, ולזה הזהירם הקב"ה בבקשה מכם שאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב, ועד"ז יתקיים בהם הבטחת הרכוש ממקור הקדושה.
translation: And it was explained that they said, may their memory be blessed, "Go and say to the children of Israel, please, ask of the Egyptians for silver vessels and gold vessels," etc. Know that there was a need to request and to warn them so much, for the righteous children of Israel were afraid to take the possessions of Egypt, as they saw what it cost them when they became wealthy from their money. And thus, they would have a part in denying the miracles of the Holy One, blessed be He, and in publicizing the miracles of the sorcerers and the forces of impurity. However, when the Holy One, blessed be He, commands to take their possessions, it is from the source of holiness, and it is not the money of the Egyptians, for it was not given to them willingly, but the Holy One, blessed be He, gave favor to the people in the eyes of the Egyptians, contrary to the natural way, for the wicked naturally hate the righteous. The reason the Holy One, blessed be He, warned them in this way is so that the righteous one would not say, "And they shall serve them and oppress them" applies to the minority of the righteous, and then they would leave with great wealth, which would not apply to them, for these were in distress and poverty in Egypt. And our forefather Abraham would be pained by the heaviness of the trials of the righteous children of Israel and by the lack of the honor of Heaven, that the believing children of Israel are under pressure and in poverty, and "And they shall serve them and oppress them" was fulfilled in them, while the wealth was not fulfilled in them. And how could they endure and stand in the trial of not benefiting from the money of the wicked? And for this, the Holy One, blessed be He, warned them, "Please, ask of the Egyptians for silver vessels and gold vessels," and in this way, the promise of wealth from the source of holiness would be fulfilled in them.
summary: In this passage, the author emphasizes the importance of the Israelites asking for the wealth of Egypt as a divine command, highlighting their initial reluctance due to fear of benefiting from the riches of the oppressors. The act of requesting these items is framed as a means to affirm their connection to holiness, as the wealth is given by God and not willingly offered by the Egyptians. This request serves to ensure that the Israelites' faith remains intact, as it distinguishes their acquisition of wealth as a fulfillment of divine promise rather than a compromise of their spiritual integrity. Ultimately, it underscores the theme that true blessings come from God and are rooted in righteousness, even amidst trials and oppression.

passage_content: ובזהנבין במאמה"כ להלן ובני ישראל עשו כדבר משה וישאלו ממצרים, ולכאורה מה צורך להודעה זו שעשו כדבר משה, ונשמע כן ממ"ש וישאלו ממצרים (עיין קושיא ג') ואפ"ל דהנה ציווי השי"ת הי' שיקחו מהם בדרך שאלה, וא"כ הוצרכו למצוא חן בעיניהם שיבטחו באמונתם ויתרצו להשאיל להם כלי חמדתם, ובדרך הטבע שנאה כבושה לרשע עלהצדיק וכמ"ש בישמח משה (פ' בלק) ששומה מאת ד' למען לא יבואו לידי התחברות עיי"ש, ובדרך הטבע לא ימצא חן בעיניהם כ"א ההולך בדרכם והדומה להם, ואיך יצוייר שהמצריים יתנו כלי חמדתם לבנ"י הכשרים שיעשו בהם רצון הבוב"ה, אלא שלא הי' זה בדרך הטבע, אלא וד' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים וישאילום ושלא יעלה על דעת אדם לומר, דבשביל שרצו ישראל להשלים רצון הבוי"ת בהשאלת כליהם, בקשו התחברותם גם ויתרו קצת מדרך היראה והקדושה כדי למצוא חן בעיניהם לזה שלל הכתוב לומר ובני ישראל עשו כדבר משה, שלא זזו אף כקוצו של יו"ד מכל דברי משה, ואעפ"כ וישאלו ממצרים כלי כסף וכלי זהב, כי הי' שלא כדרך הטבע, וד' נתן את חן העם בעיני מצרים וישאילום, ונתן הכתוב ראי' לזה וגם האיש משה גדול מאוד בעיני עבדי פרעה ובעיני העם, והפלגת צדקתו נודע וברור לכל, ומלפנים ויגרש אותם מאת פני פרעה, ועכשיו הי' גדול בעיני עבדי פרעה וגו' אלא ודאי שלא הי' בדרך הטבע מציאת החן, ועד"ז גם לגבי ישראל לא זזו מיראתם ואמונתם, ומציאת החן הי' בדרך נס ושלא כדרך הטבע, ומה ששאלו רכושם עשו כן רק לקיים מצות הבוי"ת שהזהירם על ככה, וזולת זה נתייראו לנגוע בשלהם, ובאמת כי כל הממון זכה בהם יוסף הצדיק כמ"ש וילקט יוסף את כל הכסף, וה"ה ממקור הקדושה, גם מגיע להם הרכוש עפ"י הדין בשכר העבודה שעבדו להם כאמרז"ל, והטעם העקרי כי נצטוו על ככה בגזירת השי"ת, ורחמנא אפקעא מרשותן, והשי"ת הוא הנותן וה"ז מוסיף כח קדושה.
translation: And with this we understand in the verse mentioned later, "And the children of Israel did as Moses had said, and they asked from Egypt," and at first glance, what is the need for this notification that they did as Moses had said? It seems so from what is written, "and they asked from Egypt" (see question 3). And it could be said that the command of the Holy One, Blessed be He, was that they should take from them in the manner of asking. Therefore, they needed to find favor in their eyes so that they would trust in their faith and agree to lend them the vessels of their desire. Naturally, there is a hidden hatred of the wicked towards the righteous, as it is written in "And Moses rejoiced" (Parashat Balak) that it was decreed by God so that they would not come to a connection, as is seen there. And naturally, they would not find favor in their eyes except for one who walks in their way and is similar to them. How could it be imagined that the Egyptians would give their vessels of desire to the holy children of Israel, who would do the will of the Blessed One? Rather, it was not in the manner of nature, but God gave the people favor in the eyes of Egypt, and they lent to them. And it should not enter the mind of anyone to say that because the Israelites wanted to fulfill the will of the Blessed One by asking for their vessels, they sought their connection and even relinquished a bit of their fear and holiness to find favor in their eyes. Therefore, the text negates this by saying, "And the children of Israel did as Moses had said," that they did not deviate even as much as a jot from all the words of Moses. And nevertheless, "they asked from Egypt for silver vessels and gold vessels," for it was not in the manner of nature, and God gave the people favor in the eyes of Egypt, and they lent to them. The text provides evidence for this, "And the man Moses was very great in the eyes of the servants of Pharaoh and in the eyes of the people," and the extent of his righteousness was known and clear to all. Previously, "he drove them away from the presence of Pharaoh," and now he was great in the eyes of the servants of Pharaoh, etc. But certainly, the finding of favor was not in the manner of nature. Similarly, regarding Israel, they did not deviate from their fear and faith, and the finding of favor was in a miraculous way and not in the manner of nature. And the reason they asked for their possessions was only to fulfill the command of the Blessed One, who warned them about this. Aside from this, they were afraid to touch what belonged to them. And in truth, all the wealth was acquired by Joseph the righteous, as it is written, "And Joseph gathered all the money," and it is also from the source of holiness. They are also entitled to the wealth according to the law as a reward for the work they did for them, as our sages have said. The main reason is that they were commanded about this by the decree of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and the Merciful One has removed it from their authority, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, is the giver, and this adds strength to holiness.
summary: The passage discusses the miraculous favor that God granted the Israelites in the eyes of the Egyptians, allowing them to borrow valuable items despite the natural animosity between the two groups. It emphasizes that the Israelites adhered strictly to Moses' commands without compromising their faith, and their request for the Egyptians' possessions was a fulfillment of God's directive rather than a result of their own initiative. The text highlights the divine intervention that transcended natural laws, reinforcing the idea that true holiness and righteousness come from unwavering obedience to God's will. Ultimately, it asserts that the wealth of the Egyptians rightfully belonged to the Israelites as a result of divine decree and the merit of their forefather, Joseph.
